SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been discussion in the last few days about the threat that native title might make to freehold tenure of land. Madam President, being an excellent lawyer yourself, as I understand—almost as good as my wife, Lillian Cooney, who has given me much instruction in this area—you would know that freehold land does not mean ownership of the land in the sense of a complete right over the land. If you have a freehold piece of property all sorts of other people have rights over that, whether they are tenants, next door neighbours or, indeed, the government as a whole—for example, you cannot grow opium poppies on your land. There are all sorts of relationships between the land that you own and other people. The very fundamental basis of the English law in so far as it relates to the ownership of land is that it is a system of tenure, that is, a system whereby people have rights in respect of a piece of land which others do not have or have rights in respect of a piece of land over which others may have the same sorts of rights. The typical example given is that of the relationship between landlord and tenant, but there are others as well.

SPEECH.PARA: I have copies of documents here which relate to land law and the ownership of land in Victoria—I will not read the names out; that would not be right. One letter is headed `Heritage of Victoria' and it reads:
Attached is my determination for the proposed works to a former building. I have decided to refuse the issue of a permit for the proposed works.

Heritage of Victoria is refusing a person who has the ownership of land a permit to carry out the sort of work he wants. There is the Town and Planning Country Act. Here I have a planning permit from a particular council which is allowing the development of dwellings but subject to a series of conditions which go on for page after page. These are just illustrations of the fact that tenure of land is uncertain by nature. It is true that we want to make it as certain as possible but no‐one can, under our system of law, have a situation where their possession of land is absolutely certain.

When people talk about there being uncertainty in the ownership of land—as have those opposite—they are talking about something that has not been created by native title. It has been created by the English legal system which we have adopted—and a very good system it is too. When people want certainty what they want is something that has not been guaranteed to any non‐Aboriginal person who has come to Australia. It is something which they have never been guaranteed since that time and which the forerunner of our law, the English system, had never guaranteed anybody in England. You remember reading the stories of the knights, whose fealty was to the lord, villeins, and so on. That was an arrangement set up in respect of land. Nobody owned the land in the full sense of the word, but they had certain rights over the land. Why we want to change the system that has been operating all these years on this particular occasion is a little worrying. What we are talking about here—and it ought to be said again and again—is not a native system of land‐holding; it is a common law system of land‐holding that was brought to this country from England.

It is interesting to refer to the case of Campbell v. Hall, because it set out five principles which I think are worth keeping in mind as we are having this debate. It said that where England conquers a country, takes over a country, as it has in Australia, there are certain principles followed. I will go through some of them. The second principle is this:
The conquered inhabitants, once received under the King's protection, become subjects, and are to be universally considered in that light, not as enemies or aliens.
In other words, they become full citizens. The fifth principle is this:

BREAK.PARA: The laws of a conquered country continue in force until they are altered by the conqueror.
All the High Court has been saying in Mabo and in Wik is that—that we inherited the law from English institutions which have come to us from England.
When Lieutenant Cook, as I remember he was when he took over Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you don't remember him, Barney.

—You would remember, Senator Ferguson, that at six o'clock in the evening of Wednesday, 22 August 1770 Lieutenant Cook landed on Australian soil and took possession of it in His Majesty's name and under his colours. He fired some volleys of shots and some cannons were fired from a ship. You would remember that incident. What he was doing was bringing English law to Australia. And what we are about now in our debate is not changing Aboriginal law, not changing indigenous law; we are attempting to change almost a thousand years of history, where English law set up this idea of tenure. That is what we are trying to disturb.

BREAK.PARA: When we talk about uncertainty, it is uncertainty in that law, and may I suggest that it is unfair to blame the indigenous people for uncertainty when that uncertainty has been there since Captain Cook fired his cannon on that Wednesday. It is wrong for us to propound in this debate that we are trying to get rid of an uncertainty that was introduced by Aboriginals when in fact it was introduced by the British system of law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —The Native Title Act 1993 is not working. The act that was supposed to create an atmosphere of certainty for indigenous Australians, for leaseholders, pastoralists and miners has failed because the Keating government failed to devise a satisfactory process of determination, which has resulted in uncertainty, animosity, cynicism and excessive legal costs for the parties involved and has stalled development in rural and regional Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems arising from the 1993 Native Title Act include multiple claims, because there is no adequate threshold for the right to negotiate, no limitation on the number of claims that can be made on the same land and no time limit on the lodgment of claims. This means, in effect, that native title claims could be made forevermore, which underlines the need for a sunset clause to be included in the legislation. Any Aboriginal group with a legitimate claim to any land in Australia should be well aware of it now, and in my view there should only be a relatively short period of grace for further claims to be lodged.

There is now plenty of evidence that senior ALP figures anticipated that the Native Title Act would not work when it was introduced in 1993 and that the processes provided would have to be changed. Gareth Evans, no less, made this admission recently at an AMEC lunch at the Novotel Langley Hotel in Perth, which I attended. The failure of the processes set up under the Native Title Act is illustrated by the fact that to date there have been over 660 applications for determination of native title covering about 45 per cent of Australia, and out of these 660‐plus applications only one has been resolved.
This illustrates as nothing else could the unworkability of the 1993 Native Title Act.
These problems of unworkability have been clearly recognised in the comments of the President of the Native Title Tribunal, Mr Justice Robert French, who stated on 10 March 1997:

Difficulties in the operation of the right to negotiate procedure relate to the ease with which a claimant can be registered and the absence of any requirement that the claimant or claimants consult with the relevant group of native title holders about the lodgment of the claim or any agreement that may be made under the procedure for which the Act provides. Overlapping claims . . . are commonplace. A significant number of claims is brought outside the framework of official representative Aboriginal bodies.

Those are the words of the President of the Native Title Tribunal, Mr Justice Robert French. His comments reflect the limitations of the current process of native title determinations, which, as I will explain, are reflected in what is happening with native title claims throughout Western Australia.

BREAK.PARA: The Howard government's 10‐point plan addresses the concerns raised by Justice French and so many others about the need to streamline the processes of the Native Title Act to provide not only fair and just terms but certainty for all stakeholders. The successful passage of this bill will mean that native title rights are protected by law and will ensure that just compensation is available through the indigenous land fund. It will mean that Australian farming families and pastoral families have the certainty they need to continue running their properties. It will ensure certainty for developers and mining companies, who, I add, currently generate more than $40 billion a year, which is essential for jobs and economic growth in this country, especially for rural and regional Australia.

Native title is a particular issue in Western Australia, because the state of Western Australia is currently subject to application for claims which cover over 82 per cent of it. Western Australia provides 31 per cent of this nation's mineral resources, which accounts for some 40 per cent of Australia's exports. The uncertainty for infrastructure development and resource exploration, especially in the north‐ west of Western Australia, and the importance of such developments to the national economy comprise one of the major reasons to support the Howard government's 10‐point plan which, as I say, will bring certainty and rationality to this matter while protecting the interests of Aboriginal communities, pastoralists, miners, and developers.

I would like to illustrate how the present Native Title Act has affected ordinary people in some of the towns of the north west by causing delays in the provision of infrastructure and land for housing which have resulted in rising costs for housing, as demand outstrips supply. For example, in Port Hedland, in the light industrial area of Wedgefield, 40 lots have been delayed for light industrial development. The significance of this is that the Wedgefield light industrial area is close to the massive HBI plant, which BHP is constructing in Port Hedland at a cost now running to $2.5 billion. Because no land is available for light industrial sites, contractors have not been able to establish bases in the town. This not only has been inconvenient for these contractors but also has added enormously to the cost of their operations.

The only serviceable land by the ocean for housing development in Port Hedland is at Pretty Pool. But native title claims have prevented the development of a block of 152 lots which would have gone a long way to solving the housing shortage in the town. Similarly, in South Hedland, native title has prevented the release of land for new subdivisions for housing for workers.

As a result, because of the inflow of workers for the huge BHP developments in the town, housing is at a premium, and purchase and rental prices are incredibly high. For example, a four-bedroom house in Pretty Pool or Cooke Point rents commonly for $1,000 a week; in South Hedland, the same kind of house will rent for a mere $500 to $800 a week. The cheapest rental for a flat in the Hedland area is now around $300 a week. I emphasise that this is not Manuka, Toorak or Peppermint Grove, but Port Hedland—an industrial town located 1,000 miles north of Perth, surrounded by endless millions of hectares of empty land which cannot be subdivided for housing developments because of the existing processes of the Native Title Act.

A similar picture applies in the Shire of Roebourne where massive developments are scheduled in the next five years, including the expansion of the North West Shelf gas project, the establishment of a petrochemical plant and secondary downstream processing of iron ore. These developments, worth billions of dollars, will be held up if land for housing for workers is not available, again, because of the processes of the present Native Title Act. The Shire of Roebourne's principal planner has commented that, `if the land does not become available and prices remained as high, it would be hard to convince companies not to have fly‐in fly‐out operations'. `Fly‐in fly‐out' benefits no-one in the long run, and adds nothing to regional development.

As in Karratha, native title issues in the town of Broome are having a dramatic impact on residential land availability. As demand is far exceeding supply, prices for existing housing have increased exponentially. Broome has enormous potential as a tourist resort, and there is an enormous demand from developers for land both for residential purposes and tourist facilities. But, again, due to the processes of the 1993 Native Title Act, no land can be released for these purposes which, in turn, means that no building is occurring and no new jobs are being created.

I would like to say a little about regional development and native title in the north of Western Australia. There are over 40 native title claims in the Kimberley, with some of the claims extending offshore. Not surprisingly, none of these claims has been determined due to the failure of the processes of the present act. But, until these claims are determined, no development can occur.

In Kununurra, there have been no new land releases made in the town or surrounding areas since the introduction of the Native Title Act in 1993 other than a single farming block—and that resulted in extensive litigation. A major residential subdivision involving 200 lots has been delayed due to the impact of native title. In addition, 22 light industrial lots, 10 horticultural lots, a commercial centre and a tourism site have not been able to go ahead due to the processes of the existing Native Title Act.

The progress of the Ord River development stage 2 has also been hindered by delays due to native title claims. The expansion of the Ord River project, which will provide for an additional 65,000 hectares of land in the north of Western Australia extending into the Northern Territory, has been subject to three native title applications over the proposed expansion area; and the prospect of proceeding through the formal native title process looms as the biggest deterrent for a successful outcome for this development. Native title will unquestionably significantly affect whether or not this project progresses.

I now turn to the pastoral industry, which has been the traditional industry of the north west, with the great cattle and sheep stations of the Kimberley, Pilbara and Gascoyne generating much wealth for this country. But, as is well known, the Native Title Act and the Wik decision have brought great uncertainty to the pastoral industry. It is clear that the Keating government believed that native title would not exist on pastoral leases. As recently as 18 November 1997, Graham Richardson, who formerly held sway in this house, made the concession that:
Paul Keating and his cabinet firmly believed that no native title existed on pastoral leases and were confident that the legislation they finally agreed to would give force to that view.
How wrong the High Court proved them to be!

These amendments before the Senate today will provide a basis for protecting the legitimate interests of the pastoralists while not denying the rights of genuine traditional Aboriginals of access to land for traditional purposes. While the points I have made are very important, there is an even more important reason to make the Native Title Act workable, which is the objective of these amendments. That more important reason is the need to preserve good relationships between the indigenous people of our country and other Australians.

I say this as someone who has lived in the Pilbara since 1974. In that time I have taken a great interest in issues affecting the Aboriginal population of the north west. I have attended Aboriginal bush meetings which were called by Aboriginal communities to discuss issues affecting the Aboriginal people of the north. I must say that one message which came out of those bush meetings time and time again was the view that the question of land rights was much less important than improved housing, health and educational services to Aboriginal people.

In my view, the uncertainties of the present Native Title Act are poisoning relationships between the races, and for the good of all Australians that situation must end. From the Aboriginal point of view, there is a need for reason and equity. It is now generally accepted that the concept of terra nullius was not valid: there were Aboriginal communities in Australia for thousands of years prior to white settlement and these Aboriginal communities or family groups had an affinity to their traditional lands. That was what the High Court recognised in the Mabo decision. There is not any doubt in my mind, however, that the problems we now face have been generated by the hastily drafted and poorly written Keating government Native Title Act 1993.

I personally have no problem with the concept of genuine traditional owners having rights of access to land for traditional purposes or for such genuine—and I emphasise the word `genuine'—traditional owners receiving compensation or royalties from the use of land. In fact, I would rather have Aboriginal communities generating wealth for themselves from such payments than living on government handouts. I know many Aboriginals agree with my point of view and believe that the welfare mentality which pervades Aboriginal affairs must also end.

From the point of view of many Australians, while native title was conceived as a matter of idealism and higher principle, in practice all too often it has degenerated into an unseemly grab for money. The cynicism which exists in the general community about native title claims has arisen from knowledge of the numbers of spurious claims which have been made and the fact that large amounts of money have been repeatedly paid to buy off such claims. The fact that the details of such deals are often secret due to confidentiality clauses only adds to the cynicism which exists in the general community about such arrangements.

In this atmosphere there is a need for a new start to be made to the whole issue of native title claims. I believe this legislation will provide that new start. There is a need for respect for the rights of both sides. Again, this legislation will provide the basis for that respect. In conclusion, I urge my senatorial colleagues from all parties to support this legislation because it provides justice and equity for all concerned, and that surely is an outcome which we all want to achieve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity to follow my Western Australian colleague Senator Eggleston in this debate and to perhaps correct some of the comments that he made. I regret that Senator Lightfoot, whom I will also be mentioning in my contribution, is not in the chamber. I have alerted him to the fact that in my contribution to the debate I will be mentioning his comments the other night.

SPEECH.PARA: I must draw a contrast between the debate now and the debate that concluded on Tuesday evening when the galleries in this place were full of interested people. Since that happened, the government removed the Native Title Amendment Bill from the Notice Paper, and no debate on this bill occurred in this place yesterday. The debate was interrupted by the government. The government have done that for their own ends, and they are the ones who can respond to it. The public are not in the galleries now, but I know that the public are interested in the debate. I would suggest that the majority of the public are not supportive of what the government is seeking to do in this piece of legislation.

I hope that the public in Western Australia are listening to the debate, although I doubt very much if many of them are tuned in fully because it is only 7 a.m. over there. They might be listening to the debate in Broome and they might have heard Senator Eggleston's words that Broome has stagnated because of native title. Nothing could be further from the truth. Broome is thriving. There are buildings going up, and I will not say all over the place, but certainly an enormous amount of construction and development is taking place in that town.

I will not seek to put on the record why Senator Eggleston should seek to mislead the House and the people of Australia in the manner that he did. Senator Eggleston's contribution mentioned the shortage of housing in Port Hedland. Indeed, there is a shortage of housing in Port Hedland because there is a massive iron smelting development taking place in the town. That is not the first time that such a shortage has occurred in the Pilbara region of Western Australia and it will not be the last, because any time that you get thousands of workers coming to a centre, there will be a shortage and there has been a shortage in the past.

Prior to 1993, before the Native Title Act came into being and when Senator Eggleston was a member of the Port Hedland Shire Council, there were shortages then and diffi culties in getting caravan accommodation and vacant blocks for construction. Indeed, there were shortages just down the road in the Shire of Roebourne when the North West Shelf gas development was taking place. I seek to predict that, if the Oakajee project goes ahead in Geraldton in Western Australia, there will also be shortages. The fact that it might rain one day does not mean that the Aboriginal people of Australia are causing this problem.

I want to turn very briefly to the comments made the other evening by Senator Lightfoot. There are a number of things in Senator Lightfoot's comments that I can agree with, such as the contribution that the mineral sector has made to the economy of Western Australia. The mineral sector spans the globe in terms of what comes out of Western Australia. That contribution has been magnificent and it is ongoing. I am very pleased that Western Australia can contribute in such a way.

But unfortunately there are a few other comments made by Senator Lightfoot that I cannot agree with. He mentioned that this bill is an important bill. Certainly, it may be the most important bill for him. I am not so sure that that is the case for me when debating it, because I had the opportunity in 1993 to take part in the debate on the original native title bill which later became an act. I voted on its passage in this place and it turned out that that was an important bill.

As a Western Australian I was ashamed of what happened following the passage of that bill. The government of Western Australia, the state that I represent in this place, challenged the validity of that act of parliament in the High Court of Australia. Do I need to say that that was a coalition government? It was a coalition of the Liberal and National parties of Australia. They thought and argued in the High Court of Australia that the Native Title Act was not constitutional and should have been struck out.

At the same time, the parliament of Western Australia passed the Land (Titles and Traditional Usage) Act 1993 which purported to extinguish any surviving native title in Western Australia and replace it with more limited statutory rights to usage of land—clearly a very racist act of parliament when it was finally passed. It was said at the time during the debate in the two chambers of the Western Australian parliament that, indeed what the Western Australian government was seeking to do at that point in time was engaging in an act of racism in this country. Many people, including the churches, condemned the Western Australian government for doing that at the time.

History records that the High Court upheld the validity of the Commonwealth Native Title Act, dismissed the Western Australian challenge to that act and then held that the Land (Titles and Traditional Usage) Act 1993—the Western Australian act—was inconsistent with the Racial Discrimination Act 1995 and was therefore inoperative because of section 109 of constitution.

The parliaments of Australia can indeed pass acts of parliament that are racist and, if the government has its way on this one, we in the Commonwealth might repeating that same error. I certainly do not want to have a part of it. Ultimately, the High Court of Australia will determine whether or not what is passed in this place in the next week or two is or is not inconsistent with the Commonwealth Racial Discrimination Act, which has been on our statute books for quite a number of years now.

What lends me to believe that this is in fact a racist act of parliament? I am encouraged in that viewpoint by the fact that the government, the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) and the Special Minister of State (Senator Minchin) will not release the information and the advice that it has received from its senior legal advisers, which we understand is telling the government that this bill is inconsistent with the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act.

I am also encouraged to form the view that this bill is in fact racist by the comments made by the person who is currently the Acting Prime Minister of Australia, the Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Party, Mr Tim Fischer, who said about the 10‐point plan some months ago that it:

BREAK.PARA: . . . represents a winding back from an extremist, unpractical decision of the High Court . . . there are bucketfuls of extinguishment in the 10‐point plan.

If that is the case, and I think it is the case, the High Court in adjudicating on this matter—and inevitably it will be called on to adjudicate—will rule, as the majority of the legal advice that is around has told the parliament through the various committee processes, that the bill that is before the parliament will not stand up.

I turn to some comments by Senator Eggleston and by my other Western Australian colleague Senator Lightfoot. Senator Lightfoot described the current Native Title Act and its operation as `the dead hand of native title'. There is no question about it: there are some difficulties with the act as it currently operates. The previous government had it in mind to make some amendments to the act but unfortunately, as the election got in the way, the new government was required to address that. They had developed a plan of amendment to the act to make it more real to the circumstances of life. The original bill was amended in its passage through the Senate and some of those amendments had unforeseen consequences. So there was always an expectation that the bill was going to be amended somehow, in some way. The Wik decision made it inevitable that the act would be amended.

But if the act as it was applied was a dead hand, it would have stopped everything. The mineral industry, from which my state of Western Australia benefits so much, as does the economy of Australia, both in exploration terms and in mining terms, would have caved in, would have fallen over, would have ceased to exist. That is not the case. If one looks at the statistics on investment in the mineral industry we find that, rather than winding back the amount of money that is spent on exploration in Western Australia, the amounts are increasing. If they are increasing, how can a dead hand be operating?

Figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics for actual and expected private mineral exploration in the June quarter of 1997 tell us that the figure for Western Australia has increased from $11.9 million to $188.2 million. Ninety-five per cent of the mineral exploration activities in Western Australia have invoked the right to negotiate procedures under the Native Title Act. Senator Lightfoot referred to the amount of money that has been spent by the minerals industry in exploration off‐shore. I was of the view that the previous government, and indeed the current government, were encouraging Australian companies to invest off‐shore for their own benefit, for the benefit of their shareholders and also for the benefit of Australians. Both governments, as I understand it, have encouraged that.

But on a practical level, has the Native Title Act—which does need amendment, as everybody agrees—stopped development in this country? Has it laid a dead hand on the continual growth of our economy? In my state of Western Australia the Kimberley Land Council, as Senator Eggleston and, I am certain, Senator Lightfoot would be aware, has been able to negotiate over 30 agreements on behalf of native title holders covering matters such as cultural protection, mining and exploration, tourism, agriculture, and major capital works. If you want to see some of the major capital works you do not have to travel very far from the airport in Broome. If you come in over the town to land at the airport you will have one of the major developments on your right hand side just by the airport and the other one on the left hand side. They are there, starkly in front of you. That has happened in a very short period. It has happened by a process of negotiation.

As for other parts of Australia, we have heard a lot about the Hopevale agreement in Queensland, an agreement between nine parties in northern Queensland which covers a wide range of interests and shows that, with goodwill and effort by all parties, even complex native title claims can be resolved through mediation. The agreement is between the Queensland government, Telstra, the Australian Maritime Authority, the Cook Shire Council, the Queensland Commercial Fisheries Organisation, Cape Flattery Silicone Mine, the Far North Queensland Electricity Corporation, Cape York Land Council and the Hopevale Aboriginal Council. It can happen. Not only can it happen; it is happening.

Those with a particular view want to cover their eyes to this. Those who want to take away some of the very minimum and basic rights that our native people of Australia, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, do not want to see this and do not want to recognise this, but they will be forced to do so because, like it or not, even if this bill passes and however it is amended on its way through the parliament, it will end up in the High Court. I have great confidence that the High Court of Australia will uphold and stand by the rights of the Aboriginal people of this country. And there will be many more of us. Senator Lightfoot said the other night in his contribution how proud he was to be an Australian. I can say the same thing, although I speak with a different tongue. I am a migrant to this country, like Sir Peter Abeles, whose picture appeared in an advertisement in all the major newspapers of Australia last week.

Peter Abeles has a point of view to put across. He has money in order to do so. He has an objective with that. I have a point of view to put across on behalf of my constituents in Western Australia, and I am doing that here. I have an obligation to do that. Part of that obligation is summed up in the following quotation, which the minority members of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee put into the report on the constitutionality of the bill that is currently before the Senate. Peter Wertheim, from the Jewish Board of Deputies, when speaking on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 on 5 November this year, said:

I don't want my children or grandchildren to have to get up in public in 50 years' time and apologies for my silence. There has already been far too much silence during this century. Genocide has had far too easy a run. And I could at least speak for the Jewish community when I say that we will not be mute, we will not maintain a criminal silence in the face of continuing attempts of genocide against indigenous Australia, even if it is genocide by stealth.

I commend Mr Wertheim for these views. I commend the leaders of the major churches in this country for expressing the views they have expressed in opposition to the government's plans as expressed in the 10-point plan and in this bill before the parliament. I condemn those who criticise the churches for putting forward those views. In particular, I condemn the statements by Mr Entsch, the Chairman of the Joint Committee on Native Title, calling for a boycott of the churches because some church leaders spoke out in opposition to what the government are proposing.

It is worth while ending with Mr Entsch. It should be recalled by each and every one of us involved in this debate that Mr Warren Entsch, the chairman of that committee, was in fact hand picked by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to chair that committee. It was not something that happened by accident. That decision for Mr Entsch to chair that committee—and in doing so espousing the views that he does espouse—is the decision of the Prime Minister. So, when he speaks for a boycott, he speaks on behalf of his party, his Prime Minister and his government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, rise to speak on the legislation before us now—commonly called the Wik legislation, but actually the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . At the outset of my contribution I wish to make it absolutely clear that my advice, and I believe it, is that this bill is not racist; it does not breach the Racial Discrimination Act. I have taken private advice on this myself because it was an issue that concerned me. So that is the first point I wish to make.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point that I wish to make is that there are fundamentally two reasons why we are here debating the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . The first one, and what it is mostly about, is the fatally flawed Keating legislation of 1993 which has proved to be unworkable. I will deal with that in some detail later in my contribution. The second reason is the Wik decision, but that is a fairly small part of the total amendments proposed to the 1993 legislation.

Had there not been a Wik decision, or had the decision been brought down confirming valid leases extinguished native title on pastoral leases, we would have been still here debating virtually the total substance of what we have before us now. People on the other side, including the Democrats and the minor parties, should remember that. Always remember that the decision on Wik was a four-three decision. It could easily have gone the other way. It was not clear cut. Never forget that those on the other side passed their legislation believing that native title had been extinguished on pastoral leases, and that includes the Democrats and the performance they put in on that unforgettable night.

Why is this legislation so important to Western Australia, the state that I come from? It is pretty fundamentally clear to those who live over there. But many people do not understand the Western Australian situation. They do not understand the level of crown land in WA. It is almost the total of crown land which exists in Australia—not quite; there are some other places where there is some crown land, but close to 40 per cent of land is crown land in our state. I think we have 44 per cent, to be precise, under pastoral lease and we have a variety of other titles—for example, freehold and perpetual leases—over the remainder. In total, the freehold title in WA is about eight per cent. So the impact of the original Mabo decision was very much greater on Western Australia than it was on the other states; hence there was a different response from many of those people who live in Western Australia.

I visit many Aboriginal communities. During all my primary school days, except for one year, there were more Aboriginal children at the school than there were Europeans. I developed a very close personal affiliation with them, and I still have many friends from those days. The vast majority of people in the communities hate native title. They hate what it has done to their communities. They hate the fight and the vilification that is occurring between communities. They hate the multiple claims, mounting up to 20 in some instances. In most instances it is five or six.

I was at Wongutha just last week. I had the privilege, on behalf of Senator Ellison, of opening a school building. The principal speaker made it quite clear in his opening address to me—and they asked me to take this back to the parliament of this country—that they wanted a fully developed commercial title that they could use, they could grow on, they could bring their families up on, they could trade, they could borrow money on and that they could do all the things that everybody else does under their title in Australia. Native title does not give them that, and they spelt that out very clearly. I have heard that story time and again. It is something that I believe this parliament needs to address.

Currently in Western Australia 43 pastoral leases—that was on my last count; there could be more now—are owned and operated by Aboriginal people just the same as anybody else. That is over 10 per cent of the total pastoral leases in Western Australia. That program, which I am proud to say I was involved in, was put in place when Brian Burke was the Premier of Western Australia, and it has been very successful. It is the direction in which we should be going, in my view, in terms of land ownership by our indigenous cousins or friends in this nation of ours. It has worked well, it is enjoyed by the people involved in it and it is very successful. People from those properties come to Canberra from time to time and I have the opportunity of talking to them, which I enjoy doing.

I wish to touch on one or two other things before I get into some specifics. What has galled me most in this debate is some of the racist comments that have been delivered. Racist comments are the oldest trick in the book, and they are also the dirtiest card in the pack. It is almost impossible for people to defend themselves when a racist slur is made against them because they are in a totally unwinnable position. Making those comments—we all know what they are—does not do any good for this debate or anybody. In my view, it damages the cause very seriously and it is very irresponsible.

I wish to talk about some of the issues which I think are important to my state, what I call `irresponsible actions' that have occurred and some of the matters addressed in this bill which were flaws in the previous legislation, the 1993 legislation. I refer to the irresponsible, not thought out multiple claims that have been put over a number of mining leases, over a number of waters, over some freehold land, over perpetual lease land—claims that have no hope in the world, in my view, of getting up. They have caused division. They have increased hatred, particularly in some of our pastoral areas but also in the south‐west of the state, where there were good relationships.

I attended a meeting in Mount Barker, where claims have been put over perpetual and conditional purpose leases which had been granted. One of the things that this legislation will do is address a flaw in the previous legislation. It will identify where valid land titles have been granted with exclusive possession. If exclusive possession is not granted, they are not covered. I include in those, for example, the pastoral leases in Western Australia and the western division leases in New South Wales.

In 1993 the previous government, the Labor government, made it quite clear that they believed native title had been extinguished in both those areas. We are not extinguishing native title on those because exclusive possession was not granted. People who suggest otherwise are being dishonest, and that is very sad. They might wish to criticise the fact that we are confirming the situation on title where exclusive possession has been granted but it is absolutely and totally not true to say that we are extinguishing native title in those other areas. That is very unfortunate because it clouds the good things that can come out of this legislation.

Let me touch on why we in Western Australia feel very strongly about making this piece of legislation work and address some of the issues for the benefit of all Australians. First of all, 82 per cent of my state is currently under claim. That has meant that many land holders with freehold and exclusive titles are being forced to defend their titles in the Federal Court as well as incurring significant costs in being away from their farms, their businesses, to attend mediation conferences, knowing full well that at the end of the day there is little likelihood of anything coming out of them other than division and dislike of one another.

BREAK.PARA: Can I deal with some aspects of the mining industry. I note Senator McKiernan's comments. One can use statistics to put up any argument. I do not argue with what he said, but I do argue with his conclusions. The impact has been significant, and that comes about fundamentally because of the right to negotiate simply by lodging a claim. The claims can be totally bogus but they still result in delays of up to 12 months but more likely in practice two years.

I do not disagree with Senator McKiernan when he said that it is important that we have investment offshore, but I disagree very strongly with that investment being forced offshore because mining companies cannot get access here to explorations licences or mining licences or have delays of up to 12 months, two years or beyond. Forcing investment offshore in that way is bad.

The other point I would make is that virtually all claimants demand large cash payments. Some claim a share of future profits while others demand large cash payments before they will even attend a negotiating meeting. Again, I must stress that these are individuals or groups who have simply lodged a claim with no requirement to establish a prima facie case or pass any form of registration test. That was a flaw in the previous legislation that we will address.

I will give you an example of where this occurred. This example did not occur in mining but a CBH, cooperative bulk handling, bin in a place called Borden in Western Australia in the middle of the wheat belt where it was necessary to increase the size of the grain bin. It was necessary, under the regimes that apply, for notification to be given as to whether it was open to claim. Before the individuals who made that particular claim would even go and negotiate at the site they demanded an up-front cash payment.

That is not what native title is about. It is not what the response to the Mabo decision should be. It is not even what any response should be with regard to Wik. I put that on the record as an example of the misuse of the right to negotiate. You can run through a significant number of those sorts of examples. Having said that, I am not saying that occurs in every case, but it occurs in many cases. It has caused confusion and an enormous amount of mistrust—mistrust that was not there previously.

Under the procedures that exist in Western Australia, there are now over 9,000 land titles being delayed by the procedures. There is a backlog of over 7,000 mining titles with 1,900 titles caught in this right to negotiate process. Since March 1995, only 158 leases have been granted as a result of the right to negotiate agreements, but every week a further 14 leases enters the process. That, in my view, is going backwards at a rapid rate and has to be addressed. This legislation addresses that.

Supporters of the present act claim that the right to negotiate is not a veto. But in the risky business of resource development any ability to delay a project by even 12 months can be the equivalent of a veto or it has the effect of a veto. That is what is occurring on the ground, particularly in my state. When we look at Western Australia it is a lucky state in the sense of the resources it has. Those resources can be used for the benefit of all Australians, particularly Western Australians and Western Australian indigenous people.

This process is probably harming the genuine indigenous people who live in the areas more than anyone else. It is costing them jobs and it is costing them the opportunity for training. I put on the public record here and now that a number of our major mining operations, as a matter of policy, have a number of Aboriginal youth on their staff on training courses. Labor Senator McKiernan, who is now in the chair, well knows that. The process we have now is harming that training.

I put it to the Senate and I put it to this parliament that the substance of this legislation—and there is much more one could talk about—is very important to this nation. It is very important to all in this nation whether they have been here 200 years, whether their ancestry goes back 40,000 years or whether they have arrived in the current generation—as many people who now call themselves Australians have.

Unfortunately, the emotion that has been built up, the name calling that has occurred has clouded the real issues with which it deals. I put it to those on the other side, to the Greens and to the Democrats that as they were a very big part of what went wrong with the previous legislation, the 1993 legislation, they now have a responsibility, with us on this side of the chamber, to address the problems that came out of that legislation. If they do not, or if they allow or amend this legislation to a point that it does not address the principle issues outside of the Wik decision, then they will have failed in their responsibility to the Australian community.

I particularly put that to my Western Australian colleagues on the other side of this chamber. We saw yesterday in question time what many of their state colleagues think. We know which way the vast majority of the people who vote for them in the great hinterland of Western Australia, those who returned Labor Party people to the state parliament in the Western Australian, want them to vote. They want them to support this legislation. I make a plea to them to work as hard as they can to make sure we get the substance of this through because it will be to the benefit of us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —This nation is being divided like it has never been divided before. The divisions in this nation though are not divisions between black and white. The divisions which are occurring in this nation are divisions between those who live in the cities and close to the cities and those who live outside the cities, those who live in what we call the bush, the outback, the areas away from all the trappings and enjoyments of civilisation as we know them in the capital cities.

SPEECH.PARA: Why do I say that? I say that because the current land law in this country, as a result of the native title claims and cases we have seen, has guaranteed one group of Australians security and safety. One group of Australians are guaranteed the sanctity of their property. They are the people who live in the cities. The other Australians who live outside the cities do not have that same security of title, do not have that same sanctity for their property, do not have that assurance that they crave and they deserve and they ought to have. The interesting thing is that quite a few of the people who live outside the capital cities whose titles are at threat from native title are in fact Aboriginal Australians.

One of the things that the proponents of native title have never had the honesty to tell this parliament, have never had the honesty to tell the Australian people, is that a number of the defendants in the Wik case were in fact Aboriginal Australians—Eddie Holroyd, an Aboriginal Australian; Mary Kendal, an Aboriginal Australian; Elaine Price, an Aboriginal Australian. Why are these people defendants in the Wik case? Why were their properties made subject to claim? Was it for the advancement of the Aboriginal people? Or was it for some other purpose? If the Wik claim was about rectifying the wrongs that were done to the Aboriginal people in the past—there have been many wrongs—then why did these people have to be made defendants?

Why should Eddie Holroyd, a man who has spent 20 years slogging his guts out on his bit of property, become a defendant if this is about rectifying wrongs done by whites against blacks? The Wik claim in fact is not about that. The Wik claim is about a wider political agenda, and the wider political agenda is to ensure that we undermine the property system of this country. If the Cape York Land Council were genuinely interested in the wellbeing of Aboriginal people, then Eddie Holroyd, Mary Kendal, Elaine Price and others like them would be held up as role models for the Aboriginal people. They would be held up as an inspiration for what can be achieved.

They should be held up as role models because they have proved that all the popular misconceptions about Aboriginal people are wrong. They have proved that Aboriginal people can achieve on equal terms. They have proved that Aboriginal people can become successful businessmen and successful businesswomen. But, no, these people are not held up as role models. These people have been held up for attack for the simple reason that they had the temerity to go out, to have a go and to succeed.

I ask the question: is this bill before the parliament a racist bill, as some would have you believe? It is certainly the case that this bill is controversial. But this bill is not a racist bill. Just because a bill is controversial does not mean it is racist. None of the people who have made that slur have ever proven the claim that this is racist legislation. Let me explain why that is so.

Racism can have many definitions, but the popularly accepted definition is when a bit of legislation seeks to disadvantage one group of people unfairly for the advantage of another group of people based solely on race. We have already seen that many of the people whose properties are subject to claim are in fact Aboriginal. So, when we rectify those problems, when we validate their title, we are not validating the title of whites at the expense of blacks. We are validating the title of people who have bought pastoral properties in this country, be they black, white or anything else, from a competing claim.

Of course, there will always be people who will say that this legislation is racist. But, if this legislation is racist, then so too are many other things in this country racist. If this bill is racist, so too was the bill of the previous government, which is now legislation. So too is the Native Title Act racist if this bill is racist.

I was present in this chamber four years ago for the debate. I sat across the aisle from where Senator Quirke sits now, and I heard the government of the day say that the Native Title Bill would validate pastoral leases, would ensure that there were no native title claims over pastoral leases and, in fact, would specifically extinguish native title claim over pastoral leases.

If this bill is racist, the Native Title Act is racist. If those of us who sit on this side are racist, then the people who moved the Native Title Bill four years ago are racist as well. But those are the people who are throwing the stones. I can only turn to the Bible and say, `Let he who is without sin throw the first stone.' The legislation which the previous government brought in was always intended to extinguish native title on pastoral leases. That was the intention. That is what Senator Evans told this parliament when he was sitting in that seat in front of me. He told this parliament that the intention of the Native Title Act was to ensure that there would not be native title over pastoral leases.

Now the Labor Party wants to have a Damascene conversion and say, `No, it is wrong, it is improper, it is immoral to ensure that native title does not exist over pastoral leases.' If it is wrong, improper and immoral now it was wrong, improper and immoral four years ago. But that is not what they were saying. The commitment of those opposite to these so‐called moral issues is skin‐deep in many cases. Deep down they know that this legislation gives effect to what they tried to do four years ago.

I should ask: if this legislation is racist, what of the decision of the High Court of Australia? Is it not racist to create a type of title available to only one group of people? If this legislation is racist, so too is the decision of the High Court of Australia. I do not hear anybody on the other side saying, `The High Court of Australia isn't racist.' If people who disagree with the Wik decision are racist, then so too are three of the justices of the High Court of Australia who disagreed with the Wik decision. So too is Chief Justice Brennan, who disagreed with the Wik decision. If those of us who oppose this bill are racist, then so too are those people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I know that Senator O'Chee is getting rather emotional, but I would suggest that it is inappropriate to refer to justices of the High Court as racist.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I was not saying that. I was saying that if a person who disagreed with the judgment was a racist then that allegation must be extended to three justices of the High Court. I was not saying they were racist. In fact, I was defending those people. I was defending their right to disagree with the Wik decision, just as I was defending the right of this government to disagree with the Wik decision without being called racist.
—There is no point of order. I do not believe Senator O'Chee was directly reflecting on the High Court or the judiciary of the High Court.

—Thank you very much for your wisdom, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is in fact the case—those opposite have just proven it today—that the Labor Party does not want the people to know that three of the justices who sit on the High Court disagreed with the Wik decision. It does not want the people to know that the man who wrote the lead judgment in Mabo disagrees with the Wik decision, because it does not agree with its particular polemic view of politics in this country. Senator Forshaw has just proven to the people of Australia that the Labor Party is very sensitive about this because the Labor Party is out there peddling half‐truths and mistruths in their campaign to divide this country.

BREAK.PARA: I will tell you the truth about the Labor Party, the people who sit opposite. If any piece of legislation disadvantaged the indigenous people of this country it was the Native Title Act. I will explain why.

In Mabo No. 2 the High Court of this country delivered a judgement with which I agree. It said that in the Murray Islands, where people were traditional farmers, where land was marked out, where everybody had a concept of private property ownership, that ownership should be recognised in common law. And so it was. In that case, the High Court granted private property rights to two of the successful claimants. It said, `You as individuals own this land, and you always have.'

But do you know what the previous government did in the Native Title Act? They were very sneaky. They changed that. They stole from indigenous people the right to own the land as individuals and instead inserted a provision that said that where a court made a finding that there was native title, native title must be owned by a corporation. For corporation, read `land council'. They stole away from individual indigenous people the right to own land. They said, `You cannot own this land. The only people who can own native title under the Native Title Act are land corporations.' That does not do anything for the ordinary Aboriginal or Islander.

I argued against this provision four years ago. Over the four intervening years I have maintained a passionate dislike of that provision in the bill, because I believe it is a massive and immoral fraud, aimed at consolidating the power of the land councils at the expense of Aboriginal people.

I am on record as saying that it is my view that, where Aboriginal people prove native title over unallocated vacant crown land, they should be given title to that land as freehold land. In the state of Queensland from which I come we have done nothing with these bits of land since 1859. If the white fella has done nothing with it since 1859 I think it is a bit churlish now for us to come back and say, `We are not going to let the black fella own it as freehold title.' That is what I stand for and believe in and that is what is denied to those people in the Native Title Act and was denied to them by the Labor Party when they were in government. It is what is denied to them now by the Labor Party, which continues to argue that the only people who should own Native Title are land councils.

I know that there are many Aboriginal people in Queensland who share my view. They want to own a bit of land for themselves. They want to have the opportunity to own a bit of land, be it a house in an Aboriginal community or a grazing property, and they want the opportunity to hand that land on to their children and grandchildren. But, if it is native title land, that is not possible. It is not possible, because of the legislation put through by the previous government. And shame on them for doing it, shame on them indeed.

So you can see that there are many different and conflicting viewpoints in relation to native title, and the morality does not sit on the opposite side of the chamber. There are some people on the other side of the chamber who I respect very much. Some of them are in the chamber right now. They are very honourable, moral and decent people. But I can say one thing: the stance of the Labor Party on native title has been immoral, dis honest and unreasonable. And they maintain that dishonest, immoral and unreasonable stance in the amendments they have brought forward and in their opposition to this bill.

Those opposite have said in the past that this bill is not necessary. They have said, `We don't need this bill.' Their former leader, Mr Keating said, `We don't need this bill.' Let me tell you what will happen if we do not have this bill and do not fix the problems.

Aboriginal people in western Queensland have said to me that they want this bill. They want it because the divisions which have occurred as a result of native title claims are ripping their communities apart. I will quote from some of the claims that have been made over western Queensland. There is a fiction out there that all these native title claims are about sharing the land and coexistence. I will quote from claim C00387, lodged in Queensland.
Claim C00387 is made by the Miawali and Karuwali peoples and is over large areas of the Diamantina shire council. The claim says that the Miawali and Karuwali peoples claim:
(i) the right to possession of the Land, Waters, resources and attributes of the Land and Waters . . . . (iv) the right to manage the Land, Water and resources.
And they seek a declaration which is not for coexistence but which says that native title exists in relation to the whole of the lands and waters covered by the application. Further they say:
The Applicants claim the native title rights as exclusive to themselves, and further—
they claim—
a right to exclude from the areas under claim, all except members of the claimant peoples.
This is not a claim for coexistence, this is not a claim for sharing. This is a claim for exclusive possession.

I will read you another one, Mr Acting Deputy President. This is a claim from the Kullilli people over an area of south‐west Queensland in the Bulloo shire, the Murweh shire the Paroo shire and the Quilpie shire. The claim says:
The Kullilli people claim to be entitled as against the whole world to possession, occupation, use and enjoyment of the claimed land (including subterranean land and burial grounds) and waterholes.

These claims are outrageous. Under common law nobody can own the water; yet these claims seek the water. In the state of Queensland nobody can own the minerals in the ground; yet these claims seek to own the minerals in the ground. Under common law that has never been possible. That has never been a common law right. These are not claims for common law but for something more.

Let me tell you how the people out there who have leases that are under claim feel about a claim for exclusive possession. They say, `This is a threat to us' and, of course, they have got to defend it. You would be mad not to defend this. You have got to understand that under section 70 of the Native Title Act, if you do not defend a claim which is made against you, the court can make an order for native title in the terms sought by the applicant without further reference to you. These claims encourage division. These claims require division because they put people's properties at risk and because they make their properties subject to claims for exclusive possession as against the whole world. That is divisive. That will rip communities apart.

But there is another way. That is the way put forward in this bill because it says, `Look, in relation to lands which have exclusive tenure, there will be no native title.' That is what was always intended by those opposite. That is what we are going to give effect to now and that was, in fact, the intention of six of our High Court judges in the original decision in Mabo No. 2. We give effect to that. So we confirm leases which grant exclusive possession—miners' homestead leases, grazing homestead perpetual leases, grazing homestead freeholding leases and so on in the state of Queensland.

We clarify the situation in relation to towns and sporting facilities and infrastructure. We say you can make a claim for native title but it is a claim for compensation only. For example, in relation to sporting grounds, we say these facilities exist for the benefit of everybody in the community. I fought pas sionately to have this provision inserted in the bill and I stand here to defend it before you today. I say that, where a facility is available—be it a showground, a footy field or whatever—for every member of that community, it is wrong, unjust, unfair and divisive to say that that land should be made subject to a native title claim.

We will allow a claim to go ahead but it will be a claim for compensation, and the Aboriginal people, if they can prove that claim, will get their constitutional and just rights under section 51 of the constitution—and I would have nothing less than their constitutional and just rights. I have ensured they will get their constitutional and just right. But they should not have a right to hold the rest of the people in that community to ransom when that facility is provided for everybody in that community.

I went to test what response this bill would have from people who are in the grazing fraternity. I travelled out to the Gulf of Carpentaria to see my friends in the Carpentaria branch of the cattlemen's union. They sat down with me and we spent all day at Hell's Gate. They said, `We would just like native title extinguished over all pastoral leases,' and I said, `I can understand that. That is a consistent and sensible vie. But that is not what the government is giving you. Let's talk about what is on here.' At the end of the day Ernie Camp said something to me that I will always remember. He said, `Bill, extinguishment is what we want and we will always want it. But it is probably not what we need. What we need is certainty and a framework in which we can work together—and that's what you give us. Go down to Canberra and get this bill passed.'

Do you know why he said that? Ernie Camp said that to me in the knowledge that this bill would still allow a native title claim over his land but the claim would be subject to a threshold test, which basically requires people to prove that they have had a regular physical access to the land. He said, `If they have had a regular physical access to the land, it is because I have let them and I don't have any problem with sitting down with those people.' That is what this bill does. That is not what the propagandists on the other side would have you believe, but that is what this bill does.

Let me conclude where I started. This legislation is necessary to prevent this country being ripped apart. Isn't it interesting that the people who live in the cities, where the Aborigines were shot, poisoned, murdered and moved out a long time ago and the land made subject to freehold claims, now want the rest of Australia to carry their sins and their burdens? I do not think that is fair, I do not think it is just and I do not think it is reasonable. There are people who say they will weep if this bill gets passed; I say I will weep if this bill does not get passed. This bill needs to get passed to ensure that we have one united and harmonious country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quirke, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee finished off his speech by saying he is going to weep if the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 does not go through. In about a week's time we might take him up on that. We will see how it goes. I suggest he turn it into a fundraiser because a number of us on this side would pay a good quid to see that.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to spend a lot of time on Senator O'Chee's impassioned speech on this because he has got his particular wheelbarrow to push and, obviously, before the morning is out, his staff will be sending to all of his relevant constituents in Queensland a copy of his speech and the remarks that he has made. But there are a couple of bits of his speech that really need to be teased out to see, in fact, what is behind them.

He spent a fair bit of the last part of his speech on the question of certainty. The one thing that is certain about this whole process is that it is not going to finish here today, it is not going to finish here next week and, if we do come back the week after that, it is not going to finish then either. In fact, this particular exercise is probably going to give rise to more certainty amongst the lawyers in our fraternity more than amongst pastoralists, land‐holders and traditional Aboriginal owners of particular parts of Australia. I think the one certainty about this is that, within a few years, we will be back here again because the High Court will have found something else, whether it be in Mabo or in this legislation, which will require further scrutiny and further attention.

The other point made by Senator O'Chee was that there are a large number of Aboriginals in Queensland who would just like to own a piece of land underneath them. I take his point that they do not want corporate ownership of the land. What they want is distinct individual title which, I quite openly tell the Senate, is what I have over the house in which I live. I can understand that. But I think the problem with that—and I am not an educated man in Aboriginal culture and history—is that it presupposes a European concept of property ownership where one largely does not exist. I say largely does not exist because I have not seen a lot of concepts of it.

The individual property ownership that most of us in this place are accustomed to is a European concept. It is one that, in many respects, has been imposed on Australians and I suspect that the proposition that Senator O'Chee was putting to us here is that quite a number of his Aboriginal constituents whom he spoke to on this particular matter are really, deep down, Europeans underneath a dark skin.

I suspect that that whole problem he raises is one which needs much more subtlety than has come out in the debate so far. The Aboriginal communities in Australia have had a couple of hundred years of co‐existing with an alien culture. I use the word `co-existing' despite the fact—certainly Senator O'Chee made this point—that in some areas the Aboriginals, by one means or another, were totally driven out of those communities or killed. That did happen. There were other schemes, some as recently as 25 or 30 years ago, which were implemented to try to Europeanise all Aboriginal children in this society. This year we have heard the debate in this place and elsewhere about the stolen generation.

But deep down the concept that Senator O'Chee was putting forward as one of his principal arguments against the concept of native title as it emerged from the Mabo decision and legislation is still based predominantly on a European view of what land titling is all about. He may explain that further; he may say that I am being unfair to him. He may say that I do not understand the particular problems of Queensland. I want to come to that now.

Much of the debate here this morning has been concerned with Queensland and Western Australia, where this is a much more burning issue than it is in the state from which I come. That is not to say that my constituents in South Australia are at all disinterested in this debate—they are not. They are very interested in this debate but they come at it from a very different perspective. For 200 years, until the late 1980s and early 1990s, various members of the judiciary in this country have denied the existence of Aboriginal occupation of Australia because it was an easy way to deal with a number of problems. There is no easy way in these debates. Although that has happened, many communities in Australia have recognised either the co‐existence or the continued existence of Aboriginal communities in their midst.

In South Australia that has certainly been the record. I cannot tell the Senate that it has been a brilliant record in all sorts of other ways. For instance, I remember the kids at my primary school who were taken forcibly from their parents, both white and black, but predominantly black, and placed in orphanages or foster homes. I am old enough—Senator O'Chee probably is not—to remember those days. In my grade 2 and 3 years I well remember these kids who looked so miserable and who were treated so poorly. That has come out this year and any government in Australia that has not taken some responsibility for those particular years ought to do so.

In other respects, the record is not quite as bad. Certainly in South Australia there are provisions in pastoral leases dating back to 1856. In fact, self-government in a representative fashion started in South Australia in 1856. One of the first things that happened was that all pastoral leases recognised Aboriginal occupancy of the land. Those pastoral leases today have clearly written provisions which guarantee certain native title rights. The right to trespass on the land, the right of ceremony, the right to hunt and fish and various other rights have been a legal feature of pastoral leases in South Australia for 130 years or so. Whilst many pastoralists in South Australia would like these rights extinguished, they accept them much more than is the case in the two—dare I say it—outlying states of Queensland and Western Australia.

I can understand that Western Australia has a few specific problems because the full impact of Mabo was on crown land. We can have an argument here about the impact on pastoral leases of the original native title bill that went through this place some years ago, but my understanding is that the principal impact of the original Mabo propositions and the bill that went through here was that crown land was an empty and an open question. Western Australia has the highest percentage of vacant crown land in the country. In Queensland there are all sorts of other problems, and I suspect that the record up there has not been as good in trying to come even remotely around to the concept of co‐existence that is present in the other states.

Senator O'Chee and a few others have made comments about the safety and the sanctuary of metropolitan areas. I suspect that, at least in part, some of what he is saying is correct. Indeed, the High Court seems to have said in a seven‐nil decision that there is no argument that freehold title does extinguish native title in Australia. That may be wrong but my understanding of it is that the argument is now about pastoral leases and crown land; it is not at all about freehold title land. I have more to say about that in just a moment.

I suspect that it gives Senator O'Chee and a few of the others some comfort that they can say that people like me who come from a metropolitan area really ought not get involved in this debate because rural people are the only ones who need to worry about these particular considerations, and that what we need to do is to go down the road of extinguishing the rights of Aboriginals in many other parts of Australia simply because we already have them in the metropolitan areas of Australia. But I think there is a different way forward on this, and I suspect that, even in the dark days when courts were saying things as if the Aboriginal race did not exist in Australia, just was not here at all, communities like the one that I live in in South Australia were taking a different and more humane view of that particular concept. What they were saying was that they were recognising, at least in the pastoral leases, that there were prior claims to these lands.

I suspect that this legislation before us today has a few propositions within it which are not going to survive here in the Senate. One of those propositions is the one which would lead to what the Leader of the National Party in Australia has described as bucketloads of extinguishment of native title. I imagine that the way this process will devolve if this bill goes through here is that we will have the situation where persons in ownership of pastoral leases will then be able to make application through the various state authorities to have those leases upgraded, at their own expense, to freehold title.

It seems that at the core of this legislation there is a mechanism by which there can be a wholesale extinguishment of Aboriginal rights and entitlements, to generate freehold land on large parts of pastoral Australia—provided, of course, that the pastoralists wish to go down that road, and I am sure some of them do, and provided the relevant state governments are going to authorise that particular activity. I have no doubt that there are some state governments that will go down that road as well.

I am not sure what the attitude is going to be in South Australia on this question. I would not be at all surprised if the government there did not see this as a way of doing what they have tried to do several other times in office, and that is to grant full title to a number of pastoralists in South Australia. I have no doubt that that will happen in Western Australia and Queensland and maybe other places as well. There are two problems with that. We do not have time today to go into all the implications of that, but I am not so sure that to upgrade large tracts of Australia to freehold title is necessarily in the interests of the community of Australia in general.

BREAK.PARA: That is taking us away from this debate now, and I will not do that for very long, because this is a very important debate. But I just want to give that warning, that I am not so sure that this particular process, which could lead to very large tracts of Australia being upgraded from leasehold, with all the implications that has, to freehold title, is necessarily in the interests of the Australian community in the long run. Certainly it is not going to be in the interests of those Aboriginal groups who have traditionally had some affiliation with a particular piece of land to have it ripped from underneath them.

I believe that the debate that is going to go on here for the next week or two is a very long one which is enormously complicated. I guess it is the role of senators to give advice to various people. One of the people I want to give advice to is the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). He may not welcome it, he may not even read it, he may not see it as relevant, but anyone who has got a 10‐point plan ought to be worried, because most people do not bother reading past point 1 or point 2. His 10‐point plan is an enormously complicated piece of written material which really does not cast a lot of light on what is an enormously complex process that is unfolding here in the Senate chamber.

There are a number of members of my community, however, who have had a look at this particular legislation and have tried to make sense out of it. In fact, most of the surveys that have been done show that there are only a few per cent of people out there—I think about four per cent—who really have understood what the Prime Minister is about with this piece of legislation that has come before the Senate. I have received a number of letters on this legislation, more than on anything else in the 2½ months I have been here.

There are a number of people out there who are following this process and I want to give some recognition today to some of the people who have taken the trouble to write to me. They have not sent in a piece of typewritten material with a signature at the bottom that has come from some organisation or other—not that I am downplaying the role of those organisations; I am not. I want to give recognition first and foremost to those people who have taken the trouble to actually write a letter to me, and I presume to other senators. One I will share with the Senate is under the hand of Gina Manno, from Sturt Street in Adelaide. She writes:
I urge you to vote that:
(a) there is no extinguishment of Native Title;
(b) the Aboriginal people must be given the right to negotiate;
(c) there is no undermining of the Racial Discrimination Act.
I received another letter from a constituent, Margaret Davies, who writes:

I am writing to voice my concern over the Government's proposals to amend the Native Title Act. Like many Australians I believe the amendments are racially discriminatory. Racist policies and laws are no longer tolerable in this country, and it is absolutely outrageous that the Government should be proposing such measures. The legislation is in the interests of pastoralists and mining companies. It downgrades the legal entitlements of Aboriginal people, by reducing and in some cases eliminating the right to negotiate, leaving the interests of other parties intact.

The letter goes on in a similar vein to urge that we, as senators from South Australia, reject the government bill. I have a letter here from the Adelaide Justice Coalition, which says much the same sorts of things. Again, I quote:
This legislation is so wrong that the possible threat of a double dissolution should not be used as justification for allowing it to pass. We urge you to exercise your integrity . . .
I have another letter from Michelle Lindblom of Gilbert Street, Adelaide, stating:
As a white Australian I write to make clear my absolute objection to any move to extinguish Native Title for our indigenous people.

I have a couple of other letters, again from Adelaide, and one from Torrens Park, that indicate the same sort of process. They would like to see this bill severely amended, the impact of changes that are proposed for the upgrade of pastoral title in this country to be completely taken out of the legislation.
