I would finish my remarks here today by saying that no doubt we will all have an opportunity in the committee stage of this bill to raise a series of other concerns. One of those concerns, I suspect, has to be the concept of certainty, which is where I started my address today. Why is the government so convinced that certainty will follow from this legislation? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —The Native Title Amendment Bill before us today is the necessary countenance to the totally inadequate and inferior Labor legislation, the 1993 Native Title Act. As a result of Labor's second rate response to the High Court Mabo decision, this country has had to endure a level of uncertainty unparalleled in history.

SPEECH.PARA: Eighty‐two per cent of Western Australia is now under claim for native title, with 2,265 mining title or dealing applications being bogged down. With multiple overlapping claims, the total area under claim in Western Australia is actually 183 per cent of the state's total land area. It seems absolutely incomprehensible to say to people, `Eighty‐two per cent of the state is under claim but, if you spread out all the multiple claims, it would actually equate to 183 per cent.'

Since the Wik decision, there have been more and more vexatious claims; the floodgates have been opened. In some parts of the country—most especially, some parts of my home state of Western Australia—it is not only industry, agriculture and resource development that has been paralysed but also the decisions of mums and dads.

Western Australia provides 31 per cent of the nation's mineral resources, and that provides 40 per cent of Australia's exports. What I cannot understand is how Western Australian Labor and Democrat senators can actively work against the interests of their state by voting against this bill. The bill before us has been the subject of so much misinformation it is breathtaking; the lies and scaremongering just defy belief.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—It is a shame, Senator Heffernan, because it is a balanced proposition that has been put together to try to allay the problems of all concerned. The words of certain interest groups in particular have been taken as gospel, without those words having been examined or a call being made for those groups to account for their motives.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the release of this bill, the press has deliberately exploited the highly emotive words used at times quite recklessly by the Labor Party, some Aboriginal leaders, church leaders, and a variety of individuals. They have branded the government and, thereby, its members as racist; they claim that the government is legislating for total extinguishment of native title.

To claim that the government and, thereby, its members are racist is just a disgusting and racist claim of itself. The one common denominator with virtually all of these people who have made these statements—and I have many letters like the ones Senator Quirke has just read out—is that they have not read the bill. How wrong can this play of petty politics get, whilst being aided and abetted by a media who, from my direct questions to journalists, have not read the bill either? I have yet to come across one journalist who has been able to acknowledge to me that he or she has read the bill. The claims they have made imply that they have—but, when asked directly, no, they have not.

This bill gives greater, not lesser, protection to native title than the common law; and there is no new provision in it to upgrade pastoral leases. The bill actually ensures that future government grants of additional rights to pastoral leaseholders cannot extinguish any native title—cannot extinguish the existence of native title.

Where was the media in 1993, when Noel Pearson accused the failed Keating government of being composed of `moral scurvy', and Mick Dodson described the original acts as `the latter day equivalent of guns and strychnine'? The media remained silent, although it was able to catch some great footage of the then Senator Gareth Evans and his now great friend Cheryl Kernot, doing a jig and embracing in joy in this very chamber—but a joy, it must be remembered, which was based on the understanding by the then Labor government that pastoral leases extinguished native title. Gareth Evans said:

BREAK.PARA: It is overwhelmingly likely that when this comes to be formally decided the High Court decision will confirm that properly granted pastoral leases do in fact extinguish native title.

They were former Senator Gareth Evans' words, not mine. That joy was certainly short lived. The premise of the Labor Party's extinguishment was short lived. It is only now that we are beginning to understand the full impact of the mess they have left behind.

I turn to the issue of extinguishment. This government is not seeking to extinguish native title. Of all those who claim that this bill does that, not one person has been able to point to a clause in the bill which effects it. The bill respects the common law rights of indigenous Australians and merely seeks to confirm what the High Court has said. I keep asking those opposed to this bill to direct me to the clauses which extinguish native title. They cannot. It is quite the reverse, in fact. This legislation we are debating is premised on the common law right of native title and recognises, respects and preserves both the Mabo and the Wik decisions of the High Court. It does not seek to overturn any of the developments of recent years; it merely seeks to confirm those rights determined by the High Court.

This amendment is necessary to restore a practical and workable solution to the native title mess. As the current act stands, there has been no real benefit delivered to Aboriginal Australians, despite the abundance of claims, many of which are without foundation. Growth and development in Australia has had to remain at a standstill. I have received many letters on this issue, but I received one the other day from a constituent in Western Australia which I found particularly disturbing. They were demanding that this bill be overturned; that it be thrown out. They did not care what effect that would have on people on pastoral leases because they believed they had too much say in Australia anyway. I find that sort of attitude very sad and very blinkered. I wonder if that person would be prepared to go to the people who provide export dollars for Australia, who live under very harsh climates and conditions, and say, `Fall off your land. Give up your life. Go on the employment queue.' They do not ever connect the two with jobs, income for Australia, certainty for Australia and what it means to future generations.

This bill is vital in so far as Western Australia's interests are concerned as it will facilitate the legislative provisions of the Western Australian government in regard to successful land management under land title. In Western Australia the traditional use of land by Aboriginal people is recognised and, where traditional use is impaired or extinguished in any way, compensation will be paid. Under this bill 75 per cent of compensation will be picked up by the Commonwealth government.

Western Australia produces more export income for Australia than any other state, yet we are not able to pursue the full potential of what the state has to offer because of Labor's bad Native Title Act. Uncertainty regarding native title has seen many large scale developments put on the backburner. There is mention among many in industry and tourism that investment capital is simply moving offshore.

In the Pilbara region many new exploration leases have been put on hold. It is important to remember that the mining industry in that area employs one‐third of the population, with the rest totally dependent upon it in supporting sectors. Similarly, the Goldfields Land Council has taken to lodging objections to exploration leases as a matter of course, regardless of the merits. In the past week alone some 50 objections by this group were lodged with the Western Australian Department of Minerals and Energy.

For the state of Western Australia as a whole, a very definite pattern is beginning to emerge regarding the objections lodged against exploration leases. For the fortnight ending 31 January 1997, there were 224 objections. For the fortnight ending 9 May 1997, there were 334 objections. For the fortnight ending 26 September 1997, there were 553 objections. For the fortnight ending 7 November 1997, there were 642 objections lodged against the granting of exploration licences. This has got out of hand. The floodgates have opened.

There has been a sure and steady rise in the number of objections lodged against licences to the extent that they have almost tripled over the past year. Just as tellingly but more drastic is the incredible rise in the number of exploration licences subject to negotiation. The numbers of exploration licences subject to negotiation in the same fortnightly periods were 64 in the January 1997 fortnight; 86 in the May 1997 fortnight; 232 in the September 1997 fortnight; and 283 in the November 1997 fortnight. What is the cause of the rise in objections lodged and licences subject to negotiation? The answer is simple: the inadequate legislation—the current act—has opened the right to negotiate process to total exploitation.

I would like to make the point that many miners in Western Australia are not large, multinational companies which can afford the high level negotiations and compensatory measures that are currently required under the present arrangements. For example, I understand that Hamersley Iron has recently been successful in entering into an agreement with the Gamala Group to open up the area around the proposed Yandicoogina mine. However, the agreement came at a cost of some $60 million. What chance do the smaller miners in this area have, some of which are only partnerships with very few employees, of coming to similar arrangements?

I mentioned earlier that native title as it stands goes well beyond the large industry groups often found in Western Australia. I draw the attention of the Senate to the plight of the relatively small land‐holders of the south west of Western Australia. In the Manypeaks, Perillup and Rocky Gully areas alone there have been five overlapping claims. This area is not one big pastoral grazing property on the fringe of the desert, as those opposite would have us believe, but farming properties that have been owned and operated by families for many years. They are not pastoral leases given over for grazing but conditional purpose leases and perpetual leases for farming development. Unlike pastoral leases, the holders of these properties have been given full use of the title and are now fully functioning, productive farming properties.

Without this legislation, however, the rights of farmers in this region have been thrown into doubt by five overlapping claims which have forced all farmers to immediately suspend planning for their future. Australia cannot afford that. This is not an outlandish claim and I have been made aware of numerous instances where farmers in this area and many others across the state have been unable to sell their farms until some settlement has been agreed. When one considers that, so far throughout Australia some 660 claims have been lodged yet only two have been successfully determined, I suggest that these individuals will have a very long and totally unacceptable wait.

In that same area of the south‐west currently subject to numerous claims, there are a total of 450 perpetual leases and 250 conditional purchase leases affected. These leases were allocated by the Western Australian government for agricultural development in the 1950s and 1960s following World War II and have been continuously farmed ever since. As I say, it is not just the large multi‐million acreage grazing properties of the north that we are discussing, but the average family farms too, which affects the mums and dads of Australia.

Of course, the mess created by the Labor government has also had an impact on residential properties. In the same area of the south‐west I have been made aware of a retired couple who had planned to build their dream home on land allocated by the local government for residential development. While waiting for their home to be built, the couple resigned themselves to living in a caravan for the short time required.

However, the land that was designated then became the subject of a native title claim. After three years of living in a caravan awaiting an outcome, that same couple gave up and had to apply for special planning permission to annex a small block off a nearby freehold farm to build their house. Incidentally, that same land is still a long way from determination and that couple could very easily have been living in a caravan for several more years. Anyone who says that that is an acceptable process and procedure will have a lot of explaining to do to me and to people who are so affected.

Then there is the example of what is happening to residential land in the north‐west. The Pilbara is the growing powerhouse of resource development the Australia. At present the population is about 45,000. However, this number has been estimated to grow rapidly over the coming years in response to the planned offshore gas projects, and that has had an extremely severe impact on the housing market. When trying to cope with the market pressures, the various local authorities have identified land needs for housing development, which include 800 lots in the Baynton area and 40 lots in the Pretty Pool subdivision of Port Hedland, along with more land for the accompanying light industry.

However, all of these developments have been held up by native title claims, which has had the obvious effect of artificially inflating the residential market to unprecedented levels. In Karratha alone there has been a staggering 200 per cent to 300 per cent increase in land values in just 18 months. The shire has identified 70 lots available within the town site, but this falls short of the 2,500 the Western Australian Planning Commission says is needed for the medium term, let alone the several hundred just for next year.

It defies any logic for people to tell me that they are buying up the last blocks of land around Port Hedland and Karratha. Look at the size and extent of this country and the resources of this country, yet they are saying that those towns are running out of land. They do not mean there is not any land there; they mean land that they can now buy and live on.

The 10-point plan is not about extinguishment; it is about responsible land management for the future of this country. As I have said before, there are currently 660 claim applications for determination covering 45 per cent of Australia and only two have been successfully determined.

Aboriginal Australians comprise around two per cent of the population, yet they already own or control 15 per cent of Australia and, after the passage of this bill, 79 per cent of Australia will still be open to native title claim. Where is the extinguishment? Where is the racism? Aboriginal Australians also have access to the indigenous land fund—$1.3 billion held in trust for the sole purpose of land acquisition; $45 million per year, every year, forever.

There are many Aboriginal people to whom I speak, particularly in the north of Western Australia, who want this resolved as well. It is so contradictory for some of the Aboriginal spokespersons to be claiming to speak for and on behalf of all Aboriginal people, because they simply do not. They do not speak on behalf of a lot of those people in the north‐west of my state who want this issue resolved, believe that the 10‐point plan is the correct solution, and believe that Australia should be allowed to get on, grow and develop with some certainty.

That is what they want for their families and their livelihoods. They do not want this to be bogged down forever, but their voices never get heard. It is the squeaky gate that makes the most noise that gets the most reporting, because that serves the purpose of a very biased media who simply only wants to put one side of the story and not both.

I believe that this bill provides a fair response to all Australians and its passing is vital for the future of this country. In so saying, I certainly hope that Western Australian Labor, Democrat and Independent senators will support this bill for the certainty of Western Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —This is truly one of the most important pieces of legislation ever to come before the Senate. It is important not just for its content, but for what it represents. It represents an opportunity to embrace the concept of reconciliation and coexistence with Australia's indigenous people and if we fail to take that opportunity, if we fail to travel down that road of reconciliation, then I believe our nation faces a bleak, uncertain and divisive future.

SPEECH.PARA: For me one very simple point stands out in this debate. Aboriginal people, with a real generosity of spirit, have come to the negotiating table with an extraordinary willingness to make the compromises necessary to pursue genuine reconciliation. They have lost a great deal and yet they have been willing throughout the native title debates of recent years to make concessions and to agree to a reasonable compromise. Their restraint and their patience have been extraordinary. That restraint and patience has been rewarded, not with a genuine compromise on native title, but with a piece of legislation which, in the words of the Deputy Prime Minister, Tim Fischer, provides `bucketloads of extinguishment' for native title. It significantly diminishes the rights of indigenous Australians. It is legislation which reflects the unfounded assertion of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that the High Court's Wik decision `pushed the pendulum too far in the Aboriginal direction'.

There is another very conspicuous element in the recent debate on native title. At every point at which the Prime Minister has been given the opportunity to show genuine moral leadership on these issues, to stand up for the rights of indigenous Australians and to put to rest the paranoia and exaggerations about the impact of Wik, he has failed to do so. In fact, quite the opposite. He has taken virtually every opportunity to further misrepresent both the impact of the Wik decision and of his own 10-point plan. In recent weeks, for example, he has taken to running around the country with a map purporting to show that 78 per cent of the country is susceptible to native title claims. That is fundamentally misleading.

A much more realistic map, such as the one produced by Professor John Holmes from the University of Queensland, gives a more honest picture of the reality of native title claims. Professor Holmes's map shows how native title can co-exist and will co-exist with pastoral leases—the precise question the Prime Minister is attempting to resolve with his 10-point plan. Professor Holmes divides Australia into four zones. In zone A, Aboriginal people have only limited localised connections to the land, or there is no evidence of any ongoing Aboriginal connection. In these areas there will be no significant impact on pastoralists. In zone B there is solid and extensive evidence of a connection to the land. The effect of successful claims in these areas will be similar to the access rights for traditional owners already existing in South Australia and in the Northern Territory.

In zone C there is widespread and strong connection over lands of marginal pastoral value. Here the effect of successful claims would require new regional land use agreements. Finally, in zone D, which covers much of the country, there are no pastoral leases at all. In other words, zone D is where native title is already extinguished or where native title claims are not going to come into conflict with the rights of pastoralists.

When you look at the map from that more realistic and honest perspective it becomes apparent, contrary to the exaggerated claims of the opponents of native title, that only a relatively small part of the country is going to be subject to native title claims which will bring them into potential conflict with other land users. Where that conflict does emerge there is, I believe, a compelling argument for negotiation as the way to resolve it. Inconvenience is not a ground for trampling on people's rights. The annoyance felt by some miners and pastoralists in having to sit down and talk with indigenous people does not warrant the extinguishment of native title rights.

The Democrats believe that an acceptable starting position in this debate is the proposition that indigenous rights are as important as the rights of other land users. That seems to us to be a very fair proposition. We need to be very clear about this. With the exception of the Deputy Prime Minister, I think no-one is suggesting that the holders of freehold in Australia are in any danger of losing their land to native title claims. But I want to pause for a moment and read an extract from a letter from the Deputy Prime Minister to a constituent, referring to the Native Title Act, in which he says:

That certainty was overridden by the recent High Court's decision on Wik. The same principle could apply to your suburb of Castlemaine with regard to freehold. Your title, which you purchased in good faith and with certainty, can also be thrown into doubt. There is the perception that the Wik decision is primarily a problem for those Australians living outside metropolitan cities and that the Wik decision affects only pastoralists and primary producers. This is simply not the case.

But the holders of leases, as we all know, are not generally land owners. They are land users. The land is not theirs. They generally do not have a right of exclusive possession to that land. They have been granted temporary use of the land for specific purposes, usually with some limits placed on what they can do with the property for the duration of the lease. Pastoral leases have been granted by the people of Australia. The land is not privately owned land. Having granted that lease, I believe the people of Australia are entitled to say to those lease holders: `We are now formally requiring you to share the use of that land with some other land users, in this case indigenous people who have maintained some connection with that particular piece of land.'

Once again, I do not think that is an especially unfair or onerous proposition. It is certainly a lot fairer than simply upgrading those leases to effectively exclude possession, a move that not only extinguishes native title but also represents a free gift of land from the rest of Australia to a minority of leaseholders. This does not seem to me to be a fair method of national land management, let alone a just upholding of the land rights of indigenous Australians.

No doubt there will be many others in this debate who will speak to the detail of the legislation and the question of its constitutional validity. I want to talk mainly about the right to negotiate and about the important role to be played, which I think is already being played, by local government in that negotiating process. The Australian Local Government Association is to be congratulated for the leading role which it has played in this regard, which stands in stark contrast to the `unworkability' that the government would like us to believe.

Yesterday I attended the National General Assembly of Local Government here in Canberra and I was handed a series of resolutions carried by that assembly. Those resolutions reflect the desire of local councils and shires throughout Australia to show leadership in the reconciliation and native title negotiation process. I want to place on record in the Senate part of the statement from that general assembly:

Many Councils share a vision for reconciliation. Many entered into agreements and commitments with their Indigenous people. Many have also apologised to those of their citizens who have suffered deeply from policies of forcibly removing Aboriginal children from their families.

As the third sphere of government, now is the time for us to be part of the healing process. The 750 delegates at this year's National General Assembly of Local government have approached this with an open heart. This is vitally important to the process of building inclusive and cohesive communities throughout Australia.

The assembly also expressed its `deep and sincere regret at the hurt and distress caused by policies which forcibly removed Aboriginal children from their families and homes'. As a former local government councillor, I felt a great sense of pride in the assembly and the Australian Local Government Association for being unafraid to show leadership in these matters.

Another show of leadership comes from the Western Australian Municipal Association, whose production—in conjunction with the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and the ALGA—of the booklet entitled Working with native title represents a very significant contribution to the native title process. Councillor Ken Pech, the President of the Western Australian Municipal Association, in his preface to Working with native title, says:

The challenge is to accept that the building and development of our modern Nation has involved the dispossession of land from the Indigenous inhabitants of Australia, and to accept responsibility for dealing justly with the consequences. This can only be worked out over time with very careful thought and patient negotiations by all parties on the basis of mutual respect.
He goes on:

Local governments should expand their acknowledged community leadership function by establishing local processes which open up avenues for dialogue with Indigenous Australians, to ensure that native title and reconciliation issues generally, are dealt with fairly, openly and appropriately.

His words reflect the content and tone of the Working with native title booklet. It is a booklet which offers a practical guide for local governments to resolve native title claims. It does so from a basis not of fear or hysteria, but of a genuine desire to achieve workable and fair outcomes.

The Redland shire agreement in Queensland shows how a fair and a reasonable settlement can be reached when local government adopts such an approach. It shows what can be achieved when both sides bring genuine goodwill and mutual respect to the negotiating table. That same level of goodwill and respect is of course conspicuously absent from the government's Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 .

There can be no doubt that this legislation waters down the right of indigenous people to negotiate on native title claims. The fact that some non-indigenous Australians think this is a legitimate course of action to take indicates to me how little respect there is for the rights and entitlements of indigenous Australians. There seems to be this perception that some rights, non-indigenous ones, are somehow intrinsically worth more than indigenous ones. Indigenous Australians have already given great ground on these issues. For example, they have accepted the need for a tougher threshold test for the lodging of native title claims. But they should not be expected to roll over and give further negotiating rights up simply because some non-indigenous Australians claim a greater right to have certainty in their use of lease land.

Leaving aside for a moment the question of whether or not the bill will actually deliver certainty, there are compelling arguments as to why the so-called need for certainty should fall a long way second to the basic rights of indigenous people to negotiate native title access. If they had chosen to, indigenous Australians could have simply refused to compromise on that basis. But, in their generosity of spirit, indigenous Australians have shown their willingness to give and take and to go a considerable way towards delivering as much certainty as possible without allowing their rights to be trampled into the dust.

This legislation before us in the Senate is proof that the Howard government has not returned that restraint and that respect. When the government of the day is unable to find the heart, the integrity and the moral courage to deliver a fair outcome on native title to indigenous Australians, the last democratic resort becomes the Australian parliament—and the Senate now holds the future of reconciliation in its hands.

I urge all senators to treat the native title rights of indigenous Australians with respect and honesty, just as they deserve. I urge you to give our indigenous people a reason to have faith in the capacity of the parliament of this nation to take a gigantic step towards and not away from genuine conciliation. It is time to stop this dispossession.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of sadness that I rise to participate in this debate today. Four years ago, when we debated this, the now government, the then opposition, completely abrogated their responsibility in participating in this debate and in the decisions that were made by this chamber. They took the opportunity to oppose every clause of the bill in the most unconstructive and the most destructive way that they could possibly have done so. They excluded themselves from participation. That is very sad. They excluded themselves from consultation. They also, by these actions, to me at least, give me the impression that they saw nothing wrong with the way things were previously, which was that all land title was based on an assumption of terra nullius. For anybody in their right mind to try to justify the claim that there was nobody living in this country prior to 1788 is astonishing.

SPEECH.PARA: But I am saddened also by some of the contributions, and I say `some of the contributions', that I have heard today and previously—by the lack of caring and community, the lack of appreciation that this country has many diverse cultures and many diverse views, and the lack of appreciation that we need to work together to co‐exist. Co‐existence was at the heart of the Wik determination. The Wik determination said that in some cases pastoral leases and native title could co‐exist. But, more importantly, it went on to confirm that there was a primacy for pastoral leases against any native title.

Nowhere have I heard from any of the members of the now government that particular point being made and being highlighted. Nowhere in all of the phones calls I have taken from people who have pastoral leases in the western lands area of New South Wales have they displayed an understanding of that. They have not been given an understanding by their members of parliament in the lower House that those with pastoral leases have primacy over native title where there is conflict. To not point out that particular part of the caveat that Justice Toohey put on the lead decision is grossly wrong. I would suggest that it is grossly immoral that this point has not been brought home to people or that they have not at least been told about it.

A lot of scaremongering has been done in western New South Wales by people who should know better—I thought they knew better until last night, when I heard about a letter that was written by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Fischer) to a woman in Victoria saying that they could come and take freehold. Given that the Deputy Prime Minister or an adviser wrote that letter, one has to wonder.

The people in the Deputy Prime Minister's electorate who have western leases have certainly never been given the full details of the full determination by the High Court, and I think that that is very sad. These people have been given part but not all of the information. They have been given the part of the information that then allowed people to become agitators and that stirred them up and provided them with a whole set of scenarios that I do not know how could even exist or even come to fruition. It enabled a great deal of concern and anger to be sown in these people's minds. It was very irresponsible of whomever undertook the exercise of spreading that information not to provide the full details of that ruling. It ill‐behoves whoever spread that information to speak of those people in terms that are derogatory and condemnatory.

This is an important issue. We said in 1993, when the previous bill was going through, that there would have to be amendments. We knew that because the 1993 act remains silent on the issues of pastoral leases and native title. It was to remain silent until the Wik decision was handed down, and the Wik claim at that time was before the High Court. Whilst some legal advice was certainly given that pastoral leases probably extinguished native title, the Wik case was the reason that the original bill was silent on that issue—it was left for the courts to decide. So we always knew we were going to be coming back for amendments. I am still very angry and sad that the then opposition did not take into consideration what was needed.

We are talking here about an Australian community that is very rich and diverse in its cultures and its spiritual beliefs. If you talked to the Aboriginal people and listened to the stories of their spiritual beliefs, you would understand some of the reasons why they seek native title. If you talked to the pastoralists and the farmers who have been on the land for three or four generations, you would understand their appreciation of the land as well. What I find difficult to comprehend is that these people who have developed an affinity with the land after three or four generations cannot comprehend the affinity with the land that someone whose ancestors have been here for 40,000 years must be feeling. Multiply it by 10,000 times and you might just begin to get it into some perspective.

It is interesting that during this debate we have heard from white people—very brave people, in my estimation—from those areas who have actually looked very closely at the issue and have consulted and negotiated with their black friends and with the black people that live in their area. They have come to an understanding of what they are about and have reached consensus and conciliation and are happy to allow access for traditional uses, such as ceremonies and access to sacred sites.

Why wouldn't the Aboriginal population want to visit the grave sites, the burial sites, of their ancestors? The white community want to do that. We are keen to know our ancestry and where our ancestors lie. Why wouldn't Aboriginals want to do that? Of course they do, and we have an obligation to ensure that there is co‐existence, that there is cooperation. We are not going to get that by `bucketloads of extinguishment'. That sends the wrong messages to everybody. It sends a message that one group is superior to another; it sends a message that one group has rights that another group does not have. I find this most concerning and most alarming.

I thought we were here to govern and make legislation for all people, not to discriminate against any one particular group of person in this community. I have grave concerns that what this government is trying to do discriminates against one minority group in this community. I think it is interesting to read the comments from Peter Wertheim, the President of the Jewish Board of Deputies, on the AM program of 6 November. He said:

And I could at least speak for the Jewish community when I say that we will not be mute, we will not maintain a criminal silence in the face of continuing attempts of genocide against indigenous Australians, even if it is genocide by stealth.

That is from a group of the community who have been a minority in other places and who have suffered grievously at other people's hands. It is well worth remembering that we are a community that has a very diverse culture. It is important that we recognise and remember that, to be a community, you have to recognise each other's differences, each other's strengths and work together. It is cooperation; it is co‐existence. I prefer the word cooperation to co‐existence. We need the community to care for one another and respect one another's rights.

I am not saying that there are not problems out there at present. I am certainly aware of areas where there are multiple claims over one area of land. That has led to conflict and argument, not just between the black and the white communities but between members of the white community and between members of the black community. It is absolutely essential that we strengthen the threshold test in this legislation, because the threshold testing was put into doubt by previous cases from the High Court. This legislation's ability to tighten that and to remove the uncertainty will certainly see a lot more clarity in the situation and the issue.

But some of the people I have spoken to—members of conservative parties have been spoken to—are not even aware that there are amendments in this legislation to tighten the threshold test. They have not even had that basic information passed on to them by their members of parliament. That is absolutely appalling. It just goes to reinforce my concerns that there are members in the lower House—I do not know about the upper house—who would appear not to have been providing adequate information to their community. I am absolutely horrified at that.

If people understood the situation, they would feel less scared, they would feel less angry and angered and they may then be able to actually understand the messages they need to understand. But some of these people have been stirred up and whipped up to such a state that, if you try very logically to explain and provide information, they refuse to listen. Their ears have been shut to what other people may wish to say, to what factual information people may wish to give. This failure to provide factual information to these communities is pretty appalling.

We know there are many problems with the administration of the Native Title Act. We know there has to be a tightening of the threshold test. We know there has been only one claim that has made it all the way through the tribunal. The system is clogged up with claims, some that are quite legitimate, and some that are multiple claims on the one piece of land where there is disagreement amongst the Aboriginals who are making the claims as to who has the right to make that claim. It would be fair to say that on occasions there are spurious claims and claims that would have very little, if any, chance at all if it were not for the fact that there is a very light threshold test, or that the threshold test is not being applied. In fact, if we get a tight threshold test, a lot of these claims will immediately fall by the wayside.

What the Western Division pastoralists need to know, as do all pastoralists, is that they can go about earning their living the way they have always done—that they can use the land for all the purposes they did pre‐Wik. It is very important to remember that in the Western Division lands the leases are leases in perpetuity. But their land use is very much restricted by government because it is a fragile land, and in many areas they are not allowed to undertake any other agricultural activity except grazing. Other areas they have been allowed to farm.

The New South Wales government was given one lot of legal advice that it was uncertain as to whether these leases had extinguished native title, and the Commonwealth has had similar advice. That is why they have been excluded from the list the government has put up for mass extinguishment. So these people, if this bill were to get through without being amended in any great way, might be in a more certain position than others because their land use title is fairly clear. But it is always the case that, where a title claim is in conflict with a lease, the lease will have primacy.

The Western Division people will not get certainty if they extinguish native title and if indigenous people tie them up in the courts claiming common law rights for any length of time. Wholesale extinguishment is a recipe for decades of expensive litigation and huge compensation bills—bills that this country cannot afford. We should not agree to allow the government to plough on the way it wants to.

The amendments that we think should be moved will make quite sure that pastoralists can run their properties effectively and efficiently without being tied up negotiating native title or paying compensation. The Wik decision makes it clear that pastoralists' rights prevail where there is any inconsistency with native title. I cannot make that point enough. It is something that people need to begin to understand. When that happens, people will feel a lot more settled, more certain and less traumatised.

This is about co‐existence—something that many pastoralists have lived with harmoniously for generations. It is true; I have spoken to both black and white communities who have lived in harmony. Whatever the pastoralists might have thought were their rights in the past, we must all face the fact that Mabo and Wik have told us that native title is a real property right which existed before European settlement and has survived in some places whether or not we were aware of it. We cannot now pretend that it does not exist, that it is not entitled to the same respect as any other property right or that extinguishment by parliament would not lead to decades of litigation, uncertainty and compensation.

As I said earlier, I am somewhat saddened by some of the debate that has taken place, but I am impressed by some of the speeches that have been made. It is important that we never lose sight of the fact that we need to live in a community that is just and fair—fair to all, not one group being favoured above another.

I would like to end with some comments by former colleagues who have been in this place. Some of them were here when I was here. Ian Viner, a former Liberal Aboriginal affairs minister, in the Sydney Morning Herald of 8 November said:
. . . this is a disaster for the nation, to have a Government so deliberately prepared to divide the community on a racial issue.
Neville Bonner, a former Liberal senator—of course, people will remember that Neville is in fact an Aboriginal—on PM of 29 October said:
Well, what else can you call it but racist, and what else can you call it but detrimental?
Ian Macphee, a former Fraser cabinet minister, in the Sydney Weekly of 11 November to 17 November said:

Moreover the (Law) Institute (of Victoria) asserts: "The new legislation does not merely codify common law rights but it takes away right and proposes statutory provisions which may be unconstitutional." But the ultimate condemnation by the Institute is to agree with the commission and other objective expertise that the Bill violates the Racial Discrimination Act and Australia's obligations under international human rights conventions.

There are any number of well‐considered comments along those lines from previous Liberal Party members of parliament. The current Liberal Party members of parliament would do well to reflect upon the comments of their former colleagues because they are people who have worked in the area and have developed a great deal of expertise. I urge people to be conscious of what is needed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to make a contribution to this debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . The genesis of this bill is the Mabo decision, in which the High Court recognised the form of land title known as native title based on indigenous people's traditions and customs. In response, Labor introduced the Native Title Act 1993. This act had many shortcomings. They were highlighted by the courts in the Wik decision, Brandy decision and the Waanyi decision. The result is clear: the act needs amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: The public concentration appears to have been on the Wik decision, which was contrary to the preamble to the Native Title Act itself, the then Prime Minister's second reading speech and Noel Pearson's address to the National Press Club—all of which were of the view that pastoral leases extinguish native title.

With respect, I engage Senator West in relation to her comments about pastoral leases and native title. The Hansard and public commentary is absolutely littered with quotations from her then ministers who were of the view that native title was extinguished through pastoral leases. Indeed, a former colleague of hers from her home state of New South Wales, Graham Richardson, said as much. He said that in the deliberations in the cabinet room it was the view that native title had been extinguished on pastoral leases.
Robert Tickner, the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, said in November 1994:
It was the government's clear advice, from all the quarters that it had sought legal advice, that the effect of the grant of a pastoral lease was to extinguish native title.

It ill behoves Senator West to come into this place and try to rewrite history. Her own Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Robert Tickner, was of the view that pastoral leases extinguished native title.

Senator West also made some comments about sacred sites. I agree with her about the importance of those sacred sites and the need and the right of the indigenous community of this country to visit those sites. Senator West said she was concerned that people were not providing adequate information. I say to Senator West that that is why we have the Heritage Protection Act. If you want to protect sacred sites, you ensure, as this government is doing at this very moment, that the heritage protection legislation is in place and working well and, if need be, is amended to ensure that it works well for the protection of those sacred sites. I do not think that native title was ever meant or designed, and it was not in the minds of the judiciary, to be part of a regime to protect sacred sites. They are protected under different legislation.

Those who were critical of the Wik decision have unfortunately been described by some with fairly inflammatory language. Let me say that the government upholds the decision of the High Court in Wik in its amendment bill. But let us debunk the nonsense of seeking to ascribe motives to those who disagree with the Wik decision. In doing so, it may be helpful to be reminded that three High Court judges disagreed with the Wik decision. They in fact dissented in that decision. Were they somehow racially motivated? I hardly think so because guess who one of the dissenting judges was—none other than Chief Justice Brennan, who was the author of the Mabo decision.

When you take that in context, you realise that genuinely motivated people can come to a difference of opinion on these important issues, without having to be tagged with comments such as racist scum and things of that nature. People can be genuinely motivated and come to a different conclusion. I think that needs to be understood in this whole debate.

As Senator West tried to portray it, the Wik decision sounded so simple. Co‐existence could occur between native title holders and pastoral lease holders. If there was a conflict, the pastoral lease rights would prevail. In its simplicity, the judgment, unfortunately, raised more questions than it answered. Senator Nick Minchin, the Special Minister of State, has been asked to answer some of those questions, in a legislative framework that is fair to all.

There was the option to allow the courts to continue to provide certainty through decades of court proceedings. There was the other option, which was to legislate to provide for the certainty for all Australians that is so desperately needed.

BREAK.PARA: It is not a situation where you can draw a simple line and say, `Pastoral lease rights start here and end here, and native title rights cut in at this particular point.' There will, unfortunately, be areas of grey in between, where there will be some degree of overlap, and there needs to be certainty in those areas. What we as a government have tried to do is to provide that degree of certainty and delineation.

Labor drafted its Native Title Act of 1993 on the clear assumption that native title was extinguished by the granting of pastoral leases. Within their act there was no regime for co‐existing titles. Hence our introduction of a regime of indigenous land use agreements, which will allow communities to come to their own agreements. I ask, rhetorically, `Where is the embracing of this initiative by the critics of the legislation?' Their campaign of division does not allow them to publicly support these initiatives, because they do not fit in with their campaign of misinformation. Only a few of the letters I have received out of the many hundreds in my office have acknowledged this positive initiative.

Some issues have captured the public's attention in this debate. The first is the role of the Racial Discrimination Act. Labor has proposed an amendment to the bill that the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act prevail over the provisions of our bill only. It is this sort of stunt and tactic which occasions community concern.

Labor are saying, `The Racial Discrimination Act ought to apply to the Liberal legislation but not to our previous legislation.' Labor senators, Senator Cooney, Senator McKiernan and Senator Chris Evans, have a bit of explaining to do. In 1993, they were members of the Senate Legal Affairs Committee, which was asked to report on the Native Title Act to the Senate. Guess what they said in paragraph 1.86(a) of their majority report:

The Bill should be amended to make clear that it is the intention of the Parliament that the Bill is consistent with the RDA. . . .This should not provide that the Bill is subject to the RDA because of the uncertainty that would create—contrary to one of the very basic objectives of the legislation.

In short, Labor say, `The Racial Discrimination Act ought to apply to Liberal legislation but not to ours', while recognising, as they did in the report I quoted, that to do so would—contrary to one of the very basic objectives of the legislation—create uncertainty.

Labor's proposed amendment is a classic case of the forked tongue in action. It highlights Labor's duplicity and campaign of division and their desire to create uncertainty and havoc. Where Labor failed, they do not want us as a government to succeed. Labor recognised the need for certainty, and so do we as a government. The Labor senators opposite made that recommendation because they recognised that need. But, when it is our legislation, they back away from it at 100 miles an hour.

Another issue that needs to be clarified is the right to negotiate. This is a right established by legislation for native title claimants. I would like to add here that there is a fundamental difference between being a native claimant and being a native title holder. A claimant is simply a person or group making a claim for native title. Making a claim does not mean the person or group is assured of being successful in that claim. Everybody knows and our indigenous friends fully acknowledge that there are many spurious and vexatious claims.

But the state governments under the current legislation are required by the Native Title Act to negotiate in good faith, even if the actual claim itself is not brought in good faith. Hence the need to require all parties to negotiate in good faith and to have a rigorous threshold test. That is the test which claimants have to pass before their claim can be registered and the benefit of the statutory provisions can cut in. Such a test would limit the number of multiple claims for native title that coincidentally materialise over gold mining and other resource rich areas. These multiple claims cause intra‐indigenous conflict and demean the currency of native title, thereby developing cynicism toward the concept of native title in the community at large.

Another issue to be dealt with is the concept that all people involved in agriculture through government leases or licences are somehow either rich or foreign corporations. That is simply untrue. The claim that `this legislation gives massive capital gains in land values to participants, many of whom voted this legislation into being'—as was asserted to me by a number of church groups—is simply untrue. Indeed, yesterday in a previous debate Labor Senator Bob Collins acknowledged as much through an interjection to me. Unfortunately, those sorts of claims that are made are divisive and very hurtful to the struggling rural and regional communities and are simply based on gross ignorance.

When the Native Title Act came into being, its scope was deemed to be very narrow. As a result, a substantial indigenous land fund of $1.289 billion was established to enable the indigenous communities to purchase land for their needs at the rate of $45 million per annum in perpetuity—and this in circumstances where our indigenous community, representing approximately two per cent of the population, has control or ownership of around 15 per cent of the landmass. It was in this context that the discussion about the size of the land fund took place: that the chance of getting a native title claim up was most unlikely and therefore such a huge fund ought to be made available. I support the fund. I think it was a very proper thing to do in the circumstances. I still believe that to be the case. But it should be remembered that the assessments made at the time as to the sweep of native title were very wrong.

Allow me at this stage to quote for the record Mr Noel Pearson, who said on 10 November 1993 at the National Press Club, `I rule out the possibility in Queensland of people pursuing any rights in relation to pastoral leases . . . It would be as fruitless as pursuing native title claims in relation to valid freehold titles.' They were the words of Noel Pearson. That was his understanding at the time. That was the government's understanding at the time. But we now know that that was wrong. Fine, but let us not forget that the indigenous land fund was set up on the basis of that understanding of the law and that Noel Pearson said that a claim over pastoral leases would be as fruitless as it would be over freehold. Unfortunately, we know that claims have been lodged over both. That, unfortunately, causes community disharmony.

I will also make a brief comment in relation to the very inflammatory language employed by Messrs Pat Dodson and Ian Viner in relation to this legislation when they sought to describe it—it being a bill of 293 pages—as `293 pages of extinguishment'. That is simply untrue, simply inflammatory and has no basis in fact whatsoever—and that coming from people who were allegedly the chairman and vice‐chairman of the reconciliation council! Most unfortunate language when it is acknowledged by many people, as Senator Harradine did yesterday, that quite a considerable amount of this legislation is not contentious. Yet, to make a cheap political point, people who are charged with the task of promoting reconciliation make those sorts of inflammatory comments.

Unfortunately, those sorts of inflammatory comments have been taken up by the church communities in a campaign in which they have largely spoken from a position of ignorance. Let me sidetrack briefly on to this. The churches, as indeed everybody within this community, have a right to be actively engaged in the public debate, and so I hope it shall ever be within this country. But I also hope that when people, especially churches, do speak they will engage themselves on the basis of being well informed.

So the call from many of the churches and other people for the legislation to be withdrawn or defeated is very ill considered because to do so would mean that all those non‐contentious areas that Senator Harradine referred to—those that are necessitated by the Waanyi decision and the Brandy decision of the courts—would not come into being and the whole structure of native title and the regime of native title in this country would be brought into even greater disrepute.

This has been one of the things lacking in this whole discussion about native title. I found, as a former chairman of this parliament's native title committee and as an ongoing member of it, that the hearings and the submissions always seemed to deal in broad, sweeping statements. But, when you asked people to put those broad, sweeping statements aside and you invited them what clause they were referring to in making a particular assertion, a strange silence overcame them because they could not engage in the actual letter of the legislation. They were not aware of what the legislation was saying. What they were doing was, unfortunately, repeating platitudes and other comments made by other people and they did not have a working knowledge of the legislation themselves.

Dealing with the specific issues and the real‐life, day‐to‐day examples is a lot more difficult. It requires an understanding mind and a degree of intellectual rigour, and I submit to this Senate that Senator Minchin has displayed both. The degree of consultation undertaken was exemplary. At the request of ATSIC, specific amendments appear in this legislation, as introduced, which are proof positive that it was at all times in the loop of consultations. Some types of land tenure and activities that local government and the states wanted included in the legislation were specifically rejected by the federal government in its desire to come to a fair outcome.

To conclude, there has been a history of dispossession in this country. Many injustices occurred on both sides, but mainly against our Aborigines. We as a nation are paying the consequences of that inhumanity. We are seeking to address that inhumanity through many programs of support and assistance. Native title is an important step in that process but the wisdom of Solomon is needed to ensure that as we resolve one injustice we do not create another injustice in its place. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I commence my speech today on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , I would like to acknowledge the traditional owners of Canberra and the ACT, the Ngunnawal people, whose traditional land I stand upon. As a Queenslander I would also like to acknowledge the struggles of the Wik people whose story was outlined so graphically by my colleague Senator Woodley in his speech on this bill. I would also like to specifically acknowledge the Torres Strait Islander people from the very top of the state of Queensland and the wonderful legacy of Eddie Mabo, and his supporters, who also doggedly pursued a long struggle for justice, with great results not just for his own people but for all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of weeks ago in my first speech to this chamber I mentioned what a tragedy it is that the golden and positive opportunity presented to our nation by native title and the High Court Wik decision has been squandered. This squandering of an opportunity is something which we as parliamentarians should perhaps bear an extra degree of responsibility for above others in the Australian community. Governments and parliaments have failed over many years to deal with land issues affecting indigenous people and it is about time that we shouldered that responsibility.

I wish to emphasise in my contribution today that native title is something that should be embraced, not feared; it should be celebrated, not attacked. It is possible and, indeed, desirable to see the native title issue, the High Court Wik decision, as an opportunity to contribute to reconciliation. As Senator Harradine said in his contribution, it is an opportunity to restore trust and to deal with issues without affecting but in fact promoting the development of Australia, both socially and economically. Others have tried to suggest in this debate that development has ground to a halt as a result of native title, that the cogs of our progress are being rusted or, to use Senator Lightfoot's disgraceful phrase, `the dead hand of native title' is stopping progress. Such suggestions are simply wrong.

I would like to mention a few positive agreements and developments which have occurred directly because of native title—not in spite of it or regardless of it, but because of the positive opportunities that native title has presented to us. I would like to emphasise the positive nature of these situations—these are win‐win situations. The list includes a few from areas outside my home state: the joint venture goldmine in the Katherine region of the Northern Territory; the urban subdivision negotiated with the Dunghutti Aboriginal people; an iron ore mine in the Pilbara region of WA; agreements and ongoing negotiations involving a recreation area in Byron Bay; the Cape York land use agreement negotiations, which have received a lot of publicity over many years; and a recently established bauxite mining and shipping operation in Weipa on Cape York. I would like to quote briefly from the October edition of Unity News put out by the Cape York Land Council about that agreement. This is what Brian Sawyer, the board director of Alcan, said to the Cape York traditional owners at the ceremony highlighting the signing of the final agreement:

"Thank you for letting Alcan use your land." The agreement is the beginning of an ongoing partnership which should see both groups working together to maximise the benefits of the bauxite mining project and to address many other issues of importance to the local indigenous people.

I would also like to make special mention of a recent agreement that was reached, close to where I live, near Brisbane between the Redlands Shire Council and the Quandamooka Land Council. It was signed on North Stradbroke Island—for people who have not been there, it is a wonderful place—in August this year. It was a historic agreement and a positive example of the opportunity native title presents to bring people together, to explore and to walk forward together into the future. The basis of the agreement was that both parties accepted the other's rights, interests and custodial obligations over the area and wanted to ensure that the special environment of North Stradbroke Island and surrounding Moreton Bay is preserved for present and future generations.

Redlands Shire Council and the Quandamooka Land Council chose mediation rather than litigation as a resolution process for all the issues involved. Mediation represents a commitment by both parties to an outcome which suits everybody's interests—the parties involved and the broader community. I would like to congratulate all parties involved for what they have achieved with this agreement to date. It is not a static document that is signed and then everything sits still. It is an ongoing process. That is what it is all about; it is not about figuring it all out and locking it in and then saying, `That's that one solved. Let's go and do something else.' It is an ongoing evolutionary process. That is the approach we all need to take in relation to the native title issue.

During the initial discussions for this agreement both parties agreed on two important basic issues: that the Quandamooka people are the original inhabitants of Quandamooka and by their traditional laws and customs hold inherent rights, interests and custodial obligations in relation to Quandamooka lands and waters, and that the Redlands Shire Council has statutory rights and responsibilities in relation to part of Quandamooka lands and waters. Both parties wanted to ensure that present and future land use on North Stradbroke Island was ecologically sustainable. The signing of the native title process agreements by the shire council and the land council is the first formal step towards achieving ecological sustainability and reconciliation in Redlands shire. It is not simply about land claims and people fighting over who owns what patch of dirt. That is a very simplistic and shallow approach to what is the very rich fabric of native title. This agreement has brought people together to recognise the need for future ecological sustainability, the need to develop reconciliation and community harmony. These things are way beyond who has got title rights to a particular patch of dirt. I think we all need to expand our vision about what native title is about.

Both parties, who represent major interests on North Stradbroke Island, believe that the process will facilitate the recognition of the culture and traditions of the Quandamooka people and that the process of reconciliation will benefit everybody, from long‐term residents to the occasional or one‐time visitor. As I said before, it is a wonderful place and it would be a good experience for anybody to visit there. This sort of agreement provides a great opportunity for the continuing presence of indigenous people on the island to be more clearly demonstrated to those who are visitors to the area.

These examples are just some of the many different types of agreements each of which has its local characteristics. I think that is important too, that it is not a single, monolith ic solution that can be imposed nationally. The national framework is obviously very important, but we also have to recognise that it has to facilitate a variety of different approaches at the local level, where circumstances obviously vary so much from place to place.

I am outlining these examples to emphasise the positive in relation to native title, to emphasise again that it is not a problem, it is a magnificent opportunity for all Australians if we would only open our eyes. No‐one says the existing act cannot be improved, but this bill certainly does not improve it—it makes it very much worse. It is difficult to move forward together on ways of improving the legislation and addressing things that need to be changed in the light of recent court cases in an atmosphere of division, of misinformation and of negativity that has prevailed so much in relation to this issue. That is why I wanted to emphasise the positive opportunities that native title presents.

As I have looked around this chamber since I have come into the Senate, the lack of presence of indigenous people in this chamber is clear, and that is something that has been widely recognised. It is a similar situation in the lower house in this parliament. As a collection of non‐indigenous people, if we are able to cut away the rhetoric, the important question we need to ask ourselves—and I would ask it of all senators who are present or paying attention to this speech—is this: who amongst all of us here in the Senate would like to be treated the way indigenous people are treated every single day of the week? Alternatively, who amongst us here would like to have our children subjected to the conditions that Aboriginal children and Torres Strait Islander children are subjected to every day of the week? I invite any senator who would like to be treated in the same way to perhaps indicate their willingness to receive that treatment when they are speaking on this bill, or to shout out from those who are here at the moment.

It is pretty clear that we all know how indigenous people and their children are treated in this country. We know that we would not want that for ourselves or for our children, so why should we be prepared to allow it to happen to others? In a nation that is materially wealthy and technologically advanced, it is staggering to suggest that we do not have the capacity or the knowledge to change the way we treat and cause to be treated or allow to be treated our Aboriginal citizens and our Torres Strait Islander citizens. What we fail in is the political will to effect any change. Native title provides the way forward for people to work together. It should be a mechanism for reducing conflict, an enabling mechanism towards reaching agreement.

This makes it all the more disgraceful when people engage in deliberate misinformation campaigns. Chief amongst those who I believe are guilty of this are the National Farmers Federation. I think the NFF should stand condemned not just for deliberately fostering division and misinformation but for comprehensively betraying the interests of the farmers they are supposed to represent.

Who could forget the images of the little Aboriginal boy and the white boy struggling over a Twister board, simulating the illusory land grab? That is a perfect example of a deliberate campaign to misrepresent the facts in this debate and to try to stimulate division. I wonder how much of the money spent on that campaign could have been used to help people in negotiating agreements or in providing legal advice to the farmers that the NFF purports to represent. I think it is a perfect example of peak bodies ignoring the real interests of those they are supposed to represent and pursuing their own agenda. To some extent I think some of the mining bodies could be seen as being guilty of that also.

It is something that has been realised by a number of grassroots pastoralists. Fairly recently the former Cattlemen's Union representative at the NFF, Mr Warren McLachlan, said that the farmers federation had irresponsibly put farmers through the emotional wringer through false assertions that their tenure was at risk. It is a clear example of the NFF not only playing a damaging role in terms of the country's interests but also specifically working against the interests of their own constituency.

BREAK.PARA: As we all know, this parliament saw fit in 1975 to outlaw racist behaviour by enacting the Racial Discrimination Act. I think it is important to put on the record what racism is at law. Section 9 of the act says that racism is:
. . . any act involving a distinction, exclusion, restriction or preference based on race, colour, descent or national or ethnic origin . . .
It is a real thing, and that is why the act was created.

I would like to table a copy of the native title process agreement that was reached between the Quandamooka Land Council and the Redland Shire Council. I meant to do this while I was talking about that agreement. I seek leave to table the document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I think it is important for us to be reminded of the wisdom of Mr Justice Brennan in the Mabo case when he said:

BREAK.PARA: To treat the dispossession of the Australian Aborigines as the working out of the Crown's acquisition of ownership of all land on first settlement is contrary to history. Aborigines were dispossessed of their land parcel by parcel, to make way for expanding colonial settlement. Their dispossession underwrote the development of the nation.

I believe that we have to acknowledge that fact before we can move forward. As my other Democrat colleagues are also outlining in this debate, it is the real history of the nation that we need to acknowledge—a history that is just beginning to hit the cold light of day. I repeat: it is a history that we must acknowledge before we can move fully forward into the future.

At this point, I would like to point out that there exists in relation to this legislation an ongoing struggle between the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party over validation. For the nice technical, legal word of `validation' perhaps we could substitute the words `land laundering,' because that is basically what it is. In today's Sydney Morning Herald, Margo Kingston summed up the position accurately by saying:
The left—
that is, the Left of the Labor Party—
did get rolled on validation—
or `land laundering'—

of the States' illegal grants of mining permits since 1994. Labor feared that it would blow the pending Queensland election otherwise and the right to negotiate over coastal waters—shadow cabinet was livid at the prospect.
My colleague Senator Woodley summed up the position when he said—as was also reported in that same article:
It is sad to see the ALP collapse their principles to support the validation—
or `land laundering'—

In simple words, this means they will not in this place tell the truth which is that the Goss Labor Government attempted to override native title on behalf of mining interests, and that that attempt was wrong.

I would urge the ALP not to be driven solely by electoral issues in Queensland but to recognise the justice of this issue. I know that struggle in the Labor ranks continues. I do hope that, by the time the committee stage arises, Mr Evans and some of his mining‐prone interests will see the light on the hill on this issue.

On behalf of my colleague Senator Bourne, who unfortunately is unwell and therefore unable to speak at this stage of the debate, I would like to touch on some of the international aspects of this issue. Senator Bourne has been a great campaigner on human rights issues over many years. There are many international covenants that are relevant to this issue, including the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights; the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination; and the International Covenant on Economic, Cultural and Social Rights. Our performance on the native title issue will also impact heavily on our ability to credibly participate in the ongoing development of the UN draft declaration on the rights of indigenous peoples, which is an important declaration.

If Australia wants to maintain its international diplomatic credibility and leverage on human rights issues with other nations, then it is important that we do the right thing in relation to this issue. I quote briefly from the Australian Council for Overseas Aid in relation to the international implications. ACFOA is the peak council for many non-government organisations working in the field of overseas aid and development who are often asked by partner agencies overseas what Australians are doing about the situation of Aboriginal people in Australia. That is something that the international community at the local level, as well as the national level, are very much aware of. The situation of our indigenous peoples is one of the first questions international visitors to Australia often raise.

I conclude by referring again to my first speech from a couple of weeks ago in which I stated, `If only a small effort had been given to exploring and explaining the positive benefits for all of us of the concept and of the opportunities of co-existence, none of the current divisiveness would have been necessary.' I do make this plea to the Senate and to the government: let us not make the same mistake again; let us make that small effort now, while we have the chance. As the marvellous Paul Kelly song says, `From little things, big things grow.' I fervently hope that we, with the important responsibilities we have as parliamentarians and representatives of all the people of Australia, are big enough to take this opportunity to do this little thing—to make that small effort, open our hearts and minds and embrace the positive opportunities that are presented to us.

This is not just for ourselves and it is not just for the very real, living and breathing indigenous people around the nation who are still seeking justice today. But this is also for those who have gone before and even more so for those future generations who are yet to come. As I look around the gallery—and it was great to see it packed with people the other night—I see that unfortunately this afternoon it is back to its usual empty state. But let us imagine all of those empty seats in the gallery to be filled with future generations who are yet to be born but who are watching us very closely to make sure that we do not betray their future with the legacy we hand on to them, and that the opportunity being presented by native title is not lost on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —What is Wik? What does this historic High Court decision mean to Australians? How will it impact upon our identity as a nation? How will it change the lives of indigenous Australians? These are questions that must be considered alongside the technical provisions of the Native Title Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill presented an opportunity for the government to enshrine the principles of the Wik High Court decision in legislation and, hence, proceed another step down the path of reconciliation. Never before has this parliament witnessed such an appalling rejection of what was a unique opportunity to progress, both in terms of the human rights of indigenous people and as a nation which will finally, hopefully, achieve maturity and give us dignity and credibility on the international stage. Or are we John Howard's Australia, going backwards with every step?

It is this squandering by the Prime Minister, John Howard, that will forever position this government's place in the history books. In the parliament there has never been a greater distinction between the government and everybody else. For the first time we have a government which is not about good governance of this country. It is a government born of a narrow philosophical base of free‐market dominance, which cannot see beyond the harsh, dry remedies that it is drip‐fed. It is a government that is blind to the values of an evolving community, which is demanding that reconciliation proceed with dignity.

These values have been expressed in the phenomenal ground swell of opposition to the government's Wik package. Importantly, this grassroots campaign has encompassed far more than vehement criticism of John Howard's package. It has been presented in a positive and progressive way, and has profiled all that Australia has to gain from this next step in the reconciliation process. Regrettably, the saddest indictment of politicians from the Liberal and National parties is that their main concern is the short term. They have no interest in the long-term future of this country. They are not concerned with reconciliation. They have no vision for this generation or for future generations. Since the election of John Howard in March last year, the government's emphasis—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Lundy, you should refer to John Howard as either the Prime Minister or Mr Howard.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will try to remember to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the election of the Prime Minister in March last year, the government's emphasis has been on short-sighted bandaid solutions rather than on producing real policies that have the opportunity and the capability of projecting and propelling Australia into the next century. Every parliament is remembered for how it directs or influences Australian life. Our input into areas governing education, employment, social equity, environmental issues, economics or Australia's international role and identity remain on the public record for history to judge. Whatever the issue, it seems that the Howard government is incapable of looking beyond opinion polls for their solutions.

The Labor Party recognises that the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 is a unique opportunity for the parliament to stand up and make its mark on history.
