The Senate now has the opportunity to leave its mark on the future of Australia. The debate over the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 is a watershed for all Australians. How this chamber votes will dictate how Australia's history books will be written. What we decide in the Senate will also determine how the international community judges Australia.

If the Prime Minister's bill is passed, Australia will no longer be in a position to judge or comment with any credibility on how other countries are governed, particularly in relation to human rights. If we cannot provide justice within our own society, how can we possibly question the actions of other governments? Australia, through the Howard government, will be saying to the world, `We don't have the political will or maturity to resolve the outstanding conflict that exists between our indigenous and non-indigenous population.' Australia, through the Howard government, will be saying, `We have chosen to debate native title on a racist platform because we think that best enhances our electoral chances.' How appalling; how narrow; how short-sighted; how Howard!

Let me reflect on the views of my generation. We grew up in the eighties. My generation is highly sceptical and increasingly cynical about those who represent us in this place. It is not surprising that people of my generation are sickened by the race card that has been so blatantly played by this government. Never before have I received such impassioned appeals from young people about the importance of effectively amending this bill. Never before have the representations been made to me in such a consistent way with such a consistent message. The e-mail, the written correspondence, being stopped in the street and the appeals of friends and family have added layer upon layer to the body of evidence that ultimately proves that this bill is not only technically flawed but also philosophically flawed.

For younger Australians it is an embarrassment that the government can get it so wrong. Young people are angry, frustrated, saddened and disappointed that, cynical as they may be, a group of theoretically astute adults—cabinet ministers—can get it so wrong. The claims by the government that there is a misinformation campaign in place are a smokescreen. `Blame the media' is their call. `People don't understand' they bleat. This is nothing more than an insult. People understand only too well what this bill is about. This bill is basically about whether you believe in giving Australia's indigenous people the same common law rights that the rest of Australia has. The Prime Minister's package discriminates on racial grounds.

What should concern senators opposite is that the very people they are refusing to listen to—indigenous Australians, historians, academics, unionists, actors, lawyers, musicians, artists, teachers and thousands of concerned Australians who have written to their representatives—are the people who will write and tell this history. This government—and I specifically refer to those senators opposite—will go down in history as the most petty, bigoted, ignorant and mean group of politicians since Federation if they support this awful piece of legislation, which is about taking away the rights of one group simply because of the colour of their skin.

I imagine that former Liberal ministers Fred Chaney and Ian Viner must be horrified by the prejudice and extreme rhetoric of this government. Is it the Liberal Party they know? I think not. How many of your supporters are feeling comfortable with the position you are taking? You will be judged by future Australians, and your performance in this house will mark you as having presided over one of the most discriminatory and racist pieces of legislation that this chamber has seen.

In the future, when our children and grandchildren study the events surrounding the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , the names of those senators who voted to extinguish native title will be recorded. But I reserve my most scathing comments for the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron). This minister's actions—or inactions as it turns out—will be judged by present and future Australians, and he will no doubt go down in history as the worst minister for Aboriginal affairs ever.

Never before have we seen a minister so willing to sell out his constituency for some perceived electoral advantage. Rather than defend a High Court decision that offered some sort of future for indigenous people, the minister would support foreign pastoral leaseholders and mining interests. For an example of the interests at play in this debate, you need look no further than the advertisement placed in the Canberra Times just yesterday by the minerals industry entitled, `A message to ACT Senators'. Similar ads, I understand, were placed around the country.

In contrast to the claim made in this advertisement by the minerals industry, mining exploration is not under threat by Labor's proposed amendments to the Native Title Act. Rather than wasting $8,000 on a futile advertisement, perhaps the minerals industry would have been better served by studying Labor's amendments. If there is any uncertainty—as they claim—surrounding native title, it is in the uncertainty of mining companies to continue to make immorally large profits at the expense of Australia's race relations. Their claim that delays in resolving native title will force investment and jobs offshore is nothing more than malicious misinformation. Exploration and mining continues unabated in other countries with indigenous populations, be it New Zealand, Canada or the US, where they have ostensibly dealt with native title issues.

In their advertisement, the minerals industry mention blocking opportunities for Australia. I question which Australian opportunities they are talking about. Perhaps they mean opportunities for Rio Tinto workers to seek fair and equitable working conditions. Or do they mean opportunities for indigenous people to continue tribal customs and laws? I think not. They are referring to the opportunities for mining companies to continue unfettered exploration and development without regard to the rights of traditional land‐holders.

If the minerals industry seriously claim to `support native title as a common law right' as quoted in the ad, they should welcome Labor's fair and equitable amendments to the bill without recourse to inflammatory and misleading statements. This industry had an opportunity to show some leadership in the void that has been left by the Prime Minister. They chose not to and they must carry this legacy with them from this day.

As we approach a new millennium, Australia is at a crossroads. Do we go forward? Do we progress and face our future even if that means acknowledging that the past contains many horrific acts of prejudice, disenfranchisement, racism and even genocide? Should we aim for the survival and prosperity of indigenous culture alongside non‐indigenous Australia; or do we return to the 1950s and continue the myth that Australia was uninhabited before 1788?

I stand proudly with my Labor colleagues in refuting the Prime Minister's proposed changes contained in the Native Title Amendment Bill . Let history judge the actions of the Keating government and the Beazley Labor Party with regard to native title because our commitment is unquestionable. Our amend ments seek to redress the deficiencies of the government's bill in a comprehensive and effective manner.

Today is one of those occasions where our behaviour will be remembered long after we are gone from here. Even those who have chosen to comment publicly in support of the government's Wik package outside of this place will be forever tainted with the racist brush, whilst those who have campaigned will be remembered for their strength, compassion and dignity.

I want to acknowledge the commitment of everyone who has taken the time to express their support for indigenous Australians—to write a letter, to take someone on in debate or conversation. You are the body politic. If Labor is successful in restoring some principle and sanity to the Native Title Act through our amendments, you too have a stake in that achievement. To Noel Pearson, Pat Dodson, Lois O'Donoghue, all the proud leaders of the indigenous Australian communities and all indigenous Australians: I am humbled by your dedication and energy and you are justified in your anger.

The senators opposite can choose to be remembered as being part of a progressive Senate with a social conscience and a sense of what is right and just but, under their government's proposal, they will not be able to take that course of action. I know I would be ashamed to go down in history as part of the only government to wind back the clock and return to a 19th century view of Aboriginal affairs. Everyone will be watching those opposite who make that choice.

I want my children to grow up in a society capable of bestowing justice and recognition upon our indigenous community. Effectively and comprehensively amending this bill is just another step in rebuilding Australia's future, our international reputation and the dignity and justice that our indigenous people deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to rise today to speak in this debate. It gives me an opportunity to reflect upon what this country has done to its indigenous people over 200 years and to try to make amends for that. Whilst I am proud to be a member of parliament and be given this great opportunity, I also feel a sense of shame that I have to deal with some of that history.

SPEECH.PARA: I was brought up in the Sutherland shire. It is an area that we call the birthplace of Australia, the birthplace of our nation. However, I do not think the indigenous people of this country have ever regarded it as the birthplace of the nation. For them, it represents the start of 200 years of loss of their rights, of their land, of their entitlement.

When I was a young person attending primary school, all that I learnt of our indigenous people and their culture was about people like Jacky‐Jacky, the faithful blacktracker for Edmund Kennedy. I learnt about Daisy Bates. I learnt about how Aboriginal people lived on missions. I learnt about Albert Namatjira and his great talent for painting. But, of course, that was not the real history. We were never taught the real history. We were never taught what had been done to the indigenous people, as we have now come to understand from that book of shame, the stolen children report.

When I was a young person, my recognition of Aboriginal people in this country was of the sporting achievements of people like Evonne Goolagong and Lionel Rose—people who had made it in the white man's world. I went to law school in the 1970s and I remember reading a case in property law involving Nabalco. In that decision Justice Blackburn was forced to uphold the then common law doctrine of terra nullius. It was clear from his remarks in the judgment that he had great unease with that. Nevertheless, that was the law at the time.

What was the doctrine of terra nullius? It was a doctrine that said that Australia was not a settled, inhabited continent and that the indigenous people who lived here when the white man came really did not own the land. They may have had an association with it, but the law said that they did not own it. The law said that because they were not a conquered people they had no rights to lose, unlike tribes in other countries and Indians in America.

I remember thinking at the time: how could that really be the case; how could we have a legal doctrine that was a lie? Because I knew—we all knew—that the Aboriginal people and the Torres Strait Islander people were here before us. We had come and settled this continent. When the law was saying that those prior inhabitants had no legal rights, it just did not make sense. When you think about it now, the term `terra nullius' is highly offensive. It was offensive to the prior inhabitants of this great continent. To say that they had no ownership and no real rights was to say that they had, in effect, no existence—that their occupation did not matter.

Of course, Mabo has changed that irrevocably. Finally, with Mabo, we had a decision which said that that doctrine was wrong, and it was revoked. With Mabo, we finally had legally recognised in this country, in the highest court in this land, the fact that the indigenous people did have prior ownership and that they continued to have native title rights. Whilst the court recognised that those native title rights were, in many cases, limited or extinguished, it nevertheless said that those native title rights existed. It became the duty of this parliament, then, to come to terms with that High Court decision and that major change in the approach that the courts had had to the indigenous people and their relationship with the land.

The Keating government set about seeking to deal with that decision in a fair and honest way. How do we cope with the situation where, on the one hand, we had 200 years of English common law and property law based upon freehold and leasehold title and the issuing of crown land grants and, on the other hand, we had a decision that said that the indigenous people—the prior inhabitants of this land—actually had native title rights as well?

But what did we get from the opposition at the time—the present government? We did not get a reaction which said, `Yes, this is a major change in the attitude to the history of this country of our indigenous people and we should sit down and work this thing out.' Rather, what we got was denial by the then opposition and many of the pastoral and mining interests of this country. Many of them refused to accept the High Court decision, notwithstanding its six‐one majority.

The then Premier of Western Australia—and still the Premier—Mr Richard Court, threatened and did take the legislation ultimately to the High Court. The then opposition came in here and opposed the Keating government every step of the way. They never sought to try to deal with complex issues by a process of amendment, negotiation and discussion. Rather, what did they do? They talked about the problems that would eventuate and which they clearly hoped would eventuate. They talked about how people would lose their backyards, their houses and their farms. They never once sought to try, firstly, to respect the decision of the highest court in this land and, secondly, to assist in dealing with it.

So when the government now criticises the Keating government for the problems that have eventuated from the Native Title Act and, more particularly, the issues that have now been clearly put on the table to be addressed as a result of the Wik decision, I say to the government today: it was your failing back then to cooperate that has, in many ways, led us to this problem.

In contrast, today the opposition is prepared—and has been prepared all along—to work with the government and to work with all groups to ensure that we properly, honestly, openly and fairly, without discrimination, address the Wik decision. That is why, when we get into the committee stage, we will be proposing many amendments in order to pass a bill in this Senate which does justice to the indigenous people, which respects their rights as given to them in Mabo and Wik and at the same time deals with the complexities and issues that arise that affect the pastoral industry in particular.

I am very concerned that even today as we embark upon this debate the Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin, is still trying to peddle that scare tactic that people are threatened with losing their houses—their freehold title. Why does the government continue to say this? Because it knows that its own legislation has significant flaws, that it is unjust, that it does contradict our international obligations and that it is likely to fail the constitutional test in the High Court. It seems to me that many people on the government side and their supporters still have not accepted Mabo or Wik. They still think that we should really go back to terra nullius. They would be happy if we still had that regime in place, but we do not. It is about time they realised that and came to terms with what the High Court has said.

In preparation for this debate, I have been reading through the Hansard of speeches by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and other members of the coalition. I cannot find anywhere a speech where the Prime Minister or senior ministers have actually got up and in a pro-active way talked about the rights of the indigenous people in this country. Rather, every time they get up to speak, every time they have something to say, it is reactive. Very often it sounds like they are trying to find problems and trying to drag the reputation of our indigenous people down. When they talk about ATSIC, they do not talk about the fact that this was an attempt to give the indigenous people of this country legal control over their own destiny. Rather, they go out and seek problems and then try to highlight them to discredit them.

The government's reaction to Mabo was not to say what a great demonstration of justice and reconciliation this High Court decision was and how finally the High Court had given legal recognition to the indigenous people of their ownership and previous occupation of land, and had destroyed once and for all a legal fiction. Their reaction was not to stand up and say, `What a great decision—what a great social justice decision this finally is.' Their approach was to stand up and say, `This is going to cause the farmers and the miners a lot of problems.' The focus is always on the negative. They adopted the same attitude to the stolen children report.

Faced with all that evidence, our Prime Minister could still not bring himself to apologise. Rather, he said that it was not his fault, that he was not personally responsible and that he did not subscribe to a black-armband view of history. They are all negative reactions. The Prime Minister failed to respond to the outrageous remarks of the member for Oxley, who said that she would come into this parliament and have the great privilege of being a member of this parliament but would not represent the indigenous people. What a disgraceful attitude! But the Prime Minister was silent.

Yet when Noel Pearson makes some comments about the Prime Minister or the government out of frustration, Mr Howard is very quickly in there to respond. When the churches stand up and say to the government, `You've got it wrong; stop and think,' the Prime Minister and others on the government side are quick to jump in and attack the bishops and the church leaders of this country. They have the hide to say that this is none of the churches' business and they should stick to preaching in the churches and not comment upon issues such as Wik. I agree with one thing that Senator O'Chee said this morning, and only one: this is an issue about morality. And the church leaders had a right to stand up for the indigenous people as much as anyone else had that right.

The Prime Minister says that he is a Christian. I accept that he is and I accept that he fervently holds his Christian beliefs. My knowledge of Christianity is that the greatest act of Christianity was the crucifixion, when Christ gave his life for the sins—past, present and future—of mankind. If Christ could do that, the least the Prime Minister could have done as a Christian was to apologise for the sins and injustices visited upon our indigenous people. I want to take this opportunity to express my profound sorrow and regret and apology for what was done by our forebears to the Aboriginal people.

I conclude by making some comments about the Wik decision. Whilst there may have been understandings based upon the obiter dicta of the chief justice at the time in Mabo regarding whether or not native title rights were extinguished on pastoral leases, the fact of the matter is that the High Court in the Wik decision determined that native title rights were not automatically nor necessarily extinguished by pastoral leases. Notwithstanding the fact that it was a close decision—four to three—it was nevertheless a decision of the High Court of this country. It was a decision that we as a parliament and a nation must accept, respect and deal with. We must recognise that High Court decision and deal with it appropriately by legislation.

If you believe in the rule of law, which so many people in the government tell us is one of the reasons why they support our current constitution and British heritage, you must accept it. It is no response to simply attack the judges of the High Court, as many members of the government have done.

There is an overwhelming body of opinion which believes that this legislation is unconstitutional and that it breaches the Racial Discrimination Act. The government have advice to that effect, but of course they refuse to release it. I call upon the government to accept the fact that with Mabo and with Wik, with the 1967 referendum and with the Aboriginal stockmen case, we have in recent years attempted to come to terms with that sad history of this country and we have attempted to give proper recognition to the rights of our indigenous people. I ask them to rethink this legislation, accept the amendments that will be moved by the opposition and work towards better legislation.

I conclude by saying that at the moment the eyes of the people of this country—and, indeed, the eyes of the people of the world—are upon us. This is an issue that does interest people throughout the world. Their eyes will, of course, also be upon us in the year 2000 when we have the great privilege of hosting the Olympic Games which will usher in the new millennium. Just as Olympic Games in other cities are a celebration of the history and the culture of a country—in particular, a celebration of the culture of the indigenous people of those countries—we will also seek to do the same. There is no doubt that we will want to demonstrate to the world the wonderful indigenous culture of Australia and the heritage of our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. But we have no right to do that unless we now also respect their rights, their history and their culture and we give effect to the justice of the Mabo and Wik decisions.

I thank the Senate and I thank the people of Australia, particularly the indigenous people of Australia, for giving me the opportunity to be here and to participate in this most historic and important debate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Although time prevents my addressing at length the human rights and natural justice aspects of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , I will state that I am someone who has lived through some of this century's most shameful and turbulent periods of race struggle. I refer to South Africa and Zimbabwe and the struggle in those countries between powerful elites seeking to maintain their privileged positions and the ordinary people of those countries seeking recognition of their humanity and the rights that are necessarily attached to that humanity.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall being the only boy in the boarding school at Fort Victoria—now Masvingo—who opposed the Rhodesian Front. Being a supporter of human rights—of justice for the black peoples of Rhodesia—was not exactly a popular white pastime in those days. The Rhodesian Front, later led by Ian Smith, believed in the dominance of whites over blacks.

When at university in South Africa I had the benefit of meeting and working with leaders of the black consciousness and black power movements. In those days progressive and liberal whites—small `l', not the conservative large `l' version here in Australia—used to speak and act for blacks, a kind of white progressive paternalism. It was Steve Biko in particular, whom I was privileged to know, who broke that mould and encouraged a mass movement of empowered blacks to speak out for themselves. He taught me the value of speaking `along with' the people's movement as opposed to speaking `for' them.

Australia fortunately has large numbers of empowered indigenous people who are strong advocates of human rights and justice. In this native title debate they have been well to the fore. It is a privilege for me both personally and as an Australian Democrat to be a small part of their campaign.

If there is one thing I learned from those days of struggle in southern Africa, it is that whatever perceived benefit powerful elites think they gain from denying whole popula tions their full human rights, those benefits are fleeting and come at an enormous cost to everyone, including those elites themselves. I confess that I never expected that at this stage in its history Australia would find itself embroiled in another damaging conflict on race matters. I deeply regret that this situation has arisen. No-one should underestimate the international impact this has. It is my fervent hope that this government will not lead us towards the status of international pariah on race matters. No-one should underestimate the effect that being an international pariah has on a country and its peoples.

I do not for one moment believe that we needed to have a conflict of this kind. Recognition of the rights of Australia's indigenous people did not have to be such a traumatic and divisive process. It could and should have been a process distinguished by generosity and celebration, not one which includes dishonesty, narrow‐mindedness, selfishness and greed.

The rights of indigenous peoples are an international concern. Across the world indigenous peoples and their cultures are being lost or placed under enormous pressure, quite often as a result of repressive governments working hand in hand with powerful economic forces.

It is abundantly clear now that the indigenous peoples of Australia feel that their struggle for survival and recognition is being directly undermined by the Howard government's 10‐point plan. The indigenous people of Australia do support a number of needed reforms proposed by the government to the management and processing of claims under the native title system. But they oppose racially discriminatory provisions in the bill and the erosion or extinguishment of hard‐won rights.

Who would presume to tell indigenous people that their 200 years of experience with us do not give them a very clear insight into the workings of non-Aboriginal political and economic forces and what the effects of decisions made by those elites will be on their people and their culture? The Prime Minister and his supporters have drastically overstated their case. There is profound suspicion as to their motives and attitudes.

Commissioner Michael Dodson reflected on the Deputy Prime Minister's proud boast that this bill delivers `buckets of extinguishment' when Mr Dodson delivered his native title report to the Attorney‐General in 1997. He said the 10‐point plan:
. . . cuts away at the protection of native title and delivers extinguishment and impairment of native title `bucket by bucket'.

The legality of the bill was considered by the Senate's Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. The bill is flawed on constitutional grounds, and it does not enjoy the consent of the indigenous people, which is a prime consideration in determining whether the bill breaches the races power. The bill needs heavy amendment and, when it is amended, it will be the consent of the Aboriginal representative groups at large which will determine whether the amended act will have acceptance in the community from the point of view of the races power in the constitution.

It is self‐evident, I believe, that the issue of Aboriginal consent to this law will contribute materially to the attitude of the High Court to any challenge to this bill designed to overturn it. It is in the interests of all those affected to arrive at an amended bill which enjoys consent, acceptance and support.
In the Mabo decision, Justice Brennan said:
Aborigines were dispossessed of their land, parcel by parcel, to make way for expanding colonial settlement. Their dispossession underwrote the development of the nation.

The Native Title Act did not reverse or redress that dispossession. At best it arrested dispossession by introducing a limited form of land rights—coexistence and native title—for the indigenous people. The outrage expressed domestically and internationally is that the coalition government seeks to undermine these limited rights. It is seen as further dispossession.

I want to say something about the economic forces driving the Howard government in this bill. There are provisions in the bill in relation to the management and processing of claims that contribute to improved threshold tests, more effective procedures, and greater fair ness and efficiency. Much of the intent behind such provisions has the support of indigenous and non-indigenous groups at large. Then there are the other provisions, most of which are driven by an economic agenda.

One characteristic of modern industrial and corporate organisations is their resistance to limitation or restraint. Their drive is for development, expansion and growth. Some see native title as an impediment to those economic forces. The economic agenda is a tangible one, and it is measured by money and control. `Workable', to those economic forces, means being capable of compliance with their growth and development imperatives. Those economic forces are always in a hurry. Delays caused by negotiation cost money, and agreements place limits on operations. To them, logic dictates making negotiations and agreements as quick, cheap and easy as possible.

The problem for those who focus on the economic agenda is that cultural, spiritual, historical and emotional attachments—native title—require a different mind‐set: an attention to intangibles. This bill fails to reconcile the two opposing forces and intentions, and that is why there is such a clash of wills in this matter.

Along with `workable', the other great code word of this government is `certainty'. In order to achieve—or should I say buy—certainty, the Prime Minister has stated that he is prepared to pay 75 per cent of the cost of compensating Aboriginal peoples for the expropriation or extinguishment of their native title on pastoral leases. On top of the 75 per cent to be paid by the public via the Commonwealth, the remaining 25 per cent will be paid for by the public via the states. In other words, the myth of certainty is to be achieved through a 100 per cent taxpayer funded blank cheque—a bottomless pit of financial uncertainty for the Australian community. I would like to ask: how much are this government and the various state governments that are supporting the Howard government's 10‐point plan prepared to spend in extinguishing native title, and in effectively privatising some 40 per cent of Australia?

BREAK.PARA: Mr Rick Farley, former executive director of the National Farmers Federation, said in the Age on 10 May 1997:

I think it's pretty clever politics because in effect what the pastoralists have done is use native title as an excuse to run an argument which is likely to improve their rights, and have that funded by the taxpayers.

I now wish to focus on Western Australian pastoral leases. According to the 1992 Western Australian state of the environment report, pastoral leases make up 85 per cent of Western Australia's total agricultural lands, and contribute about four per cent of total agricultural production. There are 561 Western Australian pastoral leases, covering most of Western Australia. Some of the persons and companies who own these leases are wealthy, others are not. I am advised that one‐quarter of these Western Australian leases are operated by indigenous interests. Of the remaining 400‐odd leases, a number are owned and operated by hardworking Western Australian families. But some are owned by absentee landlords, some are owned by foreigners and some are owned by residents of other Australian states. Some are multiple leaseholders. I am told, but have been unable to verify, that one Perth based pastoral lease owner has 34 leases out of the 561. If that were true it would be shocking. A minor monopoly.

So a few hundred pastoral leaseholders, some exceedingly wealthy and powerful and others not, with an iron grip over the majority of Western Australia, are the focus of all this effort by the coalition. Why? I think, as usual with the coalition, that the answer is money—lots of it!

As you would expect, those few hundred pastoral leaseholders are well connected politically and commercially. The President of the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia is Premier Court's brother. How many of Premier Court's native title advisers and consultants, and the lawyers advising his government, have connections with that industry or with agricultural interests generally? We have asked the questions, but they will not give the answers. We are left with the suspicion of conflicts of interest and unhealthy self‐interest.

Senator Herron, in answer to my question on notice No. 568, explained that the total rental income to the Western Australian community from pastoral leaseholders in 1996‐97 was $497,885.84. Given that the total area of pastoral leases in Western Australia is 94,360,000 hectares, this amounts to an annual rental income of about half a cent per hectare. As Senator Herron also advised me, expenditure by the state of Western Australia in administering and maintaining our 561 pastoral leases was $156,000 by the Pastoral Board plus $10.3 million by the Department of Agriculture.

In other words, the Western Australian public expends over $10 million dollars annually in supporting the pastoral industry and receives back, in the form of rent, a mere half a million dollars. And now the public are meant to pay multimillions more in compensation to allow pastoralists hugely enhanced property rights, together with the potential gift of freehold. Why? Whose sticky hands are in this big deal?

Then there is the nasty possibility that this bill deliberately presents an opportunity for land laundering; it is like money laundering, only with land. It goes like this. The bill will allow crown land with native title that is transferred from one government agency to another crown agency to extinguish native title. Then that transferred crown land will be sold or leased to private interests, native title free. Is this a swindle, or is it just incompetence?

What we are now being confronted with by this government is the triple bypass. On top of ongoing taxpayer subsidies to pastoralists on peppercorn rents, we face new massive compensation payouts on behalf of pastoral leaseholders for the expropriation of native title. On top of this, some pastoral leaseholders stand to make massive windfall profits from upgrading their title. In a great understatement, Rick Farley said that the Howard 10‐point plan would provide a `significant windfall for pastoralists'. He went on to say:
I hope the public debate now shifts to the morality of whether that sort of improvement in tenure resulting in financial gain for pastoralists should be funded by the public.

This deal—this proposed massive, costly and open-ended transfer of rights from the Australian public to a few hundred Western Australian pastoral leaseholders—makes a mockery of the Howard government's claims to fairness, fiscal responsibility and sound economic management. It would make much more sense all round to spend a fraction of the compensation budget on facilitating coexistence agreements between pastoral lessees and traditional owners, and thus resurrect the reconciliation process.
I want to conclude with a quote from Mr Gatjil Djerrkura on 23 January 1997:

The coexistence of rights is at the heart of reconciliation, along with respect for different values and acceptance that different sectors of the community can share resources with beneficial results. . . If (Aboriginal) communities are to make headway towards developing economic opportunities and achieving self‐empowerment, we need to have confidence that mainstream systems will work equally in our interests as they do for non-indigenous Australians. . . No indigenous person will agree to the surrender of our rights as the fee for acceptance by the wider community, and no-one truly committed to reconciliation would seek that transaction from us.

I am an optimist about this bill. I am an optimist because I believe it will be so heavily amended that this Senate will pass a bill which will meet the needs of the indigenous peoples and the non‐indigenous peoples of Australia and achieve their consent. If the Senate does not arrive at a heavily amended bill, we are going to have serious problems with its constitutionality and with the community at large. I look forward to great success with the amendments that are to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —The Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 introduced into the Senate on Tuesday is the fulfilment of another coalition election commitment to provide balance, fairness and certainty to the common law right of native title conferred by the High Court in Mabo and Wik. For the misinformed, be aware: we are building on Mabo and Wik, not dismantling the common law rights thereby conferred. The Native Title Act has simply not delivered for Aboriginal Australians or for the rest of Australia. As legislators, our aim must be to make laws that are in the interests of all of us.

SPEECH.PARA: We now have over 660 native title claims in the process of being registered. Many of these overlap, many of them are mere ambit claims, many of them unfortunately have about as much voracity as Hindmarsh Island, many of them are dividing Aboriginal communities themselves and many are raising expectations that can never be met.

There has only been one determination of native title on Australian mainland, at Crescent Head on the north coast of New South Wales. It cannot go without comment that the day after this native title was confirmed, the local land council sold part of the land. So much for the importance of the land. Any observer can only conclude that the money was clearly a more acceptable right of passage. The Native Title Act has simply not delivered. And if the ALP would talk to Aboriginal people on the ground, they would discover that.

On top of that came the High Court's decision in Wik, which has now more than doubled the area of Australia subject to possible native title claims. Something simply had to be done. In developing this bill before the Senate, the government has had exhaustive negotiations with all the competing interests. The process of discussion has been carried out by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), Senator Minchin, who is in the chamber, and others.

I commend the Prime Minister for the spirit of goodwill in which he has battled the forces of ignorance, or worse, to get this result. It has been a painstaking approach to achieve a real compromise. He has run a gauntlet of misinformed and bloody‐minded interest groups, disingenuous churchmen and opposition spokesmen like the shadow Aboriginal affairs minister, the member for Banks (Mr Melham), who appears incapable of understanding what has gone before in this debate.

I guess he is not alone in that, however, when you bear in mind the universal acknowledgment—including by the Labor Party then in government—that, prior to Wik, native title was extinguished by a valid pastoral lease. That was the genuine opinion of almost everybody, especially the Labor government. For the uninformed, extinguishment does not mean that no monetary compensation is payable to Aboriginal claimants. They continue to have that right, as occurs in the loss of any other common law right.

In developing the bill, the government has had four objectives. The first is to reduce uncertainty. Senator Faulkner, the other day, accused us of using certainty as a platitude. I remind the Senate that in 1993 the Labor legislation had about as much certainty as an ALP preselection: the certainty of a deal done here and a deal done there. The other objectives of the bill are to improve the workability of the native title process; to find a balance amongst the interests of all parties; and to maintain respect for native title, the native title claimants and the High Court's decision in both Mabo and Wik.

The government is committed to ensuring that the Native Title Amendment Bill provides a process for dealing with native title which is both fair and equitable to everyone in Australia. The fact that criticism has come from both the left and the right means we must have got it pretty right.

It is important to recall that the Wik decision was a base 4:3 decision of the High Court, with Chief Justice Brennan being in the minority but giving what he seemingly expected to be the majority judgment. Remember it was he who gave the lead judgment in Mabo, so the judge that gave us Mabo did not support Wik. People cannot it both ways—even Mr Justice Brennan thought that a valid pastoral lease extinguished native title.

This legislation is in the interests of all of us, and those special interest groups who have tried to paint our Prime Minister or the government as racists should go and read the facts and stop measuring themselves up for a new outfit of sackcloth and ashes. They are the people who are not acting in the best interests of Australia. They are the people damaging the so‐called reconciliation process. They are the people alienating the vast majority of average Australians struggling with a mortgage and being bombarded with infor mation which makes them feel guilty for something when that is inappropriate.

One of the great things about Australians is that commonsense generally prevails. Commonsense will prevail in this turbulent debate because, despite the froth and bubble, what we are proposing is a fair solution and it is fair dinkum. Our response is a hell of a lot more fair dinkum than the reaction of the likes of the Body Shop's—what a stunt that is—or the American glitz reaction of Nicole Kidman.

TALK.START.PARA: —She doesn't even live in Australia.
—Absolutely right. These are un‐Australian reactions, make no mistake about that.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take issue with one of the most regrettable comments in this debate made by Mr Noel Pearson, accusing this government of being `racist scum'. I ask this ambit claim agitator: just who is the recipient of the High Court's decision to grant a type of title on the basis of somebody's claimed race? The answer is that he is, and it is based on his race. So my advice to Mr Pearson is to cut out the humbug and the offensive language. To see the people in this government, whom I know to be people of intelligence, compassion and good will, labelled racist scum removes Mr Pearson from the envelope of courtesy.

People would recall that it was our clear election policy that, on coming to government, we would amend the Native Title Act to improve workability, and that in doing so we would respect the principle of the Racial Discrimination Act. We have done that. It needs to be said repeatedly that the cost of this native title debate is not being borne in Sydney and Melbourne; it is being borne in regional Australia. The High Court's Wik decision simply increased the need to amend and improve the original Native Title Act, given the uncertainty it created in regional Australia.

Farmers and Aboriginal people have coexisted at grassroots level for decades. That point was made so clear by my colleague Senator Boswell. I challenge the blinkered observers of this debate to acknowledge this reality. Many native title promoters seek much more than customary native title rights. They are frauds and the community is a wake‐up to these people. Native title is for traditional use of tribal land—simple. Unfortunately, it now tends to be all about money.

The original Native Title Act was a dog's breakfast. Those who were around in 1993 would recall that there were around 200 amendments, most of them from the then Labor government, when the bill arrived in the Senate—what a vote of no confidence by the government of the day on its own legislation. After it was passed, Labor never had the fortitude, or the bravery or the foresight, to attempt any further improvement. It was just too hard for the Keating government, which sat pat while mining companies pushed their exploration budgets overseas and away from working Australia's jobs.
Sir Arvi Parbo, a great Australian in anybody's view, said the following, earlier this week, as part of the report he gave to the annual general meeting of Western Mining:

It is regrettable that most of our grass roots minerals exploration effort is at present taking place outside Australia; in the current financial year only 15% of WMC's greenfields exploration budget is spent in Australia. This is not because we do not wish to explore at home—our past record proves otherwise—but because of the current uncertainty and confusion about exploration and mining titles in Australia. While no country is without problems in this area, Australia has lost its previous high standing in terms of predictability of conditions and security of titles.
That is a very damming legacy of the original native title legislation and the reason why something has to be done very soon, in fact immediately, to fix it up.

All the time farmers and pastoralists have remained in a state of false misunderstanding, having taken Mr Keating's and Senator Evans's word that their leases were secure. Mr Keating's government and Labor was and is duplicitous in many ways. None more so than in the context of their approach to native title then and now.

Our bill implements those amendments to the Native Title Act developed under the 10‐point plan. It allows for the ability of govern ments to regulate and manage surface and subsurface water, offshore resources and air space for the benefit of everybody. It provides for the validation of acts or grants on pastoral leases, or other coexisting tenures, between 1 January 1994, when the native title bill came to effect and the day of the Wik decision.It provides for the confirmation of extinguishment of native title on leaseholds that confer exclusive tenures. It confirms the High Court's Wik decision, ruling that pastoral lessees' statutory rights prevail over any surviving native title rights. It ensures that lessees, subject to proved coexisting native title rights, can be granted additional primary production rights.

The bill confirms existing access by native title claimants to pastoral leases. It provides a more effective and efficient regime for the consideration of mining applications on land where native title may exist. It ensures equivalent treatment for native title claimants and pastoralists in relation to mining and other developments on pastoral leases. It provides more efficient management of native title claims by raising the threshold test, requiring one of the claimed groups to have had regular physical connection to the land claimed for traditional purposes. It provides for the opportunity for legal assistance to be provided to pastoralists, as well as to Aboriginal claimants, in settling uncertainties that may continue. It provides for a sunset clause to native title claims, so that claims cannot be made for ever and a day, the limit being six years.

In addition, the government has agreed to fund a test case for New South Wales western division leaseholders to determine whether these leases confer exclusive tenure and extinguish native title. This is necessary because Premier Carr turned his back on western division leaseholders, refusing to place that category of pastoral lease in division four of the bill. It must be reiterated, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the federal government was unable to include these leases in the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 because the New South Wales government refused to schedule them and subsequent legal advice could not confirm exclusivity.

The bill respects native title. It increases certainty for all parties and will ensure a much better legislative framework for dealing with native title claims. Informed opinion, as distinct from much of the comment that has been made, has commended the government on its attempt to find a fair solution to the problem it inherited. All state premiers, even Premier Carr privately I am reliably advised, support this bill.

This week a number of groups of leading and fair-minded business representatives have advertised their support for our position. I note that Mr Kerry O'Brien and his ABC colleagues did not invite them to give their view. Why not? Because it does not reinforce the distorted agenda that organisation is running. These leading Australians are not fools and they are not self‐appointed cultural dietitians. They are informed and decent realists, unlike many other agitators, lawyers on the payroll and other commentators who do not understand native title—do not understand the way it has worked, do not understand what amendments are proposed and have never, I would suggest, met an indigenous Australian in their lives.

I have received a letter from the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies. It is a letter sent to all MPs and senators and is a balanced view in support of this legislation. The letter, talking about the existing native title legislation, states:
The Act—
the existing Native Title Act—

is in its present form a nonsense and must be effectively and fairly amended or Australia will continue to suffer. The current amending bill will correct many of the existing problems and is a significant improvement on the current Native Title Act. AMEC therefore supports the government's initiative and the government's amendments. The fear campaign being waged by some interest groups and some politicians is reprehensible in that it aims to protect special privileges which have been demonstrated to be able to be misused. Even the churches are now having a say on an issue on which they have been silent for four years. The only people who are not having a say are ordinary Australians who are relatively silent. They are, however, the ones who will ultimately bear the brunt of the problem on a reduced economy. Australia stands to lose a great deal if the Native Title Act is not made more commercially sensitive. The reality is that future investment could easily go elsewhere and in that process further jobs will be lost. The parliament, however, is the final arbiter of this whole matter. With great respect, AMEC suggests that it is imperative, therefore, that the parliament realises its great responsibility to get it right and to judge this matter free of bias, rather than from a narrow political viewpoint. AMEC appeals to the parliament to put native title into perspective once and for all, free of the emotions, the self‐serving politics, the ideology and tangled philosophy which native title seems to generate. Australia's interests must be put first.

This sums up what your average Australian punter feels, that this legislation is difficult and hard to understand, but as far as possible, while acknowledging the competing interests, it is a good and balanced solution.

It is in Australia's interests that this legislation should be passed to provide the certainty that is essential and to ease the heightened race tension that has built in this debate and is detrimental to all of us.
Debate interrupted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I refer to the revelation on the 7.30 Report last night that the Deputy Prime Minister's office has been writing to people raising doubts about their property rights over their own backyards, and to Senator Minchin's claims on the 7.30 Report last night that:

QUESTION.PARA: You cannot say with absolute certainty that a court at some time in the future might not find that native title revives on freehold.

Have you sought or received any advice from the native title branch of ATSIC or the Office of Indigenous Affairs that freehold title does not necessarily extinguish native title? Are you concerned about the impact of such scare mongering on the attitudes of non-indigenous Australians towards indigenous Australians, or is this precisely what the government is trying to ferment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Faulkner for the question, because something needs to be said about this. The Labor Party is causing the problems in this regard. It is fairly obvious that the High Court made a ruling and the government believes that native title has been extinguished on freehold land by the grant of residential, agricultural and other exclusive possession leases. That is why the government seeks to confirm this in the bill.

ANSWER.PARA: On the other hand the Labor Party is not prepared to do that, so it is the Labor Party that is the problem in this regard. The Labor Party has indicated that it will oppose that confirmation provision in the bill, even the confirmation that freehold has extinguished native title.

The question on the other hand that should be asked of the Labor Party is: why is the Labor Party not prepared to support that part of the bill that states that freehold has extinguished native title? The only rational reason for their position is that they think that native title can coexist with freehold. If Labor are successful with their amendments, claims will be able to be made over freehold land in the Federal Court. We think they will fail, but whilst generally the High Court has said that freehold extinguishes native title, it has not decided a case directly on this issue and that is fact. It has not decided a case directly on this issue. Chief Justice Brennan of the High Court commented in Wik that, if native title is simply suppressed rather than extinguished by the grant of a pastoral lease, then in logic this could be the same for freehold grants.

Our policy is that the enormous cost and social division of adversarial litigation on claims over freehold and other exclusive possession leases should be avoided. The question, therefore, as I said before, should be asked of Labor. If it thinks freehold grants extinguish native title, why is it opposing the provision in the bill which confirms this? Why is it opposing it? We should not forget that in 1993 Labor insisted that native title was extinguished on pastoral leases and Senator Collins has confirmed that, just as former Senator Richardson did. They believed that native title was extinguished on pastoral leases. They were wrong then and could be just as wrong now. What we are seeking is certainty. Senator Faulkner should be asked the question: why does Labor not support the government's amendments in this regard?

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, could I ask the minister as a supplementary question if he would table the document from which I think he probably misread his answer. I would also ask the minister: is his patent inability to contribute anything sensible to the native title debate the reason why your name—
—On a point of order—
—Order! I intend to deal with this, Senator Alston. I ask Senator Faulkner to finish his question and I will make a comment then.

—Thank you, Madam President. I was about to ask the second part of my supplementary question. Minister, is your total inability to contribute anything to this most important debate to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders—those people for whom you have ministerial responsibility—the reason why your name does not appear among those of the 38 senators who are to make a second reading debate contribution on this bill? Why have you not got the courage to speak up, or will this supplementary question actually shame you into it? (Time expired)

—Order! The senator is entitled to ask the minister to table the document. I do not think you should make the comments you did about drawing conclusions as to whether or not he has dealt with that adequately. I would ask you to rephrase that part.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Could I point out to you that in the full minute available to Senator Faulkner he did not even manage to get around to asking a question? All we got was a stumbling, bumbling prelude to disguise the fact that he realised himself he had to walk away from the abuse he was starting to trot out before you indicated that you would not allow him to do it. He has not even asked a question, so there is no requirement for an answer.
—On the point of order, Madam President, even you acknowledged the fact that I asked—
—Order! Senator Faulkner, you ought not to refer to the chair in that fashion.
—I do that, Madam President, not as a reflection, but because you called me to order. You asked me to rephrase the question that in fact I had asked.
—Rephrase the first part.

—Madam President, I draw to your attention that I did ask the minister to table the document from which he was in my view misreading, but you asked me to correct it and say `reading'. I also asked the minister why he did not have the courage to speak in the second reading debate and what he would do about it. There are a couple of questions for Senator Alston's interest.

—Order! There was a full minute devoted to it and not much of it was question. There was a question in the centre of it and I acknowledge that you withdrew that other slur. I ask Senator Herron to answer the question.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner engaged in his usual overacting, hectoring manner. I am not prepared to respond in like manner. It is very rare that we in the usual—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Faulkner has asked a supplementary question and the answer should be listened to.

—Senator Faulkner knows that Senator Minchin has carriage of the bill. The question of my courage has never been put to me. I can assure you, Madam President, that that is something I have never had a problem with.
—Why aren't you speaking in the debate?

—The question again is why am I not speaking in the debate. It is because my view has been put within the government. I have represented the Aboriginal people, quite rightly, as that is my responsibility within government. I continue to do so and I shall continue to do so. The other speakers in the debate have a keen interest, as I do—(Time expired)

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs to the report covering the second term of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation which will be tabled this afternoon. Will the minister outline the government's position on reconciliation and can he also indicate the practical steps that the government is taking to ensure the reconciliation process continues successfully?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ferris for the question. As Senator Ferris mentioned, the report has not yet been tabled, but I have had an opportunity to study it. I would strongly urge senators and members, and members of the public as well, to study the report. It is a very positive document that clearly outlines the progress being made in reconciliation and the way forward. It is true that there are some in the community who argue that reconciliation is under threat. I do not accept that proposition. As a government we have a strong commitment to the reconciliation process. The Prime Minister has on a number of occasions dedicated the coalition to continuing the reconciliation process as an integral part of our commitment to a fairer and more just society.

ANSWER.PARA: There are three essential elements in achieving a lasting reconciliation between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. First, there needs to be an honest and realistic acknowledgment of the injustices of the past. Second, there needs to be a mutual acceptance of the importance of working together in ensuring that our differences do not prevent us from sharing equally in a common future. Third, there needs to be a shared commitment to overcoming indigenous disadvantage and providing equality of opportunity for all Australians.

This government believes that reconciliation must lead to justice and equity for all. Australia is a decent and harmonious nation with a society fundamentally based on fairness, on appreciation of racial and cultural diversity, on tolerance and mutual respect. This government is committed to upholding these values. Indigenous Australians are a vitally important part of this society and those of us whose origins lie elsewhere should never lose sight of that fact. It is also important to stress that this government's commitment to reconciliation goes beyond just words.

We have adopted a practical approach to indigenous affairs and are concentrating our efforts on the five key areas indigenous Australians have identified as crucial to equality of opportunity. They are: health, housing, education, employment and economic development. This year alone we are spending $1.6 billion on indigenous specific programs and will spend over $400 million more in real terms in our first four years than Labor did in their last four years.

I was delighted to read the Labor Party's policy platform on indigenous affairs which was released last week. Much of the policy platform put forward by Labor on indigenous affairs is identical to the policy direction we are actively and enthusiastically pursuing. I look forward to their future support for our policies. Let me give senators a few examples. Labor's platform says:
Economic development is a key to achieving improved social and economic outcomes and self-determination for indigenous Australians as a lasting reality.

Of course the government is enthusiastically pursuing economic development as the key to improved social and economic programs. We have set up a $120 million, four year indigenous business incentive program to achieve just that. There are many other areas where Labor has looked at what we are doing and has decided—quite rightly—that our direction is the right one. In Labor's platform we also find:
Accountability must apply with equal rigour to all agencies expending public funds in this area.

Of course this government has rigorously pursued greater accountability. I believe that a tripartisan approach between indigenous people, the opposition and the government will go a long way to achieving lasting reconciliation. I want to thank outgoing Chairman, Mr Patrick Dodson, for his outstanding contribution over the period of time that he has been chairman. I quote Patrick Dodson:

BREAK.PARA: There is no worthwhile alternative to reconciliation for this nation, which we all share.

QUESTION.PARA: There was a general acceptance that an estate in fee simple—

Minister, do you accept this advice? Minister, is it not true that this government, just like the previous government, has consistently received unqualified legal advice that current grants of freehold land extinguish native title?
