INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FAULKNER

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order: the Native Title Amendment Bill was placed on the Senate Notice Paper on 12 November. I draw to your attention the fact that Senator Crane asked a question of Senator Minchin on the 17 November, this question:

INTERJECT.PARA: Why is the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 essential and what would be the consequences across Australia if the bill were not passed by the Senate?

Senator MacGibbon asked a question on 18 November about why amendments are necessary to the Native Title Act. I also remind you, Madam President, that on 19 November Senator Abetz asked a question about the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . As you know, Madam President, all those questions were ruled in order. I ask you to maintain a consistent ruling in relation to these matters, the same way that you and previous presidents have dealt with matters on the Notice Paper , and do not let Senator Vanstone get away with the oldest trick in the book be cause she cannot answer a question that has been directed to her.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been a number of questions raised on the issue of native title since it has been on the Notice Paper . In relation to one of the questions, I said that the minister ought not to deal with the content of the bill, and the question referred specifically to the bill. In relation to another question, I think the query came to me after question time and not within question time. I said that I had allowed that question; it dealt with the issue but not with the substance of the bill. The substance of the bill ought not to be debated during question time while it is on the Notice Paper , otherwise a fairly broad view has been taken of the concept of asking questions on matters on the Notice Paper on this issue and others.

—Madam President, I am happy to answer the question, but it is difficult to answer without referring to matters that relate to the bill. If you choose to allow that to be in order and not rule me out of order, then I will answer the question; if you are happy with that.
—I am happy to let you answer the question, but you ought not to be debating the bill itself.

—Thank you, Madam President. The situation is that the government does believe that native title has been extinguished on freehold land by the grant of residential, agricultural and other exclusive possession leases. That is why the government seeks to confirm this in the bill—simply to confirm a state of affairs that we believe to be the case. But the Labor Party has indicated that it will oppose that confirmation provision in the bill, even the confirmation that freehold has extinguished native title. The only rationale for its position is that it must think that native title can coexist with freehold, otherwise why wouldn't it agree to have that confirmed in the legislation?

ANSWER.PARA: So it could be the case that people will make claims with respect to freehold land for coexistence of native title. We think they will fail, because we believe that freehold extinguishes native title. But, while the High Court has said that freehold extinguishes native title, it has not decided a case directly on this issue. The Chief Justice of the High Court commented in Wik that, if native title is simply suppressed rather than extinguished by the grant of a pastoral lease, in logic this could be the same for freehold grants.

Our policy is that the enormous cost and the enormous social division of adversarial litigation on claims over freehold and other exclusive possession leases should be avoided—should be avoided, Senator Bolkus. The question should be asked of Labor: if it thinks freehold grants extinguish native title, why is it opposing the provision in the bill which absolutely confirms this? That is the point that the Labor Party needs to consider. If it believes, as we believe, that freehold does extinguish native title, then let it answer now why it will not confirm that in the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I note in your answer your acceptance that Senator Minchin and the Deputy Prime Minister have both got the legal position wrong. Can you cite even one case or one legal opinion which supports Senator Minchin's proposition that freehold title may not necessarily extinguish native title—just one case or one legal opinion available to government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, no-one needs you to put assessments and words in other people's mouths. I said what I said and I stand by it; I have not disagreed. Since you were not listening, I will buy you a few cotton buds. Let me read to you what I said. I said that Chief Justice Brennan of the High Court commented in Wik—
—One case!

—in Wik; there is your case—that, if native title is simply suppressed rather than extinguished by the grant of pastoral lease, in logic this could be the same for freehold grants. There is the peg that some people may choose to hang their hat on. You will not answer why, if you believe as we believe—
—You're stirring the public. Put your name down and speak on the bill!
—Order! Senator Bolkus, cease interjecting. You have been shouting throughout this answer.
—I have not.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I think Senator Bolkus should apologise to the chair for that remark.
—An intemperate remark. If he chooses to, he may; if not, I will ignore him.
—His leader should insist he does.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —He has a gutless leader. I note Senator Bolkus's failure to apologise and his gutless leader's incapacity to instruct him to do so. The point remains that the peg is there.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a gutless leader and you know it. You are the most gutless leader that has every sat there. You are gutless—begging Richo for your job.
—Order! Senator Vanstone!
—You are a gutless wimp.
—Senator Vanstone!
—You are a bully.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts—possibly a pleasant change. Minister, is it true that since the last federal election the government has placed an increased emphasis on Australia's national cultural institutions, assistance for emerging artists, greater access to the arts in regional Australia, innovative ways of financing film production and copyright reform? Does the government have any intention of reverting to the elitist art policies of the former Keating government? Has the minister been made aware of any alternative arts platforms? Do these other platforms seek to replicate the refreshing and inclusive approach to the arts taken by this Liberal‐National coalition government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Abetz is absolutely right. We have done an enormous amount in the less than two years that has been available to us since the last election. We commenced the construction of the national museum at a cost of $133 million. That is the museum that Mr Keating made the centrepiece of his 1993 election campaign and then ratted on.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. You have the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy President of the Senate undertaking quite audible conversations to such an extent that I cannot hear the minister's answer.
—Order! Senators on both sides will cease interjecting.

—I am delighted to interrupt yet another meeting of the sandpit club, who are burying their heads in the sand because they are not interested in arts in Australia. The fact is that we have initiated copyright reform and moral rights legislation. We have introduced a new film licence investment scheme which has the capacity to raise up to $40 million for new film investment in Australia. We have introduced a regional arts fund, an emerging artists fund and a contemporary music export fund. The Playing Australia and Visions of Australia programs have been expanded. We are providing on-line access through ArtsInfo. We have provided a performing arts multi-media library, and we have doubled the Commonwealth's indemnity scheme for the arts.

ANSWER.PARA: These are enormous achievements in the arts, and they make it absolutely extraordinary to hear the latest shadow minister, Mr McMullan, talking in terms of the coalition having done nothing new in the arts. The fact is that the arts represent the heart and soul of Australian culture. They are what makes Australia tick and they ought to be seen as the high watermark of creative expression, yet what we have is Mr McMullan running around the country talking about cultural product and the arts industry and treating it as simply another mass‐produced commodity. That is the sort of attitude that we find in the Labor Party. If we read the platform we find absolutely nothing—not a single new initiative, no criticism of any of our policies, which is clearly an endorsement of the direction in which we have been travelling.

That is what makes it so disappointing—that there is no choice in this country, as there was not indeed back in 1993, when Mr Keating, as Prime Minister, told his own staff on the eve of the 1993 election:
Labor is for the arts, of course, we're for the arts, but what have we done for them? Answer—not much.

What a devastating self-indictment. Woody Allen, who is a bit of an icon in a number of respects, once said that 80 per cent of success in life is just turning up. All I can say is Mr McMullan is the Woody Allen of the Australian arts industry, because he thinks that by swanning around and turning up at a few arts functions and going through a bit of professional hand wringing he will somehow be able to persuade the arts industry that he is offering a constructive alternative.

Of course, Mr McMullan has only just recently acquired this title. Remember after the last election those opposite had the choice of doing what we did and combining the arts with communications, but of course they could not give it to a professional philistine like Senator Schacht, could they?

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. I have been trying to listen to the answer to this question. There is obviously a meeting of the left faction of the Labor Party going on here without their leader, Senator Faulkner. I am wondering whether you could ask them to leave the chamber so that we can hear the answer.
—Look at cockies' corner! They're still at it!
—Order! Senators on my left do not have to listen to the answer if they do not wish to, but I would ask that the conversation be kept at a slightly lower level.
—They are still going.
—I am talking about the level of noise in the chamber. I am not suggesting that you may not converse with each other.

—There can be no doubt that Labor offers virtually nothing in this area by way of an alternative. Ignoring the professional philistine Senator Schacht, those opposite then gave the portfolio to Carmen Lawrence for about 12 months. She did not trouble the scorers—absolutely invisible. Of course, they inherited this portfolio from Michael Lee, whose greatest contribution was going to the film nights, where he got up and said a few introductory words and then, as soon as the lights were turned down, snuck off back to his office or wherever else it was, showing absolute disdain for the film industry and the arts of this country.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been to very many functions and have not seen any of them there. It is just a no‐show. I think Senator Lundy turned up to one of them, and I commend her for that. I would have hoped there would be a bit more attendance. It must be very disappointing indeed for the arts community to find that there is simply no alternative on offer—nothing in the platform, nothing except a bit of gratuitous criticism from time to time but no quarrelling with the direction we have taken. We have made enormous strides in the arts in the last two years. It is a great tragedy for Australia that there is nothing else out there. Indeed, the Labor Party are making it very plain day by day that they are simply not interested in this area. If they were, they would have a lot more to offer. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin. Minister, my question relates to your nationally broadcast statement on the 7.30 Report last night that, because there had not been a test case on native title claims on freehold land, `we don't yet know for a fact that native title can't revive where there has been freehold'. Is it not a fact that, as well as being morally reprehensible, this statement is absolutely untrue? Minister, is it not a fact that in the Wik case itself, which gave rise to this legislation, allegedly, Sir Maurice Byers QC, acting for the Thayorre people, put the direct proposition to the High Court that freehold title did not necessarily extinguish native title and that the High Court unanimously rejected that proposition—seven to nil?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I am very happy to answer this question but, equally, I am conscious of your rulings in relation to the point of order brought by Senator Margetts last week on the very question of debating matters on the Notice Paper , which the native title bill is. As I said, I am very happy to answer this question, because it takes the place of a dorothy dixer.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that what I said on the 7.30 Report last night related to the question of revival of native title—and you are accusing me of scaremongering on this issue! You have no place to attack me on scaremongering. Your party has been running around saying that the compensation bill for native title on Cape York as a result of our amendments would be $2,000 million—an outrageous proposition when you know as well as I do we are not extinguishing native title on pastoral leases and the current market value of pastoral leases on Cape York is $50 million—one-fortieth of this nonsense figure you are running.

The fact is—and you well know it—that Aboriginal leaders in this country believe that native title can revive when freehold is raised. When the freehold land is resumed, they argue that native title can revive. I draw your attention to what your Chief Minister, Shane Stone, said in his statement today:

The whole question of freehold will be put in doubt by the ALP's unwillingness to confirm that grant of freehold extinguishes native title. One reason is that Labor's land council mates last week hit the Northern Territory Government with a claim over former freehold land which was acquired by the Crown on the basis that this process automatically revives native title.
If I am scaremongering, tell that to your Northern Land Council mates. They are doing exactly the same thing.

In terms of legal advice on this question of freehold and native title, I draw your attention to the very eminent South Australian Solicitor-General, Mr Brad Selway QC, who said to the parliamentary committee on native title:

BREAK.PARA: Our understanding at the moment is that all judges have accepted that freehold title extinguishes native title, but we say—
that is, the South Australian government in the form of the Solicitor-General, Brad Selway QC—

that this is not self-evidently so. In Wik it was argued that this was not true. The Canadian courts have held that native title can continue to apply in respect of freehold. Academic papers have been written that suggest native title can continue to apply in respect of freehold. There are arguments that a spiritual connection is sufficient. If a spiritual connection is sufficient, then there is no reason in principle why freehold should extinguish native title.

You know this is a live issue with Aboriginal leaders of Australia. What we are doing is confirming that freehold extinguishes native title and the 60,000 exclusive tenure leases in this country extinguish native title.

The real question for this country is: why won't you support that? Why won't you guarantee the security of everyone with a freehold and an exclusive tenure in this country? Why are you leaving that question open? Why are you leaving 60,000 leases in this country subject to native title claim? You know those claims can all be made in the Federal Court. Why won't you? That is the question you have to answer.
Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Disorderly rabble, throw them out! Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I know you are angry because you know you are wrong. Minister, answer me this: what does all that bluff about lapsed freehold title have to do with the validity of the letter that was sent by the Deputy Prime Minister's senior policy adviser to householders in Castlemaine suggesting that the title to their houses was in doubt? See if you can defend that. While you are at it, will you admit that that performance last night was simply you panicking under pressure? Was it simply a case of you wanting to defend your Deputy Prime Minister in the same way as your overblown rhetoric in 1993 about our native title bill was just a case to quote you of being a team player?

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Yet again a question has been used as an opportunity for sustained verbal abuse. You should not allow that. It is all very well to have a bit of cut and thrust, we can all cope with that. But these sorts of tactics are quite deliberate. We have seen it from Senator Faulkner, who is trying to turn it into an art form, deliberately trying to intimidate people and raise the temperature on a very sensitive issue. I strongly submit that you should not allow questions to be dealt with if they are going to be put forward in that form.

—Madam President, on the point of order. I think the opposition could take a point of order from anyone other than Senator Alston who spends every answer to a dorothy dixer smearing and playing the man against any Labor Party spokesman he can find. If ever we have seen a case of miserable double standards in a point of order! If you were to rule, Madam President, that Senator Bob Collins' supplementary question was out of order, every day you would have to sit down Senator Alston from his smearing answers in this chamber.
—There has been verbal abuse and what I would call sledging going on in recent times which I think is undignified and in breach of standing orders. It would be much better if it did not occur.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bob Collins is an absolute goose. He did not ask me—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bob Collins interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a moment, Senator Minchin. Senator Collins, you have been interjecting throughout question time today. This is your question and your supplementary question. You ought at least allow the minister to deal with it.

—Senator Collins did not ask me, in his original question, about Terry Ryan's letter. He asked me about my comments in the 7.30 Report last night. What I said in the 7.30 Report last night related to the question of revival. That was the tenor of my answer, because you know very well that is a live question.

ANSWER.PARA: You did not ask me about Terry Ryan's letter. If you want me to tell you about Terry Ryan's letter, all right. But your supplemen tary did not relate to your question. You were trying to avoid what I was saying in the 7.30 Report about the issue of revival. You know perfectly well that our understanding of the common law is that freehold extinguishes native title. That is why we want to confirm it in our bill.

As I said before: why won't you agree with that confirmation and make sure that no claims can be made over freehold title? Why won't you ensure that the 21 per cent of Australia that is freehold or exclusive tenure is free of claim leaving the 79 per cent of Australia on which native title may have survived subject to claim?

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State. Minister, throughout the Wik debate your government has made the allegation that economic activity and development is very significantly impeded because of native title. Are you aware of the study by Dr Ian Manning of the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research illustrating that there is no hard evidence that native title has reduced or will reduce future mining activity? Are you further aware that ABS statistics released today show post-Mabo investment in mining is up 110 per cent since 1993 from $5.6 billion to $11.8 billion? Are you aware that the mining sector achieved record profits of $6 billion in 1995-96, will maintain that in 1997 and is on track for a similar result in 1998? Will you admit that, while some reform of process is necessary, the idea that the mining industry is at a standstill is blatantly alarmist?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —I am amazed that Senator Murray seems to think he knows more about the mining industry than the mining industry does. Mining industry leaders have made it perfectly clear what they think of the native title process. Clearly Senator Murray has never been to the Goldfields, where the Goldfields Land Council itself says that the current Native Title Act is a joke and where mining industry developments are being tangled up in massive numbers of overlapping multiple claims and destroying confidence in the mining industry.

BREAK.PARA: He seems to be completely unaware of the massive increase in the amount of exploration now going on overseas. Has he not been around the world and found Australian mining companies that would rather invest in exploration in places like India and Pakistan than in Australia because of the operation of Paul Keating's 1993 Native Title Act, which put impossible hurdles in the face of mining?

The tragedy of all of this is that the Aboriginal people will be the primary beneficiaries of the development of our mining industry. The only real hope for real economic development in outback Australia is the development of the mining industry. What is the greatest obstacle to the development of the mining industry in this country? Paul Keating's 1993 Native Title Act. I wish that Senator Murray would have a dose of reality and get into this debate properly and realise that if he wants Aboriginal people to have job security and a good future what is needed is a secure future for the mining industry. He should support our amendments, which will pave the way for the mining industry to grow and develop in partnership with Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, it is a pleasure to reel you in. In Western Australia, Minister, as much as 95 per cent of notices issued under the Native Title Act for exploration licences have been granted without objection from native title claimants. Mineral exploration expenditure in Western Australia rose by $11.9 million to $188.2 million in the June quarter of 1997, more than in any other state or territory. We recognise there are problems, but we are saying to you that you are overstating the difficulties; you are scaremongering. Minister, will you lower your tone and raise the level of the debate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray does not seem to understand his own state. I tell you, Senator Murray, that of the 1,910 acts in Western Australia which have been subject to the full right to negotiate process only 148 were cleared for grant as at 10 October 1997—a clearance rate of about 7.7 per cent. Most of the mineral tenements which have attracted the right to negotiate are mining leases, with an overall clearance rate for section 29 notices of around 18 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: The trend clearance rate for mining leases has been declining since WA began using the NTA procedures. It is only with exploration and prospecting tenures where there is any sort of reasonable clearance rate. The average period for the grant of a mining lease in Western Australia has more than doubled, from 5.3 months in 1994-95 to 11.4 months in 1996-97, and many applications have been outstanding for more than two years. You really ought to get with the facts, Senator Murray, and understand what is going on in your own state.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Minister, this morning on ABC Radio 2CN the Attorney-General was asked, after having been referred to the comments of the Special Minister of State on the 7.30 Report last night, whether people's backyards were in danger of native title claims. Mr Williams eventually responded:

QUESTION.PARA: I didn't hear the comments made by Senator Minchin. It seems to me that we've had a lot of claims made on different sides of the argument that really are unsustainable.
Minister, will you join Mr Williams in repudiating Senator Minchin's and Mr Fischer's claims that the backyards of ordinary Australians may be at risk from native title claims, and if not why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans, you are a bit sillier than I thought you were—quite a bit sillier, actually. You are usually pretty charming, but I thought you had a few brains as well. You have had this answer canvassed in here on a number of occasions today.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I am extremely worried that Senator Alston has laryngitis as he has not jumped for a point of order, so I am just interrupting debate to give him a chance.
—There is no point of order.

—I did point out that Senator Evans was, generally speaking, of a charming nature. The point is this: I did not hear the Attorney's remarks this morning, but nothing said by Senator Evans today is a repudiation of other remarks. It was simply a statement, as you allege, that some spurious claims have been made throughout this debate. If I had the time and I was responsible for this debate, I would list for them the spurious remarks made on that side of the chamber which are seeking to drag this debate down to a level that it should never go down to.

ANSWER.PARA: You are basically asking me whether I agree with the Attorney that people's backyards are not at risk. What did you hear Senator Herron say, were you listening when I spoke, and were you listening to Senator Minchin when all three put the proposition that we believe freehold does extinguish native title? There is a common agreement on that. That is what we believe to be the case. What we want to do is make that absolutely certain by putting it in the legislation. What we want to know is why you will not agree. You have heard this run once, twice, three times and this is the fourth time. I hope you have cottoned on by now.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. I note that, according to a survey by Greenpeace, 76 per cent of Australians disagree with the government's plans to increase, not decrease, greenhouse gas emissions. I ask: is the minister aware of a report released today by the World Wildlife Fund showing that a carbon tax of $1.65 a tonne, much smaller than invoked elsewhere in the world, would make land clearing uneconomic? Is it true that about half a million hectares of bush is cleared in Australia each year and this contributes to more than 20 per cent of Australia's greenhouse gas emissions? Isn't the simplest way of meeting greenhouse targets to stop clearing, and why does the government's greenhouse package completely ignore clearing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not intending to introduce a carbon tax. That is what the Labor Party wished to do. That is what Senator Faulkner, when he was in government, took to his cabinet and got overruled on in the last election. He got rolled, and I will not remind him of how that was editorialised at the time. But what we do know is that, on the target as announced by the Labor Party at the moment, there would need to be a very significant carbon tax. It has been estimated that it would be a carbon tax that would call in about $2 billion a year.

ANSWER.PARA: What would be the effect of that? It would add to the cost of doing business in this country, it would make us less competitive and it would have a negative effect on jobs. Therefore, let us get it straight, Senator Brown, you might want a carbon tax, Labor might want a carbon tax, the Democrats definitely want a carbon tax, but this government will not be introducing a carbon tax.

In the other part of Senator Brown's question there is an issue of some merit—although that is rare. That issue is that, if we can reduce the rate of land clearing, we can make a significant difference in our emissions and, therefore, a useful contribution to a better global outcome. The figures for 1990, as I recall them, had about 24 per cent of our emissions resulting from land clearing. The last inventory published showed that that had reduced to about 17 per cent. What Senator Brown would not want to acknowledge is that the rate of land clearing in this country is reducing. If it can continue to reduce, that will play a further significant part in achieving a better emissions bottom line.

Senator Brown might not understand it, but it is the objective of the government to include land issues—in our instance, principally land clearing—within the outcome of the Kyoto process, so that we can get due credit for that change, which is improving our net emissions level.

So, yes, there are two sides to this equation. The first is the need to reduce emissions where that can responsibly be done. Methods to achieve that goal have been announced by the Prime Minister. Senator Brown wants to go further into the irresponsible, in our view. The other side of the equation is that we can increase our level of plantation forests. We plan to treble our plantation forests by the year 2020, which will make a significant improvement on the side of sinks, which has the same effect as reducing emissions. If we can continue to reduce land clearance, we can make a significant improvement in that area as well.

So it is true that we approach this on a comprehensive basis—all sources, all gases and all sinks—and we believe the real test should be the bottom line. We will continue to prove up the science, to justify the figures we attach to the benefits from slowing land clearing, but that can be a way, Senator Brown, in which we can significantly contribute to a better global outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question. Why is that you make it explicit that your government is taking no action to reduce land clearing, as part of the greenhouse package or otherwise? For example, you use no leverage on the state governments through the National Heritage Trust Fund—the Telstra money—to reduce land clearance. Can you explain the government's policy of increasing plantations over 20 years—three times, as you have just said—when four years of land clearance demolishes all the effect of that as far as greenhouse gas emissions are concerned? In short, why, in your policy and in your approach to state governments in the handling of this matter, are you ignoring the major source of greenhouse emissions, which come through the vast clearance of land in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —In actual fact, we are including the issue of land clearing, as I said. Under the National Heritage Trust partnership agreements, land clearance is addressed. The commitment that has been made by the Queensland government has been applauded by the Queensland Conservation Council. So I am surprised at what Senator Brown is saying.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that we need to expand plantation forests and to slow land clearance if we want to get the maximum outcome from that side of the equation. I thought I made that clear in my answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, I refer you to the Acting Prime Minister's claims on the 7.30 Report on Tuesday and in question time in the House yesterday in which he claimed that Mr Noel Pearson was seeking exclusive possession of a number of pastoral leases. Is it not true that the land in question is presently unallocated state land, upon which all four of the previously existing pastoral leases have been cancelled by the Queensland government. Is it not true that there is currently no existing pastoral lease on the land which is the subject of the claim?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Mr Fischer has addressed that issue in the House of Representatives today. I am sure that getting it first hand is probably more useful to Senator Cook than getting it second hand from me.

ANSWER.PARA: But this does give me the opportunity to reinforce the answers that have been given by my colleagues today on this subject. What we are seeking to do in this legislation is to remove all doubt. After what has occurred in relation to pastoral leases, it is not possible for the Labor Party to stand here today and say that it is unnecessary to remove all doubt.

All you need to do is refer to the wise words of former Senator Evans, a political silk, who told us in 1993 that pastoral leases extinguished native title and that the authority for that was the High Court. Now we find, after Wik, that that is not so. In other words, in relation to pastoral leases the Labor Party misunderstood the decision of the High Court, and now action is necessary to clarify the matter.

It seems to us on this side of the chamber that certainty is a small price to pay in this legislation to remove all doubt. Why then wouldn't the Labor Party stand here with us and say, `We will ensure that we do not make again the same mistake as we made in 1993. We will join with the government in this instance and remove it from all doubt.' There is still a great deal of ambiguity—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam President: I did not ask Senator Hill the question so he could make a ministerial statement or defend the inadequacy of his colleagues. I asked him the question so I could get an answer. He has not given an answer and, if he regards what he has said as an answer, he should sit down and be quiet from this point on. Would you please direct him to now answer the question that was put to him?
—I believe Senator Hill answered it initially and is still talking on matters relevant to the question.

—I will finish by simply saying there is still a large degree of ambiguity in relation to native title. The High Court has but scratched the surface. We believe that we have a legislative responsibility to provide certainty and we will do that in every area in which we believe that all peoples of Australia are entitled to that certainty. That is why we bring this legislation into the parliament. That is why we seek to confirm the situation that we believe in in relation to freehold title and that can only be said to be responsible legislative practice.

—Madam President, I have a supplementary question for the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Last night the Deputy Prime Minister shamelessly misrepresented Mr Pearson and the other members who were part of that claim. You said today, Minister, that Mr Fischer addressed that in the other place. Did he give an apology to Mr Pearson for the shameless public misrepresentation of the facts in this matter? Did he apologise to the other claimants as well? If he did, would you repeat those apologies in this chamber? If he did not, can we deduce that the code of ministerial conduct counts for nothing in this government?
—The point I was making is that there are within this country many and varied types of title. There is still considerable ambiguity as to which ones are extinguished or not.

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. Senator Cook's question goes to a specific claim made by 600 or so applicants including Mr Pearson—a claim which does not seek exclusive possession. Mr Fischer made the assertion that it does. Mr Fischer should apologise. The question goes very much to whether the government will apologise to Mr Pearson and others, not to a wide rambling about all sorts of different land tenures. Senator Hill should actually focus on the question and not ramble on like this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Brien asked me a question on Wednesday, 19 November and I have been provided with the information. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .
—On a point of order: I ask ministers whether they could table the answers and have them incorporated in Hansard . If they are merely incorporated in Hansard we do not get them until the next day.
—I table the answer and seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
On Wednesday 19 November 1997, (Hansard page 8941) Senator O'Brien asked me to:
(i) explain the risk diminution aspect of the 45‐day rule applying to the government's proposed measures to prevent trading in franking credits;

(ii) confirm whether, in a situation where the net equity risk is such that the net delta of a financial derivative is less than 0.7, the arrangement will not attract the risk diminution aspect of the 45‐day rule; and
(iii) explain how the risk diminution aspect of the 45‐day rule will apply to employee share ownership schemes, and what is the situation where the employer is wholly by non‐residents.
The Commissioner of Taxation has provided me with information regarding franking credit trading, and now I seek leave to have this incorporated in Hansard .
As part of the measures to prevent franking credit trading the Government announced in the 1997‐98 Budget the introduction of a holding period for shares known as the 45‐day rule.

In determining whether shares are held for the requisite holding period, days during which there is in place a risk diminution arrangement are not counted. Following consultation with interested parties the rule was modified so that relevant risk diminution arrangements are those where a high level of both the upside and the downside of equity risk is removed. The mechanism for identifying these arrangements is the concept of delta. Delta, a well recognised financial concept, is a measurement of the relative change in the price of an option or other derivative for a given (small) change in the price of an underlying asset. The franking credit trading measures seek to restrict the benefits of imputation to the true economic owners of shares. The net delta concept in this context provides a financial measure of the extent of that economic ownership.

As explained in the Treasurer's Press Release of 8 August 1997 (No. 89), I confirm that where the net equity risk is such that the net delta of a financial derivative is less than 0.7 (so that, broadly speaking, the taxpayer's effective equity risk in respect of the relevant shares is 0.3 or more per share) the arrangement will not attract the risk diminution aspect of the 45‐day rule. In other words, if the net delta of the position comprising the related derivatives and shares is thirty per cent or more, the arrangement will not attract the risk diminution aspect of the 45‐day rule.

In respect of the 45‐day rule and employee share schemes, if the employee share scheme is structured in such a way that there is a risk diminution arrangement then the 45‐day rule could apply. However, the Treasurer explained in his Press Release that there will be an exemption from the rule and some of the other franking credit trading measures for `eligible' employee share schemes. I refer Senator O'Brien to the Press Release for what constitutes an `eligible' employee share scheme. This exemption applies irrespective of whether or not the employer is wholly owned by non‐residents.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday, 19 November, Senator West asked me a question on small business. I table the answer and seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
On Wednesday 19 November 1997 (Hansard page 8942), Senator West asked me:

Does this mean that if a non‐small business person beneficiary holds 100 shares in Telstra, then all of Telstra's assets would be included in the calculation of the $5 million eligibility threshold under the newly inserted sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act?
The Commissioner of Taxation has provided me with information regarding rollover relief for small businesses, and now I seek leave to have this incorporated in Hansard .

It is common for the trust deeds of discretionary trusts to prescribe as beneficiaries, any company in which a beneficiary of the trust has an interest. If a beneficiary holds an interest in a public entity, such as a listed public company, then that entity becomes a potential beneficiary of that discretionary trust. This can result in the assets of the public entity being taken into account in determining whether the trust satisfies the $5 million threshold test for the small business roll‐over relief.

An amendment is proposed to the roll‐over relief provisions to provide that where a beneficiary of a discretionary trust has an interest in a public entity and, because of the beneficiary's interest in that entity, the entity becomes a potential beneficiary of the trust, then the assets of the entity will not be taken into account in determining whether the trust satisfies the $5 million threshold test.
For example, if any beneficiary of a discretionary trust held 100 shares in Telstra, then the assets of Telstra will not be included in the $5 million threshold test.
This amendment will be introduced into Parliament in the next available Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday, 19 November, Senator Bishop asked me a question on fringe benefits tax. I table the answer and seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
On Wednesday 19 November 1997, (Hansard page 8984) Senator Bishop asked me:
(i) can you outline to the Senate how the government's proposed new arranger provisions for FBT will differ from the current arrangements?

(ii) isn't it a fact that, under the government's proposal, if a third‐party‐‐say, a client‐‐invites an employee to lunch, and the employer did not stop the employee attending the lunch, then FBT would apply?

(iii) could you please explain why the government wishes to impose FBT when an employer and an employee both attend a lunch provided by a client, yet if an employee attends on their own there may or may not be an FBT liability?

(iv) can you explain the circumstances under which FBT will be payable when an employee attends a lunch provided by the client and those circumstances where no FBT will be payable if the employee attends the lunch?
I now seek leave to have my answers incorporated in Hansard .

(i) Under the arranger provisions in the existing law, FBT is payable on benefits provided by a third party under an arrangement between the third party and the employer. The definition of arrangement is very wide. For example, an employer may be liable for FBT if the employer is aware that a third party is providing benefits to employees and does nothing to prohibit employees from accepting those benefits.

Under the amendments proposed by the government, an employer would be liable for FBT for benefits provided by a third party only if the employer has made an agreement or similar arrangement with the third party for the provision of the benefits or the employer knowingly participated in or facilitated the provision of the benefits.

(ii) No, under the amendments proposed by the government, an employer will not be liable for FBT for a benefit provided by a third party to an employee where the employer merely knows that the third party intends to provide the benefit to the employee but does not prevent the employee from accepting the benefit.

(iii) Under the amendments proposed by the government, FBT would not automatically be payable simply because an employer and an employee both attend a lunch provided by a client. FBT would be payable only if there was an agreement or similar arrangement between the employer and the third party or the employer participated in or facilitated the provision of the lunch.

(iv) When an employee attends a lunch provided by a client of the employee's employer, FBT will be payable by the employer in the following circumstances: where the employee's lunch is provided under an agreement or similar arrangement between the employer and the client; or where the employer knowingly participated in or facilitated the provision of the lunch by the client. FBT would not be payable in any other circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: This refers to the Auditor‐General's Audit Report No. 13 about the Third Tranche Sale of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia tabled on 17 November 1997.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator O'Brien asked me a fascinating question about the incorporation of transfers in ownership of non‐produced, non‐financial assets in balance of payments data. I have an answer to that. You will find it absolutely riveting. I table the answer and seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
SENATOR O'BRIEN QUESTION ON BALANCE OF PAYMENT DEFINITION
Senator O'Brien asked me a question yesterday about the incorporation of transfers in ownership of non‐produced, non‐financial assets in balance of payments data.
I seek leave to table a response to the question.
QUESTION

Can you explain how the new international standard soon to be used by the ABS to report current account data will operate? How does the new balance of payments standards incorporate transfers in ownership of non‐produced non‐financial assets? How are such transfers valued?
RESPONSE

The ABS has revised its estimates of the balance of payments in line with new standards set by the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The reclassification will bring Australia's measurement of the balance of payments into line with estimates already published by the IMF for its member countries.

Under the new standards, the capital account now includes entries for the acquisition (less disposal) of non‐produced non‐financial assets. Previously, such transactions were recorded as investment flows. The change in classification will not impact on the size of the capital account balance.
Non‐produced non‐financial assets is a category that includes embassy land and a number of intangible assets such as patents, copyrights, trademarks, and franchises.

The transfer of non‐produced non‐financial assets is valued at transaction prices. The ABS obtains information on the transfer of embassy land from ledger data, while information on the transfer of intangible assets is obtained from a survey of international trade in services.
In 1996‐97, the net value of such transfers was $28 million.

On Monday, 24 November 1997 (Hansard page 9014) Senator Brown asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister about the Remuneration Tribunal's response to the Prime Minister's request for recommendations for a new method of paying travelling allowances for members of Parliament. Senator Brown also asked about a regulation to establish an entitlement to magnetised calendars.
The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .
The Remuneration Tribunal Report which was requested by the Prime Minister is being examined.

Before a Determination is made by the Remuneration Tribunal, as is the normal course, Senators and Members will have the opportunity to review the Tribunal's report and write to the Tribunal on issues they wish to have considered.

In relation to magnetised calendars, the Parliamentary Entitlements Regulations (the Regulations) to which Senator Brown referred are made under paragraph 5(1)(b) of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act 1990. The Regulations commenced operation on 17 November 1997. Regulation 3 of the Regulations establishes the entitlement of Senators and Members to personalised letterhead stationery, newsletters for distribution to constituents and other printed material as approved by the minister for distribution to constituents. The regulations provide an entitlement to services which Senators or Members have received in recent years under varying interpretations of the previous personalised letterhead stationery entitlement. The regulations also provide a mechanism for ministerial approval of any future decisions to provide additional classes of printed material to Senators and Members.

The Government is discussing possible changes in the administration of the entitlement with the presiding officers. In the meantime, the regulations to which Senator Brown refers have been introduced as a means of standardising the application of the entitlement and ensuring that all services provided have a certain legal base.

On 19 November 1997, Senator Minchin approved magnetised calendars and emergency and community information cards for distribution to constituents as benefits to which Senators and Members are entitled (in accordance with paragraph 3(1)(c of the Regulations). That is, magnetised calendars and emergency and community cards have been approved as `other printed material' which Senators and Members are entitled to distribute to constituents.

—This is a bit like Menzies' `reds under the beds' stuff.

—What a load of nonsense. You ought to run away for a little while. The mediation process is occurring right now. If you or anyone else had attended the public meetings which were held at Mount Barker, just north of Albany, or at Jerramungup, where people were advised that they had to meet to respond to these particu lar applications, you would understand the importance of this particular aspect of the act.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot let go past the comments that Senator Murray made today in his contribution. Let me give a few figures on the current mining situation in Western Australia. There is a backlog of over 7,000 mining titles with 1,900 titles caught in the right to negotiate process. Since March 1995 only 158 leases have been granted as a result of the right to negotiate, but every week a further 14 leases enter into this process.

Does that not make it totally and absolutely clear that there needs to be certainty for mining. If ever there was a case of going backwards at a rapid rate, this is it. That is why so many of our companies are being forced to go offshore to keep their operations going. I put it to those opposite that they have a responsibility to ensure that certainty is brought into this particular aspect by the validation of titles for exclusive possession.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have just heard is a real example of how fear can be spread within the community. Yes, there are native title claims in the south‐west of Western Australia. I know of several native title claims in the south‐west of Western Australian because, funnily enough, indigenous people did live in and have links with the south west of Western Australia in a cultural and religious sense. However, having a native title claim over your property does not force anybody to have to defend their title.
—Not true.
—Senator Crane says, `Not true,' and then walks out.
—Well, I will come back.
—Order! Senator Crane, it is unruly to interject and it is even more unruly to be out of your place when you interject.
—But what she said is not true.
—Order! Senator Crane!

—It is the case that there are native title claims in the south‐west of Western Australia. It is not the case that that forces freehold land‐holders to legally defend their title. As I have stated previously, the government, in particular Senator Minchin, have displayed a level of unprecedented arrogance and paternalism in the debate about the Wik decision and the government's response to it. It is a fundamentally important issue which renders that arrogance even more reprehensible.

SPEECH.PARA: I realise this is a sore spot for the coalition at the moment because the public are beginning to find out. We heard today that Senator Minchin believes he knows better than the High Court. He knows better than seven High Court judges in Mabo and seven High Court judges in Wik. Those judges clearly stated that freehold land extinguished native title. That was not good enough for Senator Minchin and obviously was not good enough for Senator Crane. Instead, they think there is more political mileage to be made out of whipping up fear and mistrust in the community.

The whole debate has been categorised by an ability on the part of this government to recognise the distinct and unique relationship that Aboriginal people have with the land. It has been painted as akin to some sort of foreign invasion to be repelled with all the powers of the state. It has been characterised by a government that views native title purely as an inconvenient property right, to be read down in line with the narrowest possible interpretation of the common law. There is one word for a policy approach that seeks to absorb Aboriginal cultural imperatives: assimilation.

Assimilation is really a euphemism for cultural genocide. It is a policy approach which harks back to the dark, shameful days in Australia's history where the answer to the so-called Aboriginal problem was to blend indigenous people and culture into European based society. When this government diminishes and extinguishes the special property rights of Aboriginal people, it diminishes and extinguishes Aboriginal culture and, in my opinion, it diminishes itself as a country.

When the government said that they have to read down native title rights to extinguish any possibility of native title surviving in any way except in the narrowest possible form because they did not want Aboriginal people to have any greater or even different property rights than the people who have stolen their country, they dangerously echo the sentiments of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson).

There is fear within the community in 1997 for many reasons. People are fearful of their economic future and of all the changes that are occurring in the workplace. For instance, there have been many changes in the Public Service and to the means by which people survive. Instead of having a debate about those fears and the role that the government has played, the government is linking those fears with the prejudices that exist within society. That is worse than racism. It is worse than racism because, when you prey on fears and prejudices in order to achieve your own political ends, it is simply not acceptable. Anything that comes out of that must be blamed on those people who enraged those fears and who increased them for their own benefits.

There are political motives here. There are motives within various industries as to this being a good time and a good excuse to get other agendas up. These motives must be exposed. Any motives that the government has in riding on the disgraceful coat-tails of scapegoat politics should also be exposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the allegation being made against the government? The allegation made against the government is that the government is scaremongering. That is the same allegation that was made by Labor senators before the last election and before the Wik case, when people on this side of the chamber said they were concerned about the safety of pastoral leases.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will be aware that in the judgment in Mabo No. 2 the High Court said in obiter—not in the judgment, but in obiter—that a leasehold interest extinguished native title. But the High Court changed its mind and the High Court has not given a definitive judgment that says that a freehold interest extinguishes native title. They have said it in obiter, but they have not said it in a judgment.

So is it unreasonable for Senator Minchin to say that freehold land can be subject to native title claim? No, it is not, because, even if you are of the belief that freehold title extinguishes native title claims, there is nothing at the moment that stops people making a claim against freehold land.
Senator Murphy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —In one of his more erudite interjections, Senator Murphy says that I am making a fool of myself. There is only one person I am going to make a fool of, Senator Murphy, and that is you. Let me expose to you the fact that I know people in western Queensland who have freehold farming properties and they have had native title claims lodged over those properties.
—So what? That doesn't mean anything.

—Senator Murphy says, `So what?' Those people have to defend those claims. They have to go to the legal expense of defending those claims. I was of the belief that they did not have to. I shared Senator Margetts's viewpoint. I did not think they had to either, so I wrote to the Native Title Tribunal. I rang them up as well and said, `Look, there are claims over freehold property outside Roma. It is my understanding that these claims should not be made. You, the Native Title Tribunal, have accepted these claims for determination. I want you to strike them out.' I got a letter back from the Native Title Tribunal saying, `Look, we do not believe that native title survives the grant of freehold,' but they did not strike out the claim. Those people still have claims against them.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators should remember one other fact. There has been on the mainland of Australia only one successful determination of the native title and that was at Crescent Head. What happened at Crescent Head was that it was a claim against land which was the subject of freehold title, because the claimant said that the crown did not have the right to issue the freehold title. There have been claims against freehold land and Crescent Head was one of them.

BREAK.PARA: What we are saying is that there are other pieces of freehold land that are subject to native title claim, not just in Queensland, but also in Western Australia. I know that there are claims in relation to Western Australia. Mr Tuckey in the other place has spoken about them at length, as have Senator Lightfoot and Senator Eggleston. These claims are on foot.

If honourable senators on the other side genuinely believe that freehold title extinguishes native title, then they will not have any problem voting for the bill that the government has put forward. They will not have any problem voting for the provision that says, `Right. Let's end the division here and now. Let us end this division now and pass a provision in this bill that says that freehold title extinguishes native title.' If that is what you believe, then vote with your belief, vote with your conscience and vote for that provision of the bill.

But if you do not vote for that provision of the bill, it is perfectly reasonable and just for those of us who sit here to ask why. Why is it that honourable senators will tell the community that freehold title has extinguished native title but will not vote for it? Why is it that they will not vote according to what they believe? Either their beliefs are weak or maybe there is another agenda. Maybe in fact they support an agenda that says that native title in certain circumstances could coexist with a freehold title. That is the only possible reason.

If honourable senators on the other side want to end the division, the fear and the suspicion, then they will vote for this provision of the bill because it does no harm. If they honestly believe that, then this provision of the bill takes nothing away from anybody. But, if they believe there is another motive, if they believe there is another agenda and if they have another agenda themselves, then they will vote against this.

I say to honourable senators, you will be judged on the way you vote. The people of Australia will judge you and, if you say one thing and vote another way, you will be judged and you will be found out. The Democrats, the Greens and the Labor Party will be put in judgment. They will be held up for scrutiny and, if they say these things and yet refuse to put them into legislation, one can only assume that they do not have their heart in it. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.
We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:
Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:

PARA.TAB: a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

PETITION.PARA: Precedents which support our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production; irradiated foods (here and internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt‐reduced; free‐range; vitamin‐enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian Government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Native Title
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned requests that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of this country are treated justly and fairly. It is in the interest of all to build this nation in a spirit of reconciliation and cooperation with Australians of diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds.

We call on you to ensure that regional agreements with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples are pursued in good faith, so as to determine their rights to their land in a spirit of reconciliation.

The co‐existence of Native Title and Pastoral Leases on Crown Land is supported by legal principle and historic fact, upheld by the High Court. The people and Governments of Australia have a moral responsibility to give this fact real and just effect.
We call on members of the Senate to ensure that legislation regarding Native Title
(i) complies with internationally recognised principles of non‐discrimination; and
(ii) promotes Reconciliation with Australia's first peoples.

PETITION.TITLE: Native Title
PETITION.PARA: To Honourable Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we support the co‐existence of Native Title and Pastoral Leases, as upheld in the recent Wik judgment of the High Court, and believe that further restriction of Aboriginal people's access to their traditional lands will seriously diminish our nation.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should call on the Federal Government to:
1. Endorse publicly and unequivocally the High Court's Native Title decisions as just and correct decisions;
2. To resist any watering down of the rights of Indigenous Australians under the Racial Discrimination Act, and
3. To endorse negotiation as the process which will make co‐existence workable for all parties.

PETITION.TITLE: Dr James Tankey
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We, the undersigned, hereby petition you on behalf of the government of the Commonwealth of Australia, to set aside the determination made by the Professional Service Review Tribunal constituted under the Health Insurance Act against Dr James Adrian Tankey on the basis that we consider the determination to be unjust and not a true reflection on Dr Tankey.

In particular, we consider that the determination by the Tribunal in disqualifying Dr Tankey under the terms of the Health Insurance Act is contrary to our right to be treated by the doctor of our choice.

We also consider Dr Tankey to be an honest and hard‐working general practitioner who works in the best interests of his patients and we are fully satisfied with the level of service he provides to us.
Your petitioners ask, that the Senate set aside the determination made against Dr James Adrian Tankey, until a fair and equitable review process has occurred.

We request that a Senate inquiry be established to investigate the unjust practices of the Professional Service Review Tribunal. They denied a fair and equitable investigation including all stakeholders and deny an appropriate peer review.
The tribunals decisions denies all Australians their constitutional right to choose their Medical Practitioner.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Exemption Order made under s.8G of the Christmas Island Act 1958

BREAK.PARA: The Exemption Order exempts two companies from the need to comply with the operations of the Travel Agents Act 1985 (WA) as it applies to Christmas Island..

The Explanatory Statement does not indicate whether these are the only agents operating on the Island and, if this is not the case, whether other agents have been arbitrarily excluded from this scheme.
Clause (2) does not appear to serve any practical purpose as the Order must necessarily have effect until revoked and does not need the clause to say so.

Clause (3) provides that the Minister not unreasonably withhold consent to the approval of an insurance policy. In such instances, the Minister should be under an obligation not unreasonably to withhold consent. The Explanatory Statement also does not advise whether the Minister's discretion to withhold consent is subject to merits review.

The requirement in Clause (3) for the applicants to deliver the policy to the Minister could cause difficulty if an applicant subsequently wished to claim on a policy. In such circumstances delivery of a copy of the policy would appear to be sufficient.

The Explanatory Statement advises that this Order is a temporary measure only but does not indicate how long this Order will be needed. The Explanatory Statement also notes that the Order must be laid before each House of the Federal Parliament but that it need be gazetted only in the Territory Gazette . It may also be appropriate to gazette such Orders in the Commonwealth Gazette.
The Committee has written to the Minister for advice.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Locally Engaged Staff Determination 1997/31 made under s.. of the Public Service Act 1922

BREAK.PARA: The Determination provides for various aspects of medical insurance for locally engaged staff in Kenya.

New subclause 5.32.11(4) appears to limit to six the number of children a locally engaged employee may enrol in the group medical assistance scheme referred to in that clause. This would appear to discriminate improperly against those locally engaged staff who have a large family. The Committee has written to the Minister for advice.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Public Interest Determination No 7 made under Part VI of the Privacy Act 1988

BREAK.PARA: The Public Interest Determination permits the disclosure by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade of personal information about Austral ians overseas to their next of kin in certain limited circumstances.

Subclauses 2(2) and (3) would appear to be subject to a wholly uncertain condition as there is no indication of the time within which either the guidelines referred to in subclause 2(2) are to be developed, or the reasonable steps referred to in subclause 2(3) are to be taken. There also appears to be no warrant for the Privacy Commissioner to impose the further condition that the guidelines referred to in subclause 2(2) must be made with her approval. This condition also renders the whole subclause uncertain. The Committee has written to the Minister for advice.

SPEECH.PARA: 8 October 1997
The Hon Peter Reith MP
Minister for Workplace Relations and
Small Business
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Directions relating to the waiver of debts due to Comcare No.4 of 1997 made under s.114D(3)(b) of the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 .

The Committee was concerned at the advice in the Explanatory Statement that the discretion to waive debts will continue to be administered by the Chief Executive Officer in accordance with existing policy and procedures. The Committee accepts that if the previous Direction was invalid then changes need to be made. However, the Committee would welcome your advice that a fresh valid Direction will be made as soon as possible. The Act provides for an instrument to be made and it may be a breach of parliamentary propriety if this provision of the Act was disregarded.
Yours sincerely

24 November 1997
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee

Thank you for your letter of 8 October 1997 about instrument No. 4 of 1997 made under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (the SRC Act), "Directions relating to the waiver of debts due to Comcare", made under s114D(3)(b) of that Act.

By that instrument I revoked the direction that was given under s114D(3)(a) of the SRC Act in 1993. There is now no direction in force under s114D. You suggest that it may be a breach of parliamentary propriety if section 114D were "disregarded", and you therefore invite my advice that the revoked direction will be replaced by a fresh valid direction as soon as possible.

The Australian Government Solicitor (AGS) has advised that revoking a direction, and not then replacing it with a new direction, does not amount to "disregarding" section 114D. This is because the SRC Act does not require that a direction under section 114D be given, nor that a revoked declaration be replaced by a new direction. The AGS further advises that section-114D gives the Minister a discretion to choose to give a direction, but shows no Parliamentary intention or expectation that the Minister should decide to exercise this power. Accordingly, the AGS can see no basis on which revoking a direction under section 114D, and not then replacing it with a new direction, could be considered a breach of parliamentary propriety.

In deciding to revoke the earlier direction, I took into account legal advice that it would be prudent to take this course because the validity of that earlier direction was questionable. This legal advice about the earlier direction was not based on any defect in the drafting of that instrument that could be remedied in any replacement instrument. Instead, the legal difficulty is caused by the interpretation of the statutory power that was relied on in giving that direction. Any replacement direction that tried to impose on Comcare the policy reflected in the earlier direction would face the same legal difficulty.

Your letter explains that the Committee was concerned at the advice in the Explanatory Statement that the discretion to waive debts will continue to be administered by the Chief Executive Officer in accordance with existing policy and practice. This was not intended to imply that the existing policy would continue to be legally binding on Comcare; this advice in the Explanatory Statement was simply to inform the Committee of Comcare's intended practice in exercising (free of Ministerial direction) its statutory discretion.

I understand that the Senate has been given notice (on behalf of the Committee) of intention to move disallowance of the instrument that revokes the earlier direction. Disallowance of that instrument would revive the revoked direction. I suggest to you that this would have the undesirable consequence of creating uncertainty about the legal basis of decisions that Comcare makes under section 114D. As noted above, the legal advice I received was that it would be prudent to revoke the earlier direction.

The decision to revoke the earlier direction, and not accompany that revocation with a new direction, reflects the Government's decision to choose (for the time being) not to exercise its statutory power to direct Comcare about waiving debts. If further experience were to suggest that a new direction would be appropriate, the Government might decide to either give a direction consistent with the current statutory power or to ask the Parliament to broaden that statutory power. But I trust the Committee will accept that neither possibility provides any reason to revive the earlier, legally doubtful, direction.
Thank you for giving me the opportunity to respond to the Committee's concerns.
Yours Sincerely
PETER REITH
