JUDICIARY AMENDMENT BILL 1997

This bill will amend the Judiciary Act 1903 to establish the Australian Government Solicitor (AGS) as a statutory authority, separate from the Attorney-General's Department, so as to enhance its position as the government's legal firm in providing quality legal services to the Commonwealth and Commonwealth bodies.

It will also provide a framework for greater contestability in the delivery of legal services to the Commonwealth, in particular, to enable private law firms to compete for the first time for significant areas of Commonwealth litigation.

The Coalition's Law and Justice Policy for the last election included a commitment to undertake a review of legal services provided by the Attorney-General's Legal Practice, including an examination of the possibilities for government Departments and agencies to use private legal firms for litigation.
To fulfil that commitment, in November 1996 the Attorney-General commissioned a review of the Commonwealth's legal services needs and how those needs could best be met.
The review committee, which comprised an experienced businessman, a prominent barrister and the then Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department, undertook an extensive review of these issues.

The committee consulted with Departments and agencies about their legal services needs, as well as holding discussions with the Legal Practice, departmental legal units and private-sector lawyers about the delivery of legal services to government.
It also commissioned a survey of the Legal Practice's clients and a detailed business analysis of the Legal Practice, and invited public submissions on the issues being examined.
The committee's report (the Report of the Review of the Attorney-General's Legal Practice ) was delivered in March 1997 and made 16 recommendations for reform of the Legal Practice.

The committee found that the Legal Practice had made considerable improvements over recent years in its efficiency and the quality of its services (reflected in the generally positive responses to the client survey). However, significant further improvement was possible and desirable, particularly if the government solicitor were to continue to provide high-quality, cost-effective legal services in an increasingly competitive environment.
One of the fundamental questions examined by the committee was whether the retention of a government-owned Legal Practice was justified.
The committee found that maintaining government ownership of the Legal Practice was in the public interest.

The reasons for this included the ability of the Legal Practice to meet the legal services needs of the Commonwealth (which could be put at risk if the Legal Practice were sold), its abilities to meet the legal services needs of Departments and agencies because of its particular focus on government work, its ability to maintain a `whole of government' approach, its strong corporate memory, and the need for a government legal service provider to meet the unique role and needs of the Attorney-General in providing legal services which are core to government.
Accordingly, the report recommended retention of the Legal Practice as a government authority, albeit with greater contestability.

The Government considered all options, including the possible sale of the commercial parts of the Legal Practice, but has firmly concluded for the reasons outlined by the committee that they should be retained within government ownership.
However, the Government also considers that, without further reform, the AGS will face a serious risk of not being competitive in the market place.
This is principally because of the current limits on the AGS's business structure and operations, by virtue of its status as part of the Attorney-General's Department.
These limitations are not shared by the private law firms with which the AGS is increasingly being asked to compete.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Establishment of the Australian Government Solicitor

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has therefore accepted the thrust of the committee's recommendations, and in particular has decided to restructure the AGS as a new legal services provider.
The bill will implement this decision by amending the Judiciary Act 1903 to establish the AGS as a new statutory body.
The AGS will be structured in a way that maximises its ability to provide legal services and conduct its business operations, on a commercial, competitive basis.
Its separation from the Attorney-General's Department will facilitate its operation as a government business enterprise.

Consistent with the usual approach for government business enterprises (and the position enjoyed by private law firms), it will also be able to employ staff and consultants outside the usual public service regime.
Further, it will be able to charge fees at market rates in relation to the legal services it provides.
The AGS will not be established under the Corporations Law, but will be set up as a government-owned statutory authority, headed by a CEO, rather than a board of directors.
The CEO will be responsible for the management of the AGS and will otherwise have responsibilities similar to the boards of other government business enterprises.
The AGS will be able to provide legal and related services to a range of government Departments, agencies and officers, including to State and Territory bodies if they request it to do so.

Constitutional limits mean that, unlike private law firms, the AGS's potential client base is largely limited to the Commonwealth government and its agencies and a small range of persons who are acting for the Commonwealth.
The bill makes it clear that the AGS will be able to provide advice to the full range of clients within the constitutional limits.
This more focused client base will enable the AGS to deliver a unified, specialised and nationally-coordinated approach to government legal services.
The AGS is not, and cannot be, the same as privately owned law firms.
Its unique value to government is based on its government ownership and its expertise in delivering legal services to government clients.

In line with this role, some limited core areas of government legal work, primarily Cabinet, constitutional and national security matters, will be reserved to the AGS, and not be available to private law firms.

The public interest served by having the AGS undertake this role is not inconsistent with having the AGS operate at the highest level of efficiency and making a profit as a government business enterprise.
As a government business enterprise, the AGS will have, in effect, the Attorney-General and the Minister for Finance and Administration as `joint shareholders'.
Consistent with this approach, the bill gives joint responsibility to the Attorney-General and Minister for Finance and Administration for the business operations of the AGS.
This will not interfere with the legal professional functions of the AGS, nor the Attorney-General's responsibilities as First Law Officer in relation to these functions.
The Government is committed to ensuring that, as far as possible, government-owned businesses are placed in the same position as the privately-owned businesses with which they compete.
In most areas of work, Departments and agencies will be able to use private law firms to carry out their legal work.
In particular, litigation other than that in the reserved categories will be contestable.
This opening up of most categories of litigation completes the process of providing choice to government clients that was commenced in 1995.
Prior to the proposed commencement on 1 July 1998 of the new system, approval for untying of litigation will be possible on an ad hoc administrative basis.

The bill contains several measures to ensure that, consistent with the Government's Competitive Neutrality Policy Statement, the AGS will not enjoy any competitive advantage over private law firms by virtue of its government ownership.

Thus, the bill will establish a mechanism to require the AGS to pay to the Commonwealth, in respect of each financial year, an amount equivalent to the total amount of any taxation liability that would have been incurred by it under Commonwealth, State and Territory laws if it were a firm of legal practitioners.

While the AGS will not be subject to State and Territory taxation laws unless they are specially prescribed, requiring the AGS to make a tax equivalent payment will ensure that it enjoys no net competitive taxation advantage over private law firms.

Further, the Attorney-General will be empowered, together with the Minister for Finance and Administration and after consultation with the CEO of the AGS, to determine corporate governance arrangements for the AGS.

The corporate governance arrangements will enable the AGS to be required to make other payments where this is necessary to achieve competitive neutrality in respect of costs incurred by private law firms.
As with other government business enterprises, the AGS will be required to pay to the Commonwealth a dividend, analogous to the return of profits to the partners in a law firm.

Most importantly, the power to determine corporate governance arrangements will enable the arrangements that apply to the AGS to take into account the particular structure of the AGS and its function of providing legal services to government.
In addition, the AGS will be subject to the reporting, accountability and financial requirements of the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997.
The bill also gives the Attorney-General power to issue Legal Services Directions, relating to Commonwealth legal work.

These Directions will be capable of applying to Departments and agencies in receipt of legal services and to their legal services providers, including the AGS, private legal firms and `in-house' legal units.

The Directions will provide a framework for the conduct of the Commonwealth's legal affairs, but will leave prime responsibility for the effective and efficient use of legal services with Departments and agencies.

Directions will be able to be made on the full range of issues affecting Commonwealth legal work, including what work is to be contestable, reporting arrangements in relation to legal work, and compliance by legal service providers with the obligation of the Commonwealth to act as a model litigant.

This power to issue Directions will ensure that the Attorney-General, will be in a position to manage risks that could arise from the provision of legal services that are inconsistent, that lack coordination, or that do not identify and appropriately deal with whole of government and public interest issues.

This is necessary in an environment where an increased range of government legal work will be contestable by private sector firms, which are providing a significant proportion of overall legal services.

However, the Attorney-General is determined to ensure that minimum restrictions are imposed on the way legal services are provided to Departments and agencies, consistent with the aim of ensuring that Departments and agencies should be fully and directly accountable for their decisions in relation to legal services.

In line with the recommendations of the report on the Legal Practice, the Government approved the establishment within the Attorney-General's Department of the Office of Legal Services Coordination to assist the Attorney-General in discharging his First Law Officer role, especially in relation to litigation.

The Office is now operational and will assist the Attorney-General in the preparation of Legal Services Directions and in consulting with Departments and agencies, as well as the private profession, about their content.
It will also advise on Commonwealth litigation policy, both in general and in relation to particular cases.

It will have an important role to play in advising Departments and agencies on their obligations under the Legal Services Directions and on the purchase and delivery of legal services, so as to achieve maximum efficiency and appropriate risk management.

The power to issue Directions is designed to enable the Attorney-General of the day to fulfil his or her First Law Officer functions in relation to the provision of legal services to the Commonwealth.

Compliance with Directions will therefore not be enforceable other than by the Attorney-General, and only the Commonwealth will be able to raise the issue of non-compliance with Directions in any legal proceedings.

The reforms introduced by the bill will give the AGS the structure and flexibility in its business activities and legal services work to enable it to continue to provide high-quality legal services to government in an increasingly competitive market.

While public interest considerations require that a small number of core subject-matters be tied exclusively to government legal providers, for most matters Departments and agencies will be able to choose where they obtain their legal services.
The bill's reforms will ensure that the AGS is well-placed to compete for this work.
COPYRIGHT AMENDMENT BILL 1997 (No.2)
This bill is a further demonstration of this Government's commitment to copyright reform.
And it is a demonstration of this Government's ability to deliver on our reforms.
This bill is a measured, fair and practical response to the problem of unduly high prices for music sound recordings in this country.
At present, the provisions of the Copyright Act can be used by the owners of copyright in sound recordings to stop anyone else importing copies of their sound recordings.
In this way the act can be used to control the Australian market for imported copies of recordings.
This is significant as imported recordings constitute the overwhelming percentage of recordings marketed in Australia.
The bill will exempt the importation of non-pirate copies of a sound recording from infringement of copyright in either the sound recording or in the works recorded on the recording.
It will thereby remove the ability of copyright owners to control the market for each imported copy of a sound recording.

Concerns have long been held that the importation provisions of the Copyright Act have been used to obtain higher prices for records and CDs than those prevailing in some other countries, notably, the USA.
The concerns were raised in an inquiry by the Copyright Law Review Committee, on which it reported in 1988.
This was followed by an inquiry into the prices of sound recordings by the then Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) in 1990.

The PSA found that prices of sound recordings were unreasonably high in Australia and recommended either partial or full removal of copyright control over importation of legitimate copies, thereby introducing direct competition as a mechanism for reducing prices.
Unlike the Labor Government which lacked the resolve to implement the PSA Report, changing its mind repeatedly over 4 years, we have acted decisively on those recommendations.
But we have not done so precipitantly—or without regard to possible changes in the market and market behaviour since 1990.
In our election commitments we stated that we would consult industry and the community on the most effective means of lowering prices for music CDs, and we have done so.
Views were sought from a wide cross-section of the Australian music and copyright industries, including representatives of performers, record producers and music publishers, and from consumers.

Our decision to follow, in essence, the recommendation of the PSA reflects this Government's conclusion that insufficient effort had been made by the recording industry to embrace competition and provide world-competitive pricing.
While the estimates of the amount of the reduction vary, all the economic advice obtained suggests that allowing importation of legitimate CDs will lead to a reduction in prices.
It also has the potential to expand availability of overseas recordings in response to consumer demand, and will give retailers freedom of choice in sourcing supplies.
If expected price reductions lead to increased sales, artists receiving royalty income from sales may well achieve a net gain.
Of course, we are aware of the industry arguments that allowing importation will reduce returns and allow greater potential for importation of pirate copies of sound recordings into Australia.
The bill responds fully to those concerns, so far as they are justified, in the following way:
. It maintains all existing copyright owners' rights to take action against pirate copies of sound recordings.

. It limits permitted imports to legitimate copies, that is, copies of sound recordings made in conformity with the copyright law where they were made and with the consent of the maker of the original recording.

. It gives very substantial procedural assistance to sound recording copyright owners in civil actions by shifting to the defendant the onus of establishing that a copy that was imported without the copyright owner's consent is not a pirate copy.
. And it increases and simplifies the penalties for all primary copyright piracy offences in the act.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Importation of legitimate copies of sound recordings

SPEECH.PARA: The bill largely achieves its effect through excluding what are defined as "non-infringing copies" of sound recordings from the rights to take action for unauthorised importation.
The crucial provision is therefore the definition of "non-infringing copy".
Such a copy must have been made without infringing any law in the country where it was made protecting copyright in any musical or other work used in the sound recording.
In addition, it must have been made with the consent of the producer of the original sound recording or other person who is the copyright owner.
If the country where the copy was made does not protect sound recordings then the law of the country where the original recording was made comes into play.
The definition of "non-infringing copy" is explained in greater detail in the explanatory memorandum.

It is important to note that the definition is designed to ensure that the copies allowed to be imported will be legitimate copies only, while avoiding prejudice to Australia's general trade relations and obligations.
As has been mentioned, the bill will also boost and simplify the primary penalty provisions in the act.
We are committed to a copyright system that works.

The bill proposes to amend the act to provide that all primary infringement offences—not just those for infringement of copyright in sound recordings—will be subject to fines of up to $55,000 for individuals and $275,000 for corporations.
This is a 10 per cent increase over existing maximum penalties.

The maximum term of 5 years imprisonment that may currently be imposed as an alternative, or in addition, to a fine for some copyright offences by individuals will apply across all the primary infringement offences.
The language and form of these penalty provisions will also be adjusted to reflect current usage for imposition of penalties.
The act presently limits the discretion of the courts by restricting the maximum penalty for each infringing article, such as a book or a software disk.
However, the value of the copyright carried on the disk or in the book may vary considerably.
The amendments will remove maximum penalties for each infringing copy.
The maximum will apply whether there is one or many infringing copies.
The current distinction between the maximum penalty for a first offence and that for a subsequent offence is also removed for these offences.

And last, the setting of maximum penalties for infringements related to films at different levels to those for infringements for other copyright subject matter is no longer justifiable or necessary, and is also done away with.

These changes, while primarily aimed at modernising these penalty provisions, also send a clear message to the courts, as well as would-be offenders, that copyright piracy offences are serious matters.

The new approach provided for in the bill will emphasise to the courts the importance of their giving due weight to the gravity of the offences before them—having regard to the possible maximum penalties.
The increase in maximum penalties will extend to offences against performers' rights, such as making "bootleg" recordings—that is, recordings of performances not authorised by the performers.

This will act as a deterrent to those who might consider the removal of rights over parallel importation to offer a greater opportunity for commercial importation of copies of bootleg recordings, if not pirate copies of authorised recordings.

To underline further the Government's commitment to effective enforcement of copyright, the bill includes a new provision to facilitate civil actions for infringement by importation of pirate copies of recordings.

In such cases, once the plaintiff has established that the copy was imported without the copyright owner's consent, it will be up to the defendant to show, to the civil standard of proof, that the copy was made without infringing copyright in the country where it was made.
This will provide strong incentive to importers taking advantage of the new opportunity to import CDs to obtain their supplies from reputable sources.
This bill is an important measure that should be supported by all members who are interested in fair competition and a better deal for Australian consumers.
The measures to boost and simplify the penalties and enforcement procedures are substantive and wide-reaching.
The bill demonstrates our commitment to an effective and practical act that looks after the legitimate interests of copyright owners while also delivering benefits to Australian consumers.
CIVIL AVIATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

The purpose of this bill is to amend the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959, the Civil Aviation Act 1988, and other aviation‐related legislation. The amendments to the Carriers' Liability Act and the Civil Aviation Act mainly relate to the Commonwealth's initiative in introducing a national scheme requiring air carriers to carry mandatory non‐voidable passenger liability insurance.

This requirement means that, in the event of an air accident, passengers, or their relatives, are assured as far as possible of receiving compensation to the amount of $500,000 per passenger for their death or injury. The Commonwealth requirements are reflected in complementary state legislation, so that a mandatory passenger liability insurance scheme will operate nationally to cover all commercial flights in Australia. Uniform application of state legislation will not come into effect until these Commonwealth amendments are enacted.

The principal amendments proposed to the two acts are of a minor nature and are intended to make the administration of the national scheme simpler, and thereby ensure the full and effective implementation of the Commonwealth's initiative.

The amendments to the Carriers' Liability Act will authorise the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) to directly administer both the Commonwealth Carriers' Liability Act and the complementary state legislation, rather than under delegation from the Commonwealth and state ministers responsible for transport. This will clarify the position on state/Commonwealth delegation of powers, and powers of enforcement.

In addition, to assist CASA further with the enforcement of the national requirements, offences under the state acts must be regarded as Commonwealth offences. To this end, the Carriers' Liability Act will also be amended to enable Commonwealth authorities to investigate and prosecute offences under the State acts as if they were Commonwealth offences.
A further minor amendment to the Carriers' Liability Act will allow Australian governments to self‐insure their risks under the act, instead of requiring them to take out commercial insurance.

At this stage, Commonwealth and State government agencies are required to insure any passengers that they occasionally carry for reward, in accordance with the Carriers' Liability Act requirements. However, it is not the practice of Australian governments to carry commercial insurance. The bill therefore provides that, where both carrier and insurer are the Crown, the carrier need not have a stipulated contract of insurance to satisfy the technical requirements of the act, but must still satisfy CASA that the arrangements it puts in place for coverage of passengers satisfies those requirements of the act.

The amendments to the Carriers' Liability Act and the Civil Aviation Act will also impose conditions upon Air Operator's Certificates (AOCs) which will require that operators continuously hold the mandatory passenger liability insurance required by the Carriers' Liability Act. Therefore, these amendments will give CASA the authority under legislation to more effectively prevent an operator carrying passengers without the mandatory insurance. CASA will be empowered to cancel, suspend or vary an AOC where an operator allows that insurance to lapse, but continues to carry passengers.

The bill also makes a number of minor corrections to other aviation‐related legislation. The corrections, of a formal or typographical nature, in the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Act 1995 have retrospective effect, in order to ensure that they have effect from the original date of commencement of the provisions being corrected. The retrospective repeal of certain amendments in the Civil Aviation Act 1988 is purely to remove them as they are no longer necessary. The corrections and the repeal have no effect on the rights, duties and obligations of any person.

The principal amendments in this bill will ensure effective protection of an aviation consumer's entitlement to adequate compensation in the event of an air accident, anywhere in Australia. This will fully implement the original intention of the Commonwealth's initiative, in reforming this aspect of consumer protection in the aviation sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier, I was concluding my speech on how the uncertainty of this legislation, in its current form, is affecting regional Australia, particularly regional New South Wales where the western division leases have not been included in schedule 4 because Premier Carr was not prepared to say that they were leases that conferred exclusive tenure.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many projects that are being held up—about 40 projects—and some of them are worth millions of dollars. There is one at Cobar—the emu abattoir—which will provide 100 jobs. Senator West has been around that part of the world for the Labor Party saying that she supports the abattoir. The best thing she could do to make sure that that abattoir is built is to vote for this legislation. That will provide the certainty to get these sorts of projects off the ground. It would be nice to see her vote with her feet on this occasion.

Another important project that is being held up is the gas pipeline that is going from Moomba to Sydney. It has a spur that is going up to Forbes and Dubbo and further north up to Tamworth. This has been held up by recent native title claims demanding millions of dollars before they will withdraw their claims. That is a very large project that is very important to the people of regional New South Wales. It is being held up because of the erroneous nature of the previous and existing legislation.

Native title is simply killing regional New South Wales. The ALP, including Independent Mr Andren, who represents the seat of Calare, who voted with the Labor Party against the native title legislation in the House of Representatives, is standing between the present messy and unacceptable situation and the progress and jobs that will be provided by a more realistic and appropriate response to the legitimate Aboriginal claims for native title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —While people may disagree about the details of this legislation, there is absolutely no doubt that the Native Title Act needs amending. The previous government agreed with the Attorney-General's advice in 1995 that amendments to the bill were necessary, particularly after the High Court's Brandy decision. Aboriginal representative groups agree, including ATSIC and the working party, and so does Justice Robert French of the National Native Title Tribunal. An undertaking to amend the bill was part of our policy platform leading up to the election, so there was never any doubt about where this government stood on the Native Title Act in its present form.

SPEECH.PARA: South Australians are acutely aware of the problems created by the current native title legislation. We have 27 claims with the Native Title Tribunal and more are expected. Many of them claim exclusive possession and overlap claims for exclusive possession by other Aboriginal groups—perhaps a lesson may be needed in coexistence.

These claims cover almost two-thirds of the state, although, of course, native title has not been found to exist yet in South Australia. The claims have been made by 7,500 adult Aborigines who live in South Australia—one half of one per cent of the state's population. Of the landmass of our state, 18.7 per cent is already owned as Aboriginal freehold. In fact, more is owned as Aboriginal freehold than the amount of freehold owned by the rest of us, and that is before these claims are determined.

Our largest claim, covering a variety of land tenures, covers almost 152,000 square kilometres of our state, covering much of the Flinders Ranges. It is one of two claims that have been lodged by the Kuyani people. The Barngarla claim, which covers pastoral and grain growing areas of the state, includes very large areas of freehold land, reserves, extensive pastoral and other leases, crown land and land owned by other Aboriginal communities.

Freehold land in the town of Ceduna has been claimed by the Maralinga people, and they have also claimed the adjacent beaches and the foreshore and coastline of our new Great Australian Bight Marine Park. These claims are made in quite inflammatory language which demands `the possession, occupation, use and enjoyment of the land, minerals and waters to the exclusion of all others'.

Let there be no doubt: in my state significant areas of freehold land and schools, churches and community halls are included in these claims. Where is the certainty for them under the current legislation? My colleague Senator O'Chee just a few minutes ago talked about the difficulties he has had with the Queensland branch of the Native Title Tribunal in trying to have some of these freehold claims in Queensland struck out. So we can only wonder about the freehold claims in South Australia. This bill will enable states and territories to confirm that native title was extinguished over freehold land.

One of the unfortunate effects of these and other claims around the nation is the delays and the costly obstacles to new, not established, resource processing projects, which surely means that all of us suffer—all Australians lose. This is especially true of the projects around South Australia's resource rich Gawler Craton, with its exciting new prospective areas of gold, copper, nickel, diamonds, iron ore bodies and, of course, the well‐established coal reserves in that area. This area, which extends from Yorke Peninsula across several hundred kilometres beyond Coober Pedy, and which includes the magnificent Roxby Downs copper and uranium mine, is now covered by multiple native title claims by the Kuyani, Kokatha, Yandrawandha and Dieri peoples.

This is one of our most richly prospective areas, where a number of small resource companies are beginning to plan their new mines and to offer the state of South Australia a substantial boost in economic performance as well as, very importantly, jobs in the remote parts of our state.

Prospecting rights on our opal rich northern regions are now also uncertain. There is absolutely no doubt that this uncertainty is driving our resource industries offshore. Companies simply are not investing in new mines, preferring instead to extend their existing mines and to try to prolong the prospectiveness of those resource areas. This bill will restore certainty and optimism to the mining industry by improving the threshold test and introducing more flexibility into the right to negotiate process.

Aboriginal activist Father Frank Brennan has described the right to negotiate as `an appropriate means by which Aboriginal people might have some economic impoundment'. Mining companies have told the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund that they accept that native title is now a statutory infrastructure cost to be taken into account when new mines are considered and new exploration is undertaken. In fact, the increased cost of gaining access to land, using the right to negotiate process, can now represent about 20 per cent of the budget for a typical exploration project. It is therefore absolutely crucial that the right to negotiate is a clear and respected mechanism for dealing with legitimate native title claimants and not 20 separate feuding family claimants. This bill will ensure the right to negotiate is not abused. It will enable the representative bodies to also play a role in this process.

For generations, the South Australian pastoral industry—which comprises 39 per cent of our state spread over 300 or so leases—has shared its land with our Aboriginal peoples, with rights which have enabled Aboriginals to travel across, stay on, pass through or hunt, gather or forage on the land as part of their traditional activities. This bill, unlike the Labor government's legislation, preserves those current access rights for Aborigines in South Australia and in all other states and territories.

Our pastoral industry is rich in history. Over the past 150 years it has contributed enormously, providing a significant capital base for the development and economic wealth of the state. More recently, however, the industry has suffered economically from the near destruction of our wool industry and from the collapse of cattle prices. Surely these families should be able to appropriately diversify their agricultural activities to support their families, without attracting a costly and complex legal process? After all the average farm business profit in that region over the past four years is less than $4,000 per year per family. That is hardly millionaires' row, although, sadly, it has been the target of far too many misguided and cruel accusations.

You may wonder why so many of our pastoral leases are under claim. Perhaps the answer lies in the answer given to the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund by the South Australian Aboriginal Legal Rights Movement. In response to the question, `What other rights could native title possibly include that are not now covered by our reservation rights?', came this enlightening statement: `The right to negotiate.' Interestingly enough, that is a statutory right given to Aborigines by the Labor Party and certainly not discovered on the island of Mer by the High Court.

Many pastoralists have effectively shared their land with Aboriginal communities, and they have told me how betrayed they feel when indigenous leaders deny them any recognition of the spiritual attachment they feel for the land that they have occupied for generations—sometimes more than a century. How could David Ross and Noel Pearson so cruelly reject the very clear and, in many cases, deep and spiritual attachment pastoralists have to their land? Yet this is precisely what they did when they appeared before the parliamentary joint committee. It was a disgraceful renunciation of a legitimate attachment to land. This bill will enable pastoralists to manage their properties, while recognising any coexisting native title.

What this public debate has revealed to me once again is the depth and breadth of the farm‐city gap in this country and the degree to which those families in the leafy streets of our metropolitan cities fail to appreciate or even understand the reality of life in the bush: over the Dandenongs, beyond the Blue Mountains and past the Adelaide Hills.

How many residents of Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Perth and Brisbane know the heartache and uncertainty that comes with the arrival in the roadside mailbox of one native title claim after another? Some of these claims are from people living hundreds of kilometres away who have never sought to visit the farm or the region. How many of that sea of waving hands on the lawns near here were contributed by families whose homes and businesses are under claim?

This bill is a commonsense attempt to balance the interests of all Australians, wherever they live, to ensure that the resource industries of this nation continue to grow and to prosper for the benefit of all of us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this Native Title Amendment Bill 1997. I believe we have a very important opportunity in making our contribution. I certainly want to make the point, first of all, that we are making our speeches at a time that is historically important.

SPEECH.PARA: We are alive in a piece of history. To my mind it is not unlike the significance of living through the First World War, the Second World War or the fall of the Iron Curtain. What we are debating today is a piece of legislation that is of such historical importance that it equates with those events I have just mentioned.

As the Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, said the other day, `We are not just living through history; we are making history.' He reminded us that we have a great responsibility to ensure that we `get it right'. He asked, `Will generations look back upon us and our actions as something for which they must apologise or something of which they must be proud?' I believe that is the most significant question we need to ask at this time.

This legislation comes as part of the reconciliation process, and there is an importance in that too. There are many things in our history, when we look back at them, of which we cannot be proud. The stolen children report made that absolutely clear. For that we need to apologise—say we are sorry—and many of us have.

I also look back to the historical event of the 1967 referendum, which effectively gave Aboriginal people in this country the right to be citizens in their own country. Before that, Aboriginal people were effectively not citizens in this Commonwealth. They were not recognised as such, not counted as existing and not able to vote. The referendum changed all that.

It is a very interesting thing for a senator from South Australia, as I am, to reflect on the impact of that referendum, particularly because, while Aboriginal men had the right to vote, after 1894 Aboriginal women also had the right to vote in South Australia and, indeed, exercised that vote on a few occasions. In the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1902, Aboriginal people were excluded, except in so far as they did have the right to vote previously under section 41, I think. But, effectively, what happened with the 1902 act was that all Aboriginal people were then either actively denied or disregarded in terms of their right to continue to vote in their own country.

The 1967 referendum saw that injustice taken away. I have been reading an excellent report, The origins of the Commonwealth involvement in indigenous affairs in the 1967 referendum, Information Research Service Background Paper No. 11 of 1996‐97, produced by our Parliamentary Library, and the history makes an excellent piece of reading. It is interesting to read just who had what to say about the rights of Aboriginal people at that time. It is interesting to note that, when the bill for the referendum was introduced into the parliament, it was unanimously supported. For the record, I note in this report:

The Churches came out strongly in support of the Yes vote, the Heads of all the major denominations publicly pledging their support. The Anglican Primate saw it as a way of helping to build the Aborigines' self‐confidence, self‐reliance and self‐respect.
I wonder whether the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) would have raised objections about the churches' contribution in that debate. I will come back to that shortly.

The history of Aboriginal rights, particularly their right to vote, is something—through the history of South Australia—that has great resonance for me as a woman and, indeed, for women in this country because women were described as equally unfit to vote—the words used about Aboriginal people. You could not expect Aboriginal people to vote; they did not have the intelligence. That is what was said in the late 19th century and the early 20th century. They were exactly the sorts of comments that were said about women. They were equally wrong and equally offensive to both groups. But women in Australia, except Aboriginal women along with Aboriginal men, did not have to wait until a referendum in 1967 to have the right to have a say in their own country.

I move on to the significance of the Mabo decision and the history of the Native Title Act. I would like to quote from the contribution of my colleague Senator Bolkus to this debate on Tuesday, 25 November, because I think he says it very succinctly:

The Mabo decision corrected that great lie upon which this nation had been built. For over 200 years, through the application of the doctrine of terra nullius, Australian law had sought to hide the fact that we were not the first inhabitants of this land. Our law sought to pretend that the indigenous Australians did not have cultures that dealt with issues of land management, nor did the law seek to understand the very special spiritual and cultural attachment of indigenous Australians to this land—their land.

That is exactly what the Native Title Act 1993 did. It actually recognised the common law rights of Australia's indigenous people in native title. It created a mechanism for recognising and protecting native title rights and it confirmed all rights, indigenous and non‐indigenous. In the act, some native title rights were extinguished to give certainty to leases granted between 1975 and 1994, but only after significant negotiation with Aboriginal people.

The doctrine of terra nullius has its own particular irony in my state of South Australia. There was much discussion and debate and principles were established as to how the new colony would be established. While I cannot claim to be full bottle on all of these details, I do understand that Lord Glenelg and also Torrens, in discussion and formulation of the guidelines for this new colony, agreed that there would have to be compensation to the natives in the area. In fact, the British govern ment withheld the letters patent allowing the colony to be established until there was an agreement that would be the case. I am advised that when the relevant people arrived in South Australia they simply refused to implement that requirement.

It is also interesting to understand why, shortly after the establishment of that colony in South Australia, the local community saw fit to establish pastoral leases at all. The colonial office of the British government `had three objectives—to ensure the land did not pass permanently into private hands, to allow the pastoral industry to expand, and `to protect Aborigines'. They created a `special form of land tenure—the pastoral lease—which provided for joint occupation of the same land by the resident squatter and the local land‐owning clan'. Henry Reynolds in his book The Law of the Land makes a comment about this. He says, as quoted by Mark Horstman in Arena Magazine of 22 AprilMay 1996, page 31:
If it were agreed—
as we might in this bill—

that native title was extinguished on pastoral leases, contemporary Australia would show itself to the world as having less interest in protecting Aboriginal interests than the aristocratic Englishmen who ran the Empire 150 years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is Henry Reynolds?

—If you do not know that, Senator, I urge you to contact the library for a very good reference in this area. Henry Reynolds is a very fine historian, Senator. If you are suggesting, by implication across the chamber, that he would say that because he is writing from a certain perspective, I think that is a particularly insulting assessment and implication—in your remarks. But Henry Reynolds is more than able to speak for himself and I will make sure that he sees a copy of your interjection, Senator.

SPEECH.PARA: It is perfectly reasonable what the British government intended by way of acknowledging the existence of Aboriginal people and their rights to land usage all those years ago. That is what the Native Title Act did and that is what we on this side are concerned to see continues and is not deleted under the Native Title Amendment Bill , as proposed by the Howard government.

Further supporting comments come from people who, perhaps, might be regarded as an unlikely source. John Sheehan, the spokesperson for the Australian Institute of Valuers and Land Economists, which advises property investors, including all major banks, said in an interview on Friday 25 April 1997 that there was no uncertainty caused by the Wik decision, and that, in fact, the High Court decision has clarified, for the first time, the rights of pastoralists. He went on to say:

All Wik did was to confirm that there was certain rights held by pastoral lessees, they thought that they had something equivalent to freehold, but that certainly wasn't the case. Banks have always treated pastoral leases as less than freehold, a point that pastoral lessees seem to have forgotten . . . the rights that were held by pastoral lessees are unchanged as a result of the Wik decision.
It is the Howard government, with its amending legislation, that has created the uncertainty by making promises to pastoralists.

It is important to know that the government, the parliament, the pastoralists and the miners—anybody, in fact—cannot take away native title right found to exist in the common law by the High Court of Australia. The government, though, through its Native Title Amendment Bill is seeking to diminish the common law right of Aboriginal people. If this bill gets through unamended, it will certainly be challenged in the courts precisely because it goes to that point that I have just made. There will be, if this bill is passed unamended, no certainty. People need to understand that native title is not a threat to private or public property, to pastoralists or to the mining industry.

I have to say that I was for some time prepared to attribute good faith to the government on this matter. However, as I have listened to the debate over the last few months I have heard the assertions of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that the pendulum has swung too far in favour of Aborigines. I have heard the comments of the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, about this bill containing `bucketloads of extinguishment'. Last night I heard the outrageous comments of Senator Minchin that dissipated any re maining goodwill I might have had about the intentions of the government.

Senator Minchin, who is the man with special carriage of this legislation, went on national television last night and asserted that Australian homes were under threat unless the bill was passed—that even freehold title was under threat. I had presumed that Senator Minchin was a reasonable man. He is, by his own words now, a self-avowed unreasonable man. He is a man who has betrayed his own intelligence; he has certainly betrayed his own and his government's real agenda: certainty for some, but not for all, under their bill.
Laura Tingle writing in the Age this morning, 27 November, had this to say about Senator Minchin's remarks:
(It) is the most disgraceful act yet of a Government that has made an art form of the `big lie' on Aboriginal affairs ever since it came into office.
If there is one thing the High Court has explicitly, unanimously made clear about native title, it was its declaration in the Mabo decision in 1992: freehold land extinguished native title.

Laura Tingle is absolutely right. The government knows that its legislation is unfair, unconstitutional and unworkable. It will not produce certainty. It will not produce justice. It is the Howard coalition government that has persistently contributed to the hysteria and misinformation that has proliferated in the community over this debate.

The parliamentary debate before us is really about how our society, our legal system and our governments recognise the rights of indigenous people. It is fundamentally a question of social justice and it is about the process of reconciliation, of how we ourselves judge we can progress and go forward as a nation.

Last week I was astounded to listen to the extent—not just the content—of this government's attack, from the Prime Minister down, on church leaders from every denomination who spoke out against this bill saying that it was racially discriminatory, unjust and unfair. The call from the House of Representatives member Mr Warren Entsch for Christians to boycott their churches took that attack against the churches one step further. It did nothing but discredit him. The churches have always claimed a right to speak out on matters of social justice. From my perspective, sometimes it has been a sadness that they have not spoken out more often and more loudly. But, in this debate, as in the 1967 referendum, the church leaders are well worth listening to. All of them have been at great pains to inform themselves about the matters of debate, the issues and the fine detail of the impact of this piece of legislation.
It is interesting to quote Mr Howard:
It is difficult to conceive of the factual base on which some church figures have attacked my government's legislation as being racist, discriminatory or immoral.

But the Prime Minister knows, as we know, that the government had advice, via its Chief General Counsel, Mr Henry Burmester, as early as July this year, about how this legislation is discriminatory. It is interesting to watch how government front bench members of every level have ducked and twisted rather than give us access to or affirm the advice that had come to them.

I think it is also important to acknowledge the churches' right to speak out on this legislation because so many of those churches have also acknowledged their part in contributing to appalling injustice to Aboriginal people. They acknowledge that and they apologise for that. It gives, I suppose, an even keener edge to the rightness of their contributing at this time. But, most importantly, the rightness of their speaking is actually based on the efforts they have gone to to find out about this legislation, to find out the impact of it, to inform themselves of exactly what it is about.

I hope it is not the intention of the government to be racist. They say they do not wish to be, and I would prefer to understand them that way. But it is very worrying when, in the face of all sorts of most senior legal advice, Law Reform Commission advice, perhaps unsought, church advice and considered advice by scholars—all sorts of people who have examined this legislation thoroughly, who conclude that it is discriminatory, that it will disadvantage Aboriginal people and that it is therefore open to the charge of being racist, that still the government says, `Non sense, everybody has got it wrong except us.' It is time for the government to seriously take stock and listen, and in the end I believe the Senate will force them to do so. I would prefer that the government itself might have reached that conclusion.

The important thing to say is what I said in opening my remarks. I believe this piece of legislation means that I am alive and, by the good grace of the people of South Australia who have elected me to stand here, I am contributing to a decision that is historic. We do have an opportunity to make a case for the rights of Aboriginal people and non‐Aboriginal people in this country to coexist, to try to extend the process of reconciliation so that we really and truly give effect to what it means: that Aboriginal and non‐Aboriginal brothers and sisters, men and women, sons and daughters, go together, as those hands so brilliantly symbolised, for the development and extension of this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before calling Senator McGauran, I make the point that the seven hours of debate that have so far taken place on the second reading stage of this bill have been conducted in relative order. Only in recent times have there been interjections across the table. Those interjections are disorderly. This is an emotive topic. I would ask that the order that has been maintained so far in the debate be continued for the duration of the second reading stage of the bill. I call Senator McGauran.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —As a prelude to my address, I would like to say that my Deputy Leader, Senator Brownhill, from New South Wales, is in complete agreement with me that the government's 10‐point plan is the best response to the High Court Wik decision, but unfortunately, due to commitments and responsibilities he has to the trade portfolio, he is unable to address the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I must pick up something that the previous speaker opened her speech with. If ever we have heard the warped or absurd, it was the previous speaker's making a comparison between today's events and those of World War II or the fall of the Berlin Wall, for heaven's sake. No tragedy, no trauma, no loss of World War II can be equated to today's more humble events. Absolutely nothing in today's debate can be compared with the great events and infamous events of World War II, or the fall of the Berlin Wall, though no doubt that was a sad day for Senator Crowley. Nothing of today's debate can be compared with those shattering events. It really does show how desperately some wish to whip up hysteria on this issue and what false pretences they act under. The comparisons that Senator Crowley made really would be funny if the matter was not so serious.

Turning to my formal address, it is now just over five years since the High Court historic Mabo judgment. That decision held for the first time that indigenous Australians have native title rights in relation to land that are recognised by the common law of Australia. There is no argument that the High Court Mabo decision was correct. Eddie Mabo's claim was legitimate. It is only fair that his possession of the land, and his ancestors' possession before him, should be recognised. The continuous occupation by his people really was in the tradition of the common law right of `possession is nine‐tenths of the law'.

It was the previous government's response to that judgment, in the way of the Native Title Act 1993, that has raised the coalition's objection. The coalition said at the time that the act was inadequate and failed to address many of the uncertainties on the mainland arising out of the Mabo decision. The coalition identified a number of shortcomings within the existing Native Title Act that were a cause of great concern to Australian people generally. We knew then that the legislation was not workable. After four years and some 660 claims, the complex processes of the act have not yet led to the identification of any native title under the act.
The only native title determined on the mainland has been in the Crescent Head case, and that was extinguished with compensation by agreement.

In my state of Victoria, the most prominent and sweeping claim is that of the Yorta Yorta people. The claim is to the north of the state, spilling over into New South Wales. It is an area approximately bounded to the north by the towns of Deniliquin and Jerilderie, to the east by Walbundrie, Howling and Chiltern, to the south by Benalla, Euroa and Rushworth and though the west by Cohuna and Rochester. For those who wish to get their maps out, they will find that this is a massive claim covering 20 councils and shires.

The Yorta Yorta claim, made in 1994, epitomises everything that is wrong with the Native Title Act 1993, both in the spirit of the legislation and the mechanics of the legislation. For example, the obviously ambit claim is so frivolous in parts as to cause aggravation within the broad community. There are claims covering local sports grounds, recreation parks and bushwalking trails. The claims cover freehold land, local government land, crown land, Murray River frontage and the Murray River itself. The simplest understanding of the Mabo decision would conclude that the best part of the Yorta Yorta claim falls outside the criteria set in the original High Court judgment. To state one, there is the requirement to show continuous physical connection to the land claimed.

The Yorta Yorta claim is proof positive that the mechanics of the legislation require an overhaul. For example, the claim was given in‐principle approval all too automatically. No information or detail was available to anyone who had a claim placed over them—as is the case with hundreds of farmers alone. Who and how many were claiming, and what was being claimed, was detail that was not initially made public. The uncertainty and feeling of unfairness at this stage of the process were sorely felt by those under claim. What is more, access to legal aid was not available to defend the rights of those under claim, whereas the opposite was true for the claimants.

Finally, to show the faults of the Native Title Act 1993, there is the Yorta Yorta claim. Nearly four years have elapsed, yet no judgment has been made. It is true to say that in this time local government, business operators and farmers of the area have been either extremely reluctant, or will not carry out any investment or maintenance projects in the area. The government's proposed amendments, while not denying the Yorta Yorta people the right to claim native title, would restrict the right to within the High Court judgments of Mabo and Wik.

While the Yorta Yorta claim was a particular Victorian case, for Australia‐wide it was last year's High Court Wik decision that made it imperative for the government to fix the Native Title Act—both in its workability and uncertainty in law. Succinctly, the decision said that pastoral leases do not necessarily extinguishing native title, unless exclusive possession exists on the pastoral lease. Yet in 1993, the Native Title Act was clearly written on the presumption that pastoral leases extinguish native title.
To quote the movers of the act, firstly, there is the former Prime Minister Paul Keating, who stated:
. . . the issuing of freehold or leasehold extinguishes native title . . .
Secondly, the then Senator Evans, who had passage of the legislation in this Senate, stated:

. . . I think the short point is that the reasonable working assumption from just about everyone who has read the High Court judgments and understands the issues is that the pastoral leases validly granted do produce an extinguishment . . .

Given that this was the understanding by all sides of parliament, the Aboriginal community as a whole, and the rural community, is it any surprise that the Wik judgment created uncertainty and confusion? Therefore, the government's amendment bill has two aims: firstly, to reduce the uncertainty over pastoral leases; and, secondly, to simplify the native title process.

The government's amendment bill has kept faith with the basic principle of respect for the Mabo decision and the common law recognition of native title. It then follows that the bill does not seek to go beyond the decisions of the High Court as to what actions have already extinguished native title. To be clear, we do not seek to extinguish native title. But it is in the interests of all to be certain about where extinguishment has occurred.

The amendment bill confirms, in line with the High Court's judgments of Mabo and Wik, what land can be extinguished—for example, freehold land and pastoral leases that entail exclusive possession. For further certainty, the bill provides that the extinguishment is permanent. The introduction of this certainty will lift many of the frivolous claims now being made over freehold and certainly agricultural leases.

For those pastoral leases that do not claim exclusive possession, native title can be claimed. However, in line with the Wik decision, the government's amendments state that a successful claim cannot interfere with the pastoralist's legitimate primary industry activities. The amendments I have outlined in no way diminish the Aboriginal people's scope to claim native title. The principle is intact.

I now turn to deal with two other matters which are seen as being the most important but which are also riddled with confusion and inefficiencies. Firstly, there is the right to negotiate, which was put in the original legislation in recognition of the special attachment that Aboriginal people have to the land. It gives Aboriginal people a means of protecting their sacred sites.

The original act states that the right to negotiate may be waived where the act will have a minimal impact on native title. But, because it has been impossible to define `minimal impact', the chance for agreement pre‐tribunal has stalled. In Western Australia, of the 1,910 acts that are subject to the right to negotiate, 148 have been cleared—and that is an eight per cent success rate. The obvious cascading effect is a freeze on exploration and development and a logjam created at the Native Title Tribunal.

The principal changes are, firstly, that the bill retains the right to negotiate over crown land; and, secondly, the states will put in place their own regimes of negotiations, but they first must be signed off by the federal government. It is true to say that the right to negotiate will be streamlined. Certain future actions will be excluded from negotiation, for example, compulsory acquisition for third parties where the purpose is the provision of an infrastructure facility, like electricity transmission lines. All parties must negotiate in good faith. Presently, the legislation only requires the government party to negotiate in good faith. There is provision for early ministerial determination. This will ensure that negotiations focus on relevant matters and that the involvement of the arbitral body cannot be indefinitely delayed.

The second important administrative change is the threshold test for claims to be made. Currently the ability to make a claim is, in a word, slack. There are often multiple and overlapping native title claims. The claims are often spurious or frivolous, for example, claims on the Murray River or on areas of Perth. Also, claims are often far too general and uninformative. For example, some claims not only do not define the boundaries or the past and continuous connection, but there is no compulsion to identify all the claimants. Therefore, the purpose of the registration test is to ensure that only claims that have merit are registered on the register of native title claims. The conditions about the merits of the claim require the registrar to be satisfied that a prima facie case for native title has been made, and that procedures in making the claim have been carried out.

I wish to raise another matter which is related to the native title issue: that is, the indigenous land fund. The fund, supported by this government, was established in 1994 with the purpose of recognising that for many indigenous people their native title rights had already been extinguished—for example, those who live in capital cities. The land fund is intended to assist these people acquire land. By the year 2004, the fund will have some $1.4 billion in it. Every year since 1994, $45 million has been dedicated to the purchase of land.

It is important to note that this self‐sustaining land fund runs alongside or complements the ability of indigenous people to make native title claims. While I believe most Australians are unaware of this fund and would not object to the principles contained therein, they have a right to be concerned at the great many frivolous, ambit and even vexatious claims that are being made on native title. Such claims undermine the good intent and the purpose of the land fund. To many, it would look like a case of misuse of the original understanding.

BREAK.PARA: In conclusion, there are no sectional interests here. Rather, the government's moves are for the country as a whole. All Australians are equal under the law. I do not believe the amendments are unconstitutional, although that claim will be tested. They are not racially discriminatory. They do not extinguish native title. They do not wipe out the right to negotiate. They do not abolish fair and just compensation, nor do they go beyond the Mabo and Wik judgments of the High Court. Rather, they enhance those decisions and represent the interests of pastoralists and Aborigines alike. The details of the legislation prove this. Our amendments are a much needed action for an ailing piece of legislation. I commend the amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Gibbs, I note that, in accordance with my warning to the chamber prior to calling Senator McGauran, Senator McGauran was heard in silence. I thank the Senate for that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my belief that the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 contradicts the nature and implications of the High Court's Wik decision, and thus demonstrates the Howard government's desire to usurp the authority and independence of the courts. The main implication of the High Court's decision in Wik is that native title could possibly have survived on the estimated 42 per cent of Australia covered by pastoral leases. This decision essentially asserted that, while pastoral lease rights still prevail over native title rights, such leases do not signify the extinguishment of native title.

SPEECH.PARA: The Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , by contrast, is a blueprint for the unnecessary extinguishment of native title throughout Australia. It misconstrues the fundamental principles underlying the Wik decision in a blatant attempt to undermine the authority of the High Court. Such an approach demonstrates contempt for the independence of the Australian judicial system and is thus of particular concern.

Over the past few weeks I have received letters from all over Australia urging me to reject this bill and thus the 10-point plan. People from many different sectors of society are shocked at the arbitrary nature with which native title is to be extinguished. They are equally concerned that such a proposal could be put forward in the context of the need to maintain the ongoing process of reconciliation in Australia. The Native Title Act 1993 and the High Court's Wik decision seemed to indicate that both legislative and judicial bodies in Australia were supportive of the reconciliation process.

Australians are very concerned that this bill may threaten the status quo by diminishing the status of native title as a means of establishing land rights, thus alienating indigenous people. Under the government's 10-point plan native title would be permanently extinguished on areas covered by a pastoral lease—current or expired. This measure is supposedly designed to provide certainty and security of tenure for pastoralists who have been concerned by the prospect of native title claims in the wake of Wik. However, the extinguishment of native title in this instance is based on false assumptions with regard to the implications of the Wik decision.

The High Court decision by no means authorised the permanent extinguishment of native title rights by pastoral leases. Hence, the government has chosen to misrepresent the facts as a means of justifying this most unjustifiable legislative proposal. The Howard government has capitalised on the fears of small rural land‐holders as part of its campaign to rally support for the 10-point plan. There is widespread apprehension among pastoralists concerning the potential implications of the Wik decision for land‐holders.

Many fear that native title claims may result in the seizure of their property. These sorts of misconceptions have not been adequately addressed, and little has been done to explain to pastoralists how co‐existence can be satisfactorily achieved. Therefore, the Howard government has put forward a proposal that is based on false assumptions, and thus is fundamentally flawed. The rural community is being cruelly misled by a Prime Minister desperate to garner support for his most unpopular piece of proposed legislation.

BREAK.PARA: The minority report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title illustrated the potential for the extinguishment of native title to impose a huge financial burden on the Australian taxpayer. It is estimated that up to 78 per cent of Australia has been covered by a pastoral lease at some time. Therefore, any consideration of pastoral leases has widespread implications. If all pastoral leases—past and present—constitute the extinguishment of native title rights, then compensation must be awarded on just terms.

The extinguishment of native title rights in Australia on such a large scale would thus result in an incredible compensation burden for Australian taxpayers. The creation of such a large debt in order to enforce the extinguishment of native title seems excessive and unnecessary given the adequacy of agreements enabling the coexistence of pastoral and native title rights. More adequate reconciliation of these interests through negotiated land use agreements would be preferable to wholesale extinguishment as a means of providing lasting security of tenure for land‐holders.

Also of particular concern to many Australians are the implications of the Native Title Amendment Bill for Australia's relations with other countries. Many ordinary Australians are concerned that our country's status as a civilised nation has already been damaged by the debate relating to the bill's passage through parliament. Countries such as the UK and Canada have voiced significant concern about the willingness of the Howard government to depart from international standards with regard to indigenous people's land rights.

There is also widespread confusion among OECD countries with regard to the reasons for the Australian government's seemingly inappropriate and contradictory response to the High Court's Wik decision. Our Asian trading partners are already concerned by the views expressed by One Nation supporters. The Native Title Amendment Bill seems to further substantiate international fears that Australia is being subjected to a significant right‐wing backlash at the moment. Grossly ignorant and ill-informed racist sentiments, as expressed by the member for Oxley, are seemingly substantiated by a government willing to dispense with native title‐holders' rights to negotiate over land use. These factors, combined with the Australian government's reluctance to apologise in response to the report on the stolen generation, are contributing to an international perception of Australia as an increasingly racist nation.

As the country that promoted its human rights record as a feature of its bid for the 2000 Olympics, it seems ironic that the Australian government is now willing to abandon our reputation as a racially tolerant society. It is time for the Howard government to really consider the social and cultural implications of this proposed legislation.

The introduction of the Racial Discrimination Act in 1975 signified a major turning point for Australian society. It demonstrated that Australians recognised past injustices to Aboriginal people and was seeking to make amends by putting in place a permanent legislative framework to prevent such injustices from ever occurring in Australia again. Since that time Australians have embraced egalitarianism and worked together to create one of the most harmonious multicultural nations in the world. As we head towards the next century, this government seeks to undermine our international reputation and negate the values of equality and fairness upon which our nation was built

In contrast, Labor's amendments advocate coexistence rather than extinguishment as a means of solving disputes with regard to native title. The use of indigenous land use agreements is a means of implementing procedures designed to encourage a more cooperative and conciliatory approach to disputes. Such agreements offer an alternative to the extinguishment of native title by pastoral leases and would therefore remove the motive for ongoing litigation and animosity between claimants.

In my own state of Queensland such agreements are already providing an effective and workable solution. An agreement between the Redlands Shire Council and the Quandamooka Aboriginal people has established procedures by which native title issues are resolved by mutual agreement without the intervention of the courts. The Hopevale agreement is a similar arrangement between nine parties in Northern Queensland, including the Hopevale Aboriginal Council, the Cape Flattery silica mine and Telstra. Other examples of successful arrangements in Queensland include the Century Zinc, Alcan South Pacific and Chevron Gas pipeline agreements.

The fact that such agreements have already been established demonstrates that coexistence is an attainable goal. The agreements I have mentioned are all the more remarkable because they were established in the current climate of tension created by the member for Oxley.

I am deeply saddened and ashamed to report that my home town of Ipswich is now in danger of becoming a community divided by Ms Pauline Hanson, who has not just encouraged but incited the sort of racial intolerance that Australia sought to overcome by introducing the Racial Discrimination Act. The situation in Ipswich at the moment may be replicated all over Australia if this government is able to override the act by introducing this bill.

Surely it has become obvious to most Australians by now that no matter who was here first and who got here later, we are all here now and we must learn to live together as Australians—not as pastoralists and miners and Aborigines and governments but as Australians. This being the case, any legislative proposal which unnecessarily disturbs the balance of multiculturalism and incites ethnic tensions is not just unfair but ultimately threatens the security of our nation and the stability of our society.

Another particularly disturbing aspect of the Howard government's attempt to enforce the 10-point plan involves the intervention of coalition members in the deliberations of the joint parliamentary committee. The committee was selective in its consideration of submissions and failed to address the concerns of all major stakeholders. The committee subsequently voted against accepting a submission from the Australian Law Reform Commission. Hence, in this instance the objectivity of the committee's final report was substantially compromised as a result of the suppression of valid evidence highlighting criticism of the bill from various non-government agencies. It can therefore be concluded that the significance of any analysis of the bill's provisions emanating from the report of the joint committee is limited by the selective and arbitrary nature of the way in which evidence was collected.

There are a number of fundamental reasons why I oppose the Howard government's 10‐point plan as outlined in the Native Title Amendment Bill . The wholesale extinguishment of native title and the removal of the right of indigenous Australians to negotiate, constitute an unacceptable departure from current legislation designed to protect the rights of indigenous people. The government's misguided assumption that pastoral leases extinguish native title has formed the basis of a misinformation campaign designed to mislead land‐holders with regard to the 10‐point plan's capacity to provide ongoing security of tenure.

Aspects of the bill have been revealed to be unconstitutional and in breach of the Racial Discrimination Act. Hence, the proposed legislation is destined to provoke extensive litigation, resulting in ongoing uncertainty for all stakeholders. In addition, the widespread extinguishment of native title would necessitate compensatory measures which would not be required under coexistence arrangements. Therefore, the enforcement of the wholesale extinguishment of native title would impose a somewhat boundless and unrealistic bill on the Australian taxpayer. Such excessive expense could be averted by a policy of coexistence, whereby native title could be maintained.

In their attempts to secure safe passage for the bill through parliament, the government have constantly sought to mislead and misinform. They have conducted a scare campaign referring to non‐existent rights of veto and fears of land acquisition from pastoralists. These misconceptions have been compounded by a committee report censored by coalition members. As a piece of legislation, the bill would negate the recognition of native title established by previous legislative meas ures. It would alienate Australia from the international community who have already registered their alarm at government responses to the High Court's Wik decision.

Most of all, however, the bill represents a resounding rejection of the egalitarian and racially tolerant values of Australians in the 1990s. It therefore constitutes an insult to all Australians, indigenous or otherwise, who have sought to represent and support the ideals of multiculturalism. It is my firm belief that the majority of Australians—black, white and those of other ethnic backgrounds—genuinely want to live together in peace and harmony, respecting each other's cultures and beliefs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Mabo decision introduced the major new element of native title rights into the Australian system of property rights. The Native Title Act of 1993 was an attempt to manage the issue. However, the act was inadequate and unworkable. And I might say that that was a view expressed to me at the time by certain senior Labor people who were then in government. I was also led to believe, rightly or wrongly, that the then Prime Minister of the day, Paul Keating, made it quite clear that he believed that that act would have to be amended and, of course, this is what the Native Title Amendment Bill does.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the Wik decision, the confusion has increased. Early resolution of native title issues will remove major impediments to the development of the industries in the primary industries and energy portfolio—in particular, the mining and pastoral industries which are such significant contributors to the Australian economy. The government's amendments to the Native Title Act will provide the certainty sought by pastoralists and miners since the enactment of the Native Title Act and the announcement of the High Court's Wik decision.
