The key issues for orderly mineral exploration and development are, firstly, clarity as to who are the valid beneficial owners of property and the rights of those owners, whether the land be freehold, leasehold, crown or valid native title; and, secondly, clear recognition that the Crown owns the minerals. The normal procedure is that exploration companies have access to land but are responsible for the repair of any disturbance, and informal arrangements are made to minimise inconvenience to either the explorer or the land‐holder.

In relation to mineral development, applications are made for leases and negotiations are entered into with land‐holders. It is not unusual for valuations to be made on the basis of `willing buyer and unwilling seller'. This gives independent valuers latitude to be generous to landowners. The vast majority of these negotiations are settled in this way. In the absence of successful negotiation, an independent arbitration is sought and, from my own experience over many years in Queensland, this was either a land court or a mining warden. At no stage is the perceived value of the minerals or the expected profitability of the mine taken into account. The decision by the court is made simply on the basis of detriment to the valid titleholder. Royalty is paid to the Crown and this represents substantial revenue to the community—estimated for the states to be in the order of $2 billion per year. The titleholder does not have the power of veto.

The bill recognises native title; gives certainty as to validity, which has been a very major problem with overlapping claims, and we have heard speaker after speaker talk about that; gives claimants and those with valid native title exactly the same rights as apply to any other titleholder; and, where negotiations are not successful, it gives to a court the ability to make a determination in regard to compensation—which, I might say, is exactly the same as applies to any other holder of title. To claim that this is in some way discriminatory, is totally absurd. It does not take away rights. It gives valid native titleholders at least equivalent rights as apply to everyone else.

There has been a lot of misrepresentation in this debate, often propagated by people who do not have a great deal of experience of regional Australia. Mining companies are more involved in working with local and indigenous communities than ever before. The flow of royalties from mines fund Aboriginal development projects at the discretion of Aborigines. The Aboriginal community can grow and prosper in conjunction with the mining industry.

There is a popular misconception that negotiations between companies and indigenous groups are a one-way street and that the mining industry wants to circumvent indigenous interests. This is simply not the case. The industry recognises that negotiated agreements are the best outcome for the industry and the Aboriginal communities. But both parties need a system that works, a system with the backing of a statutory procedure for when negotiations breakdown. As I mentioned earlier, in my own experience 99 times out of 100 that does not occur.

The bill removes many of the impediments for the resources and energy industries imposed by the current act. It aims to facilitate the growth and development of resource based industries, which are so important for the future prosperity of all Australians. In particular, it provides for mining projects to be covered by a single right to negotiate process with valid native title holders or registered claimants. It enables exclusion of low‐impact exploration activity from the right to negotiate as part of a Commonwealth approved scheme. It supports and encourages the resolution of native title issues through the negotiation of indigenous land use agreements which will be legally binding.

It validates where necessary mining titles over non-exclusive tenures issued between 1 January 1994—which was the date of the commencement of the Native Title Act—and 23 December 1996, the date of the High Court's Wik decision. It exempts from the right to negotiate the renewal of mining titles and it exempts mining industry infrastructure from the right to negotiate. It removes the right to negotiate from small-scale mining operations such as opal and gem mining, and alluvial gold mining and tin mining, subject to conditions. For mining on leasehold land where native title may exist, it provides for the states and territories to be able to replace the right to negotiate with state based processes, giving native title claimants and holders exactly the same procedural rights with leaseholders or even people with freehold, including compensation for any loss or impairment of native title rights.

A major concern for the petroleum and fisheries industries is the effect of claims under the existing Native Title Act over offshore waters. Some claims purport to exclude all others from the area and claim full ownership of aquatic resources. The Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 continues to allow claims to be made over offshore waters because the fundamental legal question of the native title status of offshore waters is yet to be decided.

The bill removes any doubt about governments' ability to manage offshore resources. It makes it clear that governments can legislate for the management and regulation of water and aquatic resources, including fisheries, whether or not native title might exist. Governments can continue to regulate the fisheries and the petroleum industries and issue fishing licences and petroleum exploration and production permits. Native title claimants and holders are entitled to only the same procedural rights as others with corresponding rights and interests and cannot exclude others from offshore areas. There is no right to negotiate offshore.

Native title processes established under the Native Title Act have proved to be unworkable. If anyone doubts that, they just have to ask the opinion of the previous Governor-General, Bill Hayden, in the discussions that he had on the Century Zinc projects. All interests now recognise this. The bill incorporates a number of improvements to native title processes. It establishes an effective threshold test for the registration of native title claims. That is important for people who have valid claims. It stops the muddying of the waters by those who do not have valid claims overriding those who have valid claims. Where there are multiple claims, the Federal Court will make a single determination of native title and in general will not consider subsequent claims. The bill also makes improvements to the provisions for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander representative bodies. It will establish a more robust system in which representative bodies are subject to national standards of performance and accountability.

It is worth repeating what I said in May this year at the time agreement was finally reached on Century Zinc. While the agreement was a triumph for perseverance, the fact the negotiations took so long is an indictment of the previous government's Native Title Act. As I mentioned earlier, we are well aware that Bill Hayden, who led the negotiations that finally obtained agreement on the project, was extremely frustrated by the processes required by the legislation—so much so that he made his concerns public so that future negotiations may not be similarly affected.

Two years of unnecessary delay had a high cost: 3,200 direct and indirect jobs, many of them for Aboriginals, available during the construction stage of the zinc mine had been denied, in an area where there were few jobs, all because the system failed. At the end of the day, the Aboriginal communities of the Gulf received exactly the same $60 million package offered by the company back in August 1995—at a time, I might add, when it was thought that native title over the mine had been extinguished.

The unworkability of the Native Title Act puts question marks over the vital investment Australia has to attract. Investors must have certainty. The Century Zinc example shows that cannot be guaranteed under the present Native Title Act. The native title amendments must pass and operate as soon as possible to ensure that a farce like the Century Zinc case will not be repeated in Australia. It is worth noting that the size and value of Century Zinc enabled that project to bear the costs and delays resulting from the current Native Title Act. This is not the case with the very large number of smaller, less valuable projects that are currently required to meet the onerous requirements of the act.

This bill responds to the urgent national need to restore certainty to native title processes and to resolve the uncertainties arising from the Wik decision. It facilitates economic development across Australia. It strikes a balance among the interests of all stakeholders by respecting the interests of native title holders, delivering certainty for pastoralists, reducing complexity for the resource industries and recognising the appropriate role for the states and territories. It meets Australia's need for native title processes that work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen George

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the election of the Howard government in March 1996 we have witnessed the politics of division—not cohesion—in our society. The inclusive and nation building approach of the Hawke and Keating governments has been replaced with the politics of division and disconnection. Some examples of this are the Workplace Relations Act, which since its introduction has seen an escalation of confrontation in the workplace; horrific cuts to the public sector and their impact on jobs, particularly in regional Australia; attacks on the security of aged Australians and the resultant uncertainty created for those in need of nursing home care; tacit government approval of the racist agenda pursued by Pauline Hanson and her cohorts; and the 10‐point plan of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) which, if adopted by this parliament, will be a gross denial of justice to our indigenous people—a people who have already suffered enough. They have been dispossessed, killed and had their children stolen and families destroyed. It is they who have experienced decades of discrimination and demoralisation.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only will it be a denial of justice; it will mean that we as legislators have missed a rare opportunity after 200 years of disenfranchisement to engage our indigenous people as an inclusive part of our society in a manner that sustains their culture, maintains their pride and upholds their dignity. Only when that is achieved can any government claim to govern on behalf of all Australians.

The Native Title Act 1993 was a first step in achieving that inclusiveness. The High Court, in its historic Mabo decision, for the first time in Australian history recognised what we all knew existed: native title in Australia. A second step in the process was more recently the Wik decision, in which the High Court has recognised that native title rights were not extinguished by the grant of a pastoral lease, that native title rights of indigenous Australians can coexist with pastoral leases.

The government's proposed legislation seeks to diminish those rights. This is not the agenda of a government of compassion. It is a tragedy that this country does not have today a leader of vision with the necessary political maturity to deliver a political solution based on fairness and goodwill. This nation requires a legislative response based on bucket loads of compassion, not extinguishment.

Clearly, the decision in the Wik case is simple and already guarantees the rights of pastoralists. Native title and the rights of others such as pastoralists can coexist. The government and in particular the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, would have us believe that native title rights have been achieved to the detriment of pastoralists. Much of the perceived uncertainty surrounding the Wik decision of the High Court has been deliberately manufactured and promoted by this government, in cahoots with the rich mining lobby and large‐scale pastoralists.

Obfuscation, distortion and confusion are well‐worn political weapons which are deliberately being used to mislead the Australian public and honest farmers into thinking that Wik will affect them, that their right to use the land will be lost. The government are using fear and ignorance to promote their agenda.

This has been further confirmed by the recent claims of the Special Minister of State (Senator Minchin) that freehold property could be affected, that the average suburban home could be under challenge. That must rank in the same category as Malcolm Fraser's `put your money under the bed' claim just prior to the 1983 election and equally as stupid.

For the first time in Australian history we have a unique opportunity to define both the form and the substance that the relationship between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians will take in the future. This can be through a path of conflict, protracted court battles, racism and division at great cost to our nation, as would be the inevitable outcome of the government's proposed 10-point plan, or it can be an inclusive path of reconciliation, negotiation and preservation of human rights and the dignity of the individual within a cohesive society.

A central tenet to achieving that outcome is the fundamental right to negotiate. It is therefore essential in any legislation passed by this parliament that negotiating rights are strengthened and preserved for indigenous Australians. This provides no guarantee at law. The right to negotiate is not a right to veto. It is a fundamentally important right, nevertheless, as it secures the participation of all parties in any negotiated solution.

The Howard government's amendments failed to do this. The Prime Minister's 10-point plan is nothing but compulsory, forced, not consensual extinguishment of native title over enormous stretches of the country. Currently the right to negotiate in the Native Title Act 1993 is in recognition of the special attachment that indigenous peoples have to their land. It provides that, for acts relating to any significant change in land use, for example mining, and for the compulsory acquisition of native title for the purpose of making a grant to a third party, registered native title holders and claimants will have a right to negotiate before such an act can take place.

It can only be described as reasonable to include an affected party in the decision making process. The experience overseas in countries such as Canada and the United States of America has over a number of years seen that, in conflicts over the use of land between native title holders and others, negotiation has been fundamental to achieving lasting settlements.

In Canada the comprehensive land claims program was adopted by agreement of all parties in 1973. This program was designed to find ways in which indigenous Canadians can use land to become more self-sufficient in partnership with other Canadians, both corporate and individual, who have an economic interest in those lands. The aim of the program is to work out consensual agreements between indigenous peoples and government and other economic interest groups which all have a stake in the use of the land. This is a process of negotiation by consent with the underlying principle—that of coexistence—similar to Wik.

It is a process that has worked and worked well. In fact, in Canada to date they have negotiated 58 specific and treaty land entitlement claims, representing 205,000 hectares of land and $163 million; and five comprehensive claim settlements since 1983, representing 83,000 square kilometres of land and $230 million. It also recognises that the land has more than just an economic value for indigenous people.

I would now like to draw your attention to the findings of the distinguished academic from Toronto University Professor Peter Russell and what he had to say on native title. But, before I do so, if Professor Russell had been writing about native title in Australia during the debate, would he have suffered the same smears that our religious leaders have had to deal with from those on the other side for daring to speak out? Or like Hugh Kerr, a distinguished member of the European parliamentary delegation visiting Australia, who dared to address a rally outside parliament just a couple of days ago, would Professor Russell be accused of having an axe to grind, of not being independent? Would those smears be made on him? We would do well to remember that abuse is no substitute for a challenging debate.

This is what Professor Russell had to say about native title and the Canadian experience. He indicates that the payment of compensation for extinguishment of native title cannot be measured in just or similar terms. He states:

By making that equation, it denies the unique nature of Aboriginal interest in land as recognised in common law. It is a unique interest that goes beyond, above and beneath the mere material value of the land and has to do with the fundamental identity, collective and individual, of the indigenous people with their homeland.
That dimension of Aboriginal title is not one that can been monitorised and simply given a cash value and bought out.

For this reason, as Professor Russell indicates, the move in Canada and the USA has clearly been towards negotiation of agreements by consent. The Howard government's native title amendments do not include a process with a genuine right of negotiation for indigenous Australians but allow for extinguishment of native title by stealth, based on the premise that land or property rights have an economic value alone. This is both morally reprehensible and legally wrong and cannot and should not be allowed to proceed.

I wish to reaffirm the importance of the six steps of coexistence, as recommended by Australians for Native Title and Reconciliation and supported by the Leader of the Labor Party, Kim Beazley, at the rally here this week. I want to particularly emphasise step No. 4 which relates to establishing a system for negotiating binding agreements. It states:

Aboriginal people, pastoralists, miners, governments and other stakeholders need to be able to negotiate agreements about land use, in a system which is expeditious, fully supported by governments and under which agreements are backed up by statute.

In both Australia and other common law countries it is being recognised that legal disputes are a cumbersome and ineffective way of resolving conflict. The worldwide trend is towards forms of alternative dispute resolution. These are already being successfully used in Australia today in such environments as the Family Court, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the Small Claims Court of the Local Court. These environments focus on settlement of dispute through negotiation and provide arbitration only as a last resort. This is a modern, conclusive and mature way to deal with differences.

In my experience as a trade unionist, I know that the only way to achieve a lasting resolution to disputes is to negotiate an outcome that is sanctioned by all the parties to the agreement and to which they are totally committed. The right of all affected parties to participate in negotiations is fundamental in this process. If any party is excluded, then there can be no acceptance of the outcome let alone the agreement.

It is well understood in our society that agreements reached through a process of negotiation and recognition of the needs and rights of the participating parties and openly and freely entered into are much more likely to endure. This is an inherent principle in the approach taken to dispute resolution in almost every forum in Australia today. If the Howard government is allowed to remove the right of negotiation for indigenous Australians then it is removing them from the process. If they are excluded in this manner then there can be no reconciliation, commitment or genuine agreement.

The Native Title Act has already laid the foundations that are capable of resolving disputes and processing claims in an effective manner. This is seen through the many agreements that have been reached to date—such as the agreement between the Arakwal people, the New South Wales state government and the Byron Shire for joint management of a new state recreation area in Byron Bay. In addition, through a process of negotiation, agreements have been reached by Hammersly Iron at its Yandicoogina Mine, the Century Zinc project and the Chevron‐PNG pipeline project—together, worth close on $1 billion.

The Howard government amendments to the Native Title Act 1993 are firmly focused on the rights of pastoralists, miners and governments. For the most part, they ignore those of the native title holders. How can we have an effective resolution to the use of land subject to both native title rights and pastoral leases if one of the critical parties is excluded from the process? The answer is that it cannot be done and the Howard government is aware of this.

These amendments are designed to remove the rights of native title holders and secure additional rights for others at their expense—nothing less. The agenda of this government is to pay lip service to native title holders, ignore their rights and allow their title to be extinguished later.

Respect for native title rights is fundamental to the reconciliation process. The government's amendments do not meet this simple test. They do not have the support of indigenous people and would effectively extinguish their common law rights. After more than 200 years of dispossession and demoralisation, Australia as a nation must reject the voices of prejudice, ignorance and hatred. Respect for the rights of indigenous Australians is an issue for all Australians.

The Mabo and Wik judgments reflect fundamental truths about the prior occupation of this country. They lay the basis for justice, not further injustice. The amendments to the Native Title Act proposed by the Howard government clearly are racially discriminatory as they remove the rights of one race in Australia—indigenous Australians. That is why these amendments require the removal of the Racial Discrimination Act's protection before they can proceed.

These amendments are tantamount to extinguishment of native title. The path of the Howard government is one that will lead to divisions within Australian society in a manner that will need generations of trust to repair. It is an attempt to secure additional rights for the few at the expense of the many, and it will destroy the forward thinking ideals and the reconciliation process. It has implications for all Australians and is nothing more than a gigantic leap into the dark ages of racism. In modern Australia this is unacceptable and must be opposed.

The changes to these amendments proposed by the Australian Labor Party are aimed at achieving a fair and acceptable outcome for all stakeholders. They build on the substantial foundations already achieved in the reconciliation process, and they should be supported. Australians are renowned for believing in the principle of a fair go. For me this has always meant a fair go for all, and in the Australia of the 21st century that must include our indigenous people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Some four years ago I stood in this chamber and debated against the Native Title Bill, as it was then framed. At the time, I stated that the bill was incompetent and did not do what it set out to achieve. Sadly, history has proved me right.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1993, there has been only one determination of native title, and that was the Mabo decision. Also, there was an agreement relating to Crescent Head, which dealt with the surrender of native title by agreement. But apart from that there has been nothing else, despite the fact that some 660 applications for native title are remaining and that 50 per cent of this continent is under claim and 79 per cent of it is claimable under the legislation. When I debated this matter four years ago, 16 per cent of my state of Western Australia was under claim; today it is in the region of 80 per cent.

The Native Title Act has not been the panacea for indigenous Australia that people thought it would be. Nor has it advanced matters for this country generally. In fact, what this Native Title Act has done is breed division and uncertainty.

The coalition government has always recognised native title, but it believes that the management of any claim to land must be based on equity and the law. At the time of the debate in 1993, the Labor government made it clear that pastoral leases extinguished native title. During that very debate I questioned the then Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, as he then was, and he replied:

Our reading of the High Court decision is that it is overwhelmingly likely that when this comes to be formally decided again—no doubt it will be the subject at some stage of some further decision—the High Court decision will confirm that properly granted pastoral leases, for example, do in fact extinguish native title. The Prime Minister . . . has said as much. That is our legal judgment, that is our belief, that although the High Court did leave a sliver of doubt, as Senator Ellison puts it . . .

He was answering a question that I put to him during the committee stage of this debate—the longest debate in the history of this country. I asked him about the extinguishment of native title by pastoral leases, and I could not have got a clearer answer than that.

The debate was conducted on all sides with the belief that pastoral leases extinguished native title. But, as we know, since then the High Court has changed things. First there was the decision of the Waanyi case, which related to threshold tests; then the decision of Brandy, which said that judicial decisions could not be made by non-judicial people; and then there was the Wik decision, which said that pastoral leases did not extinguish native title. So we have had a successive stream of High Court cases which have altered the understanding that hitherto had been held by the prior government and this government in relation to the effect of that legislation.

It is not uncommon for parliaments to alter the law when decisions are made by a court saying that the interpretation is different to what was thought. Therefore, it is not uncommon for the government to be introducing this bill to remedy the situation—and the opposition acknowledges this with its hundreds of amendments in relation to this legislation. The opposition, when it was in government, amended the Migration Act as a result of High Court and Federal Court decisions. There is nothing new in that.

The question relates to efficacy, certainty and enacting good law. Responsible governments are not about enacting bad law. That would be irresponsible. Those critics in the community who have criticised this government as being racist and those critics in the community who have criticised this legislation as being racist simply do not understand the issue. I point out to those people and to the nation's press that, although much remains to be done in indigenous affairs—that is conceded by this government—this government has still done a great deal in the first half-term of its office.

In my portfolio, which includes education and training, I would point to a number of initiatives which deal with indigenous Australia and which have enjoyed high priority. Our indigenous education strategic initiatives program is an example. We have committed an additional $80 million over four years to this program. More money will be put into indigenous education, from pre‐school to TAFE, and we have restructured funding arrangements so that we will target literacy and numeracy.

We also have an English as a second language program. From 1998, funding will enable intensive English as a second language assistance for indigenous language speaking students from non‐English speaking communities to commence in schools for the first time. Each eligible student will attract a once only payment of just over $3,000 for intensive tuition, to assist students to reach a basic level of English communication so that they can function effectively in a mainstream classroom. The total cost to the Commonwealth is expected to be in the order of $6.2 million.

In the 1996 budget we committed $72 million over three years for indigenous higher education, including $21 million per annum for the continuation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander support funding. We also applied $6.5 million for the establishment of a number of specialist indigenous higher education centres. Expenditure for training of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders has been increased from $53 million last year to $65 million this year.

In relation to Abstudy there has been significant expenditure, anticipated to be around $130 million in 1998. We have recently varied the number of interstate trips and days away that students can spend in relation to their institutions, and some 1,500 indigenous students are expected to benefit from these changes. We are also undertaking a review of Abstudy in its current form, to make sure that it provides the most appropriate assistance. Consultations with indigenous people will be a feature of this review.

Education is an essential part of any community and any society. Training of our young people is enormously important. This year I was privileged to present the Apprentice of the Year award to Jason Jones, a young Aboriginal man from the Northern Territory. In 1994‐95, Labor's last full year of government, there were a mere 817 indigenous trainees, compared to this year when there are just under 5,000. This is where the government is working to achieve outcomes for indigenous Australians.

It is interesting to note that those critics who call this legislation racist and call this government racist do not acknowledge these important initiatives. As I said, education is essential for all Australians, especially for indigenous Australians. It has ramifications for health, self‐esteem, advancement and empowerment of the individual. If ever reconciliation is to be achieved, it is by good works and not by empty words. This government is not about rhetoric but achievement. We are looking for positive outcomes for indigenous Australians and we are looking for a native title system that works for all Australians.

In my state of Western Australia, where there has been much experience in relation to this matter, there has been uncertainty for the pastoral and mining industry. I might point out that there are a good many Aboriginal people involved in the pastoral industry and also in the mining industry. The progress of these industries will benefit all Australians, Aboriginal people in particular. Some of the best training schemes I have seen for Aboriginal youth have been provided by a mining company in the north of my state. However, such things cannot happen without development. So it is that this legislation is about outcomes. It is about making something work which has been unworkable for the last four years.

Much has been said about this bill contravening the Racial Discrimination Act. The government denies that. The government denies that this bill is racist. Much has been said about the right to negotiate. I would like to place on record the fact that the right to negotiate is attracted not to a titleholder as such but to a registered claimant.

The right to negotiate was a positive action taken under the Racial Discrimination Act. It was used in the Native Title Act in relation to the process of claims for native title and has been a vexed issue in relation to the whole issue of native title. Much has been said about how the right to negotiate has held up the determination of native title and also the progress of mining and compulsory acquisition for public works. What has happened is that this right to negotiate has been afforded to someone merely by virtue of their lodging a claim. The Waanyi case reduced the threshold, as it was understood. It reduced the claim, so that you did not have to pass a prima facie test.

At civil law if you conduct a case, if you take proceedings, there is a prima facie hurdle over which a claimant must negotiate his or her claim. What we are doing in this legislation is installing an appropriate threshold test which is in accordance with the law across this country and with the understanding of that test as it was when the Native Title Act was originally passed in 1993.

That is terribly important to remember, because the reduction of that threshold test has opened up the application of the right to negotiate so that it now attaches to a claimant who may not have much of a case. A claimant may not have much of a case but, using the right to negotiate, they can still hold up determination of a matter.

I would like to point to another aspect which relates to the competing claims we are experiencing, particularly in the eastern goldfields of my state of Western Australia. We are seeing multiple claims from competing Aboriginal families and clans. That has bred division within Aboriginal communities. This was something which the previous government did not acknowledge nor foresee, despite the fact that we warned them that the way their process was set up would incite division and would not work. We have to streamline it, and we are now doing that, by saying to the Aboriginal community, `You have representative bodies and you can work it out amongst yourselves and then bring forward the appropriate claim.'

That is a sensible thing to do. It will avoid what we have seen to date: the conflicting multiple claims and sad conflict in the various Aboriginal communities. It will also help hasten the determination because the hastening of the process will benefit all; it will benefit everyone. I have pointed to the fact that in four years there has been only one determination of native title and that was in the Mabo decision. That points to a system which does not work. The facts speak for themselves. In this bill we are making it work.

As I said, if we are to achieve reconciliation, it will be by good works, not empty words. My area of responsibility is in the area of education and training. I believe this government has done a great deal in that area. It still has much to do, but we are doing it. There are aspects of health where Minister Wooldridge has embarked on great initiatives and Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, whom I am pleased to see in the chamber tonight, has done a great deal in his portfolio in the area of indigenous affairs.

These are the areas in which we can make a difference. These are the areas where we can achieve reconciliation. But it will not be by introducing legislation into the parliament that does not work. It will not be by raising people's expectations and then seeing them dashed. It will not be by promising them the world and then giving them an atlas.

That is not what we are about. We are about outcomes and achievements—the substance—not the rhetoric that we have been seeing in the nation's press. If the press were serious, they would report some of these initiatives. If the press were serious, they would report those areas which do need attention. If those commentators who call us racist were serious, they would take time out to understand this legislation and also to acquaint themselves with what is being done in the areas where it counts, such as education and health. This legislation is just one part of it. It does not diminish rights. It, in fact, protects them on all sides of the argument. After all, that is what good government is about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 and I want to make it clear from the outset that I, of course, support the amendments that the Labor Party will move to ensure that this bill is not a racist bill, discriminating against a minority group within our community. I cannot get into the detail of the bill or the hundreds of amendments, but I do want to make some general remarks about why I believe it is important for all of us in the Senate to express a view on this bill, not just about the technical part of the amendments but also about the ethics and the moral issues associated with native title and about the style of country we want in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: During my teenage years and early adulthood, the great moral and political issue that I was involved in as a political activist was the Vietnam War and conscription. In the 1970s and through to the 1980s, one of the major issues that also drove me as a political activist was the political vandalism that had been wrought on Australian society through the sacking of the Whitlam government.

Now, in the 1990s, we are faced with the watershed issues of reconciliation, coexistence and native title. Mabo and Wik reflect the essence of these three issues. If they are not dealt with successfully, this country, at its heart, will have a deep and continuing hollowness. Great nations and great peoples have as their basis a moral and ethical heart and it is incumbent upon us, as a national parliament, to provide our nation with that moral and ethical foundation. Unless we can achieve a just outcome for our indigenous citizens, we will have failed in that responsibility.

We, as 18 million people, are extremely fortunate that as a nation we occupy a single continent. We are the only people in the world who have the luxury of having a whole continent to ourselves. But we cannot maintain a fully just and legitimate claim to our continent upon a foundation of continuing dispute with our indigenous population. I do not claim to have a close and detailed involvement with all the issues relating to our indigenous communities, or the development of legislative options to deal with the complexities of native title, but I do know that the issues surrounding this legislation make it clear that, as elected members of this Senate, we cannot shirk our obligation to reach a resolution which will be judged as an honourable, ethical and moral response.

Even before I entered this parliament, I had developed an active interest in issues relating to human rights. I am proud to have been the inaugural chairman of the Australian parliament's committee on human rights. During that time, with other members of the committee, I was exposed to some of the most horrendous accounts of human rights abuses from throughout the world. For instance, I can remember a witness from the Sudanese Refugee Association who gave a horrifying account of slavery in southern Sudan as a result of an awful civil war that still goes on to this day in that area, and that was just one of the endless list of horrifying, gut-wrenching accounts that were given to us as a committee.

BREAK.PARA: As we were considering the numerous abuses that were occurring throughout various places in the world, little did I realise that similar abuses had been taking place in Australia so recently. When I was reading the report of the stolen children Bringing them home earlier this year, after it had been tabled in this parliament, I was shocked by the revelation that as late as the 1970s Australia had its own version of slavery. It is an ugly fact that we cannot escape or hide from and it is a shameful aspect of our history which we must acknowledge.

Not since I was a teenager in the 1950s reading William Shirer's The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich and his chapter on the `final solution' and the extermination of the Jews have I been so moved or so overcome. Bringing them home was even worse because the barbarity was committed in Australia, by Australians and in my lifetime. Although it is an inadequate response as an individual, all I can do is say that l am sorry. I am sorry that the party I am a member of helped perpetrate some of the policies in government which led to a number of the atrocities that are accounted for in Bringing them home.

These three simple words—I am sorry—remind me of an experience in South Africa some years ago. In 1991 I attended, as an official visitor in South Africa, a funeral ceremony just outside Johannesburg for 42 people—young high school students—who had been massacred during those turbulent times at the end of apartheid. There were 25,000 young black people present at this funeral.

One of the people who spoke from the podium in front of the 42 coffins was Dr Beyers Naude. Naude was a white person, an Afrikaner, who had supported the National Party government of South Africa, and thereby apartheid, for many years. But eventually he found it impossible to deny what he knew was a fundamental and moral truth: it was morally wrong. He gave up the struggle between what he knew was wrong and what he knew he should do as a Christian. He was a church leader who was prepared to risk the wrath of a ruthless government and speak out honestly. He stood up for what he knew in his heart to be right, knowing that his Prime Minister would be critical and might declare him a banned person, which he did.

At the funeral he stood and addressed the crowd. In the most moving way, with tears in his eyes, he said, `All I can say to all of you out there'—the 25,000—`is three words: I am sorry.' It is a great pity that our present Prime Minister (Mr Howard) cannot find the same ability to say those three words to our indigenous people: `I am sorry.'

TALK.START.PARA: —He did.

—He has not said that, Senator Herron. As a father, in a personal sense, I can express my sorrow for what other parents and children have been subject to; as an Australian I can express my sorrow for what we have done as a nation. I am, of course, powerless to undo the past; so, too, this parliament is unable to correct the wrongs of history. However, what we can do as a parliament is to act with integrity and honour and do what we can to ensure that the wrongs are brought to an end—we can act to ensure that the principles of Mabo and Wik are upheld.

BREAK.PARA: It is a great tragedy that we have a government and a Prime Minister who seem totally unable or unwilling to provide any real leadership on these issues—a Prime Minister who lacks the generosity of spirit to seek an outcome based on truth and justice, and instead seems to be determined to destroy the progress that has been made over the past few years towards reconciliation and co‐existence.

Reflecting on the last 12 months, it is impossible not to compare the sterile words of our Prime Minister on these issues with those of Lois O'Donoghue, Noel Pearson or the Dodson brothers. The contrast in eloquence and sincerity is immeasurable. Their words will last through the decades ahead, but our Prime Minister's will only ever be remembered as mean-spirited, narrow-minded, devoid of generosity and lacking in vision.

The Labor Party's amendments are a comprehensive response to ensure that this legislation will not shame our nation but will establish a shining monument of which we and our successors will be proud. Well into the future it will be judged as having been an integral step in the process of reconciliation—a great step forward that was made possible by non-government senators standing firm in the face of a mean-spirited conservative government totally incapable of appreciating the importance of this issue to our national fabric.

I want to conclude on a broad theme which I believe expresses the very core of what all these issues are about. They go deeper than just our concept of land title. There is a symbolic importance of which we are all cognisant. Last year, in an appalling and indiscriminate atrocity, a young boy in Cairns was set alight in his schoolyard. Despite his horrific injuries and against all odds he survived that attack. His name was Tjandamurra O'Shane. His courageous struggle for life moved the nation. I was struck—I suspect like many others—by his unusual first name, and it was subsequently explained that he was named by his proud indigenous parents after the great Kimberley Aboriginal warrior, Jandamarra.

I had only ever vaguely heard of Jandamarra, but on further reading I discovered that he was a great warrior with a great natural gift for guerilla military tactics. He was not alone. Through the last century there were many other Aboriginal military leaders who fought to protect their land. In the 1890s, Jandamarra fought to defend the lands of the Bunuba people from European appropriation. Recently, Sir John Gorton, a former Prime Minister, said that Aboriginal title did not exist; they did not understand private ownership. Jandamarra proves Gorton wrong. Jandamarra fought and died defending his land, that is, his native title.

This year is the centenary of Jandamarra's death—he was killed on April Fools' Day in 1897 defending his land. And this mean-spirited government wants to mark the centenary of his death by passing what could be referred to as April Fools' Day legislation. If the legislation was not so discriminatory, not so divisive and not so full of uncertainty, then we could perhaps regard it as nothing more than a joke. But it is far more serious than that.

Of course you will not find Jandamarra's military exploits recorded in any of our school history books. He gets no mention or place of honour in our war memorials. White society does not recognise him as part of our history and has conveniently forgotten his military exploits even though for a period of at least six years he conducted a successful military campaign against overwhelming odds in the Kimberley defending his land. The cynic might argue that we do not celebrate and remember the losers but that ignores the fact that white Australia is prepared to celebrate its most glorious defeat at Gallipoli with a national day of remembrance.

Jandamarra was a great Australian warrior who died fighting for his land, his culture and his freedom. We should celebrate the centenary of his death by voting to ensure that what he died for 100 years ago is established by this parliament—that is, Jandamarra's native title and the title of his successors. And this in a year when we have seen that the courageous spirit of Jandamarra lives on through a little boy in Cairns who carries his name. In the face of a most cowardly attack he has demonstrated bravery that his namesake would be proud of. Let us hope that we can reach an outcome that we can be proud of too.

As I conclude I want to make the observation that, irrespective of the outcome, this parliament will be making a determination on native title without a single indigenous Australian being able to make a contribution in this chamber or in this parliament by casting a vote. At the same time, every other interest of our white society is represented in this place and in the other place. This parliament, this Senate, will not hear the dignified words of a Lois O'Donoghue, the passionate commitment of the Dodson brothers or the soaring eloquence of Noel Pearson, and as a result our parliament is diminished accordingly.

I want to conclude with a quote from a book called Jandamarra and the Bunuba Resistance, by Howard Pederson and Banjo Woorunmurra. This book, which only recently came to my attention, details the history of Jandamarra's resistance and his military exploits. What it points out is that white people wrote Jandamarra up as an outlaw and a criminal when in fact he was a successful military leader defending his people and defending his land. I want to read an extract from the book that certainly gives an understanding of Jandamarra. I quote:
The saga of Jandamarra and the Bunuba resistance is an epic story among many epic stories. . . . There are many Jandamarras who figure in the grim recital of Australia's colonisation.

The Bunuba people are still seeking ownership, management and access to most of their country. Some of the pastoralists whose leases occupy Bunuba land continue to deny the traditional owners access to their country. The State Government does not recognise traditional ownership and therefore refuses to entertain any joint management of national parks. The Bunuba are locked out of any real management of the lands they know better than anybody else. Windjana Gorge, Tunnel Creek, Geikie Gorge and a new national park that takes in much of the Oscar Range are state‐owned and run by public servants who live in Perth. Efforts by the Bunuba people to negotiate a major role in management for the traditional owners have been strenuously resisted by the State Government.

The Bunuba are still waiting for non‐Aboriginal people to negotiate with them on the use of their country. Until there is a negotiated settlement between traditional owners and non‐Aboriginal people today, who continue to benefit from the original invasion and dispossession, the past will remain unresolved and a shared future impossible to plan. The legacy of Jandamarra is the challenge for this nation to achieve a co‐existence of indigenous people and those who have come to live on dispossessed Aboriginal land.

Those are the concluding paragraphs from the book on the history of Jandamarra. They eloquently put the very nub of why the Labor Party is opposing this legislation. The Bunuba people have every right to have native title and access to their traditional lands. They have waited patiently for 100 years and they are still waiting. I hope that this bill is either defeated or seriously amended so that the Bunuba people can achieve their native title by negotiation. If this bill is amended by the Labor Party and other non‐government senators in this place, it will mean a major step forward for reconciliation and coexistence. I have to say that in the week ahead, when there will be many divisions, I hope that I will be able to vote and do my bit in the memory of a great Aboriginal Australian warrior, Jandamarra, but above all else vote in honour of a very brave young boy called Tjandamurra O'Shane, who in the future offers us courage to go on with the job of creating a united Australia where we can all live together. I commend the Labor Party amendments to the Senate and look forward to achieving a great result for our indigenous people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I go to my own remarks on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , might I commend the speech of my colleague Senator Chris Schacht as an intelligent and informed, sensitive and passionate statement. His comments about the Aboriginal warrior Jandamarra, who comes from the Kimberley region of my own state, Western Australia, draw to my mind a similar Aboriginal warrior of great renown called Yagan, who was declared an outlaw and a bandit and was murdered near Greenmount in Western Australia. His statue has now been raised in bronze on Heirisson Island, on the causeway crossing from South Perth to the Perth city area. I am sad to say that, as an act of gross intolerance, that bronze statue has been decapitated twice and now stands without a head on Heirisson Island as a classic example of the intolerance that operates in some parts of our community.

SPEECH.PARA: My speech will be less colourful than Senator Schacht's but, hopefully, I will be able to spend some time analysing some of the implications of this bill in greater detail. I believe that the government's Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 is, in its current form, widely recognised as a flawed piece of legislation that will, unamended, end up in multiple legal challenges in the High Court of Australia. The bill before the Senate is without doubt a recipe for uncertainty. It is because this legislation has had to be navigated through the backbench of the Liberal Party and the coalition, whose every public presentation of views has demonstrated its complete ignorance of the legal framework in which successful legislation should be pursued, that we have this situation.

Labor shares the government's stated desire for greater certainty for all stakeholders, for greater workability of the Native Title Act 1993 and for the resolution of disputes the act seeks to address. The Mabo decision brought Australia into line as the last New World nation with a British common law tradition to recognise the presettlement laws of its indigenous people, giving rise, of course, to native title. At the time there was a need for clarification of the implications for all levels of government and all holders of post‐settlement titles, as well as for potential native title claimants. There were complex legal, social and economic issues to be resolved. There was the prospect at the time of innumerable common law claims for Aboriginal native title from indigenous people, to be conducted without a statutory framework and in the absence of a single piece of case law for guidance. The consequence was a lengthy piece of complex, costly legal action and a great deal of legal and economic uncertainty. The process had the potential to be socially divisive both within the indigenous communities and between the indigenous communities and non‐indigenous Australians. Unlike most conservative political leaders across Australia, the Labor government accepted the concept of native title and set about devising a decent, workable, practical response.

A key element of the response to Mabo was the Native Title Act 1993. The act was the product of extensive and inclusive negotiations with all stakeholders. The process was further enhanced by extensive research on comparable responses in Canada, New Zealand and the United States. The government, we believe, has surrendered certainty for pastoralists and the minerals and resources industry, and decent treatment for the property rights of indigenous Australians, for a false backbench unity—a unity based on a fundamentally mistaken view of this parliament's legislative powers and an ignorance of the certainty to be found in the rule of law.

The Native Title Act aimed to provide a swift, cost‐effective and less legalistic alternative to resolving matters on a case by case basis in common law actions. It established the Native Title Tribunal, and allowed for state governments to set up approved alternative processes.

BREAK.PARA: The clearest immediate outcome from the act was the validation of every previously issued title for every existing titleholder. In particular, it validated potentially invalid past acts of governments, such as grants of interest in lands, since the commencement of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. Simply put, the aim in a prevailing atmosphere of legal uncertainty was to achieve certainty, clarity and workability.

The drafting and passage of the act was carried on in the face of stubborn refusal on the part of the coalition—at the time, the opposition—to engage constructively in the process. It makes a nonsense, I submit, of the claims of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that the flaws in the present act are the sole responsibility of the Labor government. Despite urgings by miners and pastoralists, the Liberal Party in opposition refused to participate constructively in that debate. Labor will not treat either the government or the country in that way on this bill.

The majority of conservative politicians simply rejected outright the concept of native title. They attacked the concept, and they attacked the High Court that had recognised it. The government at the time, the Labor government, took the view that the only lasting certainty for all stakeholders was that which came from consensus; any party aggrieved by the process or the outcome would challenge matters in the courts. That was what Labor's Native Title Act was designed to achieve. Labor's Native Title Act did not create rights; it created a mechanism for recognising and protecting native title rights that had been given recognition by the High Court.

There are many examples where agreements have been made under the framework of our original bill. In Western Australia the Kimberley Land Council has negotiated over 30 agreements, on behalf of native title holders, covering cultural protection, mining and exploration, tourism, aquiculture, and major capital works. Again in Western Australia, Anaconda Nickel negotiated the Murrin Murrin agreements with local Aboriginal communities, showing that cooperation between all stakeholders can, and does, work. Negotiations were carried out between the chief executive officer of Anaconda and Aboriginal elders; as a result, several native title claims were settled without delay to the company's project timing.

In the Murrin Murrin area, which is near Leonora in Western Australia, the company has now completed 23 agreements. They have also given a commitment to the training and employment of Aboriginal people to achieve a target of those people making up 20 per cent of their operational work force. But it has not only occurred in Western Australia.

In Queensland the Hopevale agreement between nine parties covers a broad range of interests and demonstrates how, with effort, complex native title claims can be resolved through mediation. That agreement is between the Queensland government, Telstra, the Australian Maritime Authority, the Cook Shire Council, the Queensland Commercial Fisheries Organisation, Cape Flattery Silica Mine, the Far North Queensland Electricity Corporation, the Cape York Land Council, and the Hopevale Aboriginal Land Council.

I have to say, I now challenge the government's claim that the native title legislation is a mess. Those examples demonstrate that is not true. The claim that the act has created a mess is not sustainable. The High Court recognised it. Labor's act created mechanisms for dealing with it. Labor recognised that native title must be recognised and cannot be legislated away.

The 1993 act is, of course, not perfect. But the coalition opposed it outright in 1993, and chose not to contribute in any way, and moved no amendments. As the incumbent government, it is now their responsibility to improve it—not to make it more unworkable and untenable.

Let me for a moment consider the possibility of legal challenges in the future. The Wik case is a common law claim. It has been in the court since June 1993. It is still there, with matters of substance related to it yet to be determined.

Think of the 600 or so claims currently registered with the tribunal. The failure in the face of a High Court challenge of a badly amended act—an act railroaded through the parliament by an unthinking government—would see all those cases and more clogging up our courts indefinitely. The pastoral industry might survive such an eventuality, but the mining industry would not. We could already be previewing a coming nightmare for the minerals and resources industry in Australia—and particularly Australian society in general.

I turn to the government's amendment bill. The opposition supports the principle that the time is right for amendment. It has always accepted that the original act would in time need to be amended in the light of practical experience in the tribunal and the Federal Court, and in recognition of new case law as it emerged. There are still many problems to be addressed: confusion over the meaning of the native title concept; the expectations that come about from the Mabo and Wik decisions; unsustainable claims, multiple claims and overlapping claims; the failure to set up appropriate state tribunals; and the failure to adequately resource the whole system.

Take the virtual gridlock in the current situation in Kalgoorlie. With its maze of overlapping, opposing and sometimes unsustainable claims, it is impacting on mining, residential development and daily life in that area. It is a dramatic example of the need for considered sustainable change to the act in the interests of all parties.

It is in the national interest that the act balance and reconcile, to the maximum possible extent, the interests and reasonable expectations of both indigenous and non-indigenous Australians, and of all of the stakeholders—be they miners, farmers, or the Australian taxpayer. It is in the interests of all Australians that they not give up on the possibility of achieving reconciliation.

The debate before us is about how Australians, our legal system and our governments recognise native title. The right to native title exists. Those rights have been recognised by the High Court as fundamental legal property rights. They are entitled to the same respect and protection as the property rights of non-indigenous Australians. The issue is how to deal with them.

The solution lies in recognising rights in an equal way, respecting Australia's tradition of European law and respecting indigenous law and native title. Both laws exist and are deserving of respect. They can both coexist. Coexistence can allow the mutual enjoyment of our land to be determined by discussion and agreement. In essence, it is about reconciliation.

I believe this nation is mature enough, compassionate enough and wise enough for indigenous and non-indigenous Australians to live together, indigenous and non-indigenous cultures to coexist side by side and the rights and interests attached to them to coexist. This government must come to understand that there is an overriding need to guarantee the constitutional validity of this legislation. That validity can be critically threatened unless it operates for the benefit of indigenous Australians.

Failure to act in a fashion that upholds the essence of the original act places at risk things that must be done now to ensure expeditious access for commercial interests vital to our national economy. This bill is seriously deficient, and it requires substantial amendment. Our areas of greatest concern include the fact that the validation provisions exceed anything necessary for addressing any real or perceived problems flowing from the Wik decision. The bill is racially discriminatory because it takes away rights from one group on the basis of race. Its provisions, if accepted, would extinguish native title rights in some cases and diminish them in others.

The government's measures purporting to confirm the extinguishment of native title through past grants of exclusive tenure involve massive over‐reach. The legislation provisions, including the schedule, do far more than confirm the current state of the common law as asserted by the government. They involve the extinguishment of surviving common law rights. It is vital that pastoralists are permitted to fully enjoy all the entitlements they have been granted under their various tenures. Both the 1993 act and the Wik decision affirm that their rights extinguish native title to the extent of any inconsistency. We will support any amendments that give greater certainty and clarity to that reality. Any amendments that invite legal challenge must undermine certainty.

Where it seeks to introduce a sunset clause, this is simply a recipe for ambit claims and guarantees a return to expensive and complex common law claims after six years. This bill must be made more practical. It must provide a genuinely attractive alternative to common law claims. It must address the legitimate need of all stakeholders. Above all, it must be decent and it must retain the beneficial status of the original act. If it does not do so, it will surely fail in the High Court.

I must assert the fact that the cultures of this nation can coexist. We can all enjoy our rights to our collective benefit in our own best interests and in the best interests of the nation. This bill is clearly not a bill that is in our own best interests and the best interests of Australia. This is the minimum achievable bill in a backbench deeply hostile to the concept of native title and deeply ignorant of the operation of the law of this nation in relation to it. It reflects surrender by this government to backbench pressure; it is not a solution.

The coalition came to power saying that it would make the Native Title Act workable. It said that it would consult widely before it introduced any amendments. The Prime Minister has not consulted widely and, by being intransigent in his position, is forgetting his role in leading the parliament and the country through this critical debate.

The government's amendment bill is divisive and has potentially huge costs in terms of time, money and human suffering. The opposition has been advised that it is potentially unconstitutional, and still the government continues to withhold its legal advice on this question, which leads the country towards further suspicion of its motives. The Prime Minister has also been very slow to hit back against the racist comments being made in Australia—to hit back against Pauline Hanson for one. He will still not apologise to indigenous Australians in line with the recommendations of the stolen generation report.

At a time when the Prime Minister and the government should be showing leadership on native title, it is now too sadly evident that they are not able to do so. In fact, they appear not to want to do so and are prepared to talk about race based elections. Australia's international reputation is being put at risk by the attitude of a government that has stubbornly continued to press ahead with a bill that will go on to be proven as racially discriminatory.

We intend to cooperate with the government to overcome the problems that it has with its backbench to produce a piece of workable legislation. On behalf of the needs of this country for certainty and the desire of all Australians to achieve that certainty, we offer cooperation to the government. But, to achieve coexistence, to achieve reconciliation, it will require this government to move away from its political motivations and its scaremongering that currently underpin its approach.

This chamber is in the midst of a debate on a bill which is capable of being concluded with some consensus and which is capable of producing an expeditious and effective result. It will require cooperation and some change of mind by the government to achieve a consensus based outcome. But, at present, that objective is not contained in this bill. So the opposition will not support the government's amendments.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.27 p.m. to 7.30 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I commence my speech tonight on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , I would like to acknowledge the traditional owners of Canberra and the Australian Capital Territory, the Ngunnawal people, whose traditional land we stand upon. Also, as a South Australian senator, like yourself, Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to acknowledge the women of the Coorong, known as Hindmarsh Island. I send a message to them that they have not been forgotten by the Australian Democrats, even if they think that they may have been forgotten by other parties in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to send my solidarity on behalf of myself and my party to the tent city that is currently being held in Victoria Square in Adelaide this week. I salute those wonderful men and women—indigenous and non-indigenous—who are committed to reconciliation and peaceful coexistence. I refer to women such as Sandra Saunders, Shirley Peasley and Nicola Guerin and men such as Brian McDermott, all of whom have played a vital role in the reconciliation process in my home state and in the formation of ANTaR and Women for Wik.

Two weeks ago I was honoured and privileged to address the Women for Wik rally in Victoria Square in Adelaide. Like the sea of hands rally on Tuesday, there was an inspiring number of men and women—members of the community—who turned up to display their commitment to the principles of reconciliation. Women for Wik is a grassroots movement that exists on a national basis and includes all political persuasions, different ethnic groups, business and industry groups, church groups, the arts, different professions, universities, the rural sector and political parties. It is also linked with national women's organisations.

Since the launch of Women for Wik in Sydney in July there has been a mushrooming of Women for Wik groups all over the nation, certainly in all capital cities and many other regional centres. Many thousands of women are involved, including Dame Roma Mitchell, the former Governor of South Australia, Jane Lomax Smith, our current Lord Mayor of Adelaide, Hazel Hawke, Caroline Jones, Margaret Whitlam, Ruth Cracknell, Jane Campion, Jan Chapman, Professor Marie Bashir, Anne Deveson and Rachel Ward. These are just a number of the many women involved in Women for Wik.

I pay tribute to these women. They were inspired by Lady Deane's call at the National Reconciliation Conference—the call that Australian women should take the lead in putting the reconciliation process back on track. I am proud to say that the women of Australia have taken her at her word and mobilised one of the most powerful national grassroots women's movements seen in this country—certainly one of the most powerful national and grassroots movements we have seen since the Vietnam War, according to some commentators. I pay tribute to Lady Deane and to her husband, the Governor-General, Sir William Deane. Some commentators have said that he has at times provided a conscience for this nation. I concur with those sentiments.

Tonight I would like to take the opportunity to speak a little about the role of reconciliation in terms of native title. As we have stated many times, the Australian Democrats believe that native title is the cornerstone of national reconciliation in this country. I wish to acknowledge the outstanding work of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. Throughout the long consultative process, the council, the composition of which includes indigenous as well as non-indigenous people, has developed some valuable principles. In short, the council sees reconciliation as dependent upon its vision—that is, a united Australia which respects this land of ours, values the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander heritage and provides justice and equity for all.

Like many people in this place—and certainly many thousands of members of the community—on Tuesday I went to the sea of hands rally. I was proud to be a part of that inspiring event, the second sea of hands rally on the lawns. It was inspiring because it served as a reminder—a timely one at that—of the great number of Australians who are committed to reconciliation and peaceful existence. It was inspiring because so many different sectors, many people and different religious groups were represented at this event. At least 100,000 Australians pledged their support by placing or supporting a hand.

I am only sorry that the display of such hands in the Senate chamber this week was objected to by one member in this place. He objected, as is his right, to advertising in the Senate chamber. Honourable senators, I was not advertising anything. I was promoting, along with Senator Lees and Senators Allison, Bartlett, Woodley and Murray, peaceful coexistence. If we are ashamed of promoting that, we should hang our heads in shame.

Today I wear the armband in honour of peaceful coexistence and justice. I wonder if any senator would deny me or my colleagues this opportunity, because I will take an arm band over a blindfold any day. Ignorance and fear should not run this debate, and too often it has. As a member of this parliament, I have been ashamed in recent days of some of the statements I have heard from some politicians and their determined ignorance about Aboriginal and Islander people in the reconciliation process.

Reconciliation is vital to the healing of Australia's spirit and to our maturing as a nation. This legislation threatens to undermine the reconciliation process. Reconciliation is about addressing disadvantage. It is about understanding the causes of disadvantage, the legacy of history and the dispossession of Aboriginal people. But most of all, reconciliation is about relationships. I am talking about relationships so poignantly encapsulated by the images of Gladys Tybingoompa and Camilla Cowley in front of the `Sea of hands'—that wonderful glorious picture—encompassed by the Jurrang people, who we heard about today in the Democrat party room. Their agreement to share access to the Scott Creek station in the Northern Territory recognises both their rights—the right of those people—and the pastoralists on whom that station is based. It respects both their rights and their love of that particular piece of land.

Reconciliation is about the relationships such as those forged in the Democrat party room this morning between my male and female colleagues in the Australian Democrats and the visiting delegation of women from the Northern Land Council who had come to express their views on cultural aspects of native title and, of course, the proposed amendments before us. I acknowledge their women, land and culture statement, which Senator Bob Collins read during his speech on the second reading debate in the chamber on Monday night. I commend that statement to all members of this place.

Their message this morning reinforced what we have been told by many groups in the community. Only last night I was told by Jason Glanville, formerly the indigenous youth policy officer of the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition, `You cannot separate native title from reconciliation.' The Democrats have heard this message; we accept this message.

Nor can you separate the life and culture of the Aboriginal people from their land, and, in trying to do so, this government is striking directly at the life and culture of indigenous Australians. You cannot separate the stolen children and other shameful events from present disadvantages suffered by indigenous people. You cannot separate history from the present. If I hit you yesterday, don't you have some redress today? What is the statute of limitations on the invasion of a country or the massacre of people, on stealing their children and the loss of much of their culture?
As the pamphlet distributed by Women for Wik states:
. . . we can not bring the children (of the stolen generation) home, but we can ensure that their Native Title rights are not taken away.

Unity in spite of, or perhaps because of, diversity comes from a heartfelt recognition of the Women for Wik statement. That statement is that any amendment of the Native Title Act which leads to extinguishment of native title is the end of the reconciliation process. The Democrats believe this. We are proud supporters of the reconciliation process and we vehemently oppose any attempts to undermine this process, whether it is through the spreading of fish and chip myths about Aboriginal and Islander people or whether it is the introduction of racist legislation and regressive laws into this place.

The government's response to the High Court Wik decision is really the next step in a series of measures that have come from this federal government which have targeted those most marginalised in our community and often have impacted most harshly on women. The government's response demonstrates a profound lack of respect for decisions of the High Court. Surely, that sends a message to nearly every Australian citizen about the surety of their rights as upheld in law. As Noel Pearson has pointed out many times, aren't these white traditional laws the very laws and traditions that apparently we are all taught to revere and respect?

I believe, as do my colleagues, that the Wik decision—the High Court's decision—was a fair decision. It was a just decision. It was one that actually achieved compromise. No‐one should be in a position to resist this; no‐one should want to resist this decision. To many, it encompassed compromise, a sharing of rights and a sharing of access to land. It was about minimising conflict. Who can forget those joyous pictures of Gladys Tybingoompa in front of the High Court dancing at the outcome. It should have been a positive decision and one that the government could reflect on and respond to positively.

I acknowledge that there are some parts of the Wik bill that are non‐controversial, such as the Brandy amendments, which all parties and indigenous groups have agreed are positive and necessary amendments. I might acknowledge most of them were proposed by, or introduced by, the former government. These amendments would have improved the Native Title Act. Instead, this bill is being used as an excuse by the government to extinguish native title. This government's amendments before us represent the single most comprehensive attempt by any government to dispossess indigenous Australians of their land.

The main concerns that the Democrats have with this bill have been outlined on a number of occasions by my honourable colleagues. They include several main areas: the possible windfall gains from the upgrade of leasehold to freehold leases; actual and de facto extinguishment; the sunset clause; and the watering down of the right to negotiate. We do strongly oppose and object to any loss of the right to negotiate and we condemn the idea of a sunset clause—simply because who else's rights in this society are subject to a sunset clause?

We know that this bill is dubious on a number of grounds, and the one that has been the main focus has been the constitutional ground. We know this because a number of reports, including the report of our very own Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee, have found this legislation constitutionally questionable.

The Democrats are not just relying on the High Court or constitutional lawyers to tell us what is or what is not racially discriminatory. We actually believe it is the responsibility of politicians—that is, of legislators—and these two chambers to make moral and value judgments all the time. We should not be in a position to refer the hard judgments to the judiciary. Clearly, in our view, the Howard amendments treat indigenous rights to land differently from those of other Australians, and we cannot, in all conscience, support that.

Politicians make moral judgments all the time. Our job is not to second‐guess legal decisions yet to be made. This government has been clear. These amendments, by the government's own admission, depend on the races power to become law. What a sad indictment on Australia in 1997.

I should acknowledge that there are exciting developments in the reconciliation process in Australia in 1997. I would like to commend to the chamber the recent publication of a document by the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition called Compact 98. It is about young people for reconciliation. This organisation has committed itself to working in the area of reconciliation until that vision is realised, and they are documenting the tangible actions of its organisations and its members and friends and supporters. This document shows that young Australians care about the nation and care about its future—as I am sure all honourable members do. In this document they point out that this involves acknowledging past wrongs.
