It means rejoicing in the wonders of this land, including the peaceful and tolerant environment in which most of us have been raised, and celebrating and respecting our environment and our natural resources—the great land and sea of this country.
I noted that one senator, in his speech this week, said:
It is foolish to make native title into a single symbolic `totem‐pole' gesture expected to give solutions overnight.
But this is a totem‐pole gesture. This legislation is extraordinarily symbolic. In fact, I suspect it is more symbolic than some of us perhaps will ever know.

This bill was an opportunity to respond in a constructive and positive way to the Wik decision of the High Court. Instead, it has been used to undermine the rights of indigenous Australians and to emasculate some of the rights that the Native Title Act has provided. It is also an opportunity to send a message to the world; and this bill does go against international trends, with the rights of indigenous people to political sovereignty being popularly asserted all over the world.

Australia has been prepared to use, and I think quite rightly, international forums to call attention to human rights abuses in other parts of the world. But we must respond when the same tools are being pointed at us. I am sure that if our foreign affairs and trade spokesperson, Senator Vicki Bourne, were here tonight she would comment further on the international obligations we have as a nation and also the implications in terms of international laws and treaties regarding this bill.

In the few minutes remaining, I wish to return to the issue of young people and reconciliation. I note that many young people—whether it was at the sea of hands, or Women for Wik, or in the many faxes, phone calls and letters that have come to our offices—have expressed their opposition to this bill. They have put forward their voices in support of reconciliation. Their voices should not be ignored in this process. I acknowledge the National Union of Students and their poster which has just been released which refers to this bill. It quite accurately referred to this bill as the `final act of dispossession'.

Why continue to perpetuate injustice? Are young people of today going to have to explain to their grandchildren that this government extinguished native title? The Howard government is creating history; yet I am scared and concerned that it will be a history of which we will be ashamed. We should be looking to the future. We should be working out how we can nourish indigenous culture.

Most indigenous Australians are actually under the age of 23—and incredibly young on average. A 1994 Australian Bureau of Statistics survey showed that many indigenous young Australians maintain strong cultural links, with more than half identifying with a clan, tribal or language group. More than two- thirds recognised homelands where they had ancestral and cultural links and almost one in five spoke an indigenous language. I believe that many of these young Australians—indigenous and non-indigenous—have a positive cultural identity. There are an increasing number of individuals who have survived racism and dispossession who are successful role models to indigenous and non-indigenous Australians.

I do not doubt some of the comments I heard in the chamber tonight—in particular from the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Senator Ellison, when he said, `Of course it is important to ensure that we put money into education, training and welfare for indigenous students and young indigenous people.' But why is the government cutting programs like the CDEP? Why have we seen $48 million worth of cuts to Abstudy programs? Why have we seen cuts to legal aid and ATSIC? Why have we seen increased fees and charges for young people who want to enter education and training institutions when these very groups that we have been talking about—indigenous people—are traditionally not only under‐represented in these institutions but completely unrepresented in some cases?

TALK.START.PARA: —Conveniently forgetting the extra $140 million I have put into indigenous education.

—I welcome the interjection, because I will commend any increase in funding, direct or otherwise, that supports indigenous and non-indigenous Australians in education and training. But, when you take $48 million out—if you are talking about putting $140 million in—you add on to that the kinds of cuts that you have made to university education generally and then suggest that scholarships are going to somehow facilitate the path to education and training for Aboriginal and Islander people, when Aboriginal and Islander people have a one in 4,000 chance of getting one of those scholarships into an institution like Sydney University. This government should hang its head in shame. How dare it use the words `education', `training' and `welfare' in relation to indigenous people and expect that we actually believe it is doing something meaningful to increase participation rates.
—With an extra $140 million.
—And how much have you taken out: $1.8 billion and you put an extra $140 million in—extraordinary.
—One hundred and forty million dollars extra into indigenous education, and you know it.
—In the minutes remaining, I do not want to talk about propping up Aboriginal communities.

Senator Vanstone and Senator Chapman, it has been the practice during the course of this debate not to interject and interrupt other senators when they are making their contribution. I am quite happy to extend that courtesy. But I think it is stretching the bounds of that courtesy to expect senators to sit here and allow another senator to claim—
—Senator Vanstone, there is no point of order. Could you—
—I have not finished what I was going to say.
—Senator Vanstone, you have not made a point of order. You are raising a point about some other time. It has been the practice during the course of this debate—
—No, I am not raising—
—If you have a point of order, can you quickly make it.
—The point of order is that, in my view, it is not in the liberty of the chair to direct that there will not be interjections during a speech. I will leave it with you.
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I was quite happy to acknowledge the senator's interjections because it gave me the opportunity to show how dismal funding and opportunities are in this nation for young people generally, but indigenous people in particular, when it comes to education and training access. This is not about propping up indigenous people or providing token amounts of welfare for education, or training or health which has been referred to. It is actually about justice. It is about recognising a social compact that looks at rights, land and native title.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally tonight I would like to send a message to the women of Hindmarsh Island and echo the sentiments of my acting leader, Senator Meg Lees: we have not forgotten you. To the Njareengerri women, like Doreen Kartinyeri and her many sisters, and of course to my wonderful friend and role model Betty Fisher, we salute your courage and persistence in light of the vilification of your beliefs, your spirituality and your culture. The state sponsored inquisition into your culture and secret business will go down in the shame pages of our history.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

Just as the decision by this Government—with the acquiescence of the Opposition—to build a bridge on your land remains a shameful part of our recent history and a reminder that the injustices against you continue.

Honourable senators, we are faced with a moral and political choice. This is not simply about constitutional questions. It is about the rights and justice of indigenous Australians. It is a totem pole—it is about the way we want to shape our nation's future and how we want to live as we approach the new millennium. I urge honourable senators to vote for meaningful reconciliation and for justice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —It really is quite sad to see that Senator Stott Despoja has chosen to continue the campaign of misinformation and misrepresentation with regard to the intent and effect of this government's Native Title Amendment Bill . This bill responds to the community's call for certainty and the government's election commitment to restore certainty to native title processes throughout Australia. While the Liberal and National Parties accepted the principles behind the Mabo and, more recently, the Wik High Court decisions, the Native Title Act itself was identified as being unworkable from the outset.

SPEECH.PARA: As of last Monday afternoon, 676 claimant applications have been lodged with the Native Title Tribunal. However, in the five years since the Mabo judgment there has been only one native title determination on mainland Australia, resolved through the court and through long processes of negotiation and with $210 million of taxpayers' funds spent.

Throughout this time there has been uncertainty, disagreement and misunderstanding within communities as decisions, development and progress have stalled. In these five years lawyers and advisers have made a fortune. Scaremongers have whipped the nation into a frenzy, pitting black against white, black against black, white against white and country against city, claiming and counterclaiming and all the while muddying the waters.

The government parties accept the Mabo judgment, which gave indigenous Australians native title rights under the common law. The government parties recognise the special circumstances of Aboriginal people and the need for a system of Aboriginal land administration. However, the previous Labor government's Native Title Act also gave the right for claimants to negotiate on future development on their land with regard to mining activity and compulsory acquisition for government purposes without any clear guidelines on who could claim, no deadlines on when to claim and no limits on compensation available to be sought.

The fact that there has been an appalling lack of development in the resource rich areas of Australia demonstrates problems in the exercising of this right to negotiate. Successful self-determination for indigenous Australians is linked to them taking their place in the national economy. This will not happen without amendments that tighten up the way the right to negotiate is currently applied. When negotiation rights hold development to ransom, the main casualties are Aboriginal people as well as the broader Australian community.

The claims under the Mabo legislation all still stand and are yet to be resolved. The Wik decision raised new uncertainties when the High Court found, by the narrow margin of four judges to three, that pastoral leases, after all the assurances to the contrary, do not extinguish all native title. This effectively meant that nearly 80 per cent of this country would have to go through the time consuming and costly negotiation and litigation processes.

The Wik decision said native title could coexist with pastoral leases. Coexistence has not been taken to mean just that traditional people can have access to pastoral lands for ceremonies, hunting, site visitation and similar purposes. It has actually been taken to mean that they have a right to have a say in respect of all development on the land.

We have also seen several legal claims by Aboriginal groups actually asking for use and enjoyment of the land to the exclusion of all others. At the negotiation table, the virtual effect of the Wik judgment has therefore been that, unless an agreement is reached that is satisfactory to the native title claimants, the development proposal on the land subject to claim has no hope of proceeding. This is entirely unsatisfactory.

The government gave a commitment to Australia that it would tidy up the mess of the Native Title Act. We have heard that our amendments to the Native Title Act extinguish native title on pastoral leases—and that false claim was again perpetrated by Senator Stott Despoja in her remarks earlier this evening.

BREAK.PARA: This was certainly the preferred action by the National Farmers Federation, but the fact is our amendments do not extinguish native title. Those who are seeking even further negotiation and compromise on this legislation need to be reminded that these amendments are already a massive compromise between pastoral interests on the one hand and indigenous interests on the other. By identifying exactly what functions in running a pastoral business are to be exempt from the right to negotiate, the bill confirms the Wik decision, which said that pastoral activities take precedence over native title activities. It gets rid of the possible and probable need to negotiate continually with the native title claimants on issues where clearly pastoral interests need to take precedence.

I recall watching the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, on the 7.30 Report on 11 November. He made it all sound so simple for native title to coexist with pastoral interests. He painted a picture to the 7.30 Report audience, asking them to imagine more than 50,000 square kilometres of pastoral land, land on which only a few cattle grazed, and asking why Aboriginal people cannot just roam around on it.

Mr Keating said that the Mabo legislation and the extended application of that legislation under the Wik determination simply give Aboriginal people common law rights and these amendments will take away those common law rights. The fact is that the Mabo legislation gave native title claimants statutory rights over and above common law rights, thereby giving them more rights than any other land-holder.

The right to negotiate is not a common law right. It is not a right enjoyed by all Australians. It is in fact a right based on race given by the previous government's Native Title Act. Pastoralists do not have a right to negotiate. If road authorities want to build a road through land subject to native title, the government has to negotiate with the claimants in the hope of arriving at an agreement as to where the road will go and what amount of compensation will be payable. The amount will be determined by how much the claimants agree to accept.

In marked contrast to this, if the road authorities wish to build a road through non-native title pastoral land, they simply advise the leaseholder or land-holder and pay compensation which is based on the market value of the land needed to be excised for the road. It is clear that the right to negotiate enjoyed by traditional claimants has gotten completely out of hand.

For further confirmation of this consider that in many cases several indigenous groups are all claiming the same area of land. In South Australia, where there are 27 separate parcels of land subject to native title claim, each parcel of land has two or more competing groups making claim. Mining companies and governments alike do not really know with whom to negotiate. Once the rightful claimants have been established, the battle lines over compensation begin with enormous demands in terms and compensation sought. If these demands are not met there is a stalemate.

All pastoral leaseholders and freeholders, regardless of race, have the right to negotiate with private developers. But in the case of compulsory acquisition by the government for infrastructure needs or for other public purpose or for mineral extraction the pastoral lessee or freeholder must accept the situation and surrender the land.

Mr Keating the other night went on to say that his government always meant for Aborigines to be able to negotiate by all under the common law. He said that the right to veto was never intended and that if the traditional owners did not negotiate then the respective state's land minister could always make the final decision. Can you imagine that? Each time a state minister would step in to make a final decision they would be accused of being racially motivated. Then it would be off to the High Court again where a decision would be held up for years.

The right to negotiate given to Aboriginal people was left wide open in the hope that this right would be sensitively applied and based on goodwill. Many of us enjoy goodwill with our neighbours. We coexist in our home streets and we try not to impinge on the rights or lifestyles of our neighbours. If two neighbours get on and there are plans put, for instance, to extend a house, the other neighbours will not mind or they might even share the costs of building a common fence. With goodwill the project goes ahead. There may be some adjustments made and there may be some fair compensation agreed.

However, if the neighbours do not cooperate, there will be appeals, the development application will be held up and eventually there will be arbitration. There will be a decision made and maybe an amount of compensation payable. In contrast, where native title is involved the negotiation remains open ended. This must not be allowed to continue. If a pastoral leaseholder is to co‐exist with native titleholders it has to be based on goodwill and a willingness to adjust to each other's needs.

Point 10 of the bill's 10-point plan refers to the setting up of indigenous land use agreements. Both pastoralists and native titleholders need to know their rights in respect of the land and, once the boundaries are drawn, be able to co‐exist and respect each other's rights to use the land. Without the boundaries being clearly defined in law, we cannot expect or respect any consideration between those in co‐existence.

Questions of privacy, liability in the case of accidents, use of existing property infrastructure and interference in each other's business are the real questions to be faced if we are to have co‐existence. Issues of security and privacy must be addressed. City residents will be unwilling to allow strangers, possibly with firearms and alcohol, into their homes or business premises. It would be a concern in the city, and it is an even greater concern in the pastoral areas where the nearest police are hours away.

Goodwill and cooperation are not fostered when the right to claim and negotiate is applied and dealt with in a racially discriminating way. Under the current legislation, it is the pastoralists who have to accept or else disprove the co‐existence of titles. If co‐existence is accepted, pastoralists face the uncertainty of trying to thrash out negotiations—perhaps in the absence of goodwill. If they do not accept the claim, they face paying the court costs in defending against the claim—in money and in precious time.

There is an attitude that Wik only affects the big pastoral stations sparsely stocked with cattle. The reality is that every bit of spare land in country towns was originally a pastoral lease. Much of it then became government land or crown land. Since the Wik decision, there has been a rush of ambit claims on this land and prime development sites, often just for the possibility of large compensation payouts if governments become desperate to acquire spare land for public infrastructure and housing.

Point 7 in our 10-point plan provides for the compulsory acquisition of land inside cities and towns for the purpose of government type infrastructure. Native titleholders would gain the same procedural and compensation rights as other land-holders. This, in effect, means that the common laws will apply equally to all land-holders regardless of race and without discrimination. Aboriginal people were given a superior negotiating position through the Native Title Act and many have taken unreasonable advantage of that position.

Greed has ensured that the Native Title Act has been unworkable. The massive claims on everything possible made it unworkable. The time taken for arbitration made it unworkable. The conflicting claimants made it unworkable. Genuine claims have been lost in the land grab.

The uncertainty is very apparent in the mining industry, particularly in South Australia. More than 45 per cent of South Australia is covered by pastoral leases, most of which are covered by native title claims. Development and investment in the mining industry has been stifled by the uncertainty of Wik and the ongoing delay in the grant and operation of mining tenements.

Because of native title legislation and questions resulting from Wik, the ability of mining companies to access tenements to carry out exploration has become increasingly difficult. The South Australian Department of Mines and Energy has not been able to grant new opal tenements on Lambina station. One hundred opal mining applications cannot be dealt with until the right to negotiate process has been completed. They are subject to native title claim because they are located on pastoral leases.

Mining applications on two gold and silver leases at O'Leary on the Wadnaminga Goldfield have been held up. In the Riverland, near Renmark, a company had a lease over a sandhill for the removal of sand. Because of the complexities and costs associated with negotiation over native title, the company has given up and has left the area.

The District Council of Le Hunte, on the Eyre Peninsula, has been trying to encourage the South Australian granite industry. There has been some very keen interest from Italy, with some areas being pegged for mining. This cannot go ahead until the negotiation process is completed.

In Gawler Craton, the most prospective mining area of South Australia, and probably Australia, several new mining discoveries cannot start mining because of native title claims. It was expected that these discoveries would have been in production by now, and it is feared that some of the companies involved are beginning to get cold feet because of the delays.

In Coober Pedy a South Australian government and Indonesian joint venture planned to trial new technology that could turn fairly low grade iron ore and coal into higher grade product. It is now subject to a native title claim. As a result of that, the core samples needed to test the new technology cannot be mined. South Australia simply cannot afford to lose these opportunities because of the shortcomings of the Keating government legislation. South Australia desperately needs the passage of this bill.

Let me summarise. Throughout Australia farming families need certainty that they can continue to run their properties. This will provide $27.5 billion to the Australian economy. Mining, currently worth $40 billion per year, is essential for economic growth, investment and jobs. This government wants to see Aboriginal people participate in realising the potential of Australia.

It is important to recognise that 353,000 Aborigines, representing two per cent of Australia's population, already own 15 per cent of the country as freehold, leasehold or crown land. This is equivalent to 117 million hectares, an area larger than New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania and the ACT combined.

Aboriginal people can still negotiate to be partners with the mining companies and still lay native title claims on some 79 per cent of this country as a result of the government's proposed amendments. The Aboriginal land acquisition fund will continue to provide $45 million every year forever for Aboriginal people to buy pastoral leases and other land.

Native title legislation is but one of the issues and policies relevant to the special needs of Aboriginal Australians. This government has done more for Aboriginal Australia in the areas of housing, health, alcohol and substance abuse, education and economic development than Labor has and we will continue to do so. It is this government's aim that Aboriginal Australians take an equal place in our society.

The legislation is a fair and reasonable solution to the problems created by the High Court's decisions and the previous government's inadequate legislation. That is why the gross misrepresentation being perpetrated about its intent and effect is extremely disappointing. In recent weeks the rhetoric has reached a crescendo, fuelled by mischievous statements from the Labor opposition.

It is indeed unfortunate that for political gain the Labor Party is prepared to peddle their fictions in the face of overwhelming fact. Perhaps it is to be expected that we would get such misrepresentation from the Labor Party. Perhaps it is also to be expected from their barrackers in the media. However, the many faithful Christian church‐goers, especially those from the bush, are entitled to expect better than they have been given by some of our church leaders.

It might be too much to expect fair comment on this legislation from the various church so-called commissions for social responsibility and the like, whose pontifications are barely distinguishable from similar secular political lobby groups. But it is the responsibility of archbishops and similar church leaders, if they are going to exercise their right to speak, to do so on a properly informed basis. This they have failed to do and are therefore guilty of perpetuating and extending the misinformation about this legislation.

Their theology is also open to question. One can understand and accept the historical links of Aboriginal people to the land in a secular sense and support sensible legislative recognition of this, as this legislation does. But it seems, at least in certain areas, that link is also imbued with non‐Christian religious significance. To the extent that this is the case, it is quite contrary to the commands of the Christian gospel for Christian leaders to be promoting such icons of non‐Christian belief.

I do not share the view of my colleague Mr Entsch that congregations should boycott their churches. The church is its lay congregation, not just its leaders. Fellow Christians should be seeking guidance to make their leaders accountable rather than boycotting them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I say at the outset that this was always going to be a difficult second reading debate, which has continued from Tuesday night into today. It has not been made any easier by Senator Schacht entering the chamber. I would remind you, Senator Schacht, that only a couple of hours ago I sat for 20 minutes and listened to you in silence.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Schacht, it has been the practice of this debate, at least an endeavour on the part of senators in this debate, to listen to one another in silence. I would appreciate if the same treatment could be afforded Senator Ferguson as should have been afforded Senator Chapman.

—I know it is a little bit above Senator Schacht to do that. I do not expect him to remain quiet for 20 minutes, although I did while he spoke and made some remarks over which I had to restrain myself very carefully. But I did listen, Senator Schacht, and I would implore you to do the same.

SPEECH.PARA: This was always going to be a very difficult debate because there are strongly held views by people on both sides of this chamber. If we cannot hold strongly held views in this democracy of Australia and express them in this chamber without being abused or ridiculed by anybody, then I think that the democracy of Australia will suffer badly.

Along with the majority of people in this chamber, I do not understand the intricacies of this bill. I am the first to admit it. I am sure that many other senators would also. There are only half a dozen senators who have spent hours and hours—some over the last 18 months and some over the last few months—poring over the amendments, poring over the intricacies of the bill, who actually understand every single piece of it. We all understand the general thrust, but very few understand the intricacies of it. So it is not my intention to try to speak about those intricacies.

I would like to make a comment about one or two things that have been said by previous speakers, including Senator Schacht, if he likes to stay for another couple of minutes. In opening the debate for the opposition, Senator Bolkus said very early in his speech:
This debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997, a bill of fundamental concern to them, is taking place without a single indigenous Australian sitting here with a voice and a vote.

Those sentiments were echoed by Senator Schacht in a speech just before dinner this evening. The question I put to Senator Schacht is: why isn't there an indigenous person on your side of the chamber if you are so concerned? You have had 97 years of this federal parliament to elect an Aboriginal or indigenous person to your side of the chamber, and you have not done it. So for you to bemoan the fact—

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't accuse you. I didn't say it was the Liberal Party.

—You have had your turn. Let me say that Senator Schacht made those claims, and if he is going to bemoan the fact that they have not got anybody on that side then they should look to their own preselection methods, they should look to their own party and make sure that somebody is there. You have never elected an indigenous person to your side of the Senate. The Greens, who have spoken so strongly in support of the Indigenous Working Group, have never elected an indigenous person to the Senate. The Democrats, to this stage, have never elected an indigenous person to the Senate. The only party that has elected an indigenous person to represent them in this chamber is the Liberal Party. Senator Schacht and Senator Bolkus, who both got up and bemoaned the fact that there is no indigenous person to have a vote, should first look to their own party and find out why it has not happened. Senator Bolkus went on to say a number of other things which I will speak on at a later stage.

SPEECH.PARA: In the run‐up to this debate, which has taken a considerable time, the bill having gone through the House of Representatives first and then being introduced into the Senate, there has been a lot of public speculation, a lot of misinformation, and a lot of public debate in the media in particular as to what should happen to this bill. The media have also represented those people who they claim have some moral right or some knowledge of the way this bill is put together and how it will affect people.

As a rural person who has spent most of my life until I came to this place with my only form of radio being the ABC—and this government has funded the ABC for many years now in its role as an independent broadcaster—what saddens me is that this debate has seen the ultimate demise of the only independent broadcaster within this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have attacked the church, you have attacked the ABC. Who is next?

—I did say that I had heard Senator Schacht in silence, but he seems determined that I should not be heard at all. I need to cite some examples, because I think it is only fair after making a statement like that that I should cite some examples of why I believe that the independence is no longer there. It is not a view that is only mine; it is a view that is shared by a lot of people throughout the Australian community today.

SPEECH.PARA: After the commencement of this debate on Tuesday night I listened carefully to the reports the next morning. The only people who were quoted were those who opposed the bill. Again, a later stage, when it came to television there was only a person who opposed the bill.

Another example was the news only an hour or so ago before I came in here tonight. The first item on the news was an item of interest regarding the current situation in New Guinea and its Prime Minister. Whom did they seek to get a response from on the Channel 2 news tonight? Not the foreign minister, not the shadow foreign minister, but former Senator Gareth Evans. They chose to speak to him. He is the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the shadow spokesman on the Treasury. I do not know whether they asked him because Mr Brereton is performing so poorly as shadow minister of foreign affairs or whether Mr Evans is performing so poorly as the shadow Treasurer, but for one reason or other the only person they asked to comment on the situation was the former Senator Evans.

That gives you some idea from just two instances. If you want another instance, I suggest that you play a re-run of the first question this morning on Radio National asked of Senator Minchin by Fran Kelly. Then see whether or not you think there is any bias on the ABC. It may only be my view, Senator Schacht, but I am deeply saddened by the demise of what I always considered was an independent broadcaster in Australia. There has been a lead‐up to this for a long time. Not only that: no‐one in their right mind could suggest that the media has portrayed the issue with any sort of balance.

Senator Schacht has invited me to speak of the role of the church and its leaders. I have been an active member of the Uniting Church all of my life, and still am. It happens to be the same church that Senator Woodley is a member of. Senator Woodley and I have diametrically opposing views, but it does not mean that both of us should not express our views—and he has, and so have some of the church leaders. But I do not believe that the church leaders can claim to represent the voice of all the people within their churches.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they never did.

—But they do, Senator Schacht, because they are the only ones that are quoted. And those other people who are the ordinary parishioners never get a chance to have their say. I can quote you two instances—
—But you are now.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not mind Senator Schacht interjecting every now and then, but a constant barrage makes it very difficult for me to even hear what I am saying—and I remind you that Senator Schacht was heard in silence for 20 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the church, I was brought up in a parish and still belong to a parish where there are very few people who share the views of Senator Woodley and who share the views of their church leaders. This has been a very difficult time because it tests the Christian faith of those who belong to those individual churches and who do not share the expressed views of their leaders. I defend their right to say so; I believe they do have a right to express those views. But to subjugate the views of many parishioners, which has happened by getting comment only from church leaders, means that the role of the churches and the views of the people within those churches have been overplayed in the media.

Let me say that the views that have been expressed by church leaders certainly are not mine. I want to put it on the public record that they are not. I know they are not the views of many people who are involved in my own parish. It does not mean that the people in those parishes are without compassion. But if, in a democracy like ours, you cannot hold a different view and be able to express it without animosity coming in, then I think there is something wrong with our own society.

I listened carefully to what Senator Andrew Murray had to say because I have a high regard for Senator Murray. He is someone in the Democrats who has, on many occasions, given a different view about economic issues and a range of other issues. I have also worked with him on several committees. However, I was disappointed when Senator Murray introduced the subject of apartheid into his speech. I was disappointed for one reason only: `apartheid' is a South African word and that is where it should stay. I do not know anybody in Australia who does not abhor apartheid and always has.

But not once did Senator Murray say in his speech that the situation in South Africa was one where 20 per cent of the population were ruling over the other 80 per cent and where that 80 per cent had very few rights and privileges. The situation is totally different from Australia, where minority groups are nothing like the size of the minority groups in South Africa. Apartheid to me is where a small minority express their views and dominate and oppress a majority of people. That is what happened in South Africa. I would certainly hope that never happens here.

I respect Senator Murray's views because I find him to be a very honest gentleman. He is expressing his views in much the same way as I am expressing mine. But there is no place in Australia for the word `apartheid' as a description of the way in which the Australian parliament is trying to revise its native title legislation. The term `apartheid' has also been used by one other spokesperson. I hope I never hear the word again because I do not think it does anything to further the debate. Certainly, it only brings ill-feeling, which is not warranted.

There has been lots of talk about reconciliation during the debate. Reconciliation is a two-way thing. What disturbed me when I heard opposition speakers talk about reconciliation was that they then used the most inflammatory language about anybody who holds a different view on this side of the chamber. We heard Senator Schacht talking about a `racist bill'. How can you have reconciliation when you have one side of the chamber using inflammatory language and calling people racist? We have had members on this side being referred to as `racist scum'. How does that progress the cause of reconciliation, because reconciliation is a two-way thing.

Reconciliation is mostly in the minds of people. It does not matter what people say, you cannot change what is in the minds of people without a long process of education. While public statements may be made in relation to reconciliation, it is the minds of people that have to be changed so that reconciliation becomes part of them and so that their feelings towards their fellow Australians are feelings of goodwill and not of divisiveness, which we have heard in some of the comments that have been made today.

The terms that have been used by those who are opposing the government's proposals do nothing for reconciliation. As a matter of fact, I think they actually retard the process of reconciliation. I hope that the committee stage of the debate, which is when all the amendments that are to be made to this bill will be debated, can be conducted and debated by people who hold strong views. It does not mean that either view is right or wrong. The process of democracy will decide which of those amendments pass and which of them fail. We are all subject to the democracy of this place. Introducing ill feeling and divisive words will do nothing for the process that we are starting tonight and that we will be going through in the next week before this bill is finished.

Can I say on a personal note that it is not very easy waking up every morning and knowing that you have a particular position on a bill, which I have on this bill, where a lot of time and effort has been put into preparing it and knowing that some people on the other side are going to refer to you as a racist.

I spent all of my early life living close to Aboriginal people. My children went to school with Aboriginal children all of their school days. In my younger days, there was a considerable amount of goodwill within our rural communities. I am not suggesting that in those times the indigenous people were well treated—because they just simply were not well treated—but there was a tremendous amount of goodwill by the people in my own community towards those whom they felt were far worse off than they were.

It is very sad for me to say that I think that goodwill has been diminishing in recent times. It is diminishing because of the public speculation and the public debate that is sometimes carried on both in the print media and on television. That public debate does not allow people to get back and try to solve the problems on a local basis, as they used to in times gone by, with much less bitterness than is evident today. My own view is that I am very sorry that has happened because I had a very enjoyable time playing footy with people of Aboriginal descent in those younger days. All of my life, I have had some really good mates amongst those Aboriginal people. Although a lot of those families have moved on, I am sorry that that same goodwill does not seem to exist today.

I am not sure that it is not there but it does not seem to exist. A lot of that is brought about by the fact that much of the writing and media comment has been made by people who live in urban areas. I do not say that unkindly, but they do live in urban areas where many of them have less contact with people of lots of other races than we have in our rural communities. I hope for the sake of Australia and for all the people of Australia that that goodwill does return, because it is important. Let us remedy the mistakes of the past—because they were mistakes. But that does not mean that the goodwill cannot exist.

It certainly does not mean that time and effort have not been put into this bill. It has been suggested by people opposite, the Greens and the Democrats that there was no negotiation. It was only a week or two after the 1996 election that Senator Minchin started talking to groups around Australia. It is now 18 months since that election and in the first six months a considerable number of Aboriginal groups all around Australia were consulted. I know a lot of people are not happy with the final result; a lot of people in the pastoral industry are not happy with the final result. As has been said before, it was never going to be possible to produce a bill that would introduce some certainty and that would please everybody. It was just never possible. I believe—I know others do not share my view—that the bill we have before us has done the best that it possibly can to look at the interests of all people. The debate will take place, the amendments will be brought forward and the democratic process of this chamber will decide whether my views or the views of somebody else are right. I am quite happy to put myself through that process because no‐one has a monopoly on right or on being perfect in anything that they do—in this place or in any other place.

There are a number of other things that I could say but I see that my time is drawing to a close. I can only conclude where I started: this is not an easy bill for this chamber to debate. There are lots of individuals who will feel the pressure as we go through the amendments over the next 10 days. There are lots of people on both sides of this chamber who will be under considerable pressure. All I can hope is that, by the time we come to the end of the debate and the decisions are made, people will accept those decisions for the manner in which they were made and know that they have been made with the best of intentions from people on both sides of the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak in this debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , I want to start by saying that I never thought we would hear statements like those we have heard in the last few days. I particularly refer to statements from the offices of the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Tim Fischer, and the Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin—the good old `fear and loathing' statements. I used to wonder why it has taken until now for the government to bring out this ridiculous claim that somehow native title may take away the freehold backyards and homes of ordinary Australians. Why wasn't it raised before? If we look at how things have progressed over the last 18 months you can begin to uncover why.

SPEECH.PARA: The government started from a position of arguing for certainty for pastoral leaseholders, miners and developers. That was, they said, the only matter that needed to be resolved. But following the public emergence of the government's 10‐point Wik plan it all started to unravel. The 1O‐point Wik plan of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) started to come under greater public scrutiny. Questions began to be raised about whether or not the 1O‐point plan could even provide the security that the government claimed it would. As the public came to understand what the government was really doing, the louder the criticism of their plan became. Legal opinions said it was unconstitutional, church leaders said it was unjust and the public opinion polls said that the government had not got it right.

This is really what led the government to raise the freehold versus native title issue with regard to people's homes and backyards. It was and is a desperate attempt to regain public support for their position. But what a low, despicable way to try to regain that support. One could be forgiven for thinking that the government has taken these steps not just in an endeavour to get support for their 1O-point plan but to create a diversion from all the other things that have gone wrong for them over the last 18 months—things such as the nursing home debacle, the child-care debacle, their lack of industry policy and so on. One could go on forever.

This approach is almost a mirror of what they did with their announcement of the work for the dole plan when they were under significant pressure in another area. These diversionary tactics seem to be becoming a trait of this government. Rather than confront an issue and debate it on its merits they seek to create smokescreens, especially when they are in trouble. It is a gutless and leaderless approach and Australians should not buy it—and I do not think they will.

What Australians want from their political representatives is an open and honest debate, and more than anything else they want a resolution that is just and fair. Australia does not have a good history of being just and fair when it comes to Aboriginal people. It took a High Court decision to correct the doctrine of terra nullius. For over 200 years our law sought to pretend that indigenous Australians did not have cultures that dealt with issues of land management. Nor did our law seek to understand the spiritual and cultural attach ment indigenous Australians have to their land. The Mabo case was the first step towards rectifying that blight on our history. The Mabo case made it clear that native title comprises a property right and that indigenous Australians have that right.

In response to the Mabo High Court decision, in 1993 we in government enacted the Native Title Act—an act that respects and preserves native title but allows reasonable use and development of the land to continue. As has been said, the act is complex—it had to be—and it was probably inevitable that it would need to be amended, not unlike any other legislation that is new and deals with very complex issues. We have not pretended that there are not problems; indeed, we acknowledge that there are. But to resolve those problems we need a fair and equitable approach—not one that winds the clock back to pre‐1993. That is the course the government is pursuing, and the late Eddie Mabo's family must surely now be anguishing that his long, hard fought fight, won fairly and squarely, could be in vain.

As I said from the outset, the Prime Minister says that he seeks to deliver certainty. He says he wants to protect native title. But he is pursuing a course of action that can do neither. There is evidence in the statements of many people. Submissions in evidence to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, which considered the constitutional aspects of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997, made the following points. Mr John Basten QC, barrister at Frederick Jordan Chambers, Sydney, said:
The Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 has given rise to serious concerns in the minds of those familiar with the issues of constitutional law.
Mr George Williams, lecturer in law at the Australian National University, said:
The bill in its current form is likely and indeed will inevitably continue the legal uncertainty surrounding Wik and surrounding native title in Australia.
Mr Ron Castan QC, barrister at Owen Dixon Chambers, Melbourne, told the committee:

. . . at the very least, there is substantial doubt about the constitutional capacity of the Commonwealth to make laws in relation to Aboriginal people which are adverse to them, or which discriminate against them. Thus, the bill, if enacted into law, will inevitably be the subject of substantial constitutional uncertainty.

It is obvious from these statements that the Prime Minister's claims about his government's bill are not true and that the bill will create even more uncertainty for indigenous Australians, mining interests and pastoralists alike.

Then there is the question of whether or not the Native Title Amendment Bill is racially discriminatory. Native title property rights are protected by the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination, which was enacted by Australia's 1975 Racial Discrimination Act. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has stated:

Section 10 of the RDA provides for equality before the law for people of all races. Enacting legislation to extinguish native title would detrimentally affect the property rights of one group of Australians . . . based on race, in that the property rights sought to be extinguished are only held by Indigenous peoples.

That says it all in a nutshell. And, of course, the federal government has legal advice from its Chief Counsel, Mr Henry Burmester, which may well contain the same warning: that its Wik legislation would breach the Racial Discrimination Act. If it does not, why don't they make it public? Why doesn't the Prime Minister? Indeed, why doesn't the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), who is sitting over there, make it public? What have they got to hide?

Of course, this is not just a debate about legal opinions; it is much more than that. It is a debate about the reconciliation of our past. It is about determining a moral and just outcome for indigenous Australians, and it should be an honest and open debate. Reconciliation—and this is something the Prime Minister doesn't seem to realise—requires the involvement of all parties, and that includes the indigenous peoples of Australia. It is difficult to see how the Prime Minister can claim to support the spirit of reconciliation when the bill he seeks to have passed by the Senate seeks to clearly exclude a fundamental principle and right of indigenous Australians—the right to negotiate. That is why so many people within the community are speaking out against the Prime Minister's legislation. That is why so many people in the community are calling for a proper approach to this debate. I myself have received numerous letters on this issue from individual Australians. Not one of them has advocated the course that the Prime Minister is pursuing.

One of the more notable members of our community who has expressed concern about this government's approach is the Governor‐General, Sir William Deane, who in an address warned that past oppression and injustices toward indigenous Australians must be acknowledged and addressed or our nation would pay a price. Sir William also questioned the nation's commitment to vulnerable and disadvantaged groups, claiming the jury is still out on whether Australia passed the test of a true democracy. The government has strongly criticised the Governor‐General for even daring to speak on this matter, but I think an observation contained in a letter to the editor in the Australian on 26 November probably sums up the situation very well. In part, that letter said:
The fact that our Governor‐General should even feel compelled to speak publicly is in itself an indication that things are seriously wrong.

The significance of this statement is even greater when you consider that it was necessary for Sir William Deane to defend the right of free speech against John Howard's claims that the churches should not speak up on issues that did not concern them. Well, the churches have spoken out, and perhaps it is time that Mr Howard and his government started to listen. Mr Toby O'Connor, National Director of the Catholic Social Welfare Commission, stated in a press release today:

Denying native title rights to indigenous people is certainly not going to solve the many other problems faced by rural communities . . . Legislation that resolves conflict by wiping out the rights of one group is not going to further the cause of reconciliation. Peace without justice is not acceptable.
In a letter to members and senators on 21 November, the National Assembly of the Uniting Church in Australia said:
The Federal Government will gravely damage its claims to moral, ethical and legal integrity if it pushes ahead with its Native Title Amendment Bill in its current form . . .
The Catholic Commission for Justice, Development and Peace, in a press statement on 24 November, said:
The concerns of rural communities will not be addressed but will be compounded by this ill-conceived legislation . . .
The best solution is through mutual understanding, discussion and negotiation . . . which benefit all parties . . .
Negotiation is the best way forward, not the abolition of rights.
Even international organisations have expressed concern at this government's approach. Amnesty International, in a letter to members of parliament on 20 November, expressed its concern:

The Native Title Amendment Bill . . . potentially breaches the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), the Covenant on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination (CERD) and Australia's own Racial Discrimination Act (RDA).

Considering all of these views, and even if one agreed with John Howard's claim that churches and others don't have a monopoly over morality, the Prime Minister would be well advised to realise that he does not have a monopoly over the right to freedom of speech.

Then we come to the misinformation campaign—the vested interest campaign. What could be described as one of the most disappointing contributions in that area is that of the mining industry. l would like to refer to a letter circulated to all members and senators in this place from the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies, dated 24 November 1997. In that letter, it says in part:
Australian industries, including the mining industry, have suffered for four years under the totally unworkable regimes prescribed by the Native Title Act.

But that is somewhat hard to believe if we do as industry keeps telling to us do—and that is, to look at the facts. I took a look at the facts. In fact, I went to AMEC's own Internet web page to have a look at how they really were suffering. Looking at that page, I found that in the mining industry:

BREAK.PARA: The value of exports of mineral and energy resources has nearly doubled since 1986‐87, rising in 1995‐96 to a record $33.9 billion.
Australian mineral exports are expected to be over $36 billion in 1996‐97 . . .
And:
WA's mineral production industry has risen consistently by approximately 5.5 percent per annum since 1991, to over $15 billion in 1995‐96.

There is nothing wrong with that. That is all good and great; all the more for it; all the better. But, of course, I am sure that Aboriginal people would not mind suffering to the same extent if they saw their rights doubling over that same period, or their rights increasing by 5½ per cent per annum. I am sure they would look forward to that with a great deal of joy.

It is not just the misrepresentation and misinformation of big business that concerns me. It is also the misrepresentations and irresponsible actions of some conservative MPs who are endeavouring to whip up a fear and loathing campaign within the community by preying on the fears and interests of particular groups of Australians.

A good example of this—and it is one in which I have a particular interest—is the issue of recreational fishing access to Australia's waterways, beaches and seas. It appears that some government members and senators are going around the country saying to Australia's fishers and anglers that, unless the Native Title Act is amended, they will lose their right to fish on the beaches and rivers of this country. Indeed, one senator, Senator Bill O'Chee, in an address to a recent Australian National Sportsfishing Association conference, said exactly that. But nothing could be further from the truth.
Under section 212(1) of the existing Native Title Act, it is clear that:
. . . a law of the Commonwealth, State or Territory may confirm . . . that any existing fishing access rights prevail over any other public or private fishing rights.

Therefore, even if Aboriginal people were to be granted native title rights over rivers, beaches or seas, they would not—if the existing act was applied—be able to exclude recreational fishing access that has already been occurring. That is the case—and it is about time that persons such as Senator O'Chee apologised to people for the nonsense they have been peddling and for conning people into believing what they are saying.

The keen interest in and support for the access rights of recreational fishers or anglers to private property, being shown by Senator O'Chee and his colleagues, are very interesting. I find it very interesting because it implies—and I think Senator O'Chee actually said this—that no-one owns the water in the rivers, and no-one owns the fish that swim in the sea.

That is all well and good. But I would be very interested to hear what Senator O'Chee has to say about all those pastoralists who currently have freehold title over land who will not let anglers access their property or beaches to go fishing. I do not see Senator O'Chee or the conservative MPs over there introducing legislation to ensure that anglers of this country get access to those waters to catch fish. No, of course not. What you will do is defend the right of those pastoralists to deny people that access. That is what you will do—and that is what you will continue to do.

But, as I indicated earlier in my speech, Labor does recognise that there are some difficulties with the existing native title legislation. That is why we have 359 amendments that are aimed at ensuring this government does not take away the native title rights of indigenous Australians—does not take away their right to negotiate—but does seek to bring about certainty and security for pastoralists and for miners in a way that we all expect, and in a way in which we all want to be treated, using that age‐old principle of fairness and justice.
That is what we will be seeking to achieve. But we will not accept—and I hope the Senate will not accept—the path of divisiveness and injustice that is proposed by this government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 because I am concerned that truth has become a casualty. The facts are being ignored by many who should know better; and the reconciliation process is being threatened by those who have chosen to politicise it.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had the great privilege over the last 20 months of being responsible for the portfolio of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. I have met hundreds of wonderful indigenous people. Throughout Australia there are many outstanding indigenous people, living and working at the community level, quietly going about their lives. These people make a tremendous contribution to their communities. And this is, in reality, an important contribution to the Australian nation. I could tell you countless stories of the people whom I have met over this period. You would not know their names. The stories of these people do not make the newspapers.

Seven years ago, the current editor of the Canberra Times commented upon how difficult it was for new players in the field of Aboriginal affairs to be accepted in the media as persons with a right to be heard. He noted that the leaders of 20 years ago were still quoted and accepted as leaders—and it is my impression that this largely remains the case today.

I believe that non-indigenous Australians must learn about the lives of those indigenous men and women who are working with such dedication to improve the conditions in which their people live. It goes further than just learning about their lives and work: non-indigenous Australians must meet them and come to know them so well, as mutual understanding and friendship grows. Again, it has been my great privilege to have made friends in that period.

Let me deal firstly, however, with the truth. Constant claims are made in the media, and even here in this place by senators—senators who, at the very least, should have read the legislation and should therefore know better—that are patently wrong. I would ask people to listen carefully to what I now say.

We are not extinguishing native title. After our amendments are passed, indigenous Australians will still be able to make native title claims over 79 per cent of our landmass. We are not removing common law rights from indigenous Australians. Despite claims to the contrary, the right to negotiate is not a common law right; it is a device which was introduced by the Keating government under the Mabo legislation.

We are not breaking the principles laid down in the Mabo and Wik decisions. Currently, there are native title claims over 45 per cent of the landmass. There are almost 700 claims, and only one has been settled. Indigenous Australians make up two per cent of the population, and currently over 15 per cent of our landmass is in indigenous hands. These are facts that cannot be disputed. Yet, when they are raised, we are told to stop using the facts because they might alarm people.

Today those opposite became very excited about comments made by the Special Minister of State (Senator Minchin) regarding freehold title. Again, Senator Minchin was only laying the facts on the table. He was not scaremongering. What did we see reported in the media tonight? The government is scaremongering. I repeat what I said earlier in the Senate on this subject: the government believes that native title has been extinguished on freehold land and by the grant of residential, agricultural and other exclusive possession leases. That is why the government seeks to confirm this in the bill.

But the Labor Party have indicated that it will oppose that confirmation provision, even the confirmation that freehold has extinguished native title. The only rational reason for their position is that they think native title can coexist with freehold. If Labor are successful, claims will be able to be made over freehold land in the Federal Court, and we think they will fail. Whilst generally the High Court has said that freehold extinguishes native title, it has not decided a case directly on this issue.

For those who would dispute this fact, I would ask them to read the comments of Chief Justice Brennan of the High Court in the Wik case when he said that, if native title is simply suppressed rather than extinguished by the grant of a pastoral lease, then in logic this could be the same for freehold grants. That is a fact. Our policy is that the enormous cost and social division of adversarial litiga tion on claims over freehold and other exclusive possession leases should be avoided.

We should not forget that in 1993 Labor insisted that native title was extinguished on pastoral leases. They were wrong then—they now agree with that, and it is accepted. They were wrong. What we are seeking is certainty in this legislation, and the only way to achieve that certainty is to put it in the legislation. While we are abused for speaking the truth, our opponents are spreading half-truths and outright lies and are resorting to hysterical sloganeering. They are misleading many well‐meaning people who really did not understand the issues.

How many people, for example, understand that Keating's Mabo legislation was intended to allow indigenous Australians to claim just 37 per cent of our landmass? Under our legislation, indigenous Australians can place claims over 79 per cent of the landmass, and that is another fact that cannot be disputed. The logical extension of the argument that we should not place the facts on the table is that it is all right for those opposed to our legislation to tell lies but not for us to tell the truth because the truth might alarm people.

This government has been accused of being racist. In fact, Mr Noel Pearson has resorted to `racist scum', `capitalist swine' and `apartheid legislation'. At least he is being consistent, because in 1993 during the Mabo debate he abused the Keating government in a similar vein. He said that there was moral scurvy in the Keating government and that the Mabo document was slimy and useless. If Mr Pearson had a logical, reasoned argument, he would use it. Instead, his arguments are so threadbare that he has been forced to resort to hysterical sloganeering. That sloganeering is designed for one purpose only: to create a racial divide. He stands condemned for that.

The media perception is that there is a united approach by Aboriginal people on native title, and this again is far from the truth. Native title has different meanings for different clans and language groups. There is even objection by some groups to our aim to rationalise claims. One area in Western Australia has 17 separate claimants, each one of which claims to be the original owner.

BREAK.PARA: I want to quote from a letter by the former Governor-General, the Hon. Bill Hayden, AC, written on 21 March this year, when he finished his role as chief negotiator on the Century Zinc mineral project. The letter states:
What became abundantly clear to me quite early is how complex, even confusing, the drafting of the relevant legislation is.
He was referring to the original Native Title Act. The letter further states:

The opportunities the legislation offers for outside manipulation of processes and for the adoption of measures which come perilously close at times to being extortion; the absence of any definition of who can be a claimant and the seemingly unlimited opportunities for people to register as such; the unrepresentativeness of some who register as claimants; the confusion and tensions which can become rampant as longstanding factions and family disputes within a tribal group manifest themselves at the expense of the issue to be settled; the jealousy and mistrust which can arise between different tribal bodies and which can impair negotiating processes. And this is by no means an exhaustive list of the problems which stop the . . . Native Title Act.
These are the words of a former leader of the Labor Party, a former Governor-General and a former President of the Labor Party. The letter continues:

I sincerely hope that the Howard Government is able to remedy these grave defects. But allowing for the nature of the Senate at times this will probably be a very difficult task. The tragedy of failure to rectify these shortcomings will cause major national economic detriment.

I referred previously to the reconciliation process. Reconciliation is about being comfortable with each other and sharing our equality. There has even been a determined attempt to drag the reconciliation process into the debate, and that saddens me. Reconciliation is far too important to be used—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind those people in the gallery that there are a lot of people who have been following this debate closely and want to hear what is being said. The standing orders do not allow comment from the gallery. In order to protect those who do want to sit and listen to this debate in silence, I would ask the attendants to monitor closely those who are not. I do want people to be able to hear the debate.

—Reconciliation is far too important to be used for cheap, dishonest political purposes. As a government, we have a strong commitment to the reconciliation process based on achieving practical outcomes. There needs to be, first, an honest and realistic acknowledgment of the injustices of the past. Second, there needs to be a mutual acceptance of the importance of working together in ensuring that our differences do not prevent us from sharing equally in a common future. Thirdly, there needs to be a shared commitment to overcoming indigenous disadvantage and providing equality of opportunity for all Australians. Over the last 20 months this government has attacked that disadvantage. We have spent more on health, education, employment, housing and law and justice in that period of time than the previous government did. Over the next four years we will spend over $400 million more than the Labor government did in their last four years. That, again, is fact.

BREAK.PARA: I am also achieving recognition that the Torres Strait Islanders hold a special place in Australian society. We have already legislated to give the Torres Strait Regional Authority control of its own budget and we have promised to introduce legislation to provide the Torres Strait Regional Authority with greater autonomy within the Torres Strait.

Before I close, I want to refer to another claim—that the government has no sense of the symbolism of native title. I strongly refute that statement. The government recognises that land lies at the heart of indigenous existence. Indigenous people need their land to fulfil spiritual and cultural needs for traditional use, for living areas and for economic purposes. Perhaps the most important issue on the national landscape involving indigenous Australians is our current response to the decision by the High Court of Australia in the Wik case. The decision's complex interaction with legislation, including the Native Title Act and the Racial Discrimination Act, have produced major difficulties and uncertainties for state and territory land administration, pastoralists, mining interests, other leaseholders and potential native title holders.

The government sees it as essential to achieve an early resolution of the uncertainties arising from the High Court's decision. But we want to make it clear that we recognise and accept indigenous native title in Australia. After extensive consultation with all parties, including indigenous interests, the government released its 10-point plan—a framework for responding to the decision. As honourable senators know, the legislation is before us. The plan is based on the non-extinguishment of native title on pastoral leases, meeting the legitimate concern of pastoralists while respecting the principles of native title. It is important to stress that point.

Despite claims to the contrary, our native title legislation does not extinguish native title on pastoral leases for indigenous people. The government's approach means that the possibility of coexisting native title is preserved over Australia's rangelands. On pastoral lease land, native title holders will have the same procedural rights as other interests in that land in relation to development. Indigenous people can continue any existing access to pastoral land. Contrary to some perceptions, common law rights in relation to native title are preserved. The right to negotiate is retained for mining where native title may be equivalent to full ownership, and there are greatly expanded provisions for negotiated agreements with native title holders on all aspects of native title.

We cannot expect to totally satisfy all interests, but we will promote policies in the national interest. We are committed to achieve just and fair outcomes for indigenous people, industry and government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset in this crucial debate on the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , I acknowledge the Ngunnawal people on whose land this great parliament has been built. In the next week the Senate will set the course of history as it amends the Native Title Act. In the words of Galarrwuy Yunupingu, on the Howard government's 10-point plan:

SPEECH.PARA: This is the final drive. This is the revisit to our waterhole to poison it yet again. This is rounding up Aboriginal people into the valley and a final shoot‐out. This is the killing of Aboriginal men, women and children one by one . . . Our right must not be taken away ever . . . Without this right we will not maintain and practice what we practice now. We will be like a dead leaf in a river that floats up and down in the stream. We will be a bird that flies freely up in the sky with no foundation, with no law, with no song, with no story.

I say, `Let us hear the strength and sting of these words and the cry from the heart that they involve.' Business and political commentators have been equally explicit about the need to amend the Native Title Act. They say that Australia's economic development, no less, is at stake. At the end of the 20th century it is no longer acceptable to promote economic interests through violent dispossession. Instead, we use the law—hence, this bill and this 10-point plan. Our choice here in the Senate is to turn back the tide of dispossession by rejecting this bill or to add yet another weight to the scales of past injustice.

Over the last two centuries the indigenous peoples of Australia have been racked with Old World contagion, shot, poisoned, enslaved, imprisoned and dispossessed of their land, their culture and their spirit. At first this was concentrated in the south, where the bulk of Australia's population and commerce is set, but now all eyes have turned to the north. This, we are told, is boom country. Population growth is going north. Mining is mostly north. Road, rail and port developments are north. New land and sea occupying industries like cotton growing, aquaculture and tourism have a great potential in the north. It is perceived, wrongly, that in the way of this progress stand the indigenous people. Certainty for this progress is required.

In these times when dark deeds of violence or force flash onto TV screens around the world in an instant, a new formula for handling this problem, which the indigenous people present, is required through the courts, through the parliaments and through the police stations of the land. As Kenneth Davidson said in today's Age:

We would all like more certainty in our lives. But it has to be shown how the nation, not simply the rich pastoralists, gain by standing on the throats of Aboriginal people. Of course graziers promise to be magnanimous because, if the general com munity accepts that it is magnanimity that allows Aborigines on pastoral leases, that magnanimity is an attempt to slide past Aboriginal entitlement.

Yet here we are deliberating not on magnanimity, but on how best to abrogate the indigenous peoples' right to the land in the interests of the onrush of development—how best to take more. It is against the taking of more—the more bucketfuls of extinguishment of native title—that we Greens will stand. We are keenly aware of the central role of land in indigenous life and culture, and the drastic consequences of dispossession. As the royal commission into deaths in custody put it:

While the particular priorities with respect to land differ as between Aboriginal People, they are united in their view that land, whether under the banner of land rights or not, is the key to their cultural and economic survival as a people. It was the dispossession and removal of Aboriginal people from their land which had the most profound impact on Aboriginal society and continues to determine the economic and cultural well being of Aboriginal people to such a significant degree as to directly relate to the rate of arrest and detention of Aboriginal people.
The impact of dispossession is indeed profound. Our Governor‐General, Sir William Deane, has commented that:

Those of us—both indigenous and non‐indigenous—who are now joined together in a crusade for true national reconciliation all know that we will not succeed until our nation has properly addressed and made significant progress towards resolving the current plight of the Aboriginal peoples in relation to practical things such as health, education, employment and living conditions. And how could it be otherwise in a context where the gap between the average life expectancy of an Aborigine and that of a non Aborigine is almost 20 years and actually widening and where Aborigines are dying from particular disease rates up to 12 times or more than those of non‐Aborigines? Clearly, we will not achieve reconciliation until we reach the stage where it can be seen that we are at least approaching the position where life expectancy and future prospects of an Aboriginal baby are in the same realm of discourse as a non‐Aboriginal one.

Crucial to that reconciliation is certainty in the land for the indigenous people. This bill torpedoes that certainty. It erodes the tenuous Aboriginal hold on land even further, and the 10‐point plan should be defeated. But if, as the majority of non‐government senators would have it, the bill is entertained for amendment rather than rejected, nothing less than standing strong on the indigenous peoples' own line in the sand will do.

If not vetoed, this bill must undergo a radical rewrite, and that is a hazardous path and one which I do not particularly like. The ALP has said that its rewrite will meet 90 per cent of the National Indigenous Working Group's recommendations, but I think that 90 per cent is not enough. What of the other 10 per cent? One major concern, for example, is the ability afforded by the government and, to a lesser but nevertheless very real degree, by ALP amendments, for leaseholders to change the use of pastoral land way beyond cattle grazing with no Aboriginal right to negotiate. This is the very heart of Wik—coexistence of native title with pastoral use—with its kernel of reconciliation of two systems able to exist in harmony side by side. Yet the bill effectively extinguishes native title on pastoral land because it does not afford that right to negotiate.

The bill allows land use changes, called upgrading of the leases, without any right to negotiate for the native title holders. That upgrading can include such things as irrigation, cotton growing, clearing natural vegetation, logging and offshore fish farming. Such pursuits will expand massively in the north in coming decades. To aid this development, leaseholders and third parties are to be given the right to, for example, construct dams and canals, extract soil and rock, and log and woodchip.

The ALP allows traditional owners to be consulted about lease upgrades, including about compensation, and the heritage laws are there to be invoked. But the bottom line is that the traditional owners, even under those ALP amendments, do not get negotiation rights. This is truly alarming. Here we have a prescription for myriad changes to land use right across the north of this country, with Aboriginal interests reduced to consultation. It is a recipe for powerlessness, inequality and long‐term disillusion or anger.
