The National Indigenous Working Group has said that native title holders, when faced with land use changes by pastoralists, should be entitled to future act processes under the Native Title Act: that is, they should have the right to negotiate, and so they should. And where, in all of this, is the indigenous right to the waters, the seas, the traditional fishing grounds of the oceans? Why is native title not extended from the land to the adjacent waters? It should be; it must be; and this is the time and place for it to happen.

But neither right, nor resolve, nor even power of persuasion can match the weight of disciplined party numbers. On this momentous issue, great sway lies with the ALP. Over there is the government with its 10‐point plan; here, the Greens line up behind the National Indigenous Working Group's line in the sand. I challenge the good heart of the Labor Party to move this way—not that way; to come this further 10 per cent.

The government needs just one of us to give it the numbers. Clearly it is appealing to Senator Harradine. Senator Harradine has an enviable record of voting for indigenous interests right up to the Hindmarsh Island issue. But, on Monday night, while allaying no anxieties, he told the Senate that we `should be open to honourable compromise'. These are words of internal contradiction.

When the indigenous people have already compromised greatly in responding to the Howard 10-point plan, where is the `honourable' in further compromise? Compromise what? The right to negotiate? The validation of past illegal acts by state governments? The plea by the indigenous women—and I will come to this in a moment—for `our law, our traditional hunting grounds, our environment'? So I call on Senator Harradine, too, to stand strong with the National Indigenous Working Group position behind their line in the sand.

I have two other points. First, a word about the environment: cattle and other introduced species have caused vast devegetation, soil loss, water degradation and the extinction of native species in Australia's arid and semi‐arid zones. The much speculated boom in the north and the multiple use future for pastoral leases poses even more threats. Governments at state and national level would do well to heed Mr John Auty, the former senior scien tist from the Top End: unsustainable pastoralism where it occurs should be replaced by a very real national effort to restore the land and invite traditional owners to join in developing the job‐rich service and tourism potential of such areas instead.

The other point is that it is essential that we find much better economic security for the first Australians. The United Nations says that Australia is the world's wealthiest country; yet original Australians are often amongst the world's poorest people because of their dispossession from the land. The wellbeing of all Australians demands that we heal this untenable situation. But where is the healing in this bill?

I had wanted Tasmanian Aborigine Michael Mansell to give this speech, but the Senate refused permission. But, to put to the Senate in words I cannot find—in Aboriginal words—the disdain for the government's 10-point plan, let me read to the Prime Minister and federal parliament the statement of the Indigenous Women's Native Title Conference in Darwin two months ago:
We are women landowners and land council members from across Northern Australia and we call on the Prime Minister and the Federal Parliament to respect and defend our native title rights.

We are lifting our voices for our rights, for our dreaming and for our culture, and for the future of our children, grandchildren and great‐grandchildren. We are speaking from our hearts for our culture, our spirituality and our law.

We want all Australians to understand that their children's rights in the land and the sea will also be diminished by the so-called 10 point plan. How will Australians be able to protect the environment for all the children if the Parliament hands over the rights of all Australians to a few big companies?
Under your amendments, Mr Howard, development can go ahead without even talking to us, damaging our culture and our law, damaging our traditional hunting grounds, and polluting our environment.

Our law tells us that our rights to land and sea cannot be broken. We are responsible for our sacred places and our traditional country from the beginning of time to the end of time. We are responsible for ensuring that the law is passed on and that our land is protected. Our spirituality can be seen and heard in our songs and dances. Native title is the recognition by Australian law of our customary spirituality and our responsibilities for land.

We reject the proposed amendments to the Native Title Act. They are an attack on our life, our religious beliefs and on our spiritual relationships with the land and sea. Sea country is just as much a part of our law as the dry land. Our people's dreamings include the dolphin, the crocodile, the turtle, the stingray and the dugong, as well as birds and all the other native animals.

We do not accept the denial of our rights on pastoral leases and other land. We will not give up our right to negotiate because the right to have a say over our country is our life. The right to negotiate enables us to protect our culture and our future.
We instruct our land councils to do everything possible to protect our rights to land and sea.
We take responsibility on behalf of all Australians and future generations to call for an end to the hysteria which is dividing this country.
We ask the women of Australia of all cultures to support us.
We will not give up our fight for our inherited rights.

May the words of the women echo in this chamber in the coming days as we debate this 10-point plan. As it stands, this bill is unworthy of this nation. It is a document of shame. I will vote against it because it should be rejected. To that end, I move:
Omit all words after "That", substitute "in view of:

PARA.TAB: (a) the insufficient consultation and negotiation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people regarding changes to the Native Title Act 1993 and the entire issue of indigenous land justice; and

(b) concern that passage of the Native Title Amendment Bill in any form will further diminish Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander native title rights and will greatly impede the process of reconciliation and healing between indigenous and non‐indigenous people;
the bill be withdrawn until full and adequate consultation has taken place".

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before calling Senator Ian Campbell, I remind those people in the gallery that I did give some warning a time ago. The standing orders of this place do not allow comment from the gallery. It is not fair that some people who have listened to the debate all day, not just for some speeches tonight, should be removed from the gallery if I order the gallery to be cleared. So I ask you, please, that you respect the ruling that there be no noise from the gallery. That is the final warning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks will be brief because I have, in my deliberations as to whether I speak in this debate or not and for how long I speak, given primary consideration to the view which I think is shared in most corners, except perhaps in Senator Brown's corner—I respect his views; I genuinely do—that it is in the national interest to have the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 dealt with. It is obviously going to be a contentious debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I am going to restrict my remarks to about seven or eight minutes because I understand that Senator Lees and Senator Chris Evans will be speaking for close to their full time and that my leader, Senator the Hon. Robert Hill, will seek to commence his speech on the second reading debate at about 10.10 p.m., allowing all but Senator Nick Minchin to speak on the second reading debate tonight. Senator Minchin will speak in the morning. So I will be restricting my remarks to a few minutes. I was not going to speak if that was going to stop anyone else speaking, because I think the resolution of this matter is important, whichever way you come to this debate.

I was involved in the native title debate that took place in this chamber at the end of 1993. I think it was the longest debate in Australian history. I was also very closely involved in the debate on the land fund bill, which followed that debate and which was to establish the Indigenous Land Corporation and the indigenous land fund. I was very lucky to have had the opportunity of chairing the Senate Select Committee on the Land Fund Bill, which gave me the opportunity to travel throughout Australia and meet literally hundreds of Aboriginal Australians and Torres Strait Islanders.

I note Senator Judith Troeth is in the chamber. She and Senator Chris Ellison from our side and Senator Barney Cooney and Senator Margaret Reynolds were on that committee. Senator Lees was on that committee as well, I think, for one of the hearings. It gave me the opportunity to move around Australia and meet a lot of indigenous people not long after the Native Title Act had passed into law. There was certainly a lot of confusion as to what the Native Title Act would deliver to indigenous people at that stage. As I recall, that was towards the end of 1994, going into 1995.

There was a lot of confusion about the provisions of the land fund bill because, to pick up a point that Senator Brown made, the land fund bill was a piece of legislation that effected, critically, about $42 million a year in terms of the money available to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders to purchase land—a significant piece of legislation in terms of the impact it could have and the betterment it could do for Aboriginal people. That was a piece of legislation whereby there had been literally no consultation outside a group of about seven or eight indigenous negotiators.

We went to places like Darwin, Cairns, Brisbane, Dubbo, Kalgoorlie and Perth. Virtually none of the Aboriginal people we met in those discussions of the select committee had had any discussion or consultation about the provisions of the land fund bill or consultation in relation to the provisions of the Native Title Bill before it passed through this place.

I think one of Senator Brown's predecessors from the Greens (WA) in former Senator Cristabel Chamarette made the point continually during her contributions on the Native Title Bill at the end of 1993, and again in the indigenous land fund debates in this place in 1994 and 1995, that the previous government, apart from its discussions with a small select group—I think they were colloquially called the `A-team' but have now become the indigenous negotiating party—had had very little consultation with other Aboriginal interests in the lead-up to either of those bills.

By contrast, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and this government have sought extensive consultations with a wide range of interests, including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and other stakeholders in this process. I am quite sure Senator Brown does not think we have had enough consultation. Others, such as pastoralists and miners, might say we have had too much. I do not think we are going to keep everyone happy in this process, but to criticise consultation I do not think is fair.

Many people would say that this government did not move quickly enough to try to resolve the uncertainty that flowed from the Wik decision. I think that as a nation we should be trying to find common ground in all of these matters. There is absolutely no doubt that the Aboriginal people of Australia are the most disadvantaged people as a race in Australia. There is absolutely no doubt in my mind or in the policies of the government that special policies need to be implemented to improve the opportunities, the living standards and the health of indigenous people in Australia. There is no doubt in my mind or in the mind of the government that providing access to land, providing recognition of native title rights where those have survived, and providing access to facilities such as the indigenous land fund are also very sensible and very good policy and must be kept in place and run effectively to ensure that that disadvantage is overcome.

In my own state of Western Australia the provisions of the Native Title Act as it applies at the moment have not achieved that. I can say from my own experience from being in Western Australia both prior and subsequent to the Native Title Act coming into force that it has not worked. It has not worked for Aboriginal people in Western Australia. It has not worked for other land-holders in Western Australia.

I do not want to get distracted even though there are very important arguments about the size of mining exploration or mineral activity or exports. I think they are very important things because they develop wealth for all Australians and, very importantly, they develop wealth in remote areas, where many disadvantaged Aboriginal people live. So that is an important debate. But what I want to say is that we should be focusing on that common ground. We need certainty for Aboriginal people. We need certainty for pastoralists who seek to make a living off the land. We need certainty for people who seek to extract minerals and other precious metals and gas from Australia as well.

As I say, that develops wealth not only for white Australians or Australians descended from European backgrounds but also for all Australians, including Aboriginal people, and particularly gives them exceptionally good employment opportunities in remote areas close to the land that they are most closely associated with. I speak mostly from a Western Australian point of view because that is where my experiences has tended to come from, even though they are not as often as I would like them these days. I would love to spend a lot more time in Western Australia.

Because I am limited by time I will contribute briefly to this debate to facilitate the bill and other speakers, particularly Senator Evans and Senator Lees. But can I say that having the existence of multiple overlapping claims—the particular case that springs most vividly to mind in my recent experience is the Anaconda Nickel project at Murrin Murrin near Laverton in Western Australia, where at last count, which was a month ago and it might have gone up since then, 26 overlapping claims had been made on one area of ground, coincidently over the nickel deposit—does not create certainty for any of the people associated with that area.

I do not know the anthropology of that particular part of Western Australia—I really do not. I know a bit about the anthropology. I have read some long books about it. I have had the great privilege and opportunity provided by my position in this parliament to talk to a lot of people in outback Western Australia and other outback parts of Australia. So I do have some limited understanding—certainly not the sort of understanding that I know many people in the gallery would have on Aboriginal issues and their relationship with land.

But I find it hard to believe that all of the people associated with the 26 claims over a relatively small part of Western Australia at Murrin Murrin would have a prima facie, bona fide, genuine link with that land. I may be wrong, however. All 26 parties who have a right to negotiate over that area may indeed have a close, long-term, continuous association with the land, or any other association with the land. If that is the case, then more power to their own.

Where you have 26 overlapping claims—and in many parts of Australia you have multiple overlapping claims—what I put to the Senate is that the Aboriginal interests that, in amongst all of those claims and counterclaims, do have the bona fide interest, the close connection, with that land have the potential to have those rights determined through native title processes absolutely submerged under a sea of legal activities.

I put aside the Murrin Murrin project, the billion dollar project, and the thousands of jobs it will create and the hundreds of jobs it is already creating for Aboriginal people in that area. I agree with Senator Bob Brown wholeheartedly on this. We really do want a mechanism that will sort out the legitimate native title interests. We want to be able to provide justice to those people who cannot get native title through that process, people who have been dispossessed, who have moved and do not have a traditional link with land but do have an historical link, as occurs where people have been moved—forcibly or otherwise—from land, by giving them access to land, which is what we did by moving a series of amendments to the land fund bill, supported by the Greens, while we were in opposition.

In fact, Senator Brown, we look forward to talking to you about that bill when it comes for debate at some stage next year. We decided that the federal government at that time had made what I thought was quite a racist—I probably should not use that term—or a paternalistic approach to Aboriginal people whereby they said that you can only make a grant of land to people under the ILC if it was to a corporation. We moved an amendment that said you should be able to make grants of land from the indigenous land fund to any form of entity—be it an individual, a partnership or a trust or any other way that any other Australian could own land. We rejected outright the position that if you were an Aboriginal you had to be a corporation and if you were a white fella it did not matter.

That justice has to be found. But you can only get that justice if you have a system that will deliver that justice through the Native Title Act, through the indigenous land fund act and through the other policies of government. There is no doubt in my mind, having seen the Native Title Act work, particularly in Western Australia, that it has stuffed up the interests of Aboriginals who are bona fide claimants. It has had a significant detrimental impact on mining and exploration activity in Western Australia. I have absolutely no doubt about that at all. It has scared pastoralists out of their wits.

If you were to sit down a bunch of employees of mining companies, a bunch of pastoralists or a bunch of Aboriginals in outback Laverton, Leonora or Meekatharra or any other places like that, around a race track, a bar or a camp fire to discuss these issues, I do not think there would be much difference between them. My plea to the Senate is to take out—to quote the word Senator Brown quoted from the conference of indigenous women in Darwin—the `hysteria' in this debate. If we take the hysteria out of it and look at the reality of how you seek to determine the rights of each of those groups of Australians, regardless of the colour of their skin, then you are starting to move towards a true reconciliation and a true respect for all of those rights.

When you get us all out there sitting on that red earth and talking about these things, you tend not to find the sorts of differences that are created on the front page of the newspaper or on the electronic media from day to day. The issues become a bit clearer out there. I certainly pray that, in the ensuing four or five days in this debate, that approach will be taken. I wish the bill a speedy passage. I will certainly be supporting it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to acknowledge the Ngunnawal people tonight—the traditional owners of the land on which this Parliament House is built. I also wish to acknowledge the Kaurna people of the Adelaide region on whose land I live.

BREAK.PARA: The Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 before us today can be called, quite rightly, the final act of dispossession. What we in this chamber do with this bill will determine more than whether Aboriginal people will be excluded from their lands and more than whether we make progress towards genuine reconciliation. It will determine what sort of country we want Australia to be as we move into the next century.

In many ways, this bill is not about the Wik decision handed down by the High Court on 23 December last year. It is about the failure of the coalition parties of this country to come to terms with the removal of the doctrine of terra nullius from our law books.

At its heart, native title is about accepting and acknowledging the real history of this country. It is not about guilt. It is not about a black‐armband view of history, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) likes to call it. It is about facing this country's past with honesty and with the willingness to address the injustices of that past. Let us be very clear about this. By accepting native title rights we are not bestowing anything upon indigenous Australians. We are simply restoring some of the rights that have always existed.

As of June this year my family has been in this country for over 200 years. That seems a long time, but when compared to an Aboriginal family tree it is just a blink of an eye. While many early white settlers may have been able to claim lack of knowledge and lack of understanding of Aboriginal issues and of the link between Aboriginal culture and the land, we cannot. We have no excuse.

In 1992, just five years ago, the High Court of Australia handed this nation an opportunity in the form of the Mabo judgment. But, while the High Court has removed terra nullius from our law books, it did not and could not remove it from the hearts and minds of many non-indigenous Australians. That will always be dependent upon a generosity of spirit, upon a will to listen and upon a desire to open one's mind to change. The Senate now has an opportunity, by substantially amending this bill, to address the historic and continuing injustice perpetrated against the original inhabitants of the nation.

The High Court gave us the building blocks to embrace reconciliation, not turn away from it. But what have this coalition government done? Their buzz words for what they want to do include `certainty' and `workability'. The question must be asked: workability for whom? Again we must ask: certainty for whom? Why must workability and certainty automatically take precedence over rights? For all the things that can be said against the present act, its main feature is that it represents the involvement of key stakeholders and, most importantly and most markedly, that of indigenous Australians.

Yes, there is a need for some changes. We have heard again tonight examples of the changes that need to be made to assist particularly in the negotiating process. The Democrats acknowledge that. Indeed, I think all parties in this chamber acknowledge that. But I do have to say here that it is obviously working very well for the mining industry, which, as today's ABS statics show, has seen a rise in investment post‐Mabo of 110 per cent, which is more than double.

Why, then, do we need those parts of this bill the government, and the mining industry, know will severely reduce the rights of Aboriginal people? Put this together with the attack on ATSIC—one of the first acts of this government—the cuts to Abstudy, the lack of an apology from this government to the stolen generations and the absence of a formal response to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report and I believe we see a meanness of spirit or a lack of understanding; at least a dearth of compassion by those with the numbers in cabinet.

Perhaps the most disappointing aspect of the debate which has ensued since the Wik decision is the manifest dishonesty from almost everybody on the government side of politics. It has ranged from misrepresentation of the decision itself—and just in the last day or so the misrepresentation of the Mabo decision—to scaremongering of the worst kind about what may happen in the bush if Aboriginal owners are able to access pastoral leases, to access their country. Let us look a little more closely at the facts.

In 1993, after the Mabo decision was handed down and before the Native Title Act was passed by this parliament, the Wik people commenced their action in the courts. Clearly, every lawyer and Attorney-General in the country worth their salt was then on notice that the question of native title on pastoral leases was a live issue. However, the question remains: if indeed the Native Title Act 1993 had subsequently extinguished native title on pastoral leases, why then was the Wik people's court action not set aside or stayed? The reason is that the question of native title coexisting on pastoral leases was, until 23 December 1996—and the Wik decision—an open one.
The coalition government have chosen not to admit that what they are really doing is adhering to Dr Hewson's position in 1993. He said:
. . . we reject—we totally reject—the government's Native Title Bill because we believe it is neither a just nor a workable response to the High Court's Mabo decision.

I believe the coalition remain of that view and the Wik decision has been conveniently used as an excuse to undo the 1993 act as far as possible, as much as they can get away with, to pass the final act of dispossession, the extinguishment of native title on pastoral leases, and to take away the right to negotiate—the compromise position reached in the face of the extinguishment of native title on freehold land. Clearly, the government's deception in this regard has been extensive.

This bill takes extinguishment further—extinguishing or, perhaps more appropriately, dispossessing native title in a number of ways. Clearly the categories of extinguishing acts depart significantly from the settled common law. That is why the Democrats will be opposing schedule 4 of the bill.

I want to talk a little about another aspect of the bill, and that is its impact on the environment. The land under pastoral leases covers some 42 per cent of Australia. Much of this is some of the most fragile land anywhere in our country. It is certainly some of the most marginal land that anyone is attempting to farm—more marginal land is generally classified as desert.

The purpose of this bill is to upgrade leases through the primary production definition, and that will result in land being used for a range of new purposes: aquaculture; cropping; farm stay tourism; maintaining, breeding or agisting animals; taking or catching fish and so on; forestry operations; and horticulture, et cetera. In evidence before the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, Mr Jim Downey of the Australian Conservation Foundation said:

I represent a group of people who have campaigned for two or three decades for the repair of Australia's environment. You know, as members of this government, the impact that this bill, if it passes the Senate, will have on those rangelands: intensification of uses and expansion of the definition of pastoral lease to primary production. The Prime Minister, on 28 April 1997, said that primary production is a very wide definition indeed. It allows for far greater uses than are presently allowable under pastoral leases and those activities will be able to be conducted `without let or hindrance from native title holders or indeed any other section of the Australian community'.

In essence, that is an environmental disaster for Australia's rangelands, certainly for the 42 per cent under pastoral lease, and the bill also has implications for the 23 per cent within conservation reserves and crown reserves.

This proposal has correctly been labelled by the ACF as the most radical change to Australia's land management policy since colonisation. It will remove the public's interest in management of the land—land which, I remind the Senate, is publicly owned. It will also enable wholesale land clearing.

Why do I say that? Let us look at a 1995 CSIRO report that showed that national land clearing rates on freehold are twice the rate for leasehold land. Obviously, if you are going to plant a crop or establish an aquaculture venture there is more than a slim chance that you are going to have to clear some land.

Already in Queensland we clear around 300,000 hectares each year at least. If this bill goes through unamended, that will dramatically increase. Soil erosion will increase; loss of native species will increase; and land will become even more marginal. This increase in the range of permissible activities will reduce the level of control government has to act in the public interest and to protect the environment.

So why this upgrading? Well, apart from the obvious windfall gain for the pastoralists, it is because of the increased conflict with native title claims. I go back to the Wik decision. It said clearly that if there is any conflict between the pastoral lease and native title then the pastoral lease prevails. This means that, rather than just having to fit in with the needs of the farmer or the pastoralist to graze stock with requirements such as fencing or perhaps a dam, if this bill passes without amendment there is now the possibility of a whole new range of conflicts, a significant increase in the potential for conflict—conflict with land clearing, conflict with cropping—and possibly with the irrigation provisions that go with it. `No, you cannot access that land. No, you cannot walk across that land. We are now using it for cotton.'

Of course, you can go on: conflict with aquaculture and all that infrastructure; in particular, conflict with `farm stay' tourism. The tourists obviously are going to want to use sites such as creeks, dams or waterholes—perhaps look at cave formations and visit sites such as chasms and mountains. Then that conflict will obviously be there if Aboriginal people also want to access some of those areas—a conflict with the accommodation that tourists are going to require and from their need to move around the property. So what the government is basically wanting to do is to increase the likelihood of conflict—and so the inability of native title holders to claim native title rights.

During my time in this chamber I have had the privilege of meeting a large number of Aboriginal women, and I just want to mention a few of them tonight: Barb Flick, formerly the AMA's Aboriginal Health Adviser and now with the Cape York Health Council; Lois O'Donoghue, former head of ATSIC; Jacqui Katona, executive officer of the Gundjehmi Aboriginal Corporation; and, of course, the Ngarrindjeri women of my home state, who are still fighting for their culture, for their lands—for Kumarangk and the Coorong beyond. I must add that they are fighting against very powerful and well organised opponents, well financed forces that will stop at nothing to quash their rights.

During discussions on this bill I have had the opportunity to meet many more indigenous Australians, and I congratulate them on their determination and their commitment as they express so powerfully their needs, their rights and the beliefs of their peoples.

PARA.TAB: I would just like to say that I am struck on this occasion by the public support and emotion in the wider community. In all my experience in politics, in all my eight years, I have never detected such community abhorrence for what a government is attempting to do.

BREAK.PARA: I would also like to congratulate the many non‐indigenous Australians who are working to protect the rights of their fellow Australians. Again, I just mention a few: the Kumarangk Coalition who are working with the Ngarrindjeri people to protect their rights and to stop the bridge to Hindmarsh Island; the Women for Wik, a strong and growing group of women from all walks of life and cultural backgrounds, inspired by Lady Deane; ANTaR—Australians for Native Title, who have been coordinating those who oppose the legislation we have before us tonight. They have organised meetings and rallies across Australia and have put together the sea of hands.

Today on ABC Radio, Barb Flick, Director of the Cape York Health Council, spoke in reply to remarks made by a pastoralist, Rosemary Wilson. Mrs Wilson had detailed how she and other prominent members of the Anglican Church near Collarenebri were boycotting church services because of the church's position in opposing the Wik legislation. Recalling her childhood in Collarenebri, Barb said:

The pastoralists of Collarenebri really behaved, in my mind, like the Scarlett O'Haras of the deep South in America. I remember vividly as a child that we had to wait in shops until all the white people were served. I remember vividly, in Collarenebri, where we were roped off like cattle in the picture theatres because people thought that sitting next to us wasn't a very nice thing to do . . .

I remember in Collarenebri the stories about my parents' generation who were denied an education because the Rosemary Wilsons had threatened the Education Department that they wouldn't send their own children to school if the Aboriginal children attended.

I have been given two other examples of that today where this is still happening in Western Australia. These kinds of memories that Aboriginal people have and what is still happening today are the sorts of things we have to ensure are finished forever—that they are conditions that we do not see into the next century.

To all those tireless supporters and to our indigenous brothers and sisters: be secure in the knowledge that the Australian Democrats will not let you down. We will continue to work with the Indigenous Working Group and to support the amendments that they are putting before us. I ask all senators to find the courage to take a stand on this vitally important matter—not just on behalf of Aboriginal Australians but on behalf of the future of our nation.

In closing, I would like to briefly mention the Wik people, whose name has become synonymous with this legislation. In 1605 the Dutch crew of the Duyfhen landed on the west coast of Cape York, only to be driven away at spear point by Wik warriors. Several other Dutch explorers who followed met with a similar fate. The experience was documented again by the English in an English journal of 1625.

The Wik people defended their land against the Dutch; they defended their land against those early British explorers. But they could not, however, defeat the British military who, as a result of colonisation and based upon the presumption of terra nullius, drove them from their lands. Mabo, and now the Wik decision, have given them access again to some of their lands, but now we and others in this chamber have to help them and Aboriginal people across this country defend that regained access to their land against this government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The following principles were found by the majority of the High Court justices in the Wik case: one, that the granting of a pastoral lease does not necessarily extinguish all native title rights; two, that native title rights could continue at the same time as the land was subject to a pastoral lease; and, three, that where there is a conflict in the exercise of those rights, native title rights are subordinate to those of the pastoral leaseholder. I ask this Senate and I ask all Australians: what is wrong with that? What is unfair in the Wik decision? To me, they seem perfectly fair and reasonable principles on which to operate.

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing revolutionary in the High Court judgment in Wik. In essence, what the court found is that, where there is a conflict between the native title rights of Aboriginal people and those property rights of the pastoral leaseholder, those of the pastoral leaseholder will take precedence and Aboriginal native title rights will be subordinated. That is what all the fuss is about. That is what the country is in uproar about—that Aboriginal people should be allowed the right to pursue native title rights where they do not interfere with the rights of the pastoralists.

It seems to me that, if anyone came to Australia with no knowledge of our history and with no knowledge of the development of this issue, they would think that it was the Aboriginal people who should be upset and protesting that High Court decision, because it is their rights that have been found to be secondary. It is their rights that have been found to be only applicable where they do not interfere in any way with the rights of the leaseholder.

An outsider might say, `But don't these people own the land? Haven't they have been here for thousands of years? Isn't it their land? Why would a lease granted to a settler to run cattle take precedence over their thousands of years ownership of the land?' I think they are good questions that we in this parliament ought to turn our minds to as we debate the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . We should not fall into the framework provided by the government's response to the Wik decision. The bill is not about implementing Wik; it is about overturning the Wik decision and going even further in removing what little right to the land Aboriginal people can enjoy in this country.

When the decision was handed down, there was outrage among pastoralists, miners and conservatives in this country. They demanded that the rights of Aboriginal people found to exist in Wik, as in Mabo, be extinguished. They claimed that their rights must be extinguished in the name of certainty. But what about fairness, what about justice and what about certainty for Aboriginal people? These are concepts that are not given any attention. Those people upset by the Wik decision reject coexistence. They say that they cannot accept coexistence and that they must have certainty by extinguishing the rights of Aboriginal people—what little of those rights that remain. I say: that is not acceptable; that is not a position that the Australian people can or should adopt.

This legislation is not about workability, as the government claims, and is not about a fair and equal response to Wik. It is largely about extinguishing rights of Aboriginal people to native title, limiting those rights and removing what influence Aboriginal people have over the use of the land to which they have claims. We see the government expressing concern to protect the property rights of white Australians, but they have no concern for the property rights of Aboriginal people. If what they want is certainty by dispossession, then they will do it without my vote.

I think this is a bizarre response. The government is very sensitive about those who claim it is a racist response. While I do not want to get into name-calling, the response is cynical, low‐road politics and is certainly not in the long-term interests of Australia. From my point of view, I celebrated when I heard the Wik decision. I thought, `That's great. That is a decision with which Australia can go forward, with which we can build reconciliation and with which we can build a better Australia,' because it was based on mutual rights. The decision recognised the rights of Aboriginal people and recognised the rights of pastoralists and miners, but said that the rights can coexist—that they can live together and work together to make this a better country and to respect each other's interests.

I thought that here was a tremendous challenge for the country, a tremendous opportunity, and I thought that the Liberal Party would do better than they have done. Members of the Liberal Party always come in here saying that they oppose handouts to Aboriginal people and that they oppose the charity mentality which they say has grown up around Aboriginal people. But when Aboriginal people have their rights recognised, the first thing the Liberals do is to rush into this place to try to get those rights removed, to try to abolish those rights. How can people get away from a welfare mentality when you will not recognise rights that have been found by the High Court to exist and which I think any fair person would have said have existed since colonisation?

The Liberal Party are failing the challenge put down by the Wik decision. The Prime Minister, John Howard, has failed the challenge miserably, and I think his failure to provide leadership on this issue has really diminished him and diminished the country. We ought to demand better leadership from this parliament. This is not a question about whether you are pro-Aboriginal, pro‐miner or pro‐pastoralist—or anti any of those groups—it is about declaring, `You can be pro‐miner, pro‐pastoralist and pro-Aboriginal at the same time,' because we all have to live here. We all have to try to get on and develop this country in the interests of us all.

This bill seeks to remove Aboriginal rights that have been recognised in the Mabo and Wik decisions which overturned 200 years of neglect of those rights. But one thing is certain: there will be no certainty if this bill is passed. This legislation will not deliver the certainty that the government claims. The only thing that will give certainty and a way forward for Australia is to make coexistence work.

The momentum is building in Australia for the development of goodwill towards Aboriginal people and co‐existence. I have been very heartened by the activities of the Women for Wik, the Australians for Native Title, the churches and all the people who have written to me and taken an interest and said, `I do not have any personal or economic interest in this but it is the right thing to do for the country. We ought to protect and recognise Aboriginal native title rights.' It has certainly helped firm me in my resolve; it has helped firm the Labor Party in its resolve. The cheap politics that the Liberal Party sought to appeal to is not working in this country. People are looking, listening and analysing. They are saying, `This is not the way forward.' I am sorry, Senator Hill, it is not the way forward. I know you are better than that but some of your colleagues who now seem to control the Liberal Party are not.

I say we should reject the fear. In the last two days the government has pulled a stunt by seeking to resurrect Richard Court's famous backyard threat claims. I thought we had grown out of that. Even Richard Court has grown up from there; even he has given that away. He has not threatened my suburban backyard in Perth for weeks. But what does this government, under pressure, struggling, losing the political debate go for? They pull it out of the bottom drawer: look out for your backyards because here come the Aboriginal people. What nonsense. What a disgrace. This government stands condemned for that because they have done nothing to add to the debate. They say, `Let's have a rational debate; let's have a debate without emotion. Don't call us racist; don't accuse us of doing the wrong thing. But, by the way, they're coming to get your backyard.' It is just not good enough. That is not the way to take the nation forward; that is not leadership.

There is a need to amend the existing bill. I had the privilege of chairing the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Native Title in the time of the previous government and I have served on it since it was formed following the passage of the Native Title Act. I recognise that there is a need to amend the bill. The Brandy decision and the Waanyi decision regarding registration of claims provide real problems that need to be addressed in practical ways. But they do not go to the question of the balance of rights established in the Native Title Act; they go to practical operational problems about making that act work. No case has been made out to upset the balance of rights between Aboriginal people and non-Aboriginal people with other interests in land established in the Native Title Act in 1993.

BREAK.PARA: The key thing I want to mention about that act is that it was established with Aboriginal consent. They were consulted; they were involved. Not all were happy, but there was a firm basis of Aboriginal consent in the establishment of that act. That is missing here. There is no Aboriginal consent to the Liberal government's bill. There has been very little in the way of real consultation.

John Howard claims that the pendulum has swung too far towards the Aboriginal people. That just proves that he has not been to an Aboriginal community since he was elected Prime Minister. Anybody who goes to outback Western Australia cannot accept that sort of argument. There is no case to be made that rights have been pushed too far in favour of Aboriginal people. In this debate we must not confuse the need to fix the very real practical problems that exist within the act—although I would argue that they are overstated on many occasions—with attempts to diminish Aboriginal rights. They are not the same thing. There are those who use the cloak of workability, certainty and problems with the act to argue what is an attempt to diminish Aboriginal rights. We should be clear about which amendments and which proposals by the government reflect which element of the criticism.

One of the most glaring concerns the right to negotiate. The Liberal Party make great play of encouraging negotiation and negotiated agreements and settlements. But what they do not tell you is that, at the same time, they reduce or take away the right to negotiate—the very right that gives Aboriginal people leverage and makes miners and pastoralists talk to them. The Liberal Party say, `We are in favour of negotiated agreements,' but it is a negotiated agreement between a person with power and a person who, under this bill, will have their power removed. That is something that must be understood by people coming to this debate: negotiated agreements are fine, they are to be encouraged, they are the way forward but they are only the way forward if they are negotiated by people with power and rights. Without those rights negotiated agreements will mean nothing.

As I said, there are some real problems with the current act. The registration test is clearly one of them and Labor will be supporting improvements in that area. The question of multiple claims, particularly in the Kalgoorlie region of my home state, is a very real issue. Unfortunately a practice has grown up there where mining companies have been prepared to pay Aboriginal claimants money in order, basically, to make them go away. This has encouraged lodgment of overlapping claims by individuals and small family groups. You cannot hide that that is a problem that needs to be fixed. The Labor Party will be supporting a fix for that problem. But that is, as I have said, an approach to fix the real practical problem and not a basis to diminish Aboriginal rights.

One other fairly unpopular point I want to make is that the current act is not the real problem; that it is not the issue at stake. If you look at international experience and the development of native title since the act was passed in 1993, you will see that we have only just begun. European Australians tend to take a one‐ or two‐year view of this. We need to apply some of the Aboriginal perspective. The development of native title in this country will take 50, 60, 70 or 100 years. There is no quick fix. The development of law and experience in this area will take time and the legal challenges will need to be worked through. Whatever legislation we pass here in the next couple of weeks will not change that. That development will have to take place.

It is a delicious irony that the one state where there is now not as much of a difficulty in dealing with validation of past acts is my own state of Western Australia where, after their failure to win their challenge to the High Court, they actually followed the provisions of the Native Title Act in terms of future act regime. So we do not need to look at the question of validation in Western Australia to nearly the same extent because Western Australia was one of the few places that, after losing their High Court challenge, applied the act. Other state governments ignored it. They said, `We are not going to apply the Native Title Act; we'll just go on and hope like hell that it does not come back to bite us.' Well, it has and now they are screaming and saying that we have to fix it for them.

Aboriginal people are saying to us, `Well, why should you fix it? We knew what the law was and they knew what the law was.' That obviously is going to be one of the key debates and one of the most difficult debates for this parliament, because state governments did not seek to apply the Native Title Act, they did not use their good offices to make it work. They did not provide goodwill in making the legislation workable, and they are in large part responsible for the problems that have arisen in relation to the Native Title Act.

I think the Liberal Party have to be very careful here because they have established a range of false hopes in the community. They have promised people that there are quick and easy solutions, that certainty will be delivered. My own state Premier, Richard Court, did that. He went down that path immediately after the Mabo decision, and I think he learnt the lesson that the courts, international pressure and the Australian community will not allow Aboriginal people to be deprived of their rights merely by the passage of a bill in this parliament. If there is no agreement generally in the Australian community, especially if there is no agreement with Aboriginal people, there will not be certainty. Those who hold out to people the promise of certainty and a positive outcome without that agreement are misleading them and are giving them false hope, because in my view it will not happen.

Legislation is not the answer here. The answer is a broad agreement within the Australian community about coexistence and about a willingness to live and work together and to recognise each other's rights. No act of parliament can provide that but an act of parliament can prevent its happening. Negotiation among the parties is the key. They must sit down and talk together; they must work it through. We can provide the framework. We can improve the legislation to assist them, but at the end of the day miners must sit down with Aboriginal people, pastoralists must sit down with Aboriginal people, and they must work through their problems and they must reach agreement. That is the only way that what people see as the problems with native title will be solved. It is in the hands of the parties, and this parliament will not give them the quick fix they seek.

I want to make the point that Aboriginal people do not expect justice from this parliament but they also do not see this debate as the end of the war. This is one battle or one skirmish in their drive to have their legitimate rights to land in this country recognised. If we think that by passing a bill in the next couple of weeks they will go away, we are grossly mistaken. They will not go away, the justice of their struggle will not dissipate and their resolve will not dissipate. They will achieve justice whatever this parliament does. I think we ought to reflect on that when we reflect on what we do in terms of the legislation.

I have had the pleasure of being involved with leading Aboriginal people like Patrick Dodson, Peter Yu and Lois O'Donoghue. They are providing enormously strong leadership to their people. There are thousands of other young Aboriginal people in the community providing leadership, leading the charge to ensure that their rights are recognised, and they will not be defeated by passage of a bill in this place. We ought not underestimate them; we ought communicate with them, bring them into the process and recognise their legitimate claims.

We also have an obligation to understand their perspective. There are a lot of pastoralists and people with mining backgrounds in this parliament. As we have reflected, it is sad that there are no Aboriginal persons at this stage. We have to try to understand the perspective of all parties: the miners, the pastoralists and the Aboriginal people. Aboriginal people will not walk away from the recognition of their rights that they received in the Mabo and Wik decisions. Whatever we think we can do, they will not give up that struggle. We ought to understand their perspective, we ought to give voice to their concerns and we ought to bring them into the debate. One of the great disappointments of this particular debate is that the government has failed to enter meaningful negotiations with those people.

This parliament will be put to the test: will we legislate away those rights so recently recognised in the courts for Aboriginal people? Well, not me; I am not in it. This seems to me a most fundamental issue. I will not be in the removal of those rights. I do not have a black‐armband view of history, but I do take responsibility for my own actions here and I will not be in it. Let us celebrate the Wik decision. Let us confirm the rights of all parties. Let us fix the practical difficulties within the current act but reject the call to downgrade or abolish Aboriginal rights. Let us embrace coexistence and make it work for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity to make a few comments on this very important piece of legislation. I acknowledge the contribution of Senator Evans. There were a number of points with which I would agree and my side would agree: his call for coexistence, his reflection on the need for peoples to live and work together and his call for a respect for each other's rights. I regret, however, that he chose to misrepresent the views of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in order to further his political interests. I also regret that he clearly misunderstood the bill that is before the parliament. I prefer to say that he misunderstood it rather than misrepresented it.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that this bill is part of a broader national debate on how best to achieve social and economic justice and equality for indigenous people. Twenty‐one per cent of indigenous Australians are either homeless or living in overcrowded conditions. Twenty per cent of indigenous families still do not have basic amenities such as toilets, bathrooms and running water. Thirty‐three per cent of indigenous students complete secondary education compared with 76 per cent of other Australians. Fourteen per cent of the prison population are indigenous Australians, from only 1.6 per cent of the population. These are important issues for which we are still searching for an adequate response. There is no doubt, however, that they fairly call for special support.

BREAK.PARA: Earlier this year the parliament celebrated the 30th anniversary of the referendum which granted the Commonwealth legislative power to make laws with respect to Aborigines. I said at that time that over those following 30 years many attempts had been made to address disadvantage and injustice. Various reforms such as dedicated health and legal services for Aboriginal people, community employment development programs, housing infrastructure, national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy and the establishment of ATSIC have all been steps upon the path towards more genuine equality. But we still have a long way to go.

We do better understand the pain and suffering of forced separation of families, resulting from practices of the past which might have been well intentioned but which devastated social and cultural structures. We must, as far as is humanly possible, redress that wrong. There is now a greater appreciation of the relationship between Aborigines and the land and the sophisticated and complex social, cultural, religious and land tenure systems, so that we better understand how loss of land and loss of identity with land has devastated indigenous self-confidence. Return of land has been, and still is, critical to achieving social justice and rebuilding that self-confidence.

Thus, we recollect with pride the decision of the Fraser government in 1976 to grant land rights to Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory; and we support the indigenous land fund, established by the previous government and continued by this government, which provides nearly $1.4 billion for indigenous Australians to purchase land. But more important than both was the decision of the High Court in Mabo, because it was a recognition by our common law that native title had, in fact, always existed.

Let there be no misunderstanding: this government accepts and respects the existence of native title, as enunciated in the Mabo decision of the High Court. We support the right of indigenous Australians to protection of that right of title. The outdated doctrine of terra nullius, a land belonging to no-one, has no place in contemporary Australia. Mabo, however, called for a legislative response to protect and respect native title rights, while providing sufficient certainty to enable economic development.

Regrettably, in that circumstance, Labor made a mess of it. What we warned at the time was that the legislation was deficient without a cooperative federal response. We warned that there was a distinct possibility that native title was not extinguished by pastoral leases. And we warned that, because of the uncertainty created by the Mabo decision, if inadequately then legislated, it contained the ingredients for a significant backlash.

These warnings went unheeded by an arrogant administration and a Prime Minister who had long previously given up listening. It has now been left to the coalition government not only to make the Native Title Act 1993 workable but also to provide a practical commonsense response to the issues which have emerged from the Wik decision of the High Court.

In essence, the High Court in Wik found that the rights conferred on the grantees of pastoral leases concerned did not necessarily extinguish native title in the areas subject to those leases. The decision raised doubts about the validity not only of previous acts done over pastoral and leasehold land but also of future activities. In essence, it found that Labor was wrong.

So the coalition has had no alternative but to legislatively respond to this and the many other deficiencies that have been found in the currently existing legislation. To my knowledge, no‐one has argued that the current native title is not deficient—not even Senator Evans who preceded me. There have been over 677 claims, with only one determination of native title in four years. It has not served indigenous or non-indigenous interests well. It does not even give legal certainty to voluntary agreements about native title. As a result, there has been an ongoing anxiety on the indigenous side and also for those representing mining and rural industries.

As I mentioned previously, the Wik judgment rendered false what the previous government claimed: that valid grants of pastoral leases extinguished native title. The Native Title Amendment Bill is a genuine attempt, in very complex and extremely difficult circumstances, to reduce uncertainty, protect native title rights, and develop a more effective framework for land management in Australia. Our firm objective from the beginning has been to arrive at a solution based on racial equality and basic fairness and justice, which also promotes Australia's national interest, which obviously includes economic interests.

We have consulted widely and in good faith. We have endeavoured to accommodate the interests of all stakeholders. And, in my opinion, the Prime Minister deserves particular credit for the personal efforts he has put in in those negotiations. Obviously, it is not an easy task. But, at the end of the day, we believe that this bill is a fair compromise between the competing interests and, specifically, against a background of Labor's legislation being falsely premised and, as such, having misled many ordinary Australians.

This task has been made more difficult by some on both sides of the debate who have resorted to extreme and unwarranted assertions to make their case. Invective and smears are no substitute for reasoned argument and balanced debate. This legislation should not be a source of division or a forum for the politics of hatred, nor should it be used for base political motives. Then there are those with significant influence who contribute from a less than well informed position. They are well meaning, and I respect their right to make social comment. But, in socially sensitive areas, it is important to have regard to the facts—and neither one side nor the other might assert what are to be the facts.

This bill gives effect to the Wik decision but integrates it into Australia's land management laws and systems. We are therefore putting in place what the former Labor government was professing to do in 1993 but which was then so badly mishandled. In debating this difficult issue, it is a time for tolerance, understanding and social cohesion. We have sought to find a just and practical response to these issues. I suggest it is time for the committee debate to be called on, for the detail of the bill to be debated, with less name calling, less point scoring and less extremism. I commend the bill to the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight because of press reports over the last week that there are currently outbreaks of whooping cough and measles in Australia. I believe there is an urgency to assist parents to get their children immunised, and this cannot be emphasised enough. The reason that I do so was that last week in the Senate the Australian Vaccination Network circulated a false and mischievous document which has influenced people against immunisation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senators that have any doubts about the efficacy of immunisation are asked to review the virtual elimination of Haemophlus Influenzae disease in immunised children since the introduction of widespread Hib immunisation. This immunisation has prevented dozens of children from suffering lifelong neurological disability. The Australian Vaccination Network believes that factors other than immunisation are responsible for the fall in immunisation preventable diseases in the Australian community. However, during the time that the Hib immunisation has been available, community health standards have effectively been constant. The only change has been the introduction of the immunisation.

The other observable fact is that, as the overall immunisation rate has fallen, there has been an increase in the number of immunisation preventable diseases. I refer specifically to some of the claims made in their leaflet. They state that vaccines contain many toxic ingredients, including formaldehyde. It is an exaggeration and is misleading to say that vaccines contain many toxic ingredients. Small amounts of additives are used in vaccines. For example, formaldehyde is used to detoxify the tetanus toxin produced in the manufacture of tetanus vaccine. The vaccine is then purified to remove any excess formaldehyde. The residual formaldehyde is in very low concentration, far lower than the maximum allowed by the standard specified in the British Pharmacopoeia, which is the standard adopted by Australia.

There was another statement that `over the past century, death rates from childhood diseases had dropped an estimated 90 per cent before the introduction of vaccines or antibiotics'. The death rate from infectious diseases dropped with improved sanitation and hygiene. However, these diseases are still highly infectious, and deaths and serious consequences still occur. Our children can only be protected by being vaccinated.

The success of the program of vaccination against Hib is testimony for the need for a vaccination program in modern Australia. This vaccine was introduced to the standard childhood schedule in 1993, and since that time we have witnessed a 94 per cent reduction in the number of Hib disease in children under five years of age. There was another extraordinary claim that:

Vaccines are cultured on animal tissue and therefore contain many bacteria and viruses other than the ones they are supposed to immunise against. For instance, the polio vaccines was (sic) contaminated with 40 known monkey viruses—one of which, SV‐40, is thought to cause cancer and has also been linked with the development of AIDS.

Only viral vaccines are cultured in material derived from animal tissues. Bacterial vaccines are manufactured in cultures free of animal cells. Careful screening and testing ensure that the resulting vaccines are free from known contaminants, including bacteria and viruses.

The SV40 virus contaminated some batches of polio vaccine between 1955 and 1963, but there has been no evidence of increased risk of mortality, especially cancer mortality, in persons who have received this vaccine. Since 1963 all polio vaccines have been demonstrated to be free of SV40 as well as other known possible contaminants. There is no scientific evidence whatsoever linking AIDS to polio vaccines.

BREAK.PARA: Another statement was that the rubella and chicken pox vaccines are cultured on cell lines of aborted foetuses. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will recall Senator Harradine's concern about this statement. The truth is that rubella and varicella—chicken pox—viruses vaccine is grown on cell lines which originated in one aborted foetus over 30 years ago—in fact, in 1961. No foetal tissue has been used recently in the testing or the production of these vaccines.

Another statement made was that vaccines do not guarantee protection from disease. That is true to an extent—just as no medical intervention guarantees 100 per cent success—but it does guarantee 95 per cent success. Vaccination is a highly effective method of providing protection against certain diseases to both children and adults. Despite that less than 100 per cent effectiveness, vaccination programs have ensured that smallpox has been eradicated from the world solely due to vaccination, and poliomyelitis is expected to be eradicated within a few years.

Another extraordinary statement was that the US government has paid out in excess of $US800 million since 1986 for vaccine damage. When we checked, there was no data available to verify the amount quoted. In fact, in Australia there has been only one known case where that has been pursued in the last 15 years. The fact that compensation has been paid does not prove that vaccines have been the cause of problems experienced. In the United States there is in place a vaccine compensation scheme which allows easy access to parents who believe that their child experienced a significant vaccine adverse reaction, and Australia does not have a similar vaccine compensation scheme.

Another statement says that in a study conducted by Dr Michael Odent—Lancet, July 1994—asthma was shown to be five times more common in children who had been vaccinated against whooping cough. It also said that two follow‐up studies since that time have confirmed these results. When we checked, we found that Dr Odent made this claim in a brief letter to the Lancet in 1994. There was no peer review of his publication and no scrutiny of his claim was possible. There appears to be no evidence whatsoever of the alleged follow‐up studies, for which no reference has been given.

I could go on. The whole document cannot be verified. It concerns me very much because there is a certain amount of truth in some of the statements, but the vast majority of these statements are completely false and cannot be justified. I am doubly concerned because I see that a recently published booklet is now on the bookstands. It was in the hands of one of my parliamentary colleagues the other day. The poor chap believed that some of the material in that was also verifiable.

I think it is important that Australian parents recognise the validity of the necessity for immunisation. The rate of immunisation in this country has fallen to the lowest level since it was introduced. We are now witnessing epidemics of a major nature, deaths and neurological damage in our children because of the laxity of parents. We have introduced a stimulus for immunisation in the Child Care Payments Bill 1997 , whereby parents need to give some evidence that a child is immunised before it is admitted to child care. The reason for that is that, with a high level of lack of immunisation, those children are at risk of infection. The corollary is that, if there is a high level of immunisation, there will be protection for those children who are not immunised. It has been estimated that fewer than two per cent, fortunately, of Australian patients have any sort of conscientious objection to immunisation. Their children would be protected if the other 98 per cent were immunised because the disease would be highly unlikely to spread within a child‐care centre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak about an issue that is quite close to my heart. I would like to begin by saying that November 1997 should be recorded as a significant month for the progression of Australia towards a phenomenon that I have called cyber democracy. Cyber democracy is about creating opportunities for political participation by citizens on‐line. In November this year the Australian federal parliament initiated an upgrade of information services that has given every elected representative the opportunity to establish an e-mail account and to have Internet access via the Parliament House offices.

SPEECH.PARA: The significance of this event should not be lost. Another avenue for communication has been established with parliamentarians. This can only make us more accessible and therefore more accountable. From my point of view, I hope that this opportunity will be used by all members and senators. I have found that e-mail has been an incredibly useful means by which I can canvass people's views and receive representations from a huge number of people as well as maintain effective contacts with my colleagues.

I hope that this initiative will also inspire parliamentarians to take an active approach to establishing an effective web page. All major political parties have already done so. I am proud to say that the Labor Party's home page is certainly recognised as leading the way in this regard, not only in providing practical information about the policies of our party but also the appropriate connections and linkages that make it serve as a useful site, whether it be for research purposes or just general interest of the public to find out a little more about what the Labor Party stands for.

Individual home pages take the issue a step further. They provide the opportunity for individuals to interact with their elected representative on a one-to-one basis. The opportunity exists to establish a series of feedback forms or, in fact, to sign an electronic petition. During the current debate on the amendments to the Native Title Act, I have found that hundreds of people have chosen to utilise this avenue to contact many of us in this place about their views. This is an entirely appropriate and effective way of letting us know what is in their minds.

This initiative is a wonderful thing but it is not without some challenges. Electronic mail has the same status as traditional correspondence. The challenge for us to document, accord and act upon what we receive in this form is something that I am sure many are tackling at the moment.

BREAK.PARA: The other big challenge with all of this is that it is great for us to be on-line—it is terrific for parliamentarians to have this facility—but it is only a truly effective means of communication if everybody has the opportunity to access the Internet and utilise this means of communication with their elected representatives.

So the issue is one of access and equity of access to new technologies such as the Internet. We know statistically that access to the Internet is still quite limited. Although Australia has one of the most impressive statistics on the take‐up of new technologies, the fact remains that the home ownership of an Internet‐connected PC relates very closely to your socioeconomic status. The more money you earn, the more likely you are to have a modem‐connected computer in your home.

The other issue about access to new technologies such as the Internet relates to the opportunity that you may have either in education or in the workplace. You should appreciate that if you are in the services sector you are more likely to be able to utilise the facilities through your workplace than you are if you work in the construction industry. You should appreciate that if you attend a university there is pretty well a 100 per cent chance that you will embark upon some course or study that will bring you into direct contact with the Internet and it will become part of the way you conduct your study and research.

If you were denied these opportunities and you do not break that barrier on the socioeconomic scale, the chances are that you are not even going to get a look in. This is why initiatives to improve access to the Internet are so critical. I noted with interest the other day the various announcements by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) about access to the Internet, be it rural and remote communities access, be it access via the education system or be it access via the community.

I would like to offer my comments with respect to these initiatives. By and large, it is a positive step. There are a proliferation of reports about how imperative it is to improve this level of access. But it is also worth noting that there were a number of projects in place prior to this government being elected that were abandoned on election, and they have only recently been revisited through the initiatives that we have heard of just this week.

One of those initiatives was in fact a rural on‐line initiative. It was through the department of regional development under the Labor government's regional economic development organisation strategy. This particular project piloted, for the first time, local call access to the Internet in rural communities. It did so by establishing a hub in Bega. The project was known as the Bega telecottage and I am happy to say that this initiative survived, despite the abandonment of that particular overarching regional initiative by the Howard government.

The other significant opportunity that was lost when this government was elected, and that I think has actually set Australia back by a large degree, was the proposed Gungahlin project. This project was a Telstra initiative with some direct Commonwealth government funding support. It proposed to take broadband services directly to a thousand houses for the purposes of laying a testbed for high bandwidth Internet and other applications related services into homes. Why was this important? Because it allowed Australia to stay at the forefront of what is a content‐driven on‐line initiative. That project was abandoned because Telstra had to tighten their books in the lead‐up to privatisation—another opportunity lost. We have not seen a project of that nature re‐emerge. We do not have the public utility available now to pursue it. We are in a situation where the government has lost effectively 18 months worth of time to establish itself in this area. Whilst I commend recent initiatives to act on rural access to the Internet and other ideas that have been very well articulated in reports delivered to this parliament some time ago, many opportunities have been lost and Australia will suffer for it.

But the point of this contribution this evening was to highlight the fact that it is of great progression in getting parliamentarians on line, but the equation is not complete until every Australian has the opportunity to access these services also.
